PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 18 citizens), Senator Short (from 4 citizens) and Senator Watson (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Simplification Legislation

PARA.TAB: 10th August 1992

PETITION.PARA: Dear Member,
We the undersigned are writing to you to voice our strong objection to the proposed "Sales Tax Simplification".
Our main concern is that if this legislation is implemented a major industry (and therefore jobs) will cease to exist.

To quote from a V.A.C.C. letter dated 29 July 1992 to all farm machinery dealers the F.M.D.A. "estimates this impost alone will cause up to 150 dealers to close their doors putting as many as 2000 people out of work in rural Australia".

This proposal will further diminish the strength of the Farm Machinery Industry; an industry whose owners and employees are already struggling in these current economic times. The number of businesses has already fallen from a high of 2400 dealerships in 1984 to a current number of approximately 800. (Figures as supplied by V.A.C.C.).
With the forecast closure of a further 150 dealerships the industry will have effectively been reduced by nearly 75% in the past 8 years.

At a time when job creation is first and foremost in the minds of both public and politicians it seems ludicrous that this proposal may cause many hundreds of hardworking and specially trained people to join the growing ranks of the unemployed—not to mention the effect to supporting businesses.
As everyday working class people we find it difficult to comprehend why a revenue raising industry will be further sacrificed to prop up our failing economy. Where will it all end?
We hope you will express these concerns to the Senate and do your utmost to quash this proposal being implemented.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Simplification Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Those provisions of the "Sales Tax Simplification Bills" as applying to the payment of wholesale sales tax on spare parts by farm machinery manufacturers and dealers and its subsequent recovery is unfair and unreasonable in that it will;

PARA.TAB: 1)prejudice the financial viability of farm machinery dealers and manufacturing businesses
2)increase farm machinery prices and increase production costs that will further prejudice the viability and competitiveness of primary production
3)not give any net gain to Government revenue

PETITION.PARA: We therefore call on the Government to withdraw the provisions involved.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 62 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 81 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag

PARA.EMPHASIS: National Flag

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
(1)They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
(2)They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:

PARA.TAB: (a)The Union Jack—itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b)The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c)The large star depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.

PETITION.PARA: (3)They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
(4)They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
(5)They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ensure that the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War and Genocide in Southern Sudan
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned call upon the Australian Government to act now to protest the genocide against the peoples of the Southern Sudan.

This forgotten war by the military dictatorship of Sudan has now been joined by Iran & Iraq. Governments of the world so quick to act in the case of Iraq's attack on Kuwait should act promptly to stop aggression in Sudan. Hundreds of thousands of people have been killed and made homeless. The largely Christian Southern Sudanese people are having unconstitutional Fundamentalist Muslim law forced upon them. The Anti-Slavery Society of Britain has reported slavery of captured women and children in Omdurman, Sudan. We urge Australia to:

PARA.TAB: Call for immediate negotiations and peace
an end to this 20th century slave trade

PETITION.PARA: the resumption and increase of Australian aid to the Southern Sudan, which has been curtailed due to the fighting.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

During the last 47 years, since the Communists have been taken over the Government in the North Vietnam, and last 17 years in the South, the Buddhist community, which is 85% of the whole population, has been badly discriminated, and strongly suppressed. Its activities have been limited. Its united, elected & structural Congregation has been banned. Its resources have been dispossessed. Many leaders have been killed, convicted or banished.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate make strong representation to the Vietnamese Government, to request them:

(1) (a) re-recognise the independent situation and the total freedom in all activities of the United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation (UVBC), which has jointly been established by all Buddhist regional branches and different lineages in 1951 (named as Vietnamese Buddhist Federation), re-named as the UVBC in 1964, and has forcibly been disbanded in 1981 by the current Communist regime.
(b) stop all of their interference and control, openly or shadowy, to the religious affairs.

(2) urgently and unconditionally release all of the religious leaders, especially the important/senior monks of the UVBC: Most Venerables Thich Huyen Quang, Thich Quang Do, Thich Duc Nhuan, Thich Tue Sy, Thich Tri Sieu, Thich Nguyen Giac. . . .who have been convicted or banished just because of their reputation or their human right activities.

(3) return to the UVBC or to other regional Buddhist communities, and make fully compensation of, all the Buddhist-community-previous-owned institutes, monuments, factories, temples, training monasteries, university, high & primary schools, and all other educational, medical, welfare, charity institutions etc., which have been taken over, misused, destroyed, illegally occupied or forcibly offered to different Government levels since 1945 in North Vietnam or 1975 in South Vietnam.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Standards
PETITION.PARA: To: Hon. Peter R. Staples,
Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services,
Parliament House,
Canberra
From: Centre name—Chillawong Child Care Centre

PARA.TAB: Centre address—33 Chillawong Circuit, Blackbutt

PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, formally notify you of our objection to the proposed Federal Government National Accreditation system for child care centres in Australia. The system is unworkable and unrealistic in terms of what it will supposedly achieve for our children. It will result in the reduction of valuable child care places (at a time when it is reported that there is a crying need for more child care places) and a galloping increase in child care fees for all parents, either on fee relief or not. At no time has the Federal Government sought our opinion as parents, nor consulted us on what we want or feel are accepted standards. Quality child care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. The Interim National Accreditation Council system is neither workable or affordable.

We will not allow elitism, in the form of a star rating system to invade the child care arena. All children in Australia are entitled to affordable quality child care and we will under no circumstances accept the National Accreditation system proffered by the Interim National Accreditation Council.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Budget Cuts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned call upon the Federal Government of Australia to implement a cut of 10% on the Defence Budget. We believe that in this post cold war international environment that expenditure of $9.4 Billion is inappropriate when one considers that Australia has no definable military threat.
The money saved from such a cut should not return to consolidated revenue but should be targeted towards areas of social justice concern such as job creation, housing, health and education.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the resolution of the Senate of 5 June 1991, as amended on 4 May 1992 and 25 June 1992, in relation to the Select Committee on Superannuation be further amended to provide that—
(1)The term of appointment of the Select Committee on Superannuation be extended till 14 December 1992, to enable the committee to inquire into and report upon:

TAB.TAB: (a)its original terms of reference which, as yet, have not been reported, namely, terms of reference (b), (d), (g), (h), (k), (n) and (q); and
(b)any other matters which are relevant to the committee's original terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: (2)The committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources to enable it to conduct its inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that, since its inception, this Committee has been extremely active in an area characterised by great complexity, rapid change and singular significance, not only to the growing numbers in the older age groups, but also to the economic well-being of the nation.

PARA.TAB: The Committee is seeking this extension for two basic reasons. The first is that of its 17 terms of reference, seven remain to be reported on. The outstanding issues include taxation arrangements, matters relating to the vesting and preservation of benefits, lump sums and annuities, the inter-relationship of superannuation with the age pension, implications for the financial system, and a number of consumer issues. All these are matters of great importance and all have their difficulties and pitfalls.

Secondly, the Government has indicated that it will respond to the Committee's first report—Safeguarding Super—at an early date and introduce legislation during these sittings. The Committee believes that it would be highly desirable for it to be in a position to examine this response, taking advantage of the expertise it has acquired during the past 12 months.
The Committee believes that it will be better able to discharge the important tasks given to it by the Senate if this motion is passed.
Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement setting out in more detail the reasons for this extension.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Committee started work a year ago, it has produced an information paper Super System Survey which described retirement income practices in 21 overseas countries. It has tabled two reports—Safeguarding Super and Super Guarantee Bills and a discussion paper Super Charges. The Chairman has made two statements in the Senate on matters arising in the course of the Committee's work.

After the Committee was established, the Government released major policy statements on prudential supervision of superannuation funds, information to be provided to fund members, the proposed superannuation guarantee levy and, on 30 June last, a comprehensive statement on Security in Retirement. The Superannuation Guarantee legislation was introduced and passed.
None of these developments had been foreshadowed at the time the Committee was formed and all have added to its workload.

The Committee's work, and in particular its reports and other pronouncements, have greatly stimulated public interest in superannuation. Submissions are still being received and now number 238. Many of these record complaints covering a wide range of topics and have tended to place the Committee in the role of consumer advocate.

The remaining terms of reference go to the heart of the design of superannuation schemes and the development of appropriate government policies. Many aspects of them are technically complex and all are politically sensitive. If the Committee is to make a worthwhile and lasting contribution in this area it will need to proceed with thoroughness and caution.

The Government has indicated its adoption in principle of the Committee's first report Safeguarding Super which recommended the implementation of a wide range of prudential controls over the establishment, administration and investment activities of superannuation funds in the interests of safeguarding members' assets. The Committee believes that it should play a part in the examination of the Government's response in the light of the experience it has gained during the conduct of its inquiries.
Legislation will be required to implement the Government's decisions, probably resulting in the further reference of bills to the Committee.
In the light of these considerations, the Committee feels that an extension of its reporting time to 14 December is warranted and seeks the agreement of the Senate to this course.

SPEECH.PARA: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS REGULATIONS APPLICATION BILL 1992
This Bill proposes to ensure the validity of amendments to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations to reflect the superannuation guarantee arrangements.

On the basis of legal advice, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 (SG Bill) was not presented to the Governor-General on 30 June 1992. That advice indicated that it would not be appropriate to seek Royal Assent owing to the fact that the SG Bill was not passed in identical form by both Houses of Parliament.

Legal advice on 30 June was that the amendments to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations could proceed and could come into effect from 1 July 1992 even though the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill had not been enacted.

That advice was on the basis that 1 July 1992 would be the commencement date for the SG Bill, when it was enacted, and that it would follow that the commencement date of the amendments to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations would be 1 July 1992.

Subsequent legal advice raised doubt about the validity of this approach. In consequence, the government decided to introduce the present Bill to place beyond doubt the validity of the amendments to the regulations from 1 July 1992.

This decision was taken to provide certainty for employers, fund trustees, employees and the superannuation industry generally that the superannuation guarantee arrangements are in place as announced.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

Since the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 came into effect there has been increasing recognition for the need to effectively manage the marine environment. The extent of this area is significant. The Australian Fishing Zone occupies a larger area than Australia itself and the Commonwealth Government is responsible for managing the majority of this area.

Marine areas differ from terrestrial areas in terms of their management requirements. The migratory nature of many marine species, the seasonal shifts in currents and nutrients, and the ease of transport of pollutants such as oil and the relatively limited knowledge we have of marine systems requires that comprehensive legal and management programs be developed.

The proposed amendments to be included in the Bill are intended to ensure that the enforcement provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 are adequate for the purpose of protecting those marine reptiles, birds and mammals to which Part III of the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations applies, by making the powers in the Act consistent with, and no less stringent than, the enforcement powers in the Whale Protection Act 1980 and the Fisheries Management Act 1991.

The need for the amendments arises from the agreement by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, that it is inappropriate for management of marine mammals and marine reptiles to be under commercial fisheries legislation, and that responsibility for those animals should be transferred to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. The Fisheries Management Act specifies that the term "fish" does not include marine reptiles or marine mammals, unlike the former Fisheries Act, and it is now necessary to ensure that the provisions of the NPWC Act are adequate to protect those species of animals.

Paragraph 71(2)(b) of the Act provides for the making of regulations for the protection and conservation of wildlife and subsection 3(1) specifies that the term "wildlife" includes animals and plants that are indigenous to the continental shelf of Australia or the superjacent waters. Those provisions of the Act are implemented through Part III of the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations, which applies in or on the continental shelf of Australia, the superjacent waters, the sea-bed and subsoil beneath those waters and the airspace above those waters. Part III protects specified animals and plants and provides for a licensing system administered by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife. In general, a licence to kill, take, keep, sell or purchase a protected animal or protected plant may only be issued for the purpose of scientific research, educational study or non-commercial propagation. Exemptions to some of the provisions of Part III apply to traditional Aboriginal hunting and to certain aspects of licensed commercial fishing.

The animals protected under Part III of the Regulations are listed on Schedules 1, 2 and 3 of the Regulations. Currently, the groups of species covered by those Schedules comprise sea snakes, seals and birds. Arrangements are in hand to add turtles, crocodiles and dugong to the Schedules in the near future, through an amendment to the NPW Regulations.

With sea snakes, turtles, crocodiles, birds, seals and dugong protected by Part III of the Regulations, and whales and dolphins protected by the Whale Protection Act 1980, all marine reptiles, birds and mammals will receive protection in Commonwealth Waters under legislation administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS).

For logistical reasons, and for efficient use of resources, enforcement of that legislation will in many cases be delegated to officers from Commonwealth or State fisheries or nature conservation agencies, who will receive appropriate appointments under the Commonwealth legislation. For example, a group of officers from the Victorian Department of Conservation and Environment has already received appointments as inspectors under the Whale Protection Act.

The Bill proposes the creation of a new category of enforcement officer with powers of enforcement able to be limited so that they apply only to offences against specific regulations in Part III of the NPW Regulations. The new category of enforcement officer is to be known as a wildlife inspector.

Because Part III of the Regulations and the Whale Protection Act complement each other in the protection of marine mammals, the enforcement powers available under those pieces of legislation need to be consistent. Furthermore, because the protection of such species of marine wildlife as turtles and dugong is being transferred to Part III of the Regulations from the former Fisheries Act, the powers of enforcement should be at least as stringent as they were under that legislation.

Effective enforcement requires that officers have powers to arrest without a warrant, seize evidence, and search a vehicle, aircraft or vessel in connection with an offence. Under the Whale Protection Act and the Fisheries Management Act, enforcement officers have powers of that kind. Under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, however, those powers are only available to wardens in Australia and in the Australian coastal sea. Amendments proposed in the Bill are intended to extend the application of those powers to the continental shelf, so that wardens and wildlife inspectors can use those powers when enforcing Part III of the Regulations.

In order to achieve consistency with the Whale Protection Act, the Bill will provide wardens and wildlife inspectors with the power to require a person in charge of a vessel to give information concerning the vessel and its crew and any person on board the vessel.

In order to achieve consistency with the former Fisheries Act and the current Fisheries Management Act, the Bill will provide wardens and wildlife inspectors with the power, pursuant to the consent of the owner or occupier of the land or premises or under a warrant, to enter and search land or premises where there are reasonable grounds to believe that there may be evidence as to the commission of an offence.
It is with pleasure that I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the basis on which research levies on grain legumes are paid to be changed from a specific rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate. At present, the Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985 (the Act) provides for the imposition of levies, on specified grain legumes, at flat rates per tonne of seed as recommended by the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) which is the representative organisation under the Act. These can be increased by regulation up to a maximum rate also specified in the Act. The levy rate for most grain legumes is currently $1.25 per tonne. Peanuts are levied at $2 per tonne and navy beans at $5 per tonne. The levies attract matching Commonwealth contributions as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

The change is being implemented at the request of the GCA and is intended to make the collection arrangements more equitable. The ad valorem levies proposed would ensure that growers' contribution to research is proportional to their net return for the particular crop grown. The GCA has recommended an initial operative levy rate of 1 per cent of the net farm gate value and a maximum rate of 3 per cent.

The Government made a commitment, in 1985, to match expenditure of approved industry levies on a dollar-for-dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production (GVP) of the relevant commodity. This policy was reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, "Research, Innovation and Competitiveness".

In this regard, the Government supports arrangements which improve the equity of levy collection arrangements and which encourage increased financial support for research by growers. This move to increase grower investment in research should improve efficiency and sustainability in their own, and the national, interest.
The change to ad valorem based levies is expected to increase the Commonwealth's dollar-for-dollar matching contributions depending on price trends for grain legumes.
The Act will commence on 1 October 1992 to coincide with the commencement of the first quarterly collection period of the new crop year for all the grain legumes involved.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: OILSEEDS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the basis on which research levies on oilseeds are paid to be changed from a specific rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate. At present, the Oilseeds Levy Act 1977 (the Act) provides for the imposition of levies, on specified oilseeds, at a flat rate per tonne of seed as recommended by the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) which is the representative organisation under the Act. This rate can be increased by regulation up to a maximum rate also specified in the Act. The levy rate for all oilseeds is currently $1.55 per tonne. The levies attract matching Commonwealth contributions as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

The change is being implemented at the request of the GCA and is intended to make the collection arrangements more equitable. The ad valorem levies proposed would ensure that growers' contribution to research is proportional to their net return for the particular crop grown. The GCA has recommended an initial operative levy rate of 1 per cent and a maximum rate of 3 per cent.

The Government made a commitment, in 1985, to match expenditure of approved industry levies on a dollar-for-dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production (GVP) of the relevant commodity. This policy was reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, "Research, Innovation and Competitiveness".

In this regard, the Government supports arrangements which improve the equity of levy collection arrangements and which encourage increased financial support for research by growers. This move to increase grower investment in research should improve efficiency and sustainability in their own, and the national, interest.
The change to ad valorem based levies is expected to increase the Commonwealth's dollar-for-dollar matching contributions, depending on price trends for oilseeds.
The Act will commence on 1 October 1992 to coincide with the commencement of the first quarterly collection period of the new crop year for all the oilseeds involved.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —We were debating the Arts, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 last night when, with 45 seconds to go, the debate was adjourned, so we are here again today to continue our remarks. This Bill is supported by the Australian Democrats. As Senator Baume so clearly outlined last night, the Bill is essentially an amalgam of amendments to a range of Bills covered by the DASET portfolio.

PARA.TAB: I would like to pick up briefly on a remark that Senator Baume made in relation to one of the Acts under consideration for amendment, that is, the National Gallery Act. As Senator Baume quite rightly pointed out, this Bill will change the name of the Australian National Gallery and this could entail a considerable cost for the ANG in changing its mastheads, letterheads and so forth. I think it is rather strange that the explanatory memorandum says that there will be no financial obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by this Bill. I fail to see how a name change of this magnitude will not entail financial obligations on the gallery as it seeks to change its mast-heads, letterheads, and so forth, to comply with the new legislation. Perhaps the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) could give us some financial details as to what it would cost the gallery to change these things in line with this name change.

As I said earlier, the Bill does contain a range of amendments to a range of Acts administered by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, and the Australian Democrats will not be opposing this legislation.

The Bill also repeals the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Act 1987 and the States Grants (Air Quality Monitoring) Act 1986. The section related to the ACT vests in the National Capital Planning Authority, from DASET, the management of Commonwealth national land acquired for the special purposes of Canberra as the national capital, with the approval of the Minister.

In the opinion of the Australian Democrats, this provision is to be supported and represents a further devolution of land management from the Department to the National Capital Planning Authority. This, we believe, should enable the NCPA to more effectively manage Territory affairs under its control, rather than through constant reference to the Department where national land is concerned. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments made by my colleague Senator Baume in relation to the Arts, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill. Senator Sowada has just mentioned the aspect relating to the National Capital Planning Authority which comes within my jurisdiction as the spokesman for the ACT on behalf of the Opposition. I want to indicate that we do support that fairly minor technical amendment to the Act so far as it relates to the National Capital Planning Authority having responsibility or power and jurisdiction to deal with national land that is the responsibility of the Federal Parliament.

PARA.TAB: There is not much more that needs to be said on that, but before resuming my seat I want to highlight a suggestion that has been doing the rounds in Canberra that possibly Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory should be nominated for World Heritage listing. That proposal is around. It is one that I guess will come to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in the not too distant future. I just alert Canberrans to the matter so that they may give it some thought and possibly have some input into whether the Australian Capital Territory and Canberra should be listed for World Heritage listing.

I am not quite sure what that would mean. I am not quite sure whether it would require the consent and concurrence of the ACT Assembly or of this Federal Parliament, because the Minister does seem to have a lot of power in determining things that happen with Canberra as a Territory. I alert the Parliament to the difficulties with World Heritage listing of the North Queensland rainforest and the severe curtailment that was put on any activity in those areas as a result of World Heritage listing.

I am not quite sure what World Heritage listing would mean for Canberra. I am not sure that too many others are too certain about what would happen. But if it followed World Heritage listing of other parts of Australia, it could mean that we would have to apply to the United Nations or to the World Heritage Commission or advisory body to get permission to do anything at all within Canberra. If we wanted to build a road, construct a fowl house or build a new Foreign Affairs building—things like that—maybe we would have to go overseas to seek permission; I do not know. Certainly, in the World Heritage listed rainforests, if one wants to do anything at all, one has to go through a series of people to try to get permission.

It is one of those things where a lot of people will say that it is taking sovereignty out of the hands of Australians. I accept that with the World Heritage listings of the rainforests there was an exclusion clause saying that development of a particularly important national nature could go ahead in the rainforest areas, provided the Australian Government approved. But it is all one of these things that comes from overseas; it is determined from overseas. One just wonders whether our national capital should be put in a position of in some way, however lightly, being subject to decisions from other people on what should possibly happen in our national capital.

I am not saying that is how it would apply to Canberra, because it seems to be rather vague and the proposals doing the rounds are fairly unclear about the subject. I am simply raising the matter at this stage to alert the people of Canberra to that suggestion that is doing the rounds. They can consider it and if they have any thoughts on it they can contact Senator Reid or me with their thoughts on the matter.

Having said that, can I concur with what Senator Baume has said and indicate again that the Opposition—as indicated by Senator Baume—will generally support the motion, with the qualifications that Senator Baume has made. We will be certainly be supporting the Act relating to the National Capital Planning Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The matters raised by Senator Macdonald, of course, are completely peripheral to the legislation. In fact, they have got nothing to do with the Arts, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill—this rather small Bill, about which so much fuss is being made.

PARA.TAB: However, I wish to respond to the one substantive point that was made by Senator Baume in the debate last night, that is, the question of the changes to be made to appointments. At present the Chairperson and some members of the Australia Council are appointed by the Governor-General acting with the Minister's advice. But because chairpersons of the Council boards are appointed by the Minister and are ex-officio members of the Council, these other members of the Council are effectively appointed to the Council by the Minister alone. I think Senator Baume conceded last night that that in itself made sense. It is considered more logical, and less expensive for administration, for the Council's Chairperson to be appointed by the Governor-General and for all other Council members and board members to be appointed by the Minister, or by the Council as the Minister's delegate. Thus the change from Governor-General to Minister in this Bill is addressed to the special structure of the Australia Council. The Government has not decided to apply it in a general way to other statutory authorities in the remainder of the portfolio. If the Government were to do that, of course, the Government would introduce all the amendments at once.

TALK.START.PARA: —Promise?

—Yes, I promise; Senator Baume and I had a discussion about this last night. I will ensure that an estimate of the cost of the National Gallery name change is provided to Senators Sowada and Baume. I must say it is not an unimportant issue. In my view, the answer to that eternal question, `What's in a name?', is `A great deal', and I think that is always the case. The point is taken and the information will be provided. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just restate what I said briefly in the second reading debate—that we oppose but will not divide on the amendment seeking to change only the Australia Council and not all other similar bodies, that is, the method of appointment by the Minister rather than the Governor-General. That is in the absence, in our view, of any argued case, despite what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) said. I do not look forward to a series of amendments, but we will no doubt get them because that has been the pattern of change to these items of legislation in recent times.

PARA.TAB: Also, we will oppose but not divide on the other matter of the name change from the Australian National Gallery to the National Gallery of Australia which, with the National Gallery of Victoria, will make it even more confusing, we believe. We will not oppose other amendments, even though we lodge our protest at the fact, firstly, that one of the amendments relates to yet another drafting error; secondly, one of the amendments relates to changing—in the case of the National Parks and Wildlife Service—the financial limits for independent action. These were changed, I think, in a couple of bites last year for every other segment of this Department's enormous activities. As I said in the second reading debate, it would be very nice if this Department could get its act together and do it all in one go. But while we oppose those two particular amendments, we do not intend to divide on them.
Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (EXCISE) BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1992SALES TAX IMPOSITION (GENERAL) BILL 1992SALES TAX AMENDMENT (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1992SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
Senator Robert Ray—I table a correction to the explanatory memoranda relating to the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The six Bills which are the subject of this debate are six sales tax Bills which purport to re-write the sales tax legislation of this country, legislation which has been in existence since 1930 and which, of course, has been amended from time to time—indeed, many times—over the ensuing 60 years but which has now been subject to the most thorough ongoing review in the 60 years of its existence.

PARA.TAB: There are at the moment something like 27 Acts of Parliament relating to sales tax, and the six Bills that are the subject of this debate today are the rewrite in essence of that existing legislation following review of it, essentially by the Australian Taxation Office. I will come back to the consultation process in a moment.

The genesis of these Bills came in the 1990 Budget when the Government announced that it would be undertaking a review of the sales tax law with a view to simplifying it. To use the Government's words, the whole thing was supposed to be purely `a simplification process'. What, I think, this debate will clearly demonstrate and what the work of the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, which has met in recent weeks, will demonstrate is that the proposed legislation, far from being a true simplification of the main concerns and complexities of sales tax law in Australia, will be at least as complex as the preceding legislation and will not really solve the grave complexity of issues that are inherent in any wholesale sales tax regime.

That, I might say at the start of this debate, is absolutely the reason why the coalition, on coming to government at the next election, will abolish the existing wholesale sales tax regime, whether it be the existing 27 Acts or, if these six Bills get through the Parliament, the consequential six Acts, because a wholesale sales tax regime is fundamentally flawed. If we have a wholesale sales tax regime, we inevitably get in it the problems of anomalies, inconsistencies and complexities that have bedevilled the sales tax system in this country for so many years at such cost and inequity to the whole of the Australian community.

We will be abolishing whatever sales tax regime we inherit and, as part of a major reform of the taxation system in Australia generally, we will be replacing it with a goods and services tax, which, by its very nature, will remove automatically virtually all of the inequities and inefficiencies of a wholesale sales tax regime. The abolition of the wholesale sales tax system and its replacement by a goods and services tax regime, which is a value added tax regime, will be only part of a major tax reform in Australia that will include an average reduction across the board of personal income tax, targeting particularly lower and middle income earners, of 30 per cent.

The third main string to the tax reform—the first being GST and the second being income tax—is the abolition of no fewer than seven taxes that now are imposed on business in this country, at very great cost to our whole cost structure and therefore to our competitiveness as a nation. The present tax structure in Australia is very negative in terms of encouraging competition amongst Australian industries and in terms of their ability to compete overseas in export markets and to compete in the domestic market against imports. It is a major drag on the Australian economy. It is a major drag on our productivity. It is a major drag on our investment. It is therefore a major cause of the absolutely horrendous unemployment situation that we have in this nation today.

As we have seen from the figures contained in the Budget released two days ago and supplemented by Treasurer Dawkins in comments he made yesterday, unemployment will continue at around the same levels under the Government's existing policies for at least another four years. That will be a matter of heated debate on many more occasions in this place and I will not go into that further today.

That is the backdrop to the six sales tax Bills that we have before us today. The Bills are said to represent the Government's attempt to simplify the horrendously complex, gargantuan, archaic, arcane, regressive, unfair and anomaly ridden wholesale sales tax system. If I have not already made it clear enough, let me make it absolutely clear at the outset that the Liberal and National parties are totally opposed to the Bills and will vote against them, even as they are now proposed to be amended very substantially by the Government. We will come back to that on many occasions in this debate.

The fact is that the six Bills before the Senate at the moment, which were rammed through the House of Representatives in 45 minutes flat by the use of the guillotine in the dying days of the last sittings, are to be massively amended and indeed emasculated by many of the changes proposed by the Government following its extensive two-year review. The Government is now backing off. It has pulled its head in. It is proposing to eliminate quite major sections of these Bills. So we are going to see a very emasculated and therefore a very messy, equally inequitable and inefficient system replacing the one that we already have.

The Government claims that these Bills represent a major overhaul of the existing sales tax law. The Government claims that the result is a major simplification of the system. Certainly the Taxation Office has laboured long in its work on this matter. The simplification review was first announced by the Government in the August Budget of 1990 and it was only on 2 April this year, in a press release by the Treasurer, that the results of that review were announced. The legislation itself did not come immediately into the House of Representatives; it was not seen for the first time until 26 May. It was guillotined through the House of Representatives in the most brutal, undemocratic, unparliamentary way, with no opportunity for debate, no opportunity for consideration or input by those millions of Australians who are going to be affected by these changes.

The results of these labours—which have been largely in-house with virtually no real consultation with the clients of the system, those who are actually going to have to pay tax, the tax practitioners who advise those who pay the tax, and so on; I will come back to that lack of consultation—certainly do represent an overhaul of the existing system. It is an overhaul which has not removed many, if any, of the fundamental weaknesses in the system.

Prima facie, those results may be interpreted by some to have included some simplification in the sense that it is now proposed that we will have six Acts of Parliament rather than the 27 Acts which deal exclusively with sales tax, but that does not, in itself, mean that the real end result is the true simplification of the wholesale sales tax regime. The main problem with the wholesale sales tax regime, so far as its complexity, its confusion and its inequity are concerned, relates to the area of exemptions and classifications. How can one product, one good, be classified as having a particular rate of sales tax applying to it?

We have a multi-rate system. There are five rates of sales tax: zero, 10 per cent, 15 per cent, 20 per cent and 30 per cent. In many cases the dividing line, in terms of defining a product as to whether it should be eligible for a 10 per cent rate, a 20 per cent rate or a 30 per cent rate, is very fine indeed. Most of the cost and the complexity in the system arises from the classification process and the process of exemption from sales tax at all. Again we have problems of definition. They are the real problems in the sales tax system, not the fact that there were 27 Acts and there are now going to be six Acts. The exemption and classification problems within the sales tax system have not been tackled at all in the review that the Tax Office has undertaken.

The Bills were rushed through the House of Representatives without any consideration. They were to have been allocated a brief four hours for debate in the Senate in the dying days of the last sittings, because the Government was at great pains to push the legislation through the Parliament so that it could have an operative starting tax collection date of 1 September or 1 October. The Government was going to apply the same guillotine process to these Bills in the Senate as it did in the House of Representatives. The coalition was violently opposed to this and I welcome the support that we received from the Australian Democrats for the establishment of a Senate select committee to examine those Bills. That examination has taken place over the recess.

I must temper my expression of pleasure at the support of the Democrats by being bitterly critical of the fact that they were not prepared to support the coalition in having a suitably lengthy timetable for the consideration of the Bills. Instead, they supported a request by the Government that the Select Committee report by yesterday, 19 August. That gave the Committee a period of only six weeks from go to whoa to establish itself, to advertise its existence, to call for submissions, to receive submissions, to conduct the public hearings, to prepare the report, produce it, agree on it and table it in the Parliament. That was an impossibly tight timetable.

As a result, the report that I think was tabled in the Senate yesterday by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Walsh, is in my view very inadequate. That is no reflection on the secretariat that laboured very hard and long to support us and which was cooperative in the extreme. But that secretariat was given—as were we members of the Committee—a totally impossible timetable and, as a result, our consideration of the Bills suffered mightily. I believe that the Australian taxpayer will pay the consequences of that as well, to a large degree, because we have not done the job that the Senate mandated us to do. Indeed, we had only two days of public hearings, which took place last Wednesday and Thursday, 12 and 13 August.

At 6 p.m. on the night of 11 August, the Treasurer put out a very skinny three-page press statement which heralded major changes in six areas that the review and the Bills that the Committee was to consider had covered. There were no amendments available for the Committee to look at the following morning and, indeed, they did not turn up at all during those two days. So the Committee was working very much with one hand tied behind its back because of the changes foreshadowed by the Treasurer, but without the specific details of those changes in the form of the amendments and, indeed, with the other hand tied behind its back because of the impossibly tight time constraints that we had.

The minority report by my colleague Senator Vanstone and me very strongly and totally condemns the Government for the way that it has handled this matter. It obviously acted to pre-empt, frustrate and confuse the operations of the Senate Select Committee. That is a major indictment of the Government because it is a classic example of the Government frustrating the legitimate, proper parliamentary process which is the underpinning of any democratic society.

Before the establishment of the Select Committee, after the brutal guillotining of the legislation through the House of Representatives, the coalition had representations flooding into us expressing grave concern about both the thrust and the detail of the Government's changes as outlined in the six original Bills. The Senate Select Committee had similar representations flooding into it. Indeed, in the space of the very tight 2 1/2 weeks that the Australian community had to make their submissions to the Committee, despite that tight timetable, we received no fewer than 150 submissions. That reflected the very grave concern, community wide, about the proposals before the Senate then and now, despite the changes that the Government is proposing.

Those representations came from a very wide spectrum of the community. They came from the manufacturing sector, the retail sector, consumers, legal and accounting practitioners, large and small businesses, the finance sector, the oil companies, the architectural and design professionals, and on and on it went. The extremely large number of differing concerns from this very wide range of representations did not involve merely matters of detail. They included, and still include, grave concerns about the fact that 250,000 farmers, for many of whom present incomes are negative, will be brought into the sales tax net for the first time.

They include the fact that probably another quarter of a million business people, who are not at the moment required to register for sales tax purposes, will have to register in order to obtain various exemptions in terms of business inputs. In other words, the sales tax net is going to extend to include up to or perhaps even more than half a million more taxpayers than it now covers. If that is not bureaucracy gone mad and if that is not the tax system gone mad, I would like to know what is.

The other concerns that came in included grave concerns about the possibility that many taxpayers would be hit for substantial retrospective liabilities of tax, and tax penalties. A leading member of one of Australia's largest and most respected accounting firms has described the Government's proposals as providing a `recipe for uncertainty and confusion' and as leading `to a great number of distortions and to many unintended consequences'.

Grave concern was expressed in many quarters about the powers that the original Bills conferred on the Australian Taxation Office, including the quite draconian penalties that the Taxation Office could impose. The Business Council of Australia, for example, described the Bills as conferring absurd and dangerous powers on the Tax Office, `enabling it to deem facts to suit its case regardless of the actual facts'. The Business Council claimed that the Bills, `with their Orwellian overtones, would grant the bureaucracy powers that are simply unacceptable in a democratic society'.

There will be significant amendments proposed to the Bills but I do not think the underlying intent will change. Under the Bills as originally drafted, the Taxation Commissioner certainly would have had enormous powers, not just to impose draconian penalties on people but also to exercise enormous powers of interpretation. I take as an example proposed new section 92 of the Bill as drafted when it came into the Senate and as it read when it was brutally guillotined through the House of Representatives.

Proposed new section 92 gives the Tax Commissioner the power to cancel tax benefits obtained by avoidance. That is fair enough; there is no dispute at all about that in principle. Let us look, however, at the power of interpretation or determination that subsection (2) of proposed new section 92, as drafted when it came into this place, conferred on the Commissioner. If the Select Committee had not been established to consider these Bills, this proposed new subsection would actually be law:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)For the purpose of cancelling a tax benefit, the Commissioner may, in the assessment, determine all or any of the following:

PARA.TAB: (a)that particular things are to be treated as not having happened;
(b)that particular things are to be treated as having been done by a different person or to have happened at a different time;
(c)that particular things that did not actually happen are to be treated as having happened and, where appropriate:

TAB.TAB: (i)to have been done by a particular person; or
(ii)to have happened at a particular time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the Tax Office or this Government realises that the totalitarian regimes of eastern Europe have come crashing to the ground in the last couple of years. This type of legislation seems to be an attempt to resurrect in Australia what has been destroyed—and absolutely rightly so—through the communist regimes of eastern Europe, notably a totally draconian, Orwellian and undemocratic approach to the taxpayers of this country.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to record that, following the work of the Select Committee and its establishment and following the huge number of representations that have been received, we have been informed that the Taxation Office is proposing—and there are amendments—to change the wording of that proposed new section. I repeat the point: if the Senate had not exercised its proper right of review, that proposed new section would today be law.

The Government will no doubt argue, and has argued, that that wording and the general anti-avoidance provision from which it comes is based on part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That was the original argument, I think, but the comparison is quite misleading. Section 177D of the Income Tax Assessment Act lists eight criteria which must be satisfied before part IVA applies. In the original sales tax Bills no such criteria were included. I am pleased to note, as I understand it, that objective criteria will now be included. But again I come back to the fact that that was not the Australian Tax Office's or the Government's approach and that it was only through enormous community concern and concern expressed by the Liberal and National parties that that change has been made, although, as I say, it in no way changes the basic underlying intent of the section. I will be asking questions and seeking total confirmation, in the committee stage of this debate, as to whether the revised general anti-avoidance procedure provisions of the Act do, in fact, totally exclude the prospect of catching up normal commercial transactions. We will be seeking a total assurance from the Government on that account.

Setting all that aside, the fact is that these Bills generally reflect a government which, despite all its rhetoric, is profoundly hostile to business. It is, in effect, profoundly hostile to the activities of the great majority of the population—those millions of Australians who generate most of our national income. Our national income is not generated by us politicians, or by the bureaucrats in Canberra or elsewhere around Australia. The income, wealth, jobs and prosperity of this country are generated by those businesses and those business people—large and, particularly, small businesses—around the nation who are striving simply to be able to do what they can do best, free of the encumbrances and interferences and Orwellian involvements of government in their activities.

The whole thrust of this Government in its actions—I think reflected in an important degree in these Bills—is to be hostile to those activities of the private sector in this country. No wonder we have the one million people unemployed and a further one million people underemployed as a result of the policies and general approach of this Government.

Let us just look at some of the recent examples. In addition to these sales tax Bills, to which I will return later, we have Senator Cook introducing legislation to meet the dictates of his old union bosses in the Building Workers Industrial Union—a union of which he is still a member. How is that for a conflict of interest? That legislation, however much watered down, can only erode confidence in the stability of private contracts and increase the costs and risks of doing business in this country.

We have the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) touting changes to the corporate law—fortunately, he has had a rethink about that as well—to expose company officers to significant extra risks, therefore threatening the very concept of limited liability itself, on which all successful modern economies are based. We have the same Attorney-General proposing changes to the trade practices law which would have the effect of ensuring that Australian based companies remain small and uncompetitive in world terms or face protracted and costly legal battles with their own government. We have a Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and a Treasurer who are beholden to and, without any scruples, will placate or buy off the Australian Council of Trade Unions and in particular Bill Kelty, or, in the Prime Minister's case at least, attempt to repay the debt of assisting him mightily in his ruthless drive for the Lodge last year. The big pay-off has been to deliver a compulsory, employer funded superannuation scheme, to be paid for by the business sector and by the scores of Australians who will lose their jobs as a result.

Time does not permit any further comment on the generality of the Bills. We have a report from the Senate Select Committee which will be the subject of debate both in the ongoing second reading stage and, more importantly, in the committee stage. I will reserve my further comments until that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the six sales tax Bills now before the Senate, I have to declare my interest in them as a primary producer. I also intend to comment generally on the whole mishmash of the legislation. Sometime in 1985, in the other place, the Treasurer of the time, who is now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), said that the sales tax system was old and archaic and it was time for it to be changed. It is a pity he was not successful in his own Caucus and party room in bringing that forward and giving us a goods and services tax instead of the sales tax because it would have saved us a lot of work today in dealing with this mishmash of sales tax legislation.

PARA.TAB: Sales tax was introduced into Australia 60 years ago, in the 1930s, in the time of the Depression, as a temporary tax on luxuries. One can see what it has grown into now. What is more, can anyone say that the luxuries of the 1930s are the luxuries of today? I do not think that anything now can be regarded as the luxury it was in the 1930s. Women's jewellery would have been a luxury in the 1930s but it certainly is not now; it is just part of everyday life.

Let us look at what the sales tax system has grown into. It is absolutely hopeless to administer. It is absolutely hopeless to work with for anyone in business, as I am. For example, to go back to the luxuries under the temporary system that was brought in in the 1930s, a car would have been a luxury in 1930, but does anyone in this chamber now say that a car is a luxury? Perhaps the Government has defined anything over $43,736.56 as a luxury because one might not need quite that sort of car and it has its own sales tax regime and depreciation treatment. A car is definitely not a luxury.

At present, Australia has a foreign debt of $165 billion, give or take a few billion dollars. One can never get a straight answer out of this Government on anything, let alone on what the foreign debt is. One would think that, in such a position, the Government would be looking at internal costs for farmers, miners, small businessmen and big businessmen and putting Australians in a position where we can compete with the rest of the world. The only way the Government is going to cut down that foreign debt is by making us competitive. But the Government and its Ministers have put more and more impediments in the way of business, and that has been the ruination of business in Australia.

It is all very well for those on the other side to bring Bills like this forward; they do not have to administer them themselves. The Australian Taxation Office administers them. None of those opposite would know where there is sales tax and where there is not half the time, and yet they sit in judgment. To my knowledge, no-one over there—except perhaps Senator Walsh—has ever paid a pay-packet out in his life. I will give Senator Walsh the benefit of the doubt. But they sit here in judgment and tell us what business must do and must not do for ever and ever. Business is paying to be a tax collector for the Government. That is why the Hewson GST package is far in front and is far simpler. There will be one form once a month.

I come back to the Bill, which is causing nothing but hardship for Australia. This foreign debt that we have created and cannot do anything about reducing flows through to all people. This is not only to business people, it flows through to the interest rates that people pay on their homes. It most definitely penalises the one group that I have already mentioned and that is the exporters of Australia—the farmers, the miners, the business people, the manufacturers. They are the ones who are copping it.

One would be looking to the Government to lessen the pool of unemployment; it is one million at present and rising fast. We have had a bit of a comeback of 0.1 per cent in the last month, but that has mainly come about not by anything this Government has done, but by the fact that some of those school leavers of last year have been absorbed. Of course, in another three-odd months we will have another set of school leavers that this Government will have to worry about and unemployment will probably hit 13 per cent.

This sort of legislation—the sales tax system—just penalises and it penalises those who have a chance of employing people. Instead of bringing in this sort of reform—and it is not reform judging by the mishmash we have here—the Government should be looking at abolishing sales tax lock, stock and barrel and starting again with a GST. It has been called a simplification, but it is far beyond a simplification and I will go back into that. Incidentally, Madam Acting Deputy President, you yourself put out a good paper on this.

It was admitted by a tax expert from our Taxation Office that it took him three days to read this jolly Bill, let alone understand it. It took three days! And that is documented in public evidence for everyone to see; do not just take my word. So if there is an expert with the Australian Taxation Office who takes three days simply to read the thing, how can a businessman, or even a businessman's qualified financial adviser, his accountant, be expected to understand it, let alone the small shopkeeper and the small farmer. There are 1,500 pages. I have not read it completely and I do not think there is anyone, including the Government's advisers, who have read the damn thing through themselves.

So it is back to the 1930s. I remember Mr John Howard in the other place advocating a goods and services tax in about 1980 and he got flogged to death. They said that he was going back to the 1960s and the 1930s. How right he was. We have a Bill of massive proportions that takes three days for an officer of the Tax Office to read and it was run through the House of Representatives in 37 minutes, or something like that.

It is a retrograde and ridiculous situation where an extra 250,000 registrations will be needed for the collection of this tax or to be exempt from this sort of tax. It is completely hopeless. The President of the Tax Institute of Australia, Ian Langford-Brown, has called on the Federal Government to scrap the current wholesale sales tax (WST) in favour of the broadly based GST. He is one person who has obviously studied it over a considerable time.

These are small examples of where sales tax will now apply where it did not before. The pet food industry and pet breeders are very small industries but they will cop an extra $3m. Read it for yourself, Madam Acting Deputy President. Plastic and rubber sheeting is now not exempt except in certain circumstances. As one who is involved in the building industry—not largely; probably a building a year—I have not been able to find out whether plastic sheeting is exempt when it is put under concrete. Of course, more sales tax will be taken off miners and farmers. Retailers who have goods produced by contract manufacturers will pay more.

At this stage, some of my comments may not be valid any more because the Government did back down at the last moment. But we cannot find out exactly where the Government has backed down and where it has not.

Contractors to government bodies will pay more. Perhaps that is based on the ruse that maybe the private contractors on other jobs can compete more fairly; I do not know. But under this Bill they will pay more. Consumers will pay more for everyday luxuries, or whatever one would like to call them, that were not covered before. There are certain things like containers for pizzas, biscuits and milkshakes. An extra $2m to $3m will be ripped out with regard to those items. There will be more sales tax on food that is used by the lower socio-economic part of the society of Australia.

If there is one part of the society of Australia that relies on fast food outlets it is the unemployed, who cannot afford anything else, and the Aborigines. I know of two Aboriginal communities in Australia probably far better than anyone sitting on the Government side of the House. They will be copping it.

Are crockery and glassware luxuries these days? Are thermostats and electrical appliances luxuries? A good one is a sewerage tank. It is all right for anyone who lives in Canberra, Melbourne, Sydney, Perth or wherever, but is a sewerage tank that is put on a farm because there is no sewerage regarded as a luxury?

TALK.START.PARA: —Septic tank.

—A septic tank; it is a sewerage tank to me. The hot water tank is another item that will attract sales tax, as will generic products in food chain stores. So the cost of production anywhere in Australia will be increased.

PARA.TAB: According to the Government, food is not taxed. That is a big lie. Once, when printing a catalogue, only the printing was taxed, but we now have more tax on that. Now the whole lot—models, photography, lay-out, design, typesetting and film advertising—will be subject to tax. What is the Government's answer in this case? It will allow exemptions of up to $10,000 for small business. But the Government is not exempting small business from anything; it is just shifting the load somewhere else. It is shifting the goalposts, if you like. The burden of collection is shifted elsewhere. After all, when that measure was brought in it was regarded as a smokescreen to take attention away from the goods and services tax, but that tax would have been a far lot easier to administer.

If these small businesses that have been exempted up to $10,000 supply to a bigger chain that is operating over $10,000 then the big chain has to make it up. So, in general, I say this: do away with the sales tax Bills and bring in the Hewson GST package.

There is another change in small specifics. On swimming pools there will be a difference in tax depending on whether the pool is made of fibreglass or is built into the ground in concrete. That, once again, comes from my experience in the building game. Why is that? The purpose or use of a swimming pool is exactly the same whether it is made of fibreglass and lifted in with a crane or whether it is built into the ground of any other material. The intent and purpose are exactly the same, yet there is a variation on the amount of sales tax paid.

This mishmash was rammed through the House of Representatives in, I think, 37 minutes—do not hold me to the number of seconds—and then it landed in this place. We were supposed to deal with this legislation before we went home for Christmas. But fortunately, due to Senator Short's work, ably helped by the Democrats, there was an inquiry. But then the inquiry itself was thrown into confusion by the Government announcing some changes at the last minute. We got the report of the inquiry on our desks yesterday. We have not had time to absorb it, let alone get the response from the Government on the inquiry's findings. The way it has been rushed through is an absolute sham.

In 1990-91, the Government announced that it would undertake a review aimed at `simplifying' the sales tax legislation. Senator Short has already gone into the reasons why it is anything but simple. We now have before us the so-called simplification Bills. From what I read, the Committee advertised and, in no time, it had received 150 submissions from all over Australia. The Committee then found out that it was anything but simple. According to the ministerial second reading speech in the House of Representatives, the main features of the legislation are:
. a significant reduction in the number of persons

SPEECH.PARA: required to pay sales tax;
That is a complete lie. It shifts the burden, not the numbers.

PARA.TAB: . a complete restructuring and redrafting of the WST legislation, in plain English, to make it simpler to use and more certain in its application;
. a streamlining of the system for acquiring business inputs and other conditionally exempt goods free of tax; and
. a significant strengthening of the anti-avoidance provisions of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has already told you about that sort of strengthening. A reading of these highlighted features would suggest that the simplification process was primarily concerned with the mechanics of the sales tax system, rather than the change to the tax base or the tax treatment of various goods and business operations. It is now apparent that this was not the case.

PARA.TAB: The proposed legislation includes clear policy changes, and we were told it was a simplification. The areas involved include external costs and leases. What a shemozzle came out of the leasing system. Another area is goods donated, or charities. From what I saw in the press release put out by the Minister, charities have now been exempted. My office received about 133 letters from Western Australian charities. I thought that in this world, in this age, and in this country, we left charities alone because of the cheap work that they do for the unfortunate people in the lower socioeconomic groups. But the Government had even decided to have a crack at them, although fortunately it has changed its mind. Other areas include businesses operating as deemed manufacturers, the coverage of tax rulings—Senator Watson could probably talk for half an hour on that alone—and the treatment of untaxed goods.

Of course, the legislation had the result of overturning the court decision which has gone against the Commissioner of Taxation in the past. That is all under the guise of simplification. Anyhow, there has been a big backdown, but there is a long way to go in backdowns yet. It will not be a backdown until it is completely thrown out.

I will go into a few specifics with regard to primary industry, which is the industry I am most interested in. Take machinery dealers—that is, machinery dealers in a country town. For example, take the average John Deere, Massey Ferguson or John Holland dealer—whatever dealers there are around. A machine would be put onto the showroom floor from the distributor, say in this case it was John Deere. The machine would be put on the dealer's floor. Normally it was sales tax free while it was sitting on the floor. If it was bought by a farmer who was exempt, then the

SPEECH.PARA: sales tax would never have been paid because under the original Bill the machine was exempt.

PARA.TAB: Under the proposed legislation, which is now changed but not changed enough—as it is, it was rushed through the House of Representatives in 37 minutes—the dealer putting it on the floor, who has all the other costs of financing it and paying interest, would have had to put the sales tax up then. If he sold it to a farmer who was exempt, he would have then been reimbursed. Madam Acting Deputy President, even you, as a solicitor in the city of Adelaide, far removed from the agricultural sector—or I think you are—would know that a combine harvester would not be used for anything else except taking a crop off, which is an agricultural pursuit. Yet in this case, this Government was attempting to put the sales tax on first.

This Government is always on about bringing in money through the door—the cash flow system, then maybe it has to go back later on. In this case of agricultural equipment, it always had to go back. Take, say, a simple new Holland header at $200,000, with 20 per cent sales tax of $40,000. That dealer would have had to put up finance for, say, six months—if he is lucky to sell it in the first season. There is six months on that at 10 per cent; honourable senators can work it out for themselves. That would be what that dealer had to borrow and pay to the Federal Government for its own programs and then, later on, it would have been refunded. But what would not have been refunded is the interest. Whether or not that fellow made a payment to the bank to put the machine on his show floor or had forgone interest if he had to finance it himself—I doubt that most of those dealers can afford that sort of thing—he would have had to put it up. He would not have got that back from the Commissioner of Taxation. He would have got the sales tax back, but not the interest.

In other words, as I said before, it is still an impost on production. The dealer's combine header is probably sitting on the floor; he could have a four-wheel drive at $150,000 sitting on the floor; he probably has a two-wheel drive at $80,000; he would normally have a hay baler at $40,000-odd to make up a reasonable show floor; and maybe a utility as well that will still be sales tax free at the end. So it does not take much to have $1m worth of stock on the floor. That, of course, would have represented $200,000 sitting in the sales tax department awaiting reimbursement, as agricultural machinery will always be tax exempt. I could forgive that if it was something that may or may not be exempt at the end. But in that case, I cannot. I understand from the Government backdown that that will not now happen.

It is up to the Commissioner's discretion, however—it is not written in the legislation—that while machinery is sitting on the showroom floor it will be exempt until its final position is settled one way or another. Although agricultural machinery is always agricultural machinery, it is still up to the Commissioner's discretion. How many commissioners will we get in Australia? What is more, how many have we now got in each State? In Perth, the Tax Office has split into two; one part has gone north and one has gone south. People do not know what office they belong to. Have they got a commissioner within reach? Is a ruling by one the same as a ruling by another? That is what worries me about this legislation. Even though the Government has backed down, there is too much at the Commissioner's discretion rather than being set in legislation so that people can read the legislation in plain English and then work out their business around it.

Even with the back-down that has occurred, there is still the same problem when parts are put onto the shelf and are then sold to exempt users. Some may not be exempt, but it is up to the one that is buying to declare whether he is exempt or not. In the original legislation it was going to be treated the same. A part went onto the floor, went into a part bin and the sales tax had to be put up.

Under the present legislation, I was told yesterday by the machinery dealers of Australia—and I have not had any direction to the contrary—once those parts are there, even though the sales tax is not paid by that dealer under the changes we have made, if a part is needed to repair a machine that is under warranty and that has been bought under sales tax exemption, that part must have its own order number, its own purchase invoice, its own invoice, and be sold to the farmer on invoice. If that is correct, it causes a lot of headaches. Not only does it cause headaches but, if a person has to bring in a special part for that, he could lose two, three, four or five days work. He could have one part sitting on the bench and yet another one would have to come from the United States. If the Machinery Dealers Association of Australia is correct on that matter, the Government had better do something about it.

Another specific matter that I would like to talk about is vehicles in agriculture. At page 7 of the explanatory memorandum for the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill 1992, under the heading `Vehicles for use in agricultural industry', it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be an exemption for certain kinds of vehicles that are used in agricultural industry. The exemption will not include certain trucks.

That is what I mean by changes in rulings. There was a ruling made some time ago that a tandem drive—say, a six-wheel truck—was regarded as a four-wheel drive. After all, what is a four-wheel drive? I think it is a vehicle that is driven by four wheels.
