A ruling came out a couple of years ago that that was sales tax exempt if used in certain ways on a farm, but now that is specifically overturned by this legislation. Can anyone tell me why four driving wheels should be treated differently, tax-wise, according to whether two wheels are at the front and two at the back rather than the whole four being down the back, with two extra at the front to balance the machine? I have not been able to get an answer as to why it is treated differently.

PARA.TAB: If the reason this ruling was overturned by the legislation and the classification was changed is that all wheels had to drive to be sales tax exempt, why are six by sixes not mentioned in the legislation? Six by six is four wheels driving at the back and two at the front, as used in forestry and in farming for taking seed and super to the paddock. I do not know whether such vehicles would be exempt. I have tried to find out but I have not got an answer. Can someone tell me that? I could go on with those sorts of things, to which I have not got answers. I believe the whole legislation adds up to far more queries and questions than ever it was meant to simplify.

I believe, after all that, that if this Government wants to do anything about sales tax it has to start all over again. I believe that, rather than simplification, it set out to broaden the base. I ask: broaden the base of what? Not less for more and enough for the others; no, just to get more in. The financial impact tells us that. In conclusion, as Senator Short said, we will be opposing the legislation, and in government we will certainly be doing a lot more about it than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The six Sales Tax Bills that are currently before the Senate were designed to simplify and improve the current wholesale sales tax system. This was indeed a very laudable objective. Unfortunately, the process has gone wrong. While I am not privy to some of the reasons, there is a lot of confusion out there so far as sales tax payers are concerned at present.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, it does appear that the issue at the last minute was rushed and, as a consequence, there were a large number of unintended consequences. The problems created are reflected in something like 140 submissions that were presented to the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. Perhaps there were an equal number of letters, protests, phone calls and so on. Despite the Government's revisions—they are substantial, and we thank it for them—the question before the chamber at the moment is: will this legislation still achieve its basic objective of simplification? While the thrust is right and the direction is right and there have been quite a lot of amendments, there is still a lot of confusion about some intermediate situations.

I just want to say that the review process, short as it was—and it was far too short—was a very necessary one and, I think, quite clearly demonstrates to the Australian people the value of a second chamber and the value of the process that we have here of referring Bills to a committee. Had these Bills not gone to the Committee, there would have been enormous additional problems because it would have taken a lot longer to expose some of the difficulties and to have had them rectified. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced, and we now have before us, a series of amendments to the amendments which reflect a revision of policy, but there are still approximately over 1,000 pages of new legislation and explanatory material and the law is still expected to come into effect on 1 December.

Let me give an example. It is fairly clear that charities will no longer be taxed in the three areas that were previously not intended to be taxed, and I think the Government has reasonably satisfactorily addressed five or six of the areas which were the focus of most of the attention of the submissions. But there are, I must say, a whole lot of intermediate areas. For example, there is still a dilemma in the minds of the natural gas industry, particularly that sector of the industry which uses natural gas vehicles. Let me explain by way of example: since 1985 compressors and associated equipment forming an essential part of a natural gas vehicle refuelling system had been exempted from sales tax. The industry is still uncertain about its position at the present time, despite the changes. This is what I say is unfortunate.

In 1990, home refuelling appliances, small compressors, were also granted an exemption. That was very satisfactory, but under the proposed sales tax simplification legislation the exemption would be removed and a 20 per cent sales tax would apply. In the event of this change, the whole natural gas vehicle fuel program throughout Australia would naturally be under threat. This additional and totally unexpected impost, without reference to the industry, would mean that the already marginal economics of natural gas as a vehicle fuel would become untenable.

This uncertainty has not been fully addressed. Because of the pressure to go through the whole raft of amendments—I have had the amendments for only about 36 hours—I put it to the Government that the problem in this good industry is that we have an abundance of natural gas and we are going to tax it out of existence, which would be unfortunate, but I believe that the problem could be overcome by a simple amendment. I hope the advisers will take note of it, because we cannot afford to lose industries unnecessarily at this critical time of deep recession.

I believe that the decision could be reversed by amending proposed item 172 to include the following words: goods for use in the preparation and use of natural gas as a fuel, internal combustion engines, parts, accessories, attachments and fittings. This simple change would mean a continuation of the natural gas vehicle fuel program through Australia. I therefore ask the Government whether it can institute the amendment to reverse what has been an apparent anomaly and, I hope, an unintended consequence.

That clearly demonstrates the intermediate dilemma in which a lot of industries now find themselves. These amendments to the amendments should have gone back to the Select Committee for further evaluation, further contact with the industry and further input. Then there would have been a lot more certainty. Sales tax, unlike income tax, is a transactions tax. It is paid up front. Technically it is possible to get one's money back but it is very embarrassing and very difficult and it is not good for customer-client relationships.

There will now be six Acts in lieu of the previous 27 sales tax Acts. That is welcome. In fact, the new sales tax law has been completely rewritten in a different style, with substantial changes in terminology. The thrust is very important. However, the Bill does nothing to overcome the inherent defects of imposing taxes at the wholesale sales tax level when nowadays that step in the distribution chain is rapidly disappearing. Also, the charges would add significantly to industry's input costs, quite unlike the coalition's Fightback policy, which is designed to remove such business charges as business input costs.

I remind the Senate that sales tax is inflationary. It adds to the cost of living. It is a hidden tax. The consumers do not know what tax is in the price they are paying. In the past eight years, the total revenue to Government has grown significantly from just less than $4 billion to just over $9 billion at the present time, and it is about to jump again under the new measures.

There are a number of problems, but I acknowledge that perhaps the most blatant difficulties with the earlier sales tax simplification legislation have been attended to following Mr Dawkins's hasty revision. We thank him for that and we acknowledge the important role played by Senator Short and Senator Vanstone on the Committee and others in drawing attention to the problems that were created by this legislation. As a result of this change, there is another big problem that we must address if we are to have any pride in Australia as a nation. We have to encourage Australian ownership in industry.

The original simplification legislation would have overcome a problem within the oil industry but, in overcoming that problem, it would have addressed a discrimination that operated against all companies that unfortunately had, by their structure, an Australian shareholding. I refer to Ampol and to Qantas.

The original sales tax legislation, as a result of the removal of the deemed manufacturer provisions, would have overcome that inequity. When the Government decided to reinstate, for very good reason, the deemed manufacturer provisions, it recreated a problem for the industry in that there was an anomaly. There was not a level playing field. As a result of this anomaly, the oil refineries that were affected were the companies that had an Australian shareholding content. I think this was, indeed, unfortunate.

One may say that they should restructure their activities to overcome the particular problems. But the question has to be asked: why should oil companies that are efficient worldwide restructure their operations simply because of the whims of governments in the way they structure their sales tax? The cost involved in restructuring to take advantage of the concession now, along the lines of the competitors, really cannot be easily quantified. In any event, there is no guarantee that the anti-avoidance provisions of the law would accommodate such actions because that is the way the legislation is written. That is unfortunate. It is difficult to restructure because the dominant purpose of restructuring is to overcome the sales tax problem, which is technically running into the problems with the anti-avoidance provisions of the law.

The legislation currently excludes investment when used in conjunction with refinery exchange arrangements, even though refinery exchange is for all intents a part of the manufacturing operation. Briefly, to avoid creating a multitude of small, inefficient refineries in Australia—and this is basically what the Government is expecting the industry to do—each company manufactures products at one or two locations sufficient for its overall needs. It exchanges part of these volumes for products from its competitors' refineries interstate to satisfy markets remote from its manufacturing location. The practice of refinery exchange appears to be unique to the oil industry. Because it is a highly volatile fuel, about 5 to 10 per cent is lost through evaporation.

To exclude refinery exchange based investment from the manufacturing concession is anomalous, and it sends a signal to the market from the Government that efficient world scale manufacturing operations are actually not encouraged. I am sure that this should not be an intention of any government. But it is my job, I believe, to focus on a few of these problems at the moment. I put it to the Government that it must address these issues.

An industry specific provision should be introduced; that is the way out. The specific amendment should be limited to those companies which are part of the group which itself manufactures petroleum products in Australia. If this proves impracticable, it should not be beyond the legislative drafters to come up with a solution to remove the inequity.

Let us look at one particular case. In 1992-93 Ampol, for example, proposes to commit over $140m of new capital expenditure, the large majority being facilities fabricated and constructed in Australia, a not insignificant proportion of which may now be subject to sales taxes excluded from the concessions. This is surely an unintended consequence. The companies proceeded on the basis that the law was going to be changed with the removal of the deemed manufacturer provisions. They were right. But at least it put them on a level playing field.

The oil industry is highly regulated, to the stage where the Prices Surveillance Authority controls the wholesale price which the industry is able to charge for its petrol. Therefore, any additional legislation, such as the sales tax simplification legislation as now amended, will cause problems of inequity. Surely, the purpose of simplification was to remove the industry. It is unique in its operation and it is at an essential time, and I think it important that we address this matter, because I feel that discrimination against companies that have an Australian shareholding content is quite abhorrent.

The basic intention of the legislation was to stimulate manufacturing investment and to make industry competitive by reducing the incidence of sales tax on business inputs. We have a problem of inequity here, so far as the Australian companies are concerned. The refiner-marketer could be a deemed manufacturer. This would mean that storage, handling and distribution facilities would be exempt and this would be clearly in line with government policy. But the policy changes affect the five refiner-marketers unequally. That is caused, it is true, by their corporate structures, which have developed differently over the years. Consequently, three organisations are now able to obtain a substantial benefit while two—the two which have Australian content—cannot. Because the deemed manufacturer provisions have now been excluded from the proposed simplification of legislation they will perpetuate a previous inequity, and we have told the Government how it should overcome the particular concern.

I will now direct some attention to some of the amendments: firstly, the general anti-avoidance provisions. Fortunately, the proposals originally put to this Senate have now been changed and a number of conditions which the Commissioner must satisfy before the provisions can be applied have got to be examined. But a notable omission from these revised amendments is what I refer to as the safe-harbour provision for ordinary commercial dealings. Without this, there will be a great deal of confusion from this new legislation. In other words, despite all the words, the principal failing of the old provision would appear to be mirrored in the new provision. The provision could be even worse than this in the proposed section 93(2) as expressed in the comprehensive terms, and might preclude the Commissioner from having regard to the matters not expressed therein.

So there are difficulties even with the revised general anti-avoidance provisions. It is true the draconian earlier content—some of it—has been withdrawn and revised, particularly the Commissioner's powers of reconstruction, but I put it to the Government that it should address this question of this notable omission in relation to a safe harbour for ordinary commercial dealings.

The untaxed goods provisions, as foreshadowed, are not to be extended to those untaxed because of the small business exemption, and the proposed amendment does now appear to fully accommodate most concerns. Under the original simplified law, donations to exempt bodies—for example, goods which were donated to a charity which were to be used in a raffle or sold for the purpose of making money—did not qualify for the exemption. This was drawn to their attention; it has now been addressed. A new item, 193, is to be introduced to provide for an exemption of goods for donation or loan to an always exempt person and we welcome that. That was certainly an unintended consequence and caused unnecessary fear across the business community. In the case of property owned or leased to exempt organisations, the scope of the proposed amendments appears to be much more limited than was indicated in the Treasurer's press release of 11 August. Examples of the types of things not covered as intended are perhaps much more limited.

I turn to short term leases: a number of new provisions are to be incorporated in the sales tax laws to provide a proportional sales tax exemption for goods which are subject to an eligible short term lease. A new provision, 15A, will set out the conditions under which the Commissioner may enter into an agreement to calculate a rebate percentage with a taxpayer.

I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that there is still one minor problem with the proposed amendment. The Taxation Office has agreed on record that the agreements to be made under the new section 15 will mirror the agreements which taxpayers will certainly have with the Taxation Office. I think it is questionable whether the words of section 15A will really facilitate such agreements. For example, most current agreements are based on revenues rather than, for example, leasing periods under this context of short term leases.

We thank the Government for the further revision in relation to goods used to repair exempt goods, because that proposed amendment does appear to cover adequately the new arrangements. Similarly, the deemed manufacturer provisions do appear to be in line with the Treasurer's press release. However, the requirement for wholesale sales will pose problems in the future as some businesses will tend to retail more and more. For example, magazine publishers will be marketing more and more by subscription and by direct mail.

In the area of sale of goods subject to approval, a new provision, section 15B, is to be incorporated into the Sales Tax Assessment Act to cover the circumstances where a person makes a loan on trial or lease of goods with the intention of subsequently selling or leasing goods to the user. The provision is aimed at situations where the goods are subject or sold subject to a trial or approved period.

While the Government has seen fit to make a number of complicated changes to the simplified sales tax Bills—that is, I suppose, a contradiction in itself—the changes do not address all the issues raised before the Senate Select Committee. Therefore, I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the best course is for the Government to put these issues, these further amendments and these outstanding issues, back to the Committee for a proper evaluation, because if ever there was a need for certainty in the law it is paramount in the area of sales tax. I put it to the Committee that some of those areas that do need to be looked at are the general anti-avoidance provisions, particularly the areas that I addressed earlier, and property owned or leased to exempt organisations. The provisions go only part of the way to satisfying the Treasurer's press release and certain of his concerns.

Many of the issues and the substance raised before the Committee have not been addressed. There is still a lot of uncertainty in the area of rulings. This is unfortunate. I refer to containers for takeaway foods: there is now a discrimination within the food industry. McDonald's and similar takeaway food outlets will be discriminated against. The original intent under sales tax law was that the containers have the same rate of sales tax that applies to the products that the containers enclose. A simplification process would have endorsed that concept. But no, we have a change whereby there is a discrimination and, instead of simplifying the area, the Government has added further confusion and is going to get extra revenue from it.

There is an anomaly with regard to the terminals used by authors and the typesetting of commercial publications. This is an area that I would have thought would have been addressed at the time. There is also the issue of equipment used by airline catering establishments. There is a confusion in the explanatory memorandum at page 136. That could be a trap for unsuspecting taxpayers. It would be fairly difficult for people making rulings within the Tax Office to perceive that perhaps there are reasons to ignore the words `no change'. So there are a number of difficulties.

While there are still many defects in the legislation, the thrust of the Government's intention was needed. Unfortunately, it appears that in the end the officers who were responsible were asked to come up with a solution, despite a two-year long term evaluation, and with a hasty answer. We have lost a lot of the benefits in the process of that research. Had they been given additional time, perhaps another three months or six months, it would have provided them with the opportunity to put these new proposals to industry for evaluation and to have presented to this Parliament in the first place a comprehensive simplification proposal.

It is not really the fault of those concerned, or of the Tax Office, which carried out its job in a very professional and very helpful manner. The responsibility must surely be sheeted home to the Government. It forced this dreadful timetable on both the Tax Office—those officers who were advising—and on this Parliament. I think it is unfortunate that the commencement date is 1 December. It is too early, given the significance of the change and the ramifications that the sales tax is going to have on industry. Given the fact that the Opposition has highlighted an entirely different approach—the Fightback approach, and a GST, which will certainly address all the issues about which we have major concerns—the Government should at least go back and have a thorough look at the question of rulings, the anti-avoidance provisions, the dilemmas that typesetters are faced with in the printing industry, the problems within the food industry, and so on.

There will be a lot of annoyed people out there, people who will feel that they are being disadvantaged. People who felt that their problems were going to be overcome by the legislation will find themselves like a shag on a rock. In the case of those Australian oil refineries that have an Australian shareholding content, I think it is absolutely atrocious that any Government should allow, for any period of time, such companies, particularly as at least one of them is investing large sums of money, to be discriminated against in such an unsatisfactory way. I look forward to further debate on this matter when the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation presents its report later in the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and related Bills. I think that what my colleagues have said about this Bill being grossly mishandled by this Government is true. It has not been driven by a need to simplify the indirect tax system—the wholesale sales tax system which virtually every practitioner believes, if it is not already in a state of breaking down, is certainly in a state of chaos and confusion. The Bill has been brought forward in an attempt by the Government to score some political points. Unfortunately, because of the appalling drafting of the Bill, and because of the anomalies in this Bill, that particular strategy fell flat.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, which considered this Bill, on working under what I believe to be very difficult conditions, including the astonishing fact that on the eve of the Committee's hearings the Government announced major changes to the Bill, which changes made it very hard for the Committee and the witnesses who were called before the Committee to carefully examine the legislation. I certainly endorse the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson that there are many aspects of this legislation, some of which I will be referring to and some of which Senator Panizza, Senator Watson and Senator Short have referred to already, that need to be re-examined and that need to go back to the Committee for careful examination and so that there can be proper consultation with people who may be dramatically affected by this legislation.

Again, as so often occurs in this chamber, a heavy responsibility falls on the Australian Democrats. In the end, this legislation, with its huge flaws, will pass because of the support of the Australian Democrats. Or is it possible for the Australian Democrats at least to ensure that the legislation goes back to the Committee so that proper hearings can be held on the full impact of the more recent amendments that the Government has brought forward?

It is an astonishing thing that the more a Minister in this Government fails, the more likely he is to be promoted. Of course, I suppose the pre-eminent example of that is the promotion of the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, to the great office of Prime Minister of this country. No man has more comprehensively failed, I believe, in the management of the economy in this country than Mr Keating, and yet the Labor Party surprisingly rewarded him with the highest office in the land.

Likewise, with Mr Dawkins. Mr Dawkins has had a ministerial career marked by notable failings, none more so, I would say, than the previous post he occupied as education Minister. One has only to go around the universities and the tertiary institutions to see what a total disaster Mr Dawkins's period in that portfolio has wreaked on that great sector of the Australian economy. And Mr Dawkins also got promotion. It is an astonishing thing that this man, whose career is marked by great failure, was elevated by the Labor Party to one of the highest offices in the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not actually seem to have got anywhere at all. What is your problem?
—I am not in the Labor Party, happily. These are Labor Party rules, Senator Collins: the more one fails, the more one is liable to get promoted.
—But if merit counts for so much—

—Senator Collins would not argue that Keating had failed as Treasurer, would he? After all, Keating produced the greatest downturn in the Australian economy for 60 years. Senator Collins would not stand up in this Parliament and argue that Mr Keating was a great Treasurer, would he? But he was promoted to Prime Minister. What a massive achievement!
—You sound a bit sensitive—
—Would Senator Collins argue that Dawkins's period as education Minister was not marked by failure?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! It is Mr Dawkins, if you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Dawkins's period as Minister—
—Senator, if you insist on answering interjections, you cannot ask for the protection of the Chair. So ignore them.

—I am not asking for the protection of the Chair, with respect. If Senator Collins wishes to raise those issues, I am always quite happy to respond to them. If he wants to pretend that Mr Keating's record as Treasurer of this country has been marked by success, I feel that it is appropriate in this chamber to respond to it.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, I think a heavy responsibility descends on the Australian Democrats to ensure that any such Bill which finally emerges from this chamber is carefully examined by that Senate Committee. Certainly, I believe that this legislation should now be referred back to that Senate Committee for very careful and close scrutiny.

It is true, as I said, that a heavy responsibility falls on the Australian Democrats in relation to this. It is not as though they are opposed to indirect taxes. We have certainly seen that from the alternative Budget which Senator Kernot presented to the Australian people some weeks ago. It was strangely called, I would have to say, Getting to Work. Nonetheless, in that document Senator Kernot set out what she believed to be proposals that should be put before the Australian people.

On a number of occasions I have drawn attention to the former alternative Budget that was the vision presented by Senator Spindler. I used to come into this chamber to attack his proposals. Essentially, Senator Spindler felt that the Australian people should have another $6.4 billion of taxes imposed on them. I suspect that I reflect the feelings of the Australian community in saying that the last thing we need is more taxes.

Senator Kernot's so-called Getting to Work document actually trumps Senator Spindler. She believes that taxes should be raised by about $7.2 billion on top of the already heavy burden of taxes that the Australian people are now paying. I am most grateful to Senator Lees for drawing my attention to that. I did mark that statement in the Getting to Work document, because there is no secret that the Australian Democrats believe that Australians are undertaxed. There is no secret about that. In fact, Senator Lees is quite open in saying, at page 14 of Getting to Work, that Australia, with the United States, has the second lowest level of taxation of OECD countries. So Senator Lees does believe that the Australian people are lowly taxed. This feature is highlighted in Getting to Work.

That is why the Australian Democrats want to impose a whole range of new taxes on the Australian people. They want, for example, to increase the income tax. The so-called jobs levy is, in effect, an increased income tax which will hit most families in this country. They believe in a fossil fuel levy which will hit just about every person who uses a power point, every factory that needs to rely on energy. It is a very heavy tax and a very heavy burden which will flow through to the costs of virtually everything produced in this country.

Senator Lees and her colleagues have proposed higher petrol taxes, in direct contrast to the sorts of proposals that are included in the Fightback program, which aims to cut the overall burden of petrol taxes by about $11 per tank of petrol. We also have proposals to lift the company tax rate, which I guess is a strange proposal in a period when we are actually trying to encourage companies to make profits to put on jobs! The response of the Australian Democrats is to increase company taxes.

It might be said that the Democrats have a responsibility to look at their policies, which I believe are an invitation to the Labor Government to lift taxes in various areas. That is why I tend to feature those quite prominently in debates in this chamber. It is not as though the Democrats are ever going to be able to put through these taxes but the Labor Party, with its high spending program, is always sorely tempted to find new areas of revenue, to find taxes. The Democrat policies on taxation are an invitation to the Labor Party to bring in more taxes.

This Bill should never have been presented to the Parliament. The aim of the Bill is not essentially to simplify the tax system. Its aim, which has been somewhat reduced because of the changes that Mr Dawkins announced, is to grab additional revenue for the Government. I believe that the Government should be condemned for bringing this Bill before the Parliament.

The Prime Minister knows, Mr Dawkins knows and all the key Treasury officers know that there is really only one way out of this wholesale sales tax mess. There is really only one way. They know it, we know it. Indeed, I suspect that even you know it, Mr Acting Deputy President: it is to bring in a goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, slug 15 per cent on Weetbix, milk, meat, shoes, clothes?
—It is very interesting, I am always intrigued to know why is it that—
—The only way is to screw the workers. Screw the workers, it's the only way.

—`Screw the workers', says Senator Collins, the man whose Government has thrown a million workers out of work. That is some screwing, I would suggest to Senator Collins. So he comes in here and pretends to have compassion.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Collins had some real compassion, and some real concern for the traditional constituency of the Labor Party he would have resigned his high office many years ago—

TALK.START.PARA: —A scorched earth, ultra right winger like you.

—The Government has scorched the earth. What is a million unemployed but scorched earth? Has Senator Collins been through Broadmeadows in Melbourne and seen the wasteland his Government's policies have created? If Senator Collins wants to see scorched earth, he should come down to Melbourne and I will take him through those suburbs. I will show him what the scorched earth policy of the Labor Party has done. But it is intriguing. Why is it that of the 24 OECD countries, 21 of them have a form of goods and services tax? Why is it that Australia finds it impossible to bring it in? In 1985, Mr Keating had one of his rare moments of insight and I daresay Senator Collins was told to get up then and defend the goods and services tax we had to have—and I bet Senator Collins hopped up and defended it. But then Mr Keating changed his mind, so Senator Collins changed his mind.

PARA.TAB: But we know that Australia is not leading the charge in this area, that Dr Hewson and Mr Reith are not leading the charge in the area of the goods and services tax. We are trying to catch up with the rest of the world. Some 50 countries today have a form of a goods and services tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at what it has done to Canada, Senator. They love it; they really love it.

—I am glad Senator Collins said, `Have a look at what it has done to Canada', but I notice he did not ask what it has done to New Zealand. Now we know that the Labor Party has become very sensitive about raising the great efforts of Mr Bolger, and the former Labor Government in New Zealand—let us give credit where credit is due—in bringing about widespread and successful tax reform, the dividends of which, Senator Collins, are now paying off.

PARA.TAB: In Canada, which has had the goods and services tax now for just on a year and a half, despite some of the strange things that were done in relation to bringing in that tax, that particular initiative is also widely regarded as a great success—but not Australia, Senator Collins, not Australia. That is because when the national interest conflicts with the narrow interests of the Australian Labor Party, we always know where Senator Collins and his colleagues are going to come down, despite the fact that Senator Collins and his colleagues were the strongest advocates of a goods and services tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not me, Senator, never.

—Can I make a prediction to Senator Collins? I will make a prediction and I am prepared to go in Hansard for him. If, by some mischance of fate, some tragedy befalls the Australian people and Mr Keating is elected Prime Minister again, let me make this prediction: within three years Australia will have a goods and services tax. Look, the man who lied about the recession, the man who lied about—and remember this great statement—
—Order! I think the honourable senator ought to withdraw the word `lie'.

—I withdraw the word. But let me recall the man who said, `There will be no capital gains tax'. Who was that? None other than Mr Keating. Who was the man who said that there would be no recession? None other than Mr Keating. Can we believe the man who, election after election, has gone on record telling gross untruths to the Australian people? Can we believe him now, particularly when we know that he was one of the strongest advocates of the goods and services tax? Can we believe him now when he says, `No, the Australian Labor Party will not be bringing in a goods and services tax'? Of course it will bring it in, and honourable senators opposite know it will bring it in. If, as I said, by some mischance Mr Keating is elected again, Senator Collins will be standing up in this chamber and arguing strongly for it because he always does. When Mr Keating changes his mind, Senator Collins changes his mind, too.
—You'll change your mind, too.

—Senator Collins was given his marching orders in his portfolio by Mr Keating and Senator Schacht. Senator Schacht and Mr Keating gave him his marching orders, and he comes into this chamber and he defends them. Senator Collins will defend anything. If he is given a brief by the Prime Minister, he will come in and defend it—that is for sure.

PARA.TAB: We know what the Labor Party would have to do, because basically the Tax Office is fully in favour of a goods and services tax. We know that. Indeed, a number of Treasury officers have gone overseas to examine what has happened in Canada with a goods and services tax; and we know the sort of advice that is coming up. We know that the Treasury has installed a massive computer program to model goods and services taxes. We know that. But let me tell Senator Collins the overriding reason why the Labor Party will be bringing in a goods and services tax. The overriding reason is that, basically, the Labor Party is faced with a massive and exploding Budget deficit. In one of the rare bursts of honesty—we have to say this—Mr Dawkins indicated that, down the track, the Labor Party has got to find some more money.

If by some mischance the Labor Party is re-elected to government, it will have to find a lot more money, and so we will find that the Labor Party will be looking for a new range of taxes. That is why I say that, whether or not Dr Hewson and Peter Reith and the coalition are elected, which I believe they will be and which the Australian people certainly at present are giving an overwhelming mandate towards, or if by some mischance Mr Keating gets into office, there will be a goods and services tax. I make that prediction; and I make the further prediction that Senator Collins will be getting up in this chamber and defending it very strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is as lightweight as everything else you say, Senator.
—It is certainly worth recording that you could never accuse Senator Collins of being lightweight.
—Yes, one could never accuse Senator Collins of being lightweight.
—How hilariously droll, Senator!

—We could recall him coming in and defending to the nth degree any change of mind that his leader tells him to do. To think that he would stand on principle in the national interest, of course, is far beyond anything that he has done in this chamber to date. Returning to the Bill, one aspect of this new Bill—
—Return to the Bill? That will be a refreshing start.

—Do not get excited. Keep calm over there. Senator Collins is part of a falling government, a government which is totally unprincipled, and a government which has totally failed. He is being tarred with that brush, and his time is almost finished. I want to draw attention to some particular aspects of the Bill which are causing concern amongst—
—Oh!
—Don't talk about the Bill! Don't break your duck!
—This is appalling.
—Not as appalling as the speech.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order!
Senator Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, I have been very tolerant of interjections from you for a considerable period of the senator's speech. I took it that the senator did not seem to mind so much. He indicated that he did not need the protection of the Chair. I think the time has now come for us all to listen to the rest of the speech in silence and without interjection. It is inappropriate that a barrage of interjections occurs throughout a senator's speech.

—One concern that has been drawn to my attention by a number of constituents which is worth bringing before this chamber is that the legislation we have before us will render virtually useless all existing rulings held by taxpayers as well as related case law. There is no doubt in my mind that the Bills before the Senate are complex. That was probably best shown by the inability of the Australian Taxation Office to provide quick answers to questions asked during the Select Committee hearings. Because of this complexity, taxpayers will have to seek rulings from the Tax Office to see whether they have incurred a tax liability.

PARA.TAB: The legislation even contains a provision to protect taxpayers from having to pay back taxes if the ruling happens to be incorrect. But the sting is that such private rulings will give protection only to those people to whom they are issued. This will leave other companies and businesses further down the chain exposed to uncertainty and potential tax claims. An example is a manufacturer who gains a ruling relating to the classification of his product. The manufacturer then sells the product to wholesalers and it is on-sold to retailers. I understand that the problem is that the ruling applies only to the manufacturer. If the ruling is found to be wrong or is reversed, only the manufacturer will be compensated. Customers who acted in good faith would then be liable for the tax.

The only way to avoid this problem is for each actor in the chain to seek an individual ruling. That means that the only way to guarantee commercial certainty is by going to the time and expense of seeking rulings from the Australian Tax Office. Not only will this so-called simplification add to business complexity and costs but it will bog down the Australian Taxation Office in a morass of individuals seeking rulings.

An issue which has been raised in the media and which, I understand, still has not been satisfactorily resolved in the amendments that the Government has brought forward is the amendments that relate to retailers such as jewellers and marketers of photographic equipment who currently sell goods tax free to Australians going overseas and to international tourists in Australia. I understand that the proposed amendments will be extremely costly and cumbersome and will cause problems for retailers and customers. Under this Bill, it will be much cheaper for all tourists to purchase their duty free goods outside Australia.I draw the chamber's attention to this statement by the Executive Director of the Jewellers Association of Australia, Ms Kim Hillard:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed procedures were so cumbersome as to effectively mean that tax free sales to Australians travelling overseas would no longer be possible.

It seems to me that the legislation before us will cause major problems in this particular sector, in addition to the other sectors to which Senator Watson and my other colleagues have drawn attention.

PARA.TAB: One aspect of the new Bills which has the prospect of costing much more is that of dual usage. Certainly where goods are used both by an exempt organisation and by a taxable organisation, exemption applies to those goods. For example, certain goods relating to the Sydney Harbour Tunnel project are exempt even though they are owned by private contractors. The Bills will ensure that an exemption will apply only where goods are leased or purchased by the exempt organisation. I understand from accountants that this provision will jeopardise many joint private sector and public sector projects and add costs to many organisations that rely on public funding. So much for the Keating Government's policy to involve the private sector in infrastructure projects!

One way to judge the worth of this legislation is to see how it matches the intent of the Government. The Treasurer, Mr Dawkins,in his press release outlining the simplification of the wholesale sales tax legislation, referred to the benefits of the simplified law. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new law will reduce the cost of administering and complying with the WST. The extension of the small business concession is a major initiative to reduce business compliance costs and will lead to a more efficient and effective indirect tax system.

I believe I have just illustrated how false these statements are and how poorly the Treasurer understands the issue of taxation reform. Even by the Government's own standards, this Bill is a failure before it has been enacted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments made by my colleagues about the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and related Bills that we now have before us. We are told that the Bills have been introduced to simplify sales tax. But unfortunately, they have created more confusion. During my speech I will develop some aspects of this confusion.

PARA.TAB: I also declare, as Senator Panizza did, that as a primary producer I have a vital interest in this legislation for a variety of reasons. The first reason—certainly not the least important—is that in a taxation system there must be equity between and within industries. This measure has been touted as simplification, but it exacerbates that lack of equity between and within industries. I will also develop that point in a moment or two.

Confusion has arisen about this legislation. I wish to develop what has been put before me, mainly by the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia, and by primary producers, particularly farmers and pastoralists, and by miners. I have not yet been able to determine, from my examination of the amendments before us, whether the concerns of the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia have been addressed. From what I have read of the amendments, those concerns have not been totally addressed.

One of the unintended consequences of this legislation on the various machinery dealers and suppliers of goods and services, particularly to rural areas, will be that the actual cost of operating each item purchased will be greater than the sales tax. As a result, sales tax will be collected by default.

I am cynical and suspicious enough to believe that the legislation has been designed in such a way as to increase the tax base while increasing the cost to the people in rural and regional Australia who supply those goods and services. These people are finding it very difficult to survive. For example, last week a local machinery dealer at Ravensthorpe told me that 60 per cent of the items that he sells have a value of $10 or less. The cost of administering the proposals before us will do nothing more than significantly increase the cost of those products beyond what the tax exemption is worth. Of course, the final user of the product will pick up the costs.

Rather than the Bills simplifying sales tax and making it easier for people involved in those industries—whether in the wheat, wool or beef industries; mining, particularly prospecting; or any arm of the agricultural or mining industries—most of the tax will be collected by default. In the long run, this not being a simple or cost-effective operation will mean that our ability to compete, in an export sense, will be severely disadvantaged.

I make reference to the haste with which this Bill, even though there has been some two years review in the development of it, was guillotined through the House of Representatives. The intention was to have it passed through this place before the winter recess. Fortunately, that did not occur. While one can be critical of the Democrats at times, one must also acknowledge that they did support us in having the legislation referred to a Senate select committee, although the way that the Committee was treated was most unsatisfactory. To have two days of hearings into what are essentially changes to 27 Bills, which was reduced to six Bills, to look at the various submissions—I believe there were around 150—and do justice to them in that time is certainly not satisfactory.

I refer to some of the comments in the report which I found interesting. The first comes from Coopers and Lybrand. I think it is a very important test and one which has been mentioned in many of the submissions. I certainly have read a number of the submissions, but not all of them. The report refers to the Coopers and Lybrand submission, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As sales tax is a self-assessing tax, it is imperative that this "new law", which replaces the existing sales tax legislation, meets all the tests of a good statute, ie simplicity, equity, efficiency and certainty. In generality, in our opinion, the legislation as it presently exists, fails all four tests.
Even with the amendments that have been put before us, I believe it still fails those four tests, for the reasons I have mentioned, and some others which I will mention in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at comments that indicate why this legislation should not be before us today, even though it was referred to the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. The Committee, chaired by Senator Walsh, said at paragraph 78:

SPEECH.PARA: The concerns raised are discussed in the body of this report. The Committee believes that the announcements made in the Treasurer's press release of 11 August 1992—
legislation by press release, I might add, in the middle of a hearing—
and the explanations and undertakings given by the ATO in relation to matters subject to the Commissioner of Taxation's discretion, address most of those concerns. The committee accepts—
I emphasise the word `accepts'—

that as witnesses have not seen the proposed amendments which give effect to the undertakings in the statement they reserve their position about whether the government's undertakings would fully satisfy their concerns. The Committee shares the concerns expressed by witnesses and believes that more time should have been available to consider the effects of matters raised in the Treasurer's press release.
That is what the Committee said in its report. I quote from what Senator Short and Senator Vanstone said in their minority report:

The hearings revealed that the Government's new proposed Wholesale Sales Tax would include a tax on food, a tax on services, a tax on exports, a tax on tourism, a tax on farmers, a tax on many manufacturers, double taxation, a tax on infrastructure and a tax on plant and buildings. These taxes are all the result of the fundamentally flawed Wholesale Sales Tax system, that this Government seeks to retain.
Their recommendations stated further:

The new law for Wholesale Sales Tax as envisaged in the Bills is fundamentally flawed. Sales Tax is a tax on goods. It is a tax that has a significant cascading effect, which results in tax on all sorts of goods and services, that is not intended.
I emphasise that it is not intended. They continued:

It is paid and borne by business. It is highly uncompetitive. It means that many Australian producers are left at a substantial disadvantage to overseas competitors, both in export markets and domestically.
The so-called "simplification" process has failed to deliver a substantially better sales tax system.

I will dwell for a moment on the disadvantages this has for Australian producers compared to our overseas competitors and highlight the particular aspect which has been drawn out quite correctly by Senator Short and Senator Vanstone. In the recent Budget nothing was done to ease the burden that exporters in this country carry. Until that burden is eased and broken down, and exporters are allowed to operate in a taxation system that is competitive and fair compared to what occurs in the rest of the world, we will continue to be disadvantaged and this country will continue to have current account problems, Budget deficit blow-outs and a number of other consequences which are not in our long term best interests.

PARA.TAB: The Budget states that the Government has in fact accepted that the best that it can do if its predictions are correct—and recent history and longer term history would suggest that they are not going to be correct—is find that an unemployment level of somewhere around 10 per cent is acceptable. One cannot come to any other conclusion but that. Until such time as we have a taxation system which does not disadvantage our capacity to be competitive in an export sense, we will continue to have the sorts of problems that I have outlined.
I will move to the minority report by Senator Kernot from the Democrats. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are still a number of anomalies which apply in the Wholesale Sales Tax.

The report from the Committee as a whole, the minority report from Opposition senators and the minority report from the Democrats, represented by Senator Kernot, all justify in a very succinct way the fact that this legislation should be referred back to that Senate Select Committee for proper and full examination of the anomalies and the things that many of the witnesses raised, if this Government at this time is going to continue down the road of a wholesale sales tax rate.

PARA.TAB: I would also support very strongly the comments of my colleague Senator Kemp when he emphasised very strongly that if by some misfortune or injustice the Keating Government was to get back into power—which I do not believe it will—this legislation would be the forerunner of a goods and services tax by the Government. Many aspects that have been brought under the wholesale sales tax revision in this Bill indicate that very strongly.

I will just move through a number of other points that I wish to raise in terms of this particular legislation. I have already mentioned the quotes from the Committee and I have mentioned the changing of the legislation by press release which the Treasurer did, as I understand it, on the eve of the first day of the two-day hearings. This was even before he had had an opportunity to have a look at the report that was to come down from the people who gave evidence. I presume that his officers in his Department did in fact take some note of some of the submissions that were put forward, but one will never know that.

Let us just talk for a moment about the current wholesale sales tax system and what is wrong with it. The first thing that is wrong with it is that it is a hidden tax; it is a dishonest tax. People do not know what they are paying. They do not know what the cost of the cascading effect of the tax is through the system. For that reason alone, if we had a taxation system which in fact was visible, people would be able to assess the actual tax they were paying and would be able to make a much fairer judgment on governments, whatever their colour, in terms of the amount of tax they were paying. They would also be able to make a much fairer judgment in terms of the businesses they were dealing with. They would be able to see just what mark-ups were being placed on goods and services, or goods in particular, because the service costs from a wholesale sales tax are very minimal, but they do have a cascading effect as a result of its indirect impact.

As I said before: what is wrong with it? It is hidden and, as a result of being hidden, it is dishonest. There is no greater example of that than the fuel excise and the way that has crept up over the last 10 years, from somewhere in the order of 6.5c to in excess of 25c a litre without anybody having a clue what was going on.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to outline to Queensland residents, that is, those whom I represent in this chamber, why I no longer carry a particular credit card which I used for 15 years. I believe my remarks are pertinent to Queensland holders of the card only, but residents of other States may wish to check whether similar circumstances prevail for them.

PARA.TAB: The card to which I refer is American Express, well known throughout Australia and, indeed, throughout most of the world. In fact, I can recall only one place overseas where my American Express card was not accepted. The incident occurred in an out of the way centre in Germany and with only Danish currency in my wallet I met a few difficulties in paying for dinner. The card is not universally accepted in Australia, but with an American Express card and a Bankcard I have never been unable to charge accommodation and travel costs in Australia. The principal reason for applying for a card some 15 years ago was to pay for accommodation and meals, as well as for other purchases, when overseas. I later used the American Express card for a wide variety of purchases in this country.

I have, however, not renewed my annual subscription to American Express, not because of a small additional impost charged by the company but because of a matter of principle. Whenever I make purchases in Queensland—this is where the vast majority of my card purchases occur—I am charged stamp duty on each transaction except the first. At 10c a transaction this is a relatively small amount but, if all the cards being used in Queensland were taken into account, stamp duty charges would net a reasonable amount of revenue for the Queensland Government. I have no complaint with that. I am a Queensland resident and, as I mentioned, most of my credit card charge purchases occur in Queensland.

This year, however, as well as paying Queensland Government stamp duty I have been billed by American Express for New South Wales financial institutions duty. Although financial institutions duty is calculated differently, the duty for which I have been billed generally equates to the amount of Queensland stamp duty payable. I have asked the company why I should pay financial institutions duty, especially when most of my purchases occur in Queensland and when my American Express account was automatically credited from one of my Queensland bank accounts. The response was that, as my payments to the company were deposited in New South Wales, the company was charged financial institutions duty on its bank deposits and has now decided to pass this charge on to its members.

I have no doubt that, under the conditions of use of an American Express card, the company can do this rather than accept the duty as a business expense, an expense which it has incurred because it entrusts its business to a New South Wales based bank. For users of the card in Queensland, however, it means that, even if their purchases are made entirely within Queensland, they have to pay New South Wales financial institutions duty. That is in addition to their Queensland stamp duty. I see no reason why Queensland citizens should prop up an ailing New South Wales economy.

I have subsequently obtained, through the bank with which I deal, a Queensland based credit card which allows me to make domestic and overseas purchases. I still pay the required Queensland stamp duty but not New South Wales financial institutions duty. I informed the American Express company that, when my renewal of $60 became payable, I would not renew. That non-renewal has now occurred, breaking a 15-year association I had with the company.

The reason I am recounting this today is to alert other American Express card holders in Queensland that they are subsidising the New South Wales Government. They would be able to find, as I did, that there are Queensland based credit cards which offer similar services to those of American Express and quite possibly cost far less than the amount charged by American Express for its annual fee.

Now that I have an alternative card to my former American Express card, I am pleased that I took the effort to change. I see no reason why I should pay financial institutions duty to the New South Wales Government because a company I deal with happens to choose a bank in New South Wales with which to lodge its deposits. Those Queensland residents who carry American Express cards, or any other card which has a similar policy attached, should investigate the possibility of discarding their card in favour of a Queensland based card.

There is an interesting postscript to the story about cutting my ties with American Express. As I knew that my association with the company was coming to an end, I discontinued using the card a month or two before my membership was due to expire. Even so, I received a final account from the company, an account for 26c. That was the financial institutions duty which the company had billed me for the last account which I had paid. I had a mind to ignore the demand for 26c but formed the opinion that the company would report me to a credit reference agency, and that my credit rating would be damaged, all for the want of 26c which the company had incurred but was intent on passing on. I duly sent a cheque for 26c.

To reiterate, I suggest that Queensland credit card holders check to see whether they too are paying tax to the government of another State, as well as to the Queensland Government. If they are, they have a remedy of discontinuing the use of that card and obtaining an equally good Queensland based alternative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a situation which I regard as nothing short of extraordinary. It relates to the situation of the F3 freeway between Sydney and Newcastle not being completed, but just ending in the middle of a swamp, eight kilometres from the national highway that it is meant to feed into. The F3 is 150 kilometres long. It is just sheer stupidity to build all of it, except for the last eight kilometres. It is obvious that a major road that links the largest city in Australia with the sixth largest city in Australia would have huge traffic volumes, and that is true. The F3 caters for all the northbound traffic leaving Sydney, going through northern New South Wales and on into Queensland. The question is: Why is the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) content to let this major freeway stop eight kilometres short of a satisfactory intersection and let minor State and local road traffic take the burden?
—It can't be in a Labor marginal.

—As Senator Macdonald has indicated, it is not in a Labor marginal. This will result in the ridiculous situation where local traffic will be severely disrupted, northbound traffic will bottleneck when the freeway just stops, local roads will deteriorate more rapidly, and the safety of motorists and pedestrians in the area will be jeopardised.

PARA.TAB: For the last six years, it has been obvious that there was going to be a problem at the north end of the F3, but no plan was devised to solve this problem, just a feasibility statement on possible solutions. It becomes even more unbelievable when one considers that the freeway ends very close to Mr Brown's electorate of Charlton. The roads in his electorate will be expected to take a lot of the burden of the dispersing freeway traffic, just as they have done for the last five years when the F3 finished at a point west of Toronto—again, in the middle of nowhere and without any proper links with other major roads. This traffic nightmare is about to be repeated, 13 kilometres further north.

To explain more fully to honourable senators who may not be familiar with the local conditions, the F3 is a federally funded road which is part of the national road system. The plan is for a network of major roads encircling the continent. The incomplete F3 has long been a break in the link. It needs to join both the Pacific Highway and the New England Highway. These roads, of course, are the major traffic routes to Brisbane. However, the F3 is going to stop just before it gets to these highways. The two northbound lanes of the freeway are going to feed into a single local road called Lenaghans Drive, eight kilometres short of the main intersection. This means that there will be a most horrendous bottleneck in peak traffic periods; peak periods such as Christmas 1993 when the connection is due to open.

The authorities building the freeway are all aware of the fact that this bottleneck will occur. The project report from the Road Traffic Authority of New South Wales in Newcastle states that the average annual daily traffic, the AADT, on Lenaghans Drive is at the moment in excess of 8,000 vehicles. This is expected to increase substantially on the opening of the next section of the freeway to Lenaghans Drive, in December 1993. Current best practice indicates that dual carriageways should be built where the AADT reaches 8,000 to 12,000. To quote the RTA:

SPEECH.PARA: The perception of inadequacy will be heightened for the northbound traffic coming from freeway standards to a relatively short length of two lane road with entering traffic, before re-entering further dual carriageways.
If the situation is going to occur and the relevant authorities know that the result will be traffic disaster, the question is: why is Mr Brown, the responsible Minister, going to let this occur?

PARA.TAB: Funding is needed urgently to connect the F3 both to the New England and Pacific highways with dual carriageway so that traffic flow can be smooth, efficient and safe and ultimately at a lower cost to private and public users. The freeway was started 30 years ago, but we are still waiting for it to be finished. At the moment, one could expect that this ridiculous situation with local traffic conditions could persist for another six years. It is more likely that we will be waiting for a further 15 years. Either way, it is simply not good enough.

The Federal Government has to see this for the very high priority that it is. This F3 is the link between Sydney and the rapidly growing and increasingly urbanised and very popular holiday destinations along the north coast of New South Wales. With this traffic feeding into Lenaghans Drive, the results during peak periods like Christmas and Easter will be similar to the five-hour traffic jams that resulted six years ago when the tollgates north of Sydney were still in operation. It is simply unacceptable for motorists to go back to those miserable conditions again. But this is what the Federal Government expects us to accept.

The national highway is a federally funded road. The route is determined by the Federal Government and, therefore, it is responsible for this plan. Last month the Minister for Land Transport announced $600m worth of road projects for high unemployment areas, but the completion of the F3, one of Australia's major roads, did not even get a look in. Even the fact that this issue is vital to the electorate of the Minister did not seem to help. This is a prime example of the ineffectiveness of ALP members of parliament in the Newcastle area.

I look forward to the result of the public consultation paper being conducted next month and the environmental impact statement being conducted on the options for the link of the F3 to the New England and Pacific highways. Lenaghans Drive is, surely, not the way to go. A completed dual carriageway for the national highway is necessary. To stop the construction eight kilometres short would be a national transport tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave notice of a motion that drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that 19 August marked the second anniversary of the death of Paul Loughlin. It also represents two years since a death has occurred in police cells within Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have two aims in raising the matter again. Firstly, as a memorial, I would like the death of this 22-year-old man to be remembered as the tragedy it was. Secondly, I see it as an opportunity to remind ourselves that such a situation should not be allowed to recur. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an account of Paul's death which was published in the May 1992 issue of the Death in Custody Newsletter.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: DEATH IN CUSTODY NEWSLETTER

PARA.TAB: May 1992

SPEECH.PARA: Lack of Care

On August 8, 1990, young NSW man Paul Loughlin (22) was at a party. The police attended following a noise complaint. His mate was arrested. Paul cycled to the Derby (WA) police station hoping to bail his friend. Paul was arrested for loitering.
Police are required to remove tobacco, matches and lighters from all those they detain. With tragic consequences, in the case of Paul Loughlin, they failed in this duty.
It is understood that at 1.45 am Paul Loughlin was placed in a cell without being properly searched and 50 minutes later suffered horrendous burns.

Because the officer in charge of was on leave the alarm in the cells was not switched to night position. Not only were people incarcerated and unsupervised there was no means of communicating that help was needed.
Paul could not understand why he had been arrested, he knew he's done no wrong.
The fire was lit in the cell as a call for help, a call for freedom. The soaring, ceiling high flames, the inevitable intense, searing heat and the dense, black smoke was not expected by the victim.
Paul walked through the flames and collapsed. He was unrecognisable with burns to almost all his body.

A police cadet living in a house directly behind the lockup was woken by yells and screams. He looked outside saw smoke and raised the alarm. He ran to the police station, unlocked the door, grabbed the cell keys and released the detainees to the exercise yard.
An ambulance took Paul to Derby District Hospital and from there by Flying Doctor to an intensive care unit at Royal Perth Hospital.
Frances Gartrell did not hear of her son's fatal injuries until told by the Anglican Chaplain at Royal Perth. The family immediately travelled from Sydney to be with their boy.
Paul Loughlin died of multiple organ failure on August 19, he survived for 11 days and his mother lived and suffered his last days with him.
The Coroner, David McCann found that the death was an accident aggravated by lack of care.

It was pointed out in the Finding that "persons detained in custody are at risk of injury or death" and that no action of the incarcerated citizen could "relieve the custodians of their duty of care towards those detained'. The Finding also emphasised the importance of a careful search and observation of each arrested person.
It can only be hoped that Paul Loughlin will be remembered as the last fatality in a WA police cell where the death had to be described as aggravated by lack of care.
Note: All inflammable mattresses have been removed from WA lockups.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This newsletter is produced regularly by Mrs Jennifer Searcy of the Campaign for Prevention of Custodial Death. In her article Mrs Searcy points out that the coroner, David McCann, found that the death was an accident aggravated by lack of care. The account incorporated in Hansard indicates the tragedy of a young man trapped by fire within the cell.

PARA.TAB: Today represents two full years free of deaths within Western Australia's police lockups. This is an extremely important improvement in police practice and it deserves appreciation and commendation. I would like to refer to some statistics on deaths in police custody in Western Australia from 1980 to the present. The record from 1970 to 1980 is incomplete but there were at least 25 known deaths. From 1980 to 1992, the number of deaths ranged from a maximum of seven in 1985 to the death-free years of 1991 and 1992. I seek leave to incorporate those figures in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures read as follows—
Deaths in Police Custody in Western Australia
Year Number of Deaths
The record for the 1970s is incomplete, but there were at least 25 deaths.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The significant absence of deaths in police cells is something which affords us great hope that police practices throughout Australia can be improved in such a way that tragedies, such as the death of Paul Loughlin, do not need to recur. It is for this reason that I mentioned in my notice of motion that the Senate should commend the Western Australian Government and the Western Australian Police for this response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. It reflects a significant indicator of improved police practice in that State. I also suggest that we should note with concern that the same indicators of improved police procedures are not present in other States. I support the memory of that young man's death, two years ago yesterday, as a need for us to look further at the implementation of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

—I wish to use this opportunity to express my concerns about the income tax rulings system, in particular the taxation draft ruling known as TR92/D24. After all the excitement and the media attention of the Budget, I believe it is appropriate that we should turn our minds to the processes by which this country is really governed and to the people who are in important in that process. Because we operate here in the full glare of parliamentary publicity, we tend to be beguiled into the belief that we are actually in control, that we get the results we expect and that when we pull these exciting levers, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) refers to, we are in control—or he is in control.

PARA.TAB: However, I would like to remind the Senate that what attracts the passing attention of the Press Gallery does not always represent the real and the ultimate exercise of executive power. I would like to illustrate what I mean by reference to the income tax system, particularly the rulings. We have had cause whilst sitting on various committees, particularly on the most recent example, the sales tax legislation Committee, to reflect upon how public announcements by politicians can be executed by the Public Service in ways which effectively frustrate the intentions of the Parliament. I would like to illustrate this more specifically and, I think, more powerfully by reference to the process of taxation rulings, in particular the reference to draft ruling TR92/D24 which relates to deductibility of interest expense of Australian companies.

In a sense, the draft ruling process can be even more insidious than the slipping through Parliament of egregious legislation. I refer specifically to that word to draw attention to what is sometimes shocking or sometimes horrifying legislation, in terms of its impact. At least with the latter case we have some opportunity to grasp the fleeting moment and stall the process, as we did in the tax legislation, to allow some proper examination, and that is quite appropriate.

Coming back to this ruling: firstly, the ruling will, through the creation of new levels of interference, add directly to the bill which the Commissioner will present to us to administer his office in the years ahead. More importantly and insidiously, it will add to the administrative costs of many Australian corporations.

Secondly, it will distort the international transactions of those corporations and it will make them a great deal more difficult. In other words, what I am saying is that through this ruling the Australian Taxation Office will make life tough for Australian multinationals. It will make it difficult for them to do business. They will have to look over their shoulders all the time as they try to build up the sorts of overseas investments which this Parliament considers to be beneficial to Australia. The injection of equity capital into overseas subsidiaries, which the Tax Office seeks to penalise, is really the only way to invest in many Asian countries, given their investment rules.

Thirdly, and more broadly, I question whether this could be part of a continuing campaign by the Tax Office to make life more difficult for Australian businesses generally, in circumstances where frequently there is really very little revenue at risk as far as the Tax Office is concerned. We spend about $1.4 billion in collecting revenue. We use a substantial portion of this to harass the very people we are asking to improve their performance, to create more wealth, to take more risks, to invest, and to employ more people. So we have to make sure we have a system where the tax administration is not working against those very objectives. I do not say it is happening overtly, but it is happening as a result of some indirect executive power now increasingly available through the tax ruling system.

We allow all this to happen because, when it actually comes down to giving effect to government policies, we simply do not yet supervise sufficiently well the activities of those officials who administer the policies which we proclaim so loudly in this chamber. In the case of the tax rulings, they do not even have to come to the Parliament; they are issued by the Tax Commissioner. Of course, there are companies which may challenge them, but it is the very brave taxpayer these days that attracts the attention of the Tax Commissioner through a legal challenge, and this process, although necessary, does impede the satisfactory administration of justice.

The draft ruling that I refer to is nine pages long and fairly complex. However, what is at the bottom of this is the question of what deductions companies should be allowed for interest on their borrowings. In essence, the Commissioner is seeking to deny companies interest deductibility in cases where a parent company may have borrowed money to capitalise a subsidiary located outside Australia. This ruling ignores the earlier legal precedent, including a case where the tax authorities lost in the full court. That is the worrying part about it. More importantly, it is another step along the way of the Tax Commissioner arrogating the power to tell these companies which of their commercial transactions he will treat as legitimate.

This ruling, I would like to submit to the Senate, is perhaps the worst that we have received in many years in terms of its implications, particularly for Australian multinationals trying to invest abroad—not only for them, but I suppose they suffer the most severe ramifications. It shows the way in which the Tax Office, in its obsessive pursuit of revenue, can directly and comprehensively work against the general economic policies of this Government and what will almost certainly be the incoming coalition Government.

Draft ruling TR92/D24 will be expensive. In summary, it will work against efficient operation of this economy. It will work against the international operations of those companies which are brave enough to go overseas and to finance their operations accordingly. It will, therefore, be against the overall objective to internationalise our economy. It will be anti-business in very broad terms at a time when we are trying to encourage business activity. Worst of all, this Parliament will have no say whatsoever in the matter.

I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and to Senator Ray, that it is time that we in this place looked much more closely at how policy is actually carried out, particularly through the ruling processes in the Tax Office. We have had, in the last 10 years, Budget after Budget, economic statement after economic statement. All of them have proclaimed ringingly the need to improve our economic performance, the need to take the shackles off business and the need to push forward to higher levels of growth and efficiency. That was never more important than now and I use this occasion, in the Budget atmosphere, to raise this matter when our economic performance is so poor and when our levels of unemployment are so socially damaging.

Pulling the so-called policy levers will not get us out of the mess. We all know that. Only a private sector driven recovery has the potential to do so. Perhaps the discrepancy between the performance that we so earnestly seek in budgets and the performance that we see so starkly outlined in the Budget Papers has something to do with the gap between the noise that is made here and the actions that take place at the official level.
I trust that the Parliament and, perhaps more importantly, the Minister will take note of these concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday and today there has been a range of statements by local government leaders throughout Australia about the unfairness of Mr Keating's job allocation program announced in the Budget. There has been an outcry on why certain areas of Australia should be helped with their unemployed while other areas of Australia miss out completely.
