In regard to the program by Mr Keating—where, incidentally, on the figures his Minister released, his electorate receives the highest amount of any in Australia, some $20m—it is interesting and not surprising that people—
—Rubbish.

—They are the Government's figures, not our figures. They are the Government's figures tabled in the House yesterday by Mr Simmons. Would Senator Ray say that they are wrong? Are they rubbery, like all of the figures in the Budget—completely rubbery, made up?
—To say $20m is rubbish.
—They are the Minister's figures. He might tell me what is wrong with them. His Government tabled them. I am only quoting from them.
—You are misinterpreting them, that is what you are doing.

—They were tabled. I will show the Minister later if he has not seen this. It is all over the pages. One cannot blame people for suggesting that it has simply been an enormous pork-barrelling exercise in Labor marginal seats.
—Why did the Gold Coast get $8m?

—I am glad that Senator Ray mentioned the Gold Coast. Does he know the councils involved? They are: Albert, Gold Coast City and Beaudesert. Does he know whose electorate they are in? They are not in McPherson or Moncrieff, two fairly substantial Liberal seats. They happen to be in the new seat of Rankin, held very tenuously by the Minister for Small Business, or whatever he is, Mr Beddall. He is being challenged by Mrs Sallyanne Atkinson, who is rather a prominent person in Queensland and who will win that seat, in spite of the fact that the Government has tossed in $13m to try to prop up Mr Beddall. So I am glad that the honourable senator mentioned that; it is most appropriate that he should. In another Labor marginal seat, where a sitting Minister is about to be done over by Mrs Sallyanne Atkinson, in a desperate attempt to keep Mr Beddall there the Government has thrown in some money. But it will not work. Mrs Atkinson will be the next member for Rankin and Mr Beddall will join the unemployment queues, with a lot of his colleagues from the Labor Ministry at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Some people suggest that this is a pork-barrelling exercise. The Chairman of the Country Mayors Association in New South Wales, Alderman David Johns, was bitterly disappointed by and criticised very strenuously the Federal Government's provision of funds for job creation schemes to metropolitan councils—just more evidence which I will come to later. Alderman Johns points out that Fairfield and Liverpool get $13.177m, while Dubbo, Wagga, Tamworth and Orange in the country, and many other country centres, receive absolutely nothing. People in Sydney suburbs such as Fairfield can travel to other parts of Sydney looking for work, but a jobless person in country centres does not have the same advantage. Alderman Johns quite rightly pointed out in his press release that the only country region to be given significant job creation funds in category 1 of the Budget allocation was that based around Lismore, which surprisingly just happens to be smack bang in the centre of two very marginal Labor seats which again the Government is desperately trying to retain!

Senator Knowles has kindly given me a note indicating, as Senator Campbell did last night, that Labor's most marginal seat in Western Australia, Stirling, gets something like $7.1m, one of the highest figures in Australia, whereas other equally deserving areas get absolutely nothing. In fact, Alderman Johns in his press release points out that only $10.9m of the $73.65m allocated to New South Wales has gone to country councils, and none of these councils are west of the Great Divide.

Non-metropolitan and coastal councils in New South Wales fare little better in the category 2 schemes. Cowra received a $344,000 grant, presumably to compensate for the recent loss of 150 jobs with the closure of Edgells. But Tamworth, which recently lost 220 jobs when East-West Airlines closed its maintenance facilities, received absolutely nothing. Alderman Johns points out, quite rightly again, the absolute inequality of Government support for unemployed people in country areas. Alderman Johns perceives, as many others perceive:

SPEECH.PARA: You can't help but feel the funding allocation has been politically motivated.

The social effects of unemployment, especially in country areas, are hurtful to individuals as well; and there should be no reason why only city people get the benefit of the Government's largess. Much of the money which the Government spends on these schemes comes from the wealth created in country areas, and it is unfortunate that the Government has not seen fit to send some of that back.

PARA.TAB: There is evidence coming in from right around Australia. My colleague Mr Philip Ruddock, the member for Dundas, has pointed out that the Ryde City Council received absolutely nothing from the Government's local capital works program, whilst councils in Mr Keating's electorate received, according to their figures—and I do not think they are right—some $20m in taxpayers' money.

Unemployment is hurting people just as much in Ryde as elsewhere in Australia. In fact, 2,422 people were registered for unemployment at the Ryde office in the month of July. It is amazing that that area gets nothing but, just across the way, Mr Keating's electorate gets a huge sum of money. Mr Ruddock has pointed out to me that there is gross discrimination on the Government's part against the northern districts. None of the councils there have been included in the scheme to create local jobs. The evidence is coming from all over Australia. Unfortunately, I have only enough time to mention a few—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an absolute disgrace.

—It is an absolute disgrace; Senator Knowles is quite right. Let me mention my area, the Cairns area. Cairns is a large and very progressive city. It is interesting to note that the Cairns City Council looks after part of Cairns and the Mulgrave Shire Council looks after another part of Cairns and surrounds Cairns. The huge unemployment problem in the Cairns city area—not in any particular shire—has been recognised by the Government, but it has been recognised in only one of those local authorities. Cairns city, quite rightly, and good for it, will receive nearly $1.7m for job creation projects and the local authority right next-door, where at least half of those unemployed people live, will receive—I could ask honourable senators to guess how much—absolutely zero, zilch, nothing.Can someone explain to me the fairness of that situation?

PARA.TAB: The Chairman of the Mulgrave Shire Council, Councillor Tom Pyne, is outraged over the issue, as well he should be. Of course, Councillor Pyne is not the normal Tory supporter. Councillor Pyne, great fellow that he is, is a well-recognised member of the Australian Labor Party. He is outraged that the Government should be so stupid and inequitable in the way it has distributed its money.

The Treasurer of Queensland, Keith De Lacy, who represents one of the Cairns seats, has bought into the deal too. He says quite meekly that he cannot understand why the Federal Government has done that. Maybe I could throw in a possible conclusion. A lot of the money goes to the State electorate that Mr De Lacy represents and he is under real threat of losing his seat to the Liberal candidate there, Mr Kel Ryan. So maybe the Federal Government was trying to prop him up. The other two seats which surround Cairns and which just happen to be in the Mulgrave Shire area are seats which Norm Millhouse and Scott Sturgess for the Liberal Party could well win from the present Labor incumbents. Maybe there is some interest in that. It is pure speculation and I do not want to indulge in it.

Suffice it to say, however, that the Mulgrave Shire Council is North Queensland's second largest local authority, it is one of the fastest growing areas in the State of Queensland, it shares that unemployment tally with its neighbouring municipality in the Cairns City Council, yet Cairns gets a large sum and Mulgrave Shire gets absolutely nothing. These distributions by the Government are simply unfair. The Government really does not know what it is doing. It is grabbing at any straw to try to save itself as a government and to try to save that one job—Mr Keating's job.

The Government does things on the run and in an ad hoc way, with no vision for the future, no long term plan, no proposals towards the end of the century which Australia really needs. It just grabs at what it sees as politically attractive schemes to try to overcome the recession that it created, with the two million people that it caused to be unemployed. The Government grabs at these things in an ad hoc fashion and then, because of that, it gets into trouble. We have been shown by example today that when governments do things on the run we get into all sorts of unfair situations.

Whilst local governments, when they receive the money, will spend it wisely—and I have every confidence in that—that is not really what Australia needs. People do not need these artificial jobs that are created and are only very short term. These projects all have to be finished by December 1993. So in 12 months they have got to be there; then they are finished. Whatever jobs are created will be gone again by December next year. What really needs to be done is for real jobs to be created. That is not done by throwing millions of taxpayers' money, which this Government does not have, at problems in politically sensitive areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayers don't have it.

—Senator Knowles is quite right, taxpayers do not have it—tick it up on the international Bankcard. Let the children and grandchildren pay for it later. But what is really needed is to give business a break. Get government off the backs of business. Get taxes off business so that they can expand. They can sell more produce and products overseas, and in doing that, create real jobs that last. That is what needs to be done. The Government had the opportunity to do that but could not bring itself to face the ACTU, or did not have the courage to do it.

PARA.TAB: What is needed is to get rid of payroll tax; to get rid of the petrol tax; to get rid of that stupid training guarantee levy; and to get rid of the stupid superannuation guarantee levy that is just putting more people out of work. They are the sorts of things that should have been done by this Government. But this Government does not have the vision; it does not have the gut courage; and it does not have the fortitude to do the things that need to be done. Fortunately, it is a government in its dying days and the people of Australia more and more can only wait for the opportunity to pour retribution on the people who have created this mess and given us the worst recession in 60 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support briefly the comments of my colleague Senator Macdonald. I particularly make reference to the situation which has occurred in Western Australia with regard to this capital grants program. The first point that I want to make in this regard is the discrimination that has occurred against country shires as far as this capital works program is concerned, and the formula that has been used.

PARA.TAB: As one works through the list of those shires that have not received any assistance from the capital works program, one finds that they predominantly, but not exclusively, come from country areas. There is a fundamental reason for this and that is that the Government, leading up to an election, has suddenly found that unemployment is a serious problem as far as its electoral prospects are concerned. Of course, in the country shires the recession has hit a lot earlier and a lot harder, and those people who fell into the unemployed category have long left. In fact, it goes back two or three years.

But also there are some enormous discrepancies in metropolitan Perth. This shows up very clearly when one starts examining the question: why is a formula devised which allows, for example, the Stirling City Council to receive what is effectively a grant of $7m, yet the neighbouring shire of Wanneroo receives nothing—and nobody can tell me that unemployment stops at local government boundaries? Go to the other side of Stirling to the shire of Bayswater and one finds that it also receives nothing. I wanted to make the point that when one starts doing the breakdown under the formula that is put forward, it is interesting to find where the majority of the money falls.

Certainly we find in the paper released from the office of the responsible Minister, Mr Simmons, that in such cases as Stirling there has been an enormous distortion of the figures. For example, Stirling has been counted in five electorates for the $7m, which is five times seven. It makes it appear that there is $35m and there was equity of treatment. But when one breaks it down and allocates, as best as can be estimated, the areas of the shires and where they fall, we find in Stirling, for example, which is held by Mr Edwards, something like the sum of $6.5m will be spent.

We then go to Fremantle. If we break it down once again on an area basis, we find that the sum is somewhere around $5.5m. We then go to Canning. Once again, breaking it down according to area—and I am sure that Senator Ray would be well aware that Fremantle is held by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, and that Canning is held by Mr Gear—we find that the figure is $4.5m. We then move across to Perth, which is currently held by Dr Charlesworth. Mr Stephen Smith is the candidate for the Labor Party, and we find that there is an allocation in the order of $4.5m.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a Keating staff member.

—That is right. As Senator Knowles quite correctly said, he is a Keating staff member and no doubt had some part in putting together this formula. We then go to Swan, which is currently held by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), or, as he is known in Western Australia, the Minister for Unemployment. We find that the allocation is in the order of $3.8m. We then go to Brand, which is held by Ms Fatin, and we find that the allocation is $3.5m. We then hit the first Liberal seat, that is, Forrest held by Mr Prosser; and that is some $1.2m less, at $2.3m or in that order.

PARA.TAB: If this is not a blatant political exercise in pouring money into Federal marginal seats in Western Australia, I do not know what it is, and it should be condemned as such. If the Government had any decency it would re-look at this particular formula and would take into account all shires that have this particular problem as far as unemployment is concerned and would get a formula which is much fairer. There is no justification for what has been done as far as this capital works program is concerned. I say good luck to those unemployed people who are going to get some assistance. It is long overdue. But I condemn the Government for the way that it has put this formula together and the unfair way in which the money has been allocated in Western Australia.

It comes through, as Senator Macdonald has said, consistently in a number of States. I wanted to add my comments to what has been said here today. The figures show quite clearly how political this exercise is, and how a Prime Minister is endeavouring to buy his seat back by stacking the money up in favour of Labor marginal seats in Western Australia. And I think it is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the lunch suspension, I will make some comments. When the Standing Orders Committee moved for the lunchtime procedure on Thursdays, it was meant to be for non-controversial contributions initially—the fact that it has evolved in other ways is just bad luck, I say for the record—and it was to replace first reading debates on money Bills. Now this Thursday procedure has allowed for speeches which have become more like adjournment speeches. I do not think anyone would want to change that because, if it gets people off the adjournment and onto Thursday lunchtime, that would be a remarkably good thing. But I just note for the record how it has changed over the years. I do not object to its changing, but it also may mean, seeing that I have lunchtime duty at this time, that I may respond to some of the points made where normally I would not seek to intervene.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald and Senator Crane have made baseless allegations today about the local government grants—not so much Senator Crane, who tried to grasp it. For the record, I want to state what the criterion is. Yes, certain local government areas have got more money than others, and that does not make anyone who does not get the money happy. But the criterion on which these grants were made was to help those specific areas that had unemployment 0.5 per cent above the national average. That was the criterion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying it is just coincidental it is all in Labor marginal seats?

—If the honourable senator is saying that was a factor, she is entitled to make an allegation that that criterion was adopted for that purpose. I have no idea; I doubt it; but that is a relevant allegation to make if the honourable senator wants to make it.
—It does look strange.

—Nevertheless, there is a formula that makes sense. One has to have some formula. The formula was, as I stated for the record, 0.5 per cent above the national average. When people say, `Look, you have given the money to this shire to help with unemployment and there is a neighbouring area of unemployment, right next door', it is just as likely that some people living in that municipality immediately next door will be those that get the jobs. Jobs are not restricted—
—What about the allocation to the shires?

—This is not an allocation to shires on the basis that every shire has an entitlement, as in some other local government schemes in which one would seek to distribute money pro rata or on some other basis. It does not fit into that type of scheme. Artificial divisions, where one council or one local government area gets funds and the one immediately next door does not, do not affect the employment prospect of the one next door. That is the point I am making.
—It just shows that Labor marginal seats have the worst unemployment.

—Senator Knowles would find, if she looked in the library and went back to the socioeconomic breakdown of electorates over the years, that some remarkable things were thrown up. In recessionary times, traditional Labor electorates have a higher rate of unemployment than others. From a look at the poverty line, however, the poverty index by electorate, the thing that really comes home as the more interesting point is how many National Party electorates are right up there at the top. That is something that surprised me when I first looked at it. Yes, there are relationships.
—It does not surprise me, because you are pushing all the farmers to the wall.

—Not necessarily. These figures go well back, to 1975-83, when Senator Knowles's Party was in Government. She has forgotten that; she does not recognise that era. In a Stalinist way, that has been blacked out of the history of the Liberal Party, but the figures have not changed dramatically one way or another since then. One should not blame this particular Government for those—
—The Prime Minister is still blaming us.

—The honourable senator's Party has a lot to be blamed for. I know how much honourable senators opposite want a 15-minute speech from me, but they know how little chance they have of that, even by baiting me. I would just restate for the record that a criterion for distributions was needed; it is a set criterion in terms of percentage of unemployment. As I pointed out and as Senator Macdonald does not agree, when Brisbane—where there are several Labor seats, some of which are marginal—gets $3m and the Gold Coast, which is substantially safe Liberal territory, gets $8m, I really do wonder about this brilliant formula. I am sure some of our members wonder about this brilliant formula, which shoves $8m into, essentially, two safe Liberal seats and spreads $3m across four or five Labor marginal seats.
—That is grossly unfair.
—I am sure I will draw Senator Crane's comment to the Minister's attention, in that the honourable senator does not support the $8m going to the Gold Coast but wants it all to go into Brisbane.
—I didn't say that.
—That was the implication of what the honourable senator said.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.38 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the comments of the recently deposed Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, in which he said of the Keating Government's forecasting credibility:

QUESTION.PARA: Now while I think in a sense you could say that optimism, those figures that were put out so glowingly in February could be politically understandable, the desire of a new leader to, as I say, inject a sense of optimism, I believe that as a result of those figures that were put out then the credibility problems of the Government now, at the time of the Budget, have been increased for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Mr Hawke, the former Prime Minister, deposed by the present Prime Minister, as we all know. Does the Minister agree with his former leader, that the Government's ludicrous forecasts in the One Nation statement have now left the Government with no credibility in respect of its forecasting? Furthermore, does he agree that they were presented to the Australian people for political reasons? How can the people of Australia believe that the forecasts contained in Tuesday's Budget are any less politically manipulated and unattainable?
—First of all, let me say about the forecasts—
—You should have retired a few months ago.

—Senator Macdonald should retire to the pub. A number of commentators have suggested that the growth forecasts in the Budget err on the side of conservatism. In respect of the unemployment forecast, for example, if it can be said to be an optimistic forecast, a glowing forecast, it is not open to that sort of criticism.

PARA.TAB: As far as the question of Senator Chapman is concerned, Bob Hawke was making a commentary, as he now does, in a speech in Western Australia yesterday, I think. The first thing I have to say is that he praised the Budget as being both responsible and relevant. In so far as the Budget forecasts relate to the One Nation scenarios, as we called them at that time—

TALK.START.PARA: —`As we called them at that time'!

—We did. The revision of the growth figure, for example—I have been asked questions about this in the Senate already this week—is simply based on the fact that there has been a change in the world environment since the One Nation forecast was made.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true, there has been. Those opposite would not know about that, I presume.
—You should have retired a couple of months ago.

—Senator Macdonald should retire to the pub; that is where he belongs. That is where he spends most of his time. The fact of the matter is, if one looks at the OECD forecasts during the intervening period, one sees a distinct change in the OECD forecasts about the world economy, and one sees a change in the OECD forecasts about the Australian economy. That has happened. It is a dynamic world in which we live and these changes take place.
—Not in Australia.

—Senator Macdonald says, `Not in Australia'. The OECD forecasts are more optimistic for Australia than they are for a number of other countries in the OECD. The Opposition should try to keep up with the world in respect of these changes which are taking place.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of Senator Button's reference to growth forecasts, I refer him to yesterday's statement by Treasurer Dawkins that his Budget is based on economic growth forecasts of 3 3/4per cent in 1993-94 and 4 per cent in each of the following two years. I ask the Minister whether these Budget forecasts of GDP growth are very similar to those contained in One Nation, namely, 4 1/2 per cent, 4 1/4 per cent and 3 3/4per cent for the same three years? If so, does this not mean that these Budget forecasts are subject to precisely the same criticisms as those correctly levelled by former Prime Minister Hawke at the One Nation forecasts?

—No, it does not mean that at all. These are Budget forecasts for the next three years. I have already explained to people whose heads really cannot perhaps comprehend it that there is a difference between the situation in February when One Nation was brought down and when this Budget was brought down in August. That is a substantial difference relating to the—
—The forecasts are almost the same.
—No, they are not the same.
—They are very similar.
—Senator Short says that a forecast of 3 per cent growth is the same as a forecast of 4 1/2 per cent growth. That is not true, I am sorry; it does not even add up.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's attitude to reports that the United States, the United Kingdom and France intend to declare a no-fly zone in southern Iraq? What are the chances of this leading to a confrontation and renewed fighting with Iraq?

—As honourable senators would have seen in the press, the UK has announced that it does intend to contribute military aircraft to patrol a no-fly zone in southern Iraq to protect the Shi'ite. Prime Minister Major has said the Security Council resolutions provide the legal authority for this action to be taken. It is expected that similar decisions will be taken shortly by both the United States and France.

PARA.TAB: As to the Australian reaction to this, as I said in the Senate on 18 August, a couple of days ago, the Government is greatly concerned that Iraq has persistently flouted the authority of the UN resolutions right across the board and in particular in relation to the Shi'ite. The special rapporteur appointed by the Commission on Human Rights to inquire into the human rights situation in Iraq briefed the Security Council last week. In a scathing critique of Iraqi repression of civilians, he confirmed that Iraq was flagrantly in breach of the human rights provisions of resolution 688, particularly as they affected the Shi'ite and the Kurds. Again, as I said in the press release on 16 August, the Australian Government calls on Iraq to end its repressive military action against the Shi'ite and to allow humanitarian aid to the wounded and displaced.

So, in light of that, against that background of concern and statements, we would support the UK proposal to patrol a no-fly zone in southern Iraq to protect the Shi'ite from attacks by Iraqi aircraft. We are awaiting final details, but we expect that the prohibition would prevent Iraqi aircraft from flying south of the thirty-second parallel. It would supplement, of course, another prohibition which has been in effect for more than a year on Iraqi aircraft flying north of the thirty-sixth parallel to protect the Kurds.

As to the likely effect of all this, we certainly hope that the declaration of a no-fly zone will not lead to renewed hostilities with Iraq. The no-fly zone in the north of the country has operated for more than a year without leading to military clashes. That gives some grounds for confidence in that respect, but it is really up to Saddam Hussein. Again, as I said a couple of days ago, Saddam Hussein would be very ill-advised to underestimate the determination of the international community in seeing him comply with UN resolutions in all respects, including his treatment of the civilian population.

We have not been asked to contribute militarily to this proposed operation, but approval has been given for three Australian Defence Force personnel serving with US and UK forces to deploy to the Middle East with their units if required—and I would expect that to be the extent of any involvement by Australia in this exercise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In particular, I refer the Minister to comments made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, on the Budget yesterday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Now by what has happened you've got the Government in a situation where it's going to have over its head this threat of further taxes.

Given this threat hanging over the Government of new and further taxes revealed in the Treasurer's Budget Speech and expanded in Budget Paper No. 1, when will the Government come clean with the Australian people and show a glimmer of honesty and tell them what these hidden taxes will actually be?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the phrase `hidden taxes' is an invention of the—
—There are lots of Max Walshes in this country.

—He did not have anything to say about this. This phrase is an invention of the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party. Of course, it is a normal scare tactic, which the Opposition is very good at. What we are talking about is the year 1995-96 in circumstances in which Budget parameters can change, as they change regularly every year. What we are talking about is the possibility of correcting a deficit forecast—a remote possibility if the deficit is not as planned in 1995-96. Of course, that is a matter which is ludicrous in the context of the current economic and political circumstances.

PARA.TAB: All that one can be certain about is that the Opposition will impose a $27 billion tax on the Australian people which will provide a burden on every household in this country buying clothing and other consumer goods, particularly food. That will be a burden on the poorer section of the community more than a burden on the wealthier section of the community, as taxes of that kind always are.
If the Opposition were allowed to be in government in this country, we can be confident that it would impose that burden on the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security advise the Senate about the proposals to increase the rate of age pension payments and how this could be achieved?
—I wish to advise Senator Reynolds and the Senate in general that the Government has in fact announced a modest real pension increase from next January.
—Extremely modest.
—In saying that I should indicate to Senator Alston that we find no difficulty in providing real increases for the 1.4 million age pensioners, unlike the coalition policy.
—But you have clawed it all back.

—According to Senator Alston—and he does lead with his chin sometimes—the coalition does find it difficult to increase the pension. I suppose it is appropriate that Senator Alston should intervene at this stage because it was only yesterday in the House of Representatives that the Minister for Social Security, in answering a question, repeated what Senator Alston was quoted as saying in the Australian Financial Review of 6 March this year. In that article, and of course in the Senate yesterday, Senator Alston said that it would be very difficult to increase the pension and he also said that people ought to realise that.

PARA.TAB: Despite that, and probably in the light of that, it is very educative to note that there is a clear distinction between those on this side when it comes to Australia's 1.4 million pensioners and the Opposition. Senator Alston was obviously regretting those words when he came into this chamber yesterday and tried to escape from the impact of them.

Despite the recession and despite the ageing population, we have increased age pensions by some 13.7 per cent over the life of this Government. We will continue to protect those most in need. In this Budget we will be increasing the pension in real terms by $2 per fortnight for single pensioners and $3.30 per fortnight for couples in January next year. We have not disguised the real level of the increase. Dr Blewett gave figures in the House of Representatives yesterday and acknowledged that it was a modest real increase.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Macdonald

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This question and the Minister's answer seem to be directly contrary to standing order 73(i), which indicates that questions shall not ask for a statement of government policy. Also, standing order 73(2) says:

PARA.TAB: Questions shall not anticipate discussion. . . which appears on the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.PARA: I wonder whether the Standing Orders mean anything at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not consider the Minister's reply to be out of order. It might be becoming long, but he is not being helped by constant interjections from the other side.

—As I was saying, we have not attempted to disguise the real level of our increase. We acknowledge that it is modest and we acknowledge that it is appropriate for the budgetary circumstances facing the Government.

PARA.TAB: As I said at the outset, we place high priority on protecting those in greatest need. We will continue to meet our commitment of maintaining the pension at above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. As I have also said, this has involved real increases in the past.

As opposed to this, we have seen the response from those opposite. They have no commitment to maintaining the pension at that 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The truth is that the one commitment they will make to social welfare is to reduce it by some $2 billion. Their only commitment to age pensioners is an 8 per cent increase in the age pension to compensate for their all pervasive 15 per cent consumption tax.

I can understand why they are squirming on the other side. This is not the first time that Senator Alston, for instance, has been caught out with respect to age pensioners. The previous time was on 18 June when he raised the question of euthanasia. Mr President, in closing, I table a letter to you from the Minister for Social Security detailing how Senator Alston was caught out on that occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get back into your phone box, you sleaze.
—I ask for a withdrawal of that comment from Senator Alston.
—Yes, I ignored it, but it is unparliamentary, Senator Alston, and I ask you to withdraw it.

—Mr President, I do withdraw it. However, I draw to your attention that this Minister has deliberately ignored all that was said by way of personal explanation yesterday and deliberately perpetrated a series of gross misrepresentations. I therefore explain the background of my withdrawal.
—Order! That is not a matter for me to determine.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. I refer to last week's findings of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, which confirmed longstanding evidence of the multi-million dollar illicit trade in confidential government information. I ask the Minister: does he agree that the ambit of existing privacy legislation needs to be extended to cover the private sector, including the purchasers of confidential information? Secondly, does he agree that it is urgent to introduce legislation making wrongful disclosure of confidential information a criminal offence with substantial penalties, both under the telecommunications power of the Commonwealth and under the Crimes Act, with corresponding mirror legislation by the States?

—I am aware of the report made by the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales concerning this very extensive trade, as it appears, in the trafficking of information—personal information, confidential information and information which persons have a right to expect will be held in very strict secrecy, apart from the purpose for which they supplied it to the government agency or, perhaps, to the private organisation concerned. The Australian Federal Police is, of course, following up those aspects of the report which might have to do with Commonwealth offences. As I understand it, the AFP has been assisting the Independent Commission during the course of its inquiries.

PARA.TAB: As to Senator Spindler's question about the ambit of existing legislation, it is important to note that the House of Representatives Committee under Mr Lavarch has taken on a series of terms of reference. He has indicated that this report will be a very important part of the Committee's deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —A real stunt.

—Senator Patterson says, `Do something'. In fact, this Parliament has done something. As Senator Patterson will know, in both the social security and health areas, legislation has passed through this chamber which provides for an offence equivalent to receiving stolen goods. In other words, a person who solicits another person to go out and obtain this information from, particularly, government agencies is himself guilty of an offence. That has been a particularly good and innovative part of those statutes, although it may well be that a more comprehensive statute could be put in place. I understand that we will get reports from Mr Lavarch's Committee in relation to that umbrella offence. It may be that Sir Harry Gibbs's committee also has some worthwhile things to say in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler also asked about making the wrongful disclosure of confidential information a criminal offence. Already in relation to government held information, it is a criminal offence to wrongfully disclose it under section 70 of the Crimes Act, and under specific statutes that wrongful disclosure is also dealt with. I guess Senator Spindler's question relates to whether in fact there might be a crime created for situations where private organisations holding information which it could be anticipated should be kept in a confidential manner disclose it without the permission of the person concerned, and Senator Spindler suggests the telecommunications power might be used in that regard. This can be taken into account by the Government; it will be taken into account.

However, it has to be said that in relation to the Privacy Act there already has been a significant extension to the private sector so far as credit reports are concerned. In regard to that particular important part of the confidential arrangements that people have when they enter into credit arrangements with financial institutions, there are very stringent safeguards to try to preserve the privacy of material held by credit reporting agencies. What has emerged from the report and from Senator Spindler's question is of great importance and I am sure that we will take this into account in further deliberations within the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: how long will it take for the Lavarch Committee to report and when does the Minister anticipate effective legislation being put into place, seeing that the findings of the New South Wales Commission have surely disclosed all the evidence that the Government needs for urgent action on this matter?

—I have already indicated that, so far as the disclosure of information held, for example, in Social Security or Health is concerned, not only are very considerable penalties provided for those who involve themselves in disclosing that information—or first obtaining it—but those who solicit the disclosure are also subject to penalties. That is an important step that has already been taken by the Parliament. I am not quite sure of the timetable of the Lavarch Committee, but I can assure Senator Spindler that when it does report the Government will give very timely and speedy consideration to its recommendations.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the details of the assistance package the Government has agreed on for the new wool processing plant to be built in Geelong by a subsidiary of the German company BWK? Can the Minister also explain what assistance is available to other companies planning to build further wool processing plants? In light of criticisms of the Government's support for BWK, can the Minister tell the Senate why the program under which the assistance is being provided was set up?

—If I might deal with the last part of the question first, the program has been set up through the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. We introduced legislation in 1987 for that Authority and amended it again in 1991. In that legislation we provided for assistance for firms adding value to raw materials in Australia. That legislation was supported on both occasions by the Opposition and it was under that program that this process was set up.

PARA.TAB: The reason this assistance has been offered to BWK is that throughout the world at the present time it is recognised in the textile industry that there is a shift going on from Europe to the Asia-Pacific region. A number of companies are considering new investments in further wool processing plants in this part of the world and there is a window of opportunity for Australia to win new investments in further processing of the woolclip. But we have to compete with other countries in this region to obtain those plants.

If one takes the BWK example referred to in the question, substantial offers of assistance were, I understand, made to it by other countries. It is because we are the largest producer of wool in the world and because we should be processing more of our wool—currently we process only 5 per cent of the woolclip, which is a disgraceful performance in international terms—that the Government saw the need for us to take advantage of this window of opportunity.

It has been quite clear from scattered statements by Opposition spokesmen and so on that the Opposition would let that window of opportunity close and let those plants go to other countries. The Government is not prepared to do that, consistent with our general view of industry policy, which we have developed over a number of years, in terms of assistance to industries like steel, which might have closed down under Opposition policies but which have been very successful under the Government's policies.

The new plant at Geelong is an $85m investment. The Federal Government will support that investment through a taxable grant of $5m and a loan of $15m. A number of claims have been made—particularly in the Geelong region, I notice—by Opposition spokesmen that the Government is discriminating in favour of this company and against other wool processors, particularly Australian ones. These claims are absolute nonsense. Any company planning to invest in such a plant can apply to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority in the same way as this company did. It is generally accepted that, to be economically viable, these plants have to produce at least 4,000 tonnes of wool per annum.

The program to which I referred earlier in my answer to this question gives the flexibility to provide support through a combination of loans and grants, unlike the grants-only part of the TCFDA program, which is supported under different incentives. Australia is the world's biggest wool producer, yet we process only 5 per cent of the total clip to top stage in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been in government for 10 years. Why haven't you done something about it?

—Yesterday somebody referred to a `low base' from which this Government started in developing industry. The low base was the coalition government—27 years of it. There were 27 years of low base, right throughout the 1970s, and one per cent growth in manufacturing a year—an extraordinarily bad performance. As a result of neglect over many years, the wool industry, which is one of the great industries of this country, slipped over a period of years into decline. The result of Australia's poor performance is that Australia misses out on export income. A tops making plant adds 35 per cent to the value of Australian wool. By 1996, this plant will increase the proportion of the clip processed here to 8 per cent, and investments in other companies, which I am confident will take place, will increase that proportion further.

PARA.TAB: BWK is committed to achieving a 49 per cent Australian ownership of the Geelong project within five years and hopes to attract investment in the project from wool growers, amongst others. This week's announcement is a sign that Australia can attract these new investments in further wool processing plants. I very much welcome Geelong, a once great wool centre for this country which declined in the 1960s and 1970s as a great wool centre, being restored to that role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 72, my question is addressed to Senator Short. It relates to his notice of motion No. 1013, in which Senator Short refers to the damaging blow-out in Government spending and expresses grave concern at the impact of the Government trying to meet its finance needs. Does Senator Short regard this as an urgent motion and, if so, does he intend bringing it forward for debate?

—I thank Senator Campbell for his excellent question. Yes, this is an urgent motion because of the implications of the massive financing problem arising from the Government's $8.6 billion increase in spending in the Budget. The Parliament and the public must be told the full story as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: The Senate must debate urgently that the underlying deficit to be financed this year is not $13.4 billion but $20.5 billion when adjustment is made for the creative accounting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order that a question be asked in relation to a notice of motion or an anticipated urgency motion?
—The question is in order. I am listening to see whether the Senator begins debating the notice of motion, but so far it is in order.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They like dishing it out, but they do not like taking it. The reason this is urgent is that that $20.5 billion deficit is going to have to be paid for in the end and paid for through increased taxes. What are the taxes the Government will be forced to impose? The coalition, in its Fightback program, has set out its full revenue and expenditure proposals and it is urgent that the Government do likewise. The matter is all the more urgent—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Twice in the last few sentences of Senator Short's answer he has referred to the

INTERJECT.PARA: reasons for his motion being an urgency motion. Is it in order for him to start debating the question of the urgency of his motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Short that it is not in order to debate the notice of motion, but I am sure there are ways he can get around it.

—I fully accept that and I am explaining why the matter is urgent. The matter has become even more urgent in the last 24 hours because the Treasurer has adamantly refused to present the Government's revenue forecasts for the next three years. We know the Government will be forced to impose significant tax increases. The Treasurer admitted in his Budget statement on Tuesday that there will be tax increases, but he refused to outline the details. The Treasury has said that a range of taxes will have to be increased. It specifically mentions withholding tax on interest, increased fringe benefits tax and the changes to the prescribed payments system.

PARA.TAB: I will be seeking the support of the Senate to debate the impact of these measures because the Keating Government's proposals on withholding tax alone will tax every person who receives interest on his or her savings—every pensioner, every retiree, every child starting savings, every business and every family. That measure could be a $2 billion tax on savings.
Australians need also to know what is behind the prescribed payments system changes. Is it yet another attack on contractors? The proposal for yet another increase in the fringe benefits tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a further point of order. Senator Short preceded this particular contribution by saying that these are the reasons he would seek the support of the Senate in relation to the motion he will bring on. That must be a debating technique.
—I think Senator Short is beginning to debate the motion and I would ask him to conclude as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I apologise for the length. But I am not being helped by the constant interjections from the other side. Let me say again: the matter is very urgent because, to raise the necessary amounts that the Government requires, the Government will have to broaden substantially fringe benefits tax. It will have to include tax exempt organisations, schools and hospitals and also it will have to raise the rate of fringe benefits tax and effectively tax jobs.

PARA.TAB: Another possibility is that it will have to tax the compulsory employer superannuation contributions, and that is a tax on retirement funds. They are just some of the hidden taxes buried in the back of the Budget that the Treasurer has admitted to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Short, I think you should conclude, given the amount of time that you have taken.

—I conclude, if I may, by saying that it is absolutely clear that the Senate must urgently debate these proposals. The Government has proposed tax cuts which it simply cannot deliver. Either Mr Keating will have to have a huge increase in the taxes that he has already admitted to or he will have to impose a goods and services tax, but without the offsetting $13 billion in personal income tax cuts or the other generous compensation provided in the coalition's Fightback proposal.
—Order! Senator Short, your answer has run for 6 1/2 minutes.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Under standing order 168, I request that Senator Short table the document from which he read every word of his answer.
—I call Senator Devereux.

—My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen media reports following yesterday's meeting of the ACTU Executive indicating that the Government's proposal for a wage increase targeted at low paid workers is now in doubt? Can he advise the Senate whether these reports are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I might say, Mr President, that it depends on which newspaper one read because I think only the Melbourne Herald, or the Herald-Sun as it calls itself, had a wages disaster type headline. Everyone else recognised the truth and, in their various ways, hailed this as a major and significant change.

PARA.TAB: Last week the Government put to the ACTU a proposal either to support a national wage case increase of 1.4 per cent, which is the inflation rate for the relevant period, or to change the wages system, support workplace bargaining and, as well, argue for a wages adjustment for low paid workers on minimum rates awards of $10 per week from 1 March 1993 and $10 a week from 1 March 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will the IRC say about that?

—That is a singularly misinformed or ignorant interjection on the basis that this was a proposition from the Government to the ACTU and the matter, if it is accepted, will then go to the IRC for determination. But at this stage it is only a matter for discussion.

PARA.TAB: The decision of the ACTU yesterday was a decision that took note of the social wage component of the Budget. It is important once again to reiterate that what the Government is concerned about and what the ACTU is concerned about through the accord is not simply the matter of wages. It is actually the matter of living standards. Living standards are determined by the level of wages, by the level of taxes and by the social wage—that is, the public goods supplied to households and the cost of supplying them. So the basic issue here is living standards.

The ACTU Executive gave the Budget a big tick. It approved the social wage component in the Budget and it recognised that the Budget focus is a focus for jobs and more jobs, and a focus to take care of those Australians who are not in a position to take care of themselves because of their low incomes, their health, their age or some other disability.

What the ACTU Executive said to us, by virtue of its decision yesterday, was that a new wage system will now be introduced into Australia. This will be a decentralised wage system—a system that will be built on enterprise or workplace bargaining—and the ACTU will put its shoulder to the wheel as a first priority in delivering that system. This is exactly in conformity with the second option that we put to the ACTU.

The ACTU has also said to its affiliates that if it is not appropriate or if it finds that employers, as is their right, do not choose to enter into a workplace bargain, they should file an application to amend their awards for the $10 and the $10, meaning that those applications can be brought on at an appropriate time for the Industrial Relations Commission to deal with them.

I take this response by the ACTU, which has also asked for some further discussions on this matter and wishes to talk the matter through further with its affiliates, as a very positive response, a good response and a response that should be hailed as that by all the commentators. We are now constructing a once-in-a-century shift in wage fixation—a movement from centralised to decentralised wage fixing in a managed way, smoothly, without a big bang and without following the course that the Opposition would choose to follow of increasing taxes, lowering wages and engaging in cultural cleansing by conducting an ideological campaign against the union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. The issue of debating the question has been raised on a number of occasions during Question Time today. It is very clear that Senator Cook is now attempting to debate the question and I ask you to bring him to order.
—I think Senator Cook has been in order so far.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was making the point—and I will make it again—that this is a smooth transition, a managed devolution of the wages system from a centralised system to a decentralised system. It can only occur smoothly and in this way with the cooperation of the social partners.
—What about the WWF in Tasmania and what they have done to us?
—You want to see what Ray Groom says.

—A climate of confrontation, a climate of tax increases through a consumption tax and a climate of trying to bid down wage rates is disruptive and confrontationist; it leads to social divisiveness and it does not create the circumstances in which this sort of transition can be arranged.
—You were approached and refused to do anything.
—That is a lie.
—I take the response of the ACTU as a very positive one, and I look forward to proceeding with further discussions with the ACTU in due course.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I am not sure whether you heard the interjection, but Senator Tate interjected that I was telling lies. I will make a personal explanation afterwards, but I ask him to withdraw.

—On the point of order, Mr President, if one interjection meets another interjection in this place, no-one knows who it is directed towards. You cannot take objection to that sort of thing, Senator Walters.
—Order! I did not hear the interjections from either side because there were too many interjections coming from either side. Have you finished the answer, Senator Cook?

—I conclude on this point. It is a pity that Senator Walters was interjecting. It is against Standing Orders. If one raises a point of order because one is conducting oneself against Standing Orders, that seems to me to be totally improper. It is a pity that she was not listening, because she would have learnt something about industrial relations which would be the first and probably the only thing she would ever know about it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to efforts made by Australian law enforcement agencies to locate the Gillespie children who were recently taken from Australia in breach of an order of the Family Court. Is it true that Coastwatch and the Australian Navy monitored a disabled boat off Australia's northern coastline a week or so after the Gillespie children were reported as missing? Why were Australia's Federal Police still informing the Government on 24 July that the Gillespie children were still in Australia when it now appears that they had left Australian shores by boat off northern Australia about a week earlier? Was there any communication between Coastwatch and Customs authorities and the Federal Police, who had the principal responsibility for the search? Will the Government release a full report on the search for the Gillespie children, including the nature and level of resources committed and the nature and extent of communications between the Australian Federal Police, Immigration, Customs and Coastwatch authorities?

—A series of questions was asked by Senator Hill in relation to this important matter. There was Coastwatch and Royal Australian Navy involvement in responding to Mayday calls which were picked up by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. That did take place. The AFP itself was not aware, during the course of the Coastwatch response to those Mayday calls, of the Coastwatch interest in a particular vessel. Coastwatch had not been tasked by the AFP or by Customs in relation to any particular vessel, because there was no identification or description of a vessel which would enable a task to be given to Coastwatch in relation to a particular search related to the abduction and disappearance of the Gillespie children.

PARA.TAB: There were other questions asked by Senator Hill. I was not able to note them all, but I can assure him that very considerable resources were allocated by the Australian Federal Police and the Customs Service for the search. From personal knowledge and from conversations I had with the Deputy Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police—and staff of my ministerial office have had many conversations with those holding operational responsibility within the Australian Federal Police—I understand that very considerable resources were dedicated to this search. Unfortunately, they were not effective in locating the fact that the Gillespie children, with the prince, escaped the Australian jurisdiction.

This happens from time to time. There are other such occasions and one occurred a few weeks ago with the abduction of a child in Bondi. In that case, the tremendous cooperation between the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service and the New South Wales police led to the speedy location and return of the child. In the Gillespie case the cooperation did not lead to the identification of the fact that the prince and the children were going to be spirited away as they were. How they were spirited away is still a matter of operational sensitivity. Investigations are still continuing and, whilst I offer Senator Hill or the relevant spokesman a briefing on these operational matters, I believe that it would be most unwise to elaborate further on the situation. I think I will eventually be able to satisfy Senator Hill that considerable resources were devoted to this very important search, but it still failed to prevent the removal of the children from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. What will be the cost of transferring resource assessment functions from the Bureau of Mineral Resources to the newly created Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Sciences? What will be the effect on the other programs of the former Bureau of Mineral Resources? What is the motive for reorganising the Bureau of Mineral Resources, and why was this motive and its hasty implementation program not shared with the geo-scientific profession or with BMR stakeholders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I was first asked what the cost would be. I do not have a briefing note on cost and, if I may, I would like to take that part of the three- or four-part question that I have been asked on notice and reply later. The Bureau of Mineral Resources has had a key role in providing advice to governments on resource matters, as well as being an advisory body carrying out strategic mapping aimed at providing the geological knowledge necessary to support the success of our mineral and petroleum exploration industries.

PARA.TAB: These are two discrete functions and, contrary to some media report, the resource assessment function is not primarily focused on servicing resource companies. Its main role is to provide the essential petroleum and minerals assessment input to advice to government.

Accordingly, this function is being transferred to the new Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Sciences, which is now to be called ABARS. The direct number of staff involved is about 55, with some additional clerical support staff, compared with the total current BMR complement of about 550. A physical transfer of these staff will most likely be required. The cost is currently being investigated. Although I will provide Senator Bell with details on this matter later, I am advised in this brief that it is not expected to be a major cost.

The strategic research and mapping function carried out by the remainder of the BMR will continue to be carried out by the Australian Geological Research Organisation, AGSO, while the review announced by Mr Griffiths and Mr Crean on 13 August runs its course. I can table the joint announcement by Ministers Crean and Griffiths about the new arrangements for the Bureau of Mineral Resources which may help an understanding of this.

It is correct that a considerable number—126 in total—of representations were made on this matter to the Prime Minister and relevant Ministers prior to the announcement of the review. Most were based on extremely ill-informed press speculation. Many letters sought consultation on any review of the BMR functions and administrative arrangements.

Since the Ministers made the announcement for the review there have been virtually no further letters. The indication is that industry accepts the bona fides of the Government in conducting the review, which of course will involve full consultation with industry. I understand Mr Lauchlan McIntosh, the executive director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, was reported as stating that he was pleased with the name change, which brought the body's identity into line with that of its overseas counterparts, and that the issues could be canvassed by way of inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and it follows the answer that the Minister gave to Senator Spindler. Is not the issue of new laws a red herring, because to disclose information is an offence already? So why is not the law as it relates to abuses within the Commonwealth bureaucracy being enforced?

—This Government takes very seriously the question of unauthorised disclosure of confidential information which is held by Federal Government agencies. Indeed, Senator Panizza is quite right to identify the fact that under the Crimes Act the disclosure of confidential information is an offence. The point is that in order to prosecute successfully one needs of course to gather evidence, to be aware, to detect the offence and to gather admissible evidence. When the AFP is able to do so, it does so.

PARA.TAB: I have already indicated in answer to Senator Spindler that the AFP was conscious of and worked in harmony with the Independent Commission Against Corruption on this particular inquiry. I have already had a report from the Commissioner of the Federal Police as to the steps that he is taking to follow up the matters which have emerged from the gathering of evidence using the very special powers of the Independent Commission Against Corruption—powers which are not available to an ordinary police force, by decision explicitly of this Parliament.

Nevertheless, with the benefit of those inquiries made by the Commissioner under the Independent Commission Against Corruption, the AFP is working on the material that came out of that Commission. I can assure the honourable senator that the question of relevant prosecutions will be followed up with the Director of Public Prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and it refers to the Budget and a family where the father is the sole income earner—a middle income for a skilled worker under many workplace agreements—where the wife is a full time home-maker and a voluntary community worker and where they have two student children. Is it not a fact that that family has suffered a real drop in disposable income of 13 per cent over the past seven years? Is it also a fact that last January this particular family, as a result of the changes to Austudy, lost another $20 a week? I have been searching in the Budget for something that would redress the situation for that family and have not been able to find it. Perhaps the Minister will be able to enlighten me.
—I cannot enlighten Senator Harradine on the specific example he gives, but I will certainly obtain an answer for him as soon as possible.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In early 1989 the then Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, sought government permission to buy—
—You are predictable.

—Senator West sounds like a canary; I wish she would just pipe down. The then Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, sought government permission to buy a third duty free car, a Mercedes Benz. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade knocked back his request, as is evidenced by the cable tabled in the Senate yesterday. But, before he received this reply and just one day after he sought permission, Mr Burke, in typical ALP mate style, went ahead and bought the car anyway—duty free, of course.

PARA.TAB: Given Mr Burke's actions and the fact that he was made aware of car purchase guidelines as early as August 1988, on what basis did the Minister tell the Senate on 28 April this year, `Mr Burke's actions in respect of motor vehicle purchases were in accordance with the same regulations and procedures as apply to all other heads of mission and that there was no ground for regarding this situation as any different'? I put to the Minister that it is vastly different.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave that response on 28 April because, to the extent that there had been demonstrated to be potential irregularities in Mr Burke's car purchases in Ireland during his tenure there, those irregularities had been corrected before he left office. Certainly there was no basis for any assumption that he had been treated differently.

PARA.TAB: So far as the question of the purchase and disposal of the car to which Senator Knowles is referring, might I say this. The sequence of events in relation to Mr Burke's car purchases is more than a little tangled, I frankly acknowledge. But, in order to untangle it, I have had a chronology prepared and a list of Mr Burke's purchases which explain, I hope now

ANSWER.PARA: clearly, exactly what occurred. I table that list and attached paper and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. To assist Senator Knowles, I pass across a couple of copies to her at the same time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: [DOCUMENT OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 352]

TALK.START.PARA: —What the situation thus described reveals, I think, in relevant part is as follows. In August 1988 Mr Burke purchased two duty free vehicles, a Toyota Corolla and a Toyota Starlet. The Department's records show that approval was sought on 6 January 1989 from the Irish Foreign Ministry to import duty free, as a third duty free vehicle, a Mercedes Benz 230E. That same document indicated that approval was given by the Irish authorities and the vehicle was registered, as Senator Knowles has said, on 11 January 1989.

PARA.TAB: On the same day, however—I presume later that day—Canberra declined approval, which was communicated to Mr Burke, for a third duty free vehicle on the grounds that Mr Burke's request, at least as then formulated, did not constitute exceptional circumstances.

The important thing is what happened the next day in response to that particular advice from Canberra. On 12 January 1989, Mr Burke wrote to the Irish revenue commissioners seeking, then and there, to pay all outstanding taxes and duties on the Toyota Starlet—one of the first duty free cars that he had purchased. That is not a matter that has been in the public domain hitherto, but it does explain, I think, a great deal about what subsequently happened. The Toyota Starlet, in respect of which he had thus sought to pay outstanding taxes and duties, was then written off in an accident on 16 February, after this application was lodged and before—

TALK.START.PARA: —An Irish joke.
—It was not Irish lightning. It was written off on 16 February, after this application was lodged and before it was acted on by the Irish authorities.

PARA.TAB: The writing-off of the vehicle overtook Mr Burke's application to pay all outstanding taxes and duties, but what happened was that those outstanding taxes and duties were paid out of the insurance pay-out. It is not true to say, as the West Australian newspaper did and as Senator Knowles has leapt to the conclusion, that the crash was the only thing which regularised Mr Burke's situation. Rather, his letter of 12 January 1989 effectively regularised that situation.

To anticipate Senator Knowles's inevitable request for the release of that and other relevant documents related to the Toyota Starlet, I am happy to put those documents now on the public record. The documents relating to that particular car were, in fact, not produced in response to the FOI request. The decision maker in my Department—without any reference to me, as is appropriate in these things—took the view that as that particular car had, in effect, become privatised, or been the subject of a duty payment, it was not, therefore, properly the subject of the FOI request because it did not relate to anything, any more than the purchase of a toilet roll did, done by him in the pursuit of any privilege attached to his office.

It may be that that was an excessively stringent reading of the privacy guidelines that apply to this, given the history of that particular vehicle. For those reasons—and with Mr Burke's permission, because of the privacy implications of this—I now put that document on the public record.

In the light of this matter being raised again, as it has been over the last few days, I have asked my Department to go back very carefully over the whole file in this matter to satisfy itself, and to satisfy me, once again, that all aspects of Mr Burke's vehicle purchases were, in fact, completely regularised by the time he left his post. Because of the obvious deficiencies in that administrative circular and in some of the procedures associated with the way in which—

TALK.START.PARA: —What were the deficiencies in the circular?

—Obviously, the terms of that circular do not direct themselves with any enormous degree of clarity to, for example, the question of whether the limit on the number of vehicles that can be purchased during a posting is a total limit to the number of transactions, or whether it is a limit to the number of vehicles that can be held at any one time, just to take one example.

PARA.TAB: Because of some uncertainties as to what these circular provisions actually do say, and in my belief that they can certainly be improved in their communication and clarity, I have asked the Department to review the content of that circular and its accompanying procedures to ensure that there is absolute clarity in the rules governing these transactions in the future. I table those documents accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 August Senator Kernot asked me a question about amendments to the wholesale sales tax exemption for certain paper products made wholly from recycled fibre. I sought to obtain an answer from the Treasurer about certain aspects of her question and I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised by the Treasurer that:

`It is common for wholesale sales tax (WST) changes to take effect from the day after legislation is introduced. A recent example was the cut in WST on `sub-luxury' passenger motor vehicles announced in the One Nation statement.

This is because destabilising commercial `speculation' can be triggered by advance statements of intentions to change WST arrangements: for example, there could be a disruptive surge of imports of products which are to become taxed at a higher rate.
The Government made the decision after weighing up all the issues and the pros and cons for business and workers and the environmental objectives—it was not made lightly.
While some companies who rely on the subsidy provided by the tax exemption say they will be hard hit by the amendment, other companies say they would be hard hit by the retention of the exemption.

The Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia has advised the Government that up to 400 jobs may be lost if the Bill does not go through. Unions also support the narrowing of the exemption.
Given these concerns the Government naturally wanted the measure to come into effect as soon as possible so decided to make the date of effect the day after introduction of the legislation.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the answer to my question?

—Senator Kemp asked me about forward estimates in respect of revenue and outlays in the Budget. Governments in this country have never published forward estimates of revenues, and the forward estimates in respect of outlays, of course, are in the Budget Papers.
—One Nation published them.

—I am talking about Budgets. The statements relating to revenues and outlays in the One Nation statement were described as scenarios at the time. They were not described as forecasts of forward estimates.
—`Rubbery figures' is what you actually mean.

—Senator Short should know better than that. He made a speech earlier today when he was trying to answer a silly question and referred to forward estimates of revenues, as if that was something which had ever been done in this country; it has not.
—It was in the One Nation statement.

—No, I am talking about Budgets. The situation is that there has never been a publication of forward estimates of revenues. As a result of measures introduced by this Government, this country leads the world in respect of the publication of the forward estimates of outlays.

—At this stage I want to answer a question that I was asked earlier in the week by Senator Walters. Following a statement I made in the Senate on Tuesday, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Knowles and Senator Walters commented or asked questions on the security procedures at the Senate entrance.

PARA.TAB: For the information of honourable senators, I advise that visitors to the Senate are required to walk through a metal detector and subject their baggage to X-ray examination before entering Parliament House. Except during periods of increased threat, photographic pass holders are not required to pass through the metal detectors or to submit their baggage to an X-ray screening. I am advised that visitors accompanying senators are not always required to submit their baggage to X-ray screening.

These security procedures do not vary between sitting and non-sitting periods. However, the current review of security will address the adequacy of screening procedures applying at all entrances to Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask whether you can give us any reason why pass holders are not screened. The impression of a number of senators when the screening process was set up was that they would be screened. Could you give some explanation as to why it is that pass holders generally are unscreened?

—Senator Walters, in reply to your question, I cannot give an answer at this stage. However, I can assure you that the questions you have raised, including the one you have raised now, as I have said, are being looked at in the current review of security.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of Question Time today Senator Bolkus gave an answer which bordered on gibberish. I did not particularly want to respond to it, other than to respond to a letter which he tabled at the end of his answer. Therefore, I seek leave to table a reply to that letter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today during Question Time I interjected when Senator Cook was speaking and asked him what he was going to do about the outrageous actions of the Waterside Workers Federation in Tasmania, which resulted in Hobart losing a $105m joint fishing venture with the Russians and the dry dock, as well as the $20m repair and maintenance facilities.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate responded. I said by way of interjection, `You were approached and did nothing about it', to which he responded, `That was a lie'. Senator Tate and Mr Kerr were approached to do something about it. All I can say to Senator Tate is that he did not do anything about it because, at the moment, the Waterside Workers, who had made an agreement that there would be three waterside workers to man each hold in the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. While this may have begun as a personal explanation, Senator Walters is now clearly canvassing and debating another issue. I think you should call her to order.
—It is a personal explanation, Senator Walters. I really do not think that you should turn it into a debate.

—Mr President, how am I to say that Senator Tate was wrong in saying that I told lies? I do not understand how I can put forward a personal explanation unless I can prove that what I said was correct and that Senator Tate was wrong in saying that it was a lie.
—Has Senator Walters finished?
—I will allow Senator Walters to continue, but there is a fine line between personal explanations and going into a debate and I would ask her not to turn it into a debate.

—I do not intend to debate it. I just want to explain why I believe Senator Tate was wrong in saying that it was a lie. Senator Tate acknowledged that he was approached about it. As to the dispute in Tasmania, the Waterside Workers had made an agreement that they would have three men per hatch. When Mr John Coombs, who is taking over from Tas Bull, came down to Tasmania and stopped the—
