—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I take the same point of order that I took earlier, that Senator Walters is not now making personal explanation; she is debating a separate matter and every senator in this chamber knows it.
—Senator Walters, I ask you to conclude the personal explanation as soon as possible.
—For heaven's sake, I am trying. Mr Coombs came down and altered that decision and made it eight members of the WWF, and of course that scuppered the venture.
—Nothing to do with me.
—Senator Tate just said, `Nothing to do with me'. That is exactly what he said when he was approached—`Nothing to do with me'.
—Another lie.

—I do not care what Senator Tate says or what he calls me. The point is that what the Waterside Workers have done is scupper that venture and Senator Tate did nothing to stop it. He may well say that he made approaches, but he did not do a thing, as I said, to stop the Waterside Workers scuppering that scheme for Tasmania.
—Mr President, I take the point of order that I put before, and another point of order that Senator Walters is clearly flouting your ruling, Mr President.
—I hope that Senator Walters has now finished her personal explanation.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My office was phoned by the Marine Board of Hobart to say that it had a technical problem on the waterfront. I immediately asked the executive director of the Marine Board and the managing director of the fishing company concerned to come to my office with Mr Kerr. We had a long discussion. Senator Walters claims that I did nothing; I am answering her. We had a long discussion.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that I went down personally to the Waterside Workers office on the Hobart wharves and talked with three officials there and tried to come to some understanding. I then spoke to the Marine Board and the managing director of Trident Seafoods about those discussions. I had discussions with the secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council. I had a discussion with the assistant secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation nationally. I involved myself as much as I could in the interests of the Port of Hobart and of employment in Tasmania to resolve this matter. The fact that I was unsuccessful does not mean that I did nothing. That was Senator Walters's accusation and that is what I reject entirely.

It is interesting—although I am perhaps trespassing a little—to note that Mr Phil Ryan, the endorsed Liberal candidate for Denison, said that Tasmania had lost the development because of the intransigence of the Waterside Workers Federation and the inaction of the Premier, Mr Ray Groom, who for two weeks had not answered correspondence from the company seeking his intervention. I did intervene, I did my best, and I am very sad that I was unsuccessful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a very short personal explanation and it will only be a few words—
—Order! You will have to seek leave.
—I seek leave.
—Is leave granted?
—If the Senator seeks leave from this Senate to explain in a personal explanation why, for example, someone has—
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Would you mind explaining to me on what basis Mr Aulich is—
—I am speaking on a point of order.
—What point of order?
—`Senator Aulich' to you.
—Order! Yes, I would like correct titles to be used. Senator Aulich, you are taking a point of order. Do not involve yourself in the debate.

—Mr President, in no way have I involved myself in the debate. I am saying simply that if Senator Walters wishes to seek leave to make a personal explanation in this chamber she should at least give us the reasons why she seeks leave and then this chamber can make its decision about that. For her to get up and to ask for leave without giving us any indication of why she intends to seek that leave is plainly out of order. She has already—as you know, Mr President—had her opportunity in the Senate to explain herself.
—Order! The position that I am placed in is that Senator Walters is seeking leave.
—To do what?
—That is not up to me to determine. Is leave granted?
—Senator Walters has been given leave to make a personal explanation. She will not be given leave—on the grounds of stretching the friendship beyond repair—if she seeks to make a statement at large.
—Is leave granted?
—I ask for two minutes.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Tate referred to a paper this morning in which Mr Ryan said that the Premier of Tasmania had been accused of not answering correspondence. The project was halted on 27 July. The first letter to the Premier was on 10 August. The second letter was on 13 August. As a result, there was absolutely no possibility of the Premier—
—Mr President, a point of order—
—Order! I do not really see how this is a point of order.
—Is this a personal explanation, Mr President?
—No, I do not really think it is.
—Well, ask her to sit down.
—Order! I can do without the advice I am getting from both sides. I call Senator Bishop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take further note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop on 19 August 1992, relating to an investigation of allegations of sexual harassment by a staff member of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I am moving this motion and adding information to what was dealt with yesterday is that I have been informed that certain other things have occurred that I think are relevant to the Senate's consideration of this matter. I would add that I gave Senator Evans notice that I intended to do this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't give me notice of any substance you were going to raise.

—Of course I did not give Senator Evans notice of the substance. He will hear it now. The nature of the substance of the matter is this: subsequent to raising the matter yesterday, I am told that the husband of the woman who has claimed has himself laid a formal claim against action taken by him as a result of his reaction to the sexual harassment that his wife complained of. I am informed that the husband was recalled to Australia and returned to Australia without any reasons for that return being given to him until such time as he was in Australia.
—Nonsense.

—I am further told, and I would welcome the Minister's comments on this, that prior to his being shipped back to Australia a conversation took place between Mr Butler, the diplomat concerned, and Mr Forrester, the Deputy Secretary, who Senator Evans told us yesterday was in fact the man who has been placed in charge of the investigation, conciliation, counselling—use what term you will—that is investigating the claim of the wife of the man who was sent back to Australia. Yesterday, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a long and complex background to the people involved in this case. There was a question of disciplinary action arising in relation to the husband of the woman concerned. That is a matter in issue.

He also referred to matters which Mr Forrester had in his mind through this conciliation process. My concern is that the Minister cannot say that justice is seen to be done if the man who has been given the responsibility of investigating the claim of the woman concerned was in fact in conversation with the man against whom the complaint is made—that is, the diplomat concerned—about returning her husband to Australia.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Evans said yesterday that this matter concerned `questions of fundamental privacy and fundamental decency'. I also put to the Minister that the matter concerns a question of fundamental justice. If justice is to be done, it must be seen to be done. If Mr Forrester in fact had been in conversation with Mr Butler, I do not see how he can be the man in charge of the operation. I would welcome the Minister's comments on the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop has shown by her contribution all the dangers that attend a rush into the public domain based on one-sided, manifestly incomplete and, on this occasion, significantly inaccurate information. Let me explain why I make those particular points. It is the case that the Department is currently investigating a grievance lodged by a departmental officer, who does happen to be the spouse of the person who has made an allegation about sexual harassment in the embassy in Bangkok, concerning the termination of that officer's posting in Bangkok in February this year.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I ought to just say this before I go into one more point of detail: the grievance was lodged under procedures provided for under the Public Service Act, regulation 83. It is being handled entirely consistently with those regulations. Those regulations require in the first instance that an officer be appointed to investigate the grievance and report to the Secretary. The Secretary appointed a senior officer of my Department—in this instance the divisional head for the Americas and Europe, Mr Greg Wood. He is yet to complete his investigations and to report.

It would be, with one exception, inappropriate for me to disclose any further information relating to this particular grievance procedure because to do so would be an invasion of the person's privacy and could jeopardise the conduct of the grievance. The exception I will make is in reference to Senator Bishop's claim that no reasons were given for the person's termination until his return to Australia.

I am advised very explicitly by the officer concerned who directed the Bangkok officer to return, Mr Forrester, that three quite clear reasons were given to the Bangkok officer as to why his termination was to occur. Those reasons were put to him in the context of that Bangkok officer having four days in the first instance—he sought an extra day, making it five altogether—to reply and in effect give reasons why that termination should not proceed on the particular grounds that were identified to him. I do not go into the substance of those grounds. I do not seek to evaluate those grounds. That is a matter, obviously, for the grievance procedure.

I do not propose to go into any more detail. I do not think anyone should. I just make the point that on that one particular matter which Senator Bishop chose to put into the public domain, to make an allegation about—and do not give me a wind-up signal—

TALK.START.PARA: —The last one is the most important point.

—I will come to the other matter. In relation to what Senator Bishop put in the public domain, she simply got it wrong, as I am advised. That shows all the peril and all the danger of embarking on this sort of crusade.

PARA.TAB: As to the identity of the officer who was involved in that termination process at the Canberra end, it was Mr Forrester. Mr Forrester did talk to Mr Butler, certainly. Mr Forrester also communicated directly with the Bangkok officer concerned and the officer in Bangkok, the husband of this woman, was in no doubt whatsoever that Mr Forrester was the officer concerned making the decision about his future.

Nor was the wife, in the context of her sexual harassment complaint, in any doubt about the identity of Mr Forrester as the person handling, in the first instance, that complaint; nor was she in any doubt about Mr Forrester's role in relation to her husband. That was something that was open to her at any stage to express concern about and to go down any one of the other routes that were available to her for resolving this matter if she thought, for whatever reason, including the identity of the officer engaged in this conciliation process, she was not going to get a fair go. That remains the case. None of those options has been excluded.

I just want to take this opportunity to put further on the record my understanding of the advice that has been given to me about the precise procedures that have been followed. None of this is inconsistent with anything I said yesterday or the day before but it just adds another point or two to it.

I want to say this: since the complaint was first brought to the attention of my Department—I am talking now about the sexual harassment complaint—it has been handled, on all the advice available to me, and I endorse this conclusion, in strict accordance with the Public Service Commission's guidelines. One of the most important principles that the Department sought to observe contained in those guidelines is that of confidentiality in order to protect the privacy of both parties. Might I, in that respect, refer, as I should have yesterday, to page 44 of the guidelines on eliminating sexual harassment, which state:

SPEECH.PARA: Privacy principles require that internal disclosure should be limited strictly to those staff who need to have access for official purposes, e.g. those investigating a complaint or taking follow-up action.
Those strictures obviously apply with even more rigour to someone seeking to put this into the public domain.

PARA.TAB: In following the guidelines, my Department has done the following things: it has ensured that the complainant was fully aware of all the options available to her from the time she first reported the matter to a departmental workplace harassment contact officer. I have spelt out previously—I do not repeat them—what those options were. The Department has provided the complainant with copies of the Public Service Commission's guidelines on eliminating sexual harassment and the departmental policy statement on workplace harassment, the relevant part of which I tabled yesterday.

The Department sought advice on several occasions in fact—this is the question I left not specifically answered yesterday because I was not clear what the answer was—from the Merit Protection and Review Agency, as is required by those guidelines, to confirm the correctness of the process being followed. Again, my Department maintained regular contact with the complainant in order to provide further opportunities for her to discuss any concerns that she might have. This contact included meetings between the complainant, her spouse and two female members of the Department's workplace harassment group. Two additional meetings were attended also by Mr Forrester. Mr Forrester and one of the workplace harassment contact officers maintained contact with the person against whom the complaint was made, as one would expect.

As to my own role in this, let me say just once more and, again, in slightly more detail, that I am aware that ambassadors are appointed by the Executive Council on my recommendation. This does require me to satisfy myself in this particular case, where the person against whom the complaint has been made is an unattached officer of the Public Service, that these matters are being handled in accordance with the Public Service Commission's guidelines. Mr Forrester has reported to me twice now in writing. There has been some supplementary oral reporting in the last couple of days. It is for those reasons that Mr Forrester has reported to me on progress and he will continue to do so while he remains involved.

It would, however—and this is the key point—be quite inappropriate for me to intrude further into the actual handling of this matter. I am sure that point would be understood by anyone who has any sensitivity or understanding about the way in which these delicate personnel matters should be handled. I hope that that is a sufficiently complete answer to put this matter in the public domain to rest once and for all unless, of course, the complainant should herself choose to raise it in some other public forum.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am afraid that the explanation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) raises more questions than it answers. First of all, I think it is important to know why this matter is on the public record. It certainly was not me who put it there. This matter came on to the public record as a result of a Sydney Morning Herald article on 29 July, written by John Lyons, the Herald's correspondent in New York.

PARA.TAB: On that occasion he reported the full allegation made by the woman concerned, right down to the details of dimmed lights, soft music—the full bit. The article includes comments by Mr Butler. He chose to give them. He explained why he liked soft music and low lights, and why he might be a fertile field for speculation. He then chose, after two more articles—one in the Age and one in the Australian—to have an interview with AM. In that interview with AM he chose to speak about it again.

The matter has become particularly contentious because on each occasion that the Minister has answered a question I have asked, he has given one answer and then come back to the chamber and changed it. Just as he did in answer to Senator Knowles's questions on Brian Burke and just as he did with the Marshall Islands affair, he has given one answer and had to change it each time he has come back into the chamber. The one thing he has done today which is very rewarding is that he has admitted that he is responsible in this matter because Mr Butler was appointed by the Executive Council on the Minister's personal recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I know that Senator Bishop is particularly interested in this, but the sorts of matters that she is dealing with are the sorts of matters that will be before the tribunals or the conciliation processes—
—No!

—Senator Bishop says no. We do not know how far this will be taken, but certainly the process which the complainant has taken so far is according to a particular statutory formula. The whole of the Standing Orders go towards protecting people's rights. If we want to speak, we can, but it is not appropriate, in terms of what is fair to people's rights, that these sorts of things should be pre-judged and canvassed in this chamber. It may bring pressure to bear on the conciliation process, the mediation process or, later, the decision making process. I simply ask people to remember that this is not the appropriate chamber to deal with this matter. It has been dealt with in an appropriate way in the sense that the appropriate way is set out in the statute. I simply beg, rather than anything else, people to remember that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I remind Senator Cooney that I cannot uphold the point of order because the sub judice rule does not apply here. Any action that may be occurring before a semi-judicial authority—as people describe that authority—is not of any relevance here. It is a question of whether one considers it is appropriate to debate the issue or not, and the answer is that Standing Orders do not preclude such a debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I quickly reiterate that I am dealing with matters that are on the public record. They have been placed on the public record by people who are involved in the matter, other than myself. However, I think it is important to look at the chronology of this matter. What we are really debating in this chamber is whether the Minister has acted properly in the conduct of this matter. That is what is really at stake here.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. We are not debating this issue; we are actually engaging in a character assassination of an individual. The whole of the Senate is being linked to this reprehensible activity. In all decency, I make the plea with Senator Cooney to Senator Hill, as Leader of the Opposition, to stop it, and stop it now.
—I doubt whether that was a point of order, but I will nevertheless seek to argue it by saying—
—Senator Hill, please make your remarks on a point of order.

—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President. We have a responsibility to ensure that the Minister properly administers his Department. I will tell the Senate how the matter arose. What disturbed me in the first instance was that there were reports that a woman had made a claim of sexual harassment against a very senior bureaucrat. I immediately saw a situation of strength against weakness—I say this with respect to some honourable senators—in the power struggle within the bureaucracy. I read a response in the newspaper that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was seeking to conciliate the matter. That seemed to me—and we have since had explanations as to the statutory background for it—to be a pretty unusual response. I am putting it in a historical perspective because I have been asked to intervene. That response from the Department struck me as being pretty strange.
—It is an indication of your own state of mind.

—I will get to you. This was because of this position of unequal strength in the process. I thought that the Department would establish an inquiry to see whether the case had been made out and, if so, to take certain actions that would follow therefrom. That is why the question was asked in the first instance, as I understand it, by Senator Bishop the other day.

PARA.TAB: Then information came to light to suggest that in fact the woman's husband—who also turned out to be a DFAT employee in Bangkok—was returned from Bangkok to Canberra by the Department, allegedly for incompetence or some other breach. That complicated the matter considerably, because here we have a negotiating process taking place within the Department whilst the husband of this woman apparently has some action hanging over his head. That concerns me. I immediately ask whether there can be a proper process within the Department as to whether this woman's claim had been made in circumstances where something was being held over her husband.

Since then, further evidence has come to light suggesting that the action being taken against the husband was really quite serious. Today, the matter has been further complicated by the fact that we find that the same bureaucrats are involved—and have been involved—in the process concerning the two parties at that early stage. I think that raises many questions as to whether the Department is handling this sensitive matter properly and whether the Minister is meeting his responsibility to ensure that the Department handles this matter properly. It is quite within our rights to ask questions relating to those matters, and if we did not do so we would be failing in our responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just having a good salacious wallow!

—Order! I return to the points of order. If honourable senators recall, there were two points of order raised, one the longest in the history of the Senate by Senator Hill, to which I think there is no need for any reply from me. The second was from Senator McKiernan. I ask that nobody else raises any points of order on the basis that he has raised his. Senator Cooney, I have already quite clearly indicated that there are no sub judice rules in the Senate. In fact, Senator Bishop is clearly in order to pursue this issue by virtue of the motion in which she is asking the Senate to take further note of the Minister's statement. I call Senator Bishop.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I was saying before we had those intervening points of order, what is important in this matter we are discussing is not the truth or otherwise of the allegation that has been made—that is for someone else to determine—but whether or not the Minister has handled this matter properly. My contention is that he has not.

PARA.TAB: It is important to look at the chronology. This event occurred in February 1992. Six weeks later the husband of the woman concerned, who is a Thai national and may not understand the nuances of Senator Evans's guidelines—and I will come back to those in a moment—was returned to Australia after a telephone conversation took place between Mr Butler, that is the person who is alleged to have perpetrated the harassment, and Mr Forrester. During the process of that conversation, I understand that a ground for his return was discussed.

Senator Evans says that the husband was given the grounds for his termination of that position in Thailand. My information is that he was not given the grounds for that termination prior to his leaving that were in fact subsequently cited as the grounds for his termination. Senator Evans has said that the husband was given grounds prior to his leaving Thailand. He has not told us whether the grounds that allegedly were told to this man prior to his leaving were the same as the ones that he was given when he returned to Australia and told that his position in Thailand was terminated. He could well have been told that he was being recalled to Australia for any number of reasons. I will be interested to see whether Senator Evans can check that point out so that we can have more information on it.

But the most important point—more important than that point—is the fact that the guidelines that are established by the Public Service Commission, which are indeed the husbanding of the original ones of the Public Service Board, are merely guidelines. They do not have the force of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another bit of scuttlebutt; the grounds are the same. You just invent things and hope that the denial won't be reported. You are a shamelessly indecent piece of work. You are just telling a lie!

—They are guidelines. Indeed, the guidelines set out that the supervisor of the person concerned is to be the person appointed. Would somebody mind removing that glass so that it does not end up across this side of the chamber. You're getting a little irascible, Senator Evans.

—Order! Senator Bishop, this debate has the potential to be a trifle fiery. It does deal in fact with some very sensitive issues. For that reason, I advise you to do as all honourable senators normally do, that is, to address your remarks through the Chair. Then Senator Evans, the Minister, would in no way want to interject or have reason to interject as a result of that. So I call you again.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I heard the remarks of Senator Evans and I was absolutely disgusted by them.
—Oh!
—Oh dear!
—It is wonderful how the Labor women really show their colours on these issues. Don't you two show your colours!

—Order! Senator Kemp, take your seat, please. Again I have cause to indicate to another senator that it is better to address remarks through the Chair. Again, you were directly addressing senators on the other side. There will be interjections, this debate will get out of hand and you will probably complain. If you have a point of order to raise, please raise it so that Senator Bishop can use the rest of her valuable time in this debate. Do you have a point of order to raise?

—Yes, I do. I had rather hoped that in view of the comments that you were making to Senator Bishop, you would ask Senator Evans to withdraw the remarks that he had just made to Senator Bishop, which I thought were absolutely appalling. I ask you to ask him to withdraw them.
—Which remarks are you referring to?
—He said she's telling lies.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order, I have noticed that when Senator Evans loses his temper, he tends to use words that he otherwise might not choose to use. But the next thing that I am told occurs is that he throws things. Indeed, yesterday when I was speaking—
—Senator, take your seat—
—On a point of order—

—Both take your seats, please. If you wish to raise a point of order on a particular issue, then please indicate to me what that issue is, what the problem is and what the word is. If I deem it to be unparliamentary, I will ask Senator Evans to withdraw it. One at a time, can you indicate to me what is the matter to which you object?
—Senator Evans said, regarding Senator Bishop, that she was an indecent shameless piece of work, and then called her a liar. I ask you to ask him to withdraw those comments.
—I am sorry, I did not hear that, and that is not my recollection of anything that Senator Evans said. But if Senator Evans did say that then he will obviously withdraw, but I did not hear that.

—I cannot tell a lie, Mr Acting Deputy President. I did utter words to that effect. I did so on the ground that Senator Bishop introduced a new canard into the debate to the effect that there were different grounds given after the event to those given before the event. I am advised the grounds were exactly the same. Five minutes ago you said he was given no grounds at all. You were told that there were grounds given, so then you make another allegation that the grounds were different after the event. You make things up as you go along.
—I do not!
—That is shameless where I come from, but if it is unparliamentary to say it is shamelessly indecent, I withdraw accordingly.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, he was merely asked to withdraw.
—Senator Evans has withdrawn. Senator Bishop, do you wish to continue the debate?
—Thank you, I do. I just want to make the point, if I may—
—Calmly!
—Thank you for your calm voice, and calmness is part of my style, if you do not mind, as distinct from the gentleman across the table. So if I could put it—
—There is not a big market for your sort of style.
—Order!
—If I could put a point through you, Mr Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, I do not want to draw attention to the fact that you have repeatedly ignored my requests for order.

—Thank you. The part of the intervention that Senator Evans just made that I cannot accept is the part where he said he cannot tell a lie. He used the word `canard'. He is one of the bigger canard tellers in this place.

PARA.TAB: If I may go back to the substance of the matter and add that the reason that I asked for the glass of water to be removed was the fact that when Senator Evans starts to use passionate, irreverent and rather unpleasant language, it is usually followed by his throwing something, I am informed, by people who have, shall we say, the unfortunate habit of having to work with him. Indeed, yesterday when I mentioned that he made a habit of throwing ashtrays, telephones, glasses and scissors, I had a phone call in my office to say, `Keep it up. And by the way, you can add staplers to the list'. The water is back—we will watch it!
Going back to the substance of this matter, I said the most important issue is that Mr Forrester, who had the discussion with Mr Butler—a mate of Senator Evans and the most senior diplomat we have—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's another little fib, Bronwyn; he is not the most important.

—Perhaps the second most important then. What are you—the most important? This was a most important diplomat, personally appointed by the Executive Council on the recommendation of the Minister—the man against whom the complaint was made—had a conversation with a departmental officer who has been placed in charge of oversighting the inquiry. That is the most concerning point that I have raised today.
—It is not an inquiry.
—Of course there is an inquiry. You also told us yesterday—
—It is not an inquiry, you goose! I have told you that 50 times before.
—Oh dear, move the glass again; Senator Evans is losing his temper again.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! We have heard of canards, but `a goose' is not parliamentary. Would the Minister withdraw the word?

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the word, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—The Minister obviously thinks that this matter is hugely amusing. It obviously tickles his schoolboy sense of humour. He is not called `Biggles' for nothing. This is a very serious matter concerning someone who is in a master-servant relationship, as I said yesterday, where the woman is in a weak position, where the Minister is the first best mate of the man against whom the claim is made—and the Minister sits there and wants to use flippant language, insulting language, anything but deal with the substance of the matter. The Minister did the same with the Burke matter and the Marshall Islands affair, and he is doing the same with the Butler affair. It just will not do. All mates together: we have one rule for mates and another for everybody else.

PARA.TAB: I told the Minister yesterday that I was very concerned about this matter for the simple reason that I have raised in this chamber another issue concerning a woman who raised a complaint. It took three years for that matter to come to fruition and in the interim that woman suffered greatly. I do not want to see a repeat of that here.

We have here the potential for pressure to be placed on this woman and/or her husband to make them abandon the claim. If it is abandoned, it can be neatly swept under the carpet and there will be no findings, nothing known about the outcome and no criticism of the way the Minister has handled or has failed to handle it. To try to say that the Minister has dealt with it properly, when every day he has had to come back into the chamber and correct himself, when every day new information has had to be dragged out of him—and his only response has been to play not the issue but the woman and to use insulting, unpleasant language and think that that absolves him of any responsibility—quite frankly, I do not find acceptable and neither do people who listen in either, be they in the building or elsewhere.

This is a serious matter. It deals with the competency of the Minister. We have seen three examples—as I said, this is now the third example—of his incompetence. When the Burke trial starts, we may see more of the issues affecting this Minister. I understand that trial starts on 23 November, so there will be many things to hear. No doubt those opposite would like to have an election before it starts.

Then we come to the Marshall Islands affair. Just so we know of the Minister's degree of competence, again we had conversations with members of his departmental staff who knew information that was pertinent to matters he was dealing with in the Senate, and when he became appraised of it while this Senate was still sitting he did not bother to come back here and tell us. He tries to tell us that he did not know of any of this information because nobody told him. On this Butler matter, no doubt he would have had no knowledge of this either if it had not been raised in this chamber. Now it is on the public record, as I said.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have done your best to kick it along in a totally shameless fashion.

—Would somebody move the glass; the temper is going again. The reason I have raised these additional pieces of information is that, as the matter is aired further, more pieces of information come to light. What we have to ensure is that this woman gets a fair go, that her husband gets a fair go, and that they are not made the victims of this Minister's incompetence and are not made the victims of the sorts of attitudes that we hear by way of interjection from Senator West and Senator Evans.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I previously mentioned reprehensible behaviour. We have actually reached contemptible behaviour because what Senator Bishop has just said has virtually convicted a person who has been accused of some offence.
—No, she has not.
—Yes, she has. When you examine the record, she has virtually convicted, because she has protected the woman. Did she mention the person who has been accused? This is contemptible.

—Senator McKiernan, I take your point and I understand your feelings. The point of order you have raised is the third point of order that Government members have raised in relation to a supposed sub judice rule. I repeat once and for all: there is no sub judice rule; it is entirely up to the Senate itself to decide what is appropriate in terms of the discussion of any trial or pending semi-judicial authority. So I have to reject the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Just in case Senator McKiernan cannot understand, we are not discussing here the truth or otherwise of the allegation that has been made concerning either party. What we are discussing is the competence of the Minister and whether he has carried out his responsibilities as the Minister concerning this affair. We are not discussing a matter between two clerks who sit on the second left-hand side of a room in a large departmental building. We are discussing a matter that is affecting a person who was appointed on the recommendation of the Minister by the Executive Council, and a lowly stenographer. That is what we are discussing. We are discussing someone who is known to be a mate of a particular inner circle of the Minister's, and we are discussing someone who is in a lowly position and her husband who has also now made a complaint.

PARA.TAB: So let us get it straight: here in the Senate chamber today we are discussing whether or not the Minister has failed yet again, just as he did in the Burke affair and in the Marshall Islands affair and as he has done now in the Butler affair, and refused to properly investigate the matter. As I said, in his response to me earlier the one thing that he said that I took great delight in hearing was that he is responsible. So we look forward to the Minister departing from his previous record and coming to this Senate and giving it information in an orderly and proper way and not having to have it extracted painfully like a dentist pulling teeth.

The truth of this matter and the fact that there is a need for justice is the reason this matter has been brought to this point at this stage. There will be plenty of other opportunities for the matter to be investigated further until finally we make sure that the Minister is doing his duty; otherwise he should resign.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Kemp on 19 August 1992, relating to the provision of Budget estimates and forecasts.

SPEECH.PARA: The point at issue here is that Senator Button was responding to my question yesterday as to whether the Government would be prepared to table in the Senate the forward estimates of outlays and revenues, particularly revenues, through to the year 1995-96. He said he would find out whether that information could be tabled.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button said in the chamber today that it was the practice of the Government not to include such projections in the Budget Papers. In a technical sense, of course, Senator Button is right. However, in relation to the One Nation statement which was brought down by the Government this February, the Government did put down its forward estimates of revenues and outlays, and I suggest that it did this for a very good reason. The reason it did this was to attempt to argue that its tax cuts were affordable. On page 149 of the One Nation statement, we see the very table which I have asked the Government now to update and to present to the Senate so that we can see whether the tax cuts which were proposed in One Nation and which were, to a certain extent, confirmed in the Budget Speech of Mr Dawkins on Tuesday night are still affordable.

Mr Deputy President, you will be aware that this has become a matter of important public debate. We know that the Treasury has prepared these forward estimates of outlays and revenues and we know that the Government has a problem, because the Government itself has told us in the Budget Speech that there is a problem. It has signalled that it is possible that a number of taxes will have to be raised.

I suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, to the media and to the Australian people that it is vital that if we are going to properly evaluate this Budget and see what hidden time bombs this Budget has in store for us, we must know now, and the Government must tell us, what its forward projections of revenues are. In an attempt to justify the One Nation statement, the Government was quite happy to put forward such projections. It is not happy to put forward such projections now and I suggest that the very reason for this is that it would show a huge black hole in the Government's prospective budgets in the years ahead. I suggest that this can mean only one thing—further sharp rises in taxes as the Government itself has hinted at in the Budget Papers.

I am not asking something which is unreasonable, because the Opposition has outlined in the Fightback statement its year on year projections to show how the very substantial income tax cuts which we have proposed can be afforded. Therefore, as we go towards the next election, it is not unreasonable that, through the Government's great resources, Mr Tony Cole and Dr Preston—who spent such time going through the forward projections of the coalition's Fightback program—turn their minds, as I am sure they already have, towards encouraging the Government to publish these forward estimates so we can make a direct comparison and the Australian people can be better informed.

We understand, on our view and from other sources, that a huge black hole has emerged in the forward projections of the Government's Budgets in the next two or three years which will make it impossible to afford the income tax cuts it promised without further sharp rises in other forms of taxation.

It is important that we get these figures. Senator Button has refused to table the figures in the Senate today, but I urge the Senate, the media and the Australian public to put as much pressure as possible on the Government to come clean and show us how big this black hole is and what sorts of taxes will be imposed on the Australian community if by some mischance Mr Keating was elected Prime Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on radiological services in relation to medical benefits. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O Zakharov
Chairperson
Standing Committee on Community Affairs
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Zakharov
INQUIRY INTO RADIOLOGICAL SERVICES IN RELATION TO MEDICARE BENEFITS
I write in response to the Report of the Committee's Inquiry into Radiological Services in Relation to Medicare Benefits which was tabled at the end of April 1992.

The Government intends to conduct a further review of radiology services. At this stage, consultations have commenced with the medical profession and it is proposed to hold consultations with other organisations. The purpose of these consultations is to assist in planning the review. An opportunity will be provided for wider input from interested groups into the development of proposals. It is intended that the development of proposals will include necessary research and further consultation with interested groups before they are adopted.
A specific response to each of the Committee's recommendations follows.
Recommendation 1—Repeal of Regulations
The Government adopted Recommendation 1 of the Committee and action was taken to repeal the Health Insurance (1991-1992 Diagnostic Imaging Services Table) Regulations (Amendment) on 30 April 1992.
Recommendation 2—Further Research and Consultation

The Government has agreed to a further review of radiology services and informal discussions have taken place with the medical profession on future directions. Discussions are also planned with organisations that represent radiographers and medical centres. It is proposed that views obtained from them will be taken into account in developing proposals.
See response to Recommendation 3 for comments on research.
Recommendation 3—Further Research to include detailed surveys
The Government accepts the need for further research and this will be undertaken during the course of the review.
Recommendation 4—the Medicare Benefits Consultative Committee and the Department consult more widely
The Government supports the Committee's recommendation. The matter will be raised at the next general meeting of the Medicare Benefits Consultative Committee, planned for August 1992.
Overservicing

At paragraph 4.25 of its Report, the Committee requested that a separate report be prepared by the Department and the Health Insurance Commission concerning overservicing. A report will be made to the Committee by 1 November 1992.
Tabling
This response will be formally tabled on the next first available sitting day when Parliament resumes.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN HOWE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report on radiological services in relation to Medicare benefits was tabled by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on 28 April. It was an important report in many ways and led to the repeal of regulations which were due to commence a few days later.

PARA.TAB: The Government has accepted all of the Committee's recommendations and I would like to comment on the implication of this. In effect, the Government has acknowledged that the processes and time frame of the proposed reforms were totally inadequate. The original intention was to make quite substantial changes in the operation of radiological services, without having much idea of the impact of this.

It was the Committee's belief that such a procedure was impractical and could have substantial effects on the community. It was clear that a number of the organisations and involved groups had not been consulted adequately about the proposed changes and that even a number of radiologists believed that they had not been given sufficient information on the issues.

One consequence of this high-handed approach was the failure to recognise the important role played by rural general practitioners providing radiological services in remote areas, and the need for out-of-hours services in certain locations. Another consequence was the amount of opposition to the proposed restructure that surfaced during the Committee stages. This illustrated the wide-ranging and potentially devastating effect the restructure would have on many. It also points to the need for adequate consultations with groups likely to be affected by reforms in the area of health services in order for the provision of radiological services to meet the differing needs of the community. The Committee recommended that further consultations were essential and I was delighted to see that the Government has recognised the importance of consulting with those groups which will be affected by new regulations.

The Committee believed that it was essential for any changes that were to be made to be made as part of a comprehensive reform. There seems to be little logic in a piecemeal approach with a drastic cut to the income of some practitioners, an increase in the fees of other practitioners and little idea of either the short or long term effect of such changes on the availability and cost of services in the community.

It is difficult to understand why any change of this magnitude would have been undertaken in the atmosphere of misinformation, poor planning and general disorder which marked the process. It was evident from the number of submissions to the Committee—and in fact the number was 96—and from the public hearings that there was no rational structure to the reorganisation.

This piecemeal approach was also manifest in both the research undertaken during the planning of the restructure and the limited consultation that occurred during this phase. For a policy that was supposed to provide a cure to existing problems and to prevent any reduction in the quality of future radiological services, it was surprising how little evidence was marshalled to demonstrate the nature and causes of those alleged problems, and how little research was conducted to understand what sort of radiological services would be needed to meet the future community needs.

Answers to these complex questions depended on systematic research and consultation with a range of organisations. However, these issues were foreclosed by a narrow and simplistic approach adopted by those who prepared the restructure. Even the findings of the consultants employed to prepare the costing models of radiological practices—for instance, that cross-subsidisation was untenable—were ultimately eschewed in favour of arguments of only one of the groups involved in the provision of radiological services.

For these reasons I am pleased that the Government has endorsed the Committee's recommendations that further research be conducted into a wide range of issues relating to the provision of flexible and possibly more specialised radiological services, including after-hours services, and that those responsible for planning the reforms consult more widely on the matters which impact on patients, State government services, medical practitioners and the other professionals.

It also should be noted that the Government has recognised the Committee's concern that the issue of overservicing, as it relates to radiology, needs to be thoroughly researched and its causes understood before any changes are made to legislation already in place which is designed to address this issue. Suggestions were continually made that overservicing was rife, that it was a major problem and that the implementation of the new fee structure would put an end to this type of fraud. However, no evidence was put forward by the Department or the Health Insurance Commission to substantiate these allegations.

Naturally, the Committee was concerned at such charges and has requested the Department to provide a report on the matters to see whether there was any such relationship between overservicing and the growth and provision of certain types of services. The Committee believes that this process would be more sensible than developing further legislation, as there was no proof that the legislation already in place was ineffective.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Come in Cinderella—the Emergence of Adult and Community Education. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING—`COME IN CINDERELLA—THE EMERGENCE OF ADULT AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION'

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 1

The Committee recommends the immediate establishment of a high level Working Party to develop a national policy on adult and community education, drawing upon the findings of this Report, to be launched by mid-1992. The Committee suggests that the Working Party be convened jointly by the Australian Education Council (AEC) and the Conference of Ministers of Vocational Education, Employment and Training (MOVEET).
RESPONSE
The report will be referred to State Ministers for consideration of the report generally and this recommendation in particular.
Recommendation 2

The Committee recommends the immediate establishment by the Commonwealth of a formal Advisory Committee on Adult and Community Education to assist the Minister in Policy formulation and other matters related to the sector. This Advisory Committee should be of the type provided for in Section IV of the Employment, Education and Training Act, 1988, and its membership shall reflect the diversity of the sector. The Advisory Committee shall:

SPEECH.PARA: report to the Minister, via the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET), on the role of the Commonwealth in adult and community education, in particular concerning the priorities, strategies, targets and resources associated with the provision of adult and community education by both government and community-based agencies;
formulate a draft Commonwealth policy and contribute to the development of a national policy by the States, Territories and Commonwealth under the auspices of the AEC and MOVEET;
monitor the implementation of national policy and report to the Minister on the extent, efficiency and equity of its implementation;
provide advice regarding desirable changes to existing Commonwealth structures and policies which would facilitate the implementation of national policy; and
liaise with other councils of NBEET to encourage a coordinated, mutually supportive approach to the provision of adult and community education by the schools, TAFE and higher education sectors.
RESPONSE

PARA.TAB: The Chair of NBEET has been asked to advise on an appropriate structure within the Board to advise on adult and community education issues. The nature of initial references to NBEET on adult and community education policy will need to be determined in the light of discussions with the States identified in response to Recommendation 1.
Recommendation 3

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training designate an office within the Department to be responsible for the implementation of Commonwealth policy in adult and community education, and to ensure that adult and community education has a permanent presence within the Commonwealth bureaucracy. The office should have close links with related areas, notably those dealing with vocational education and training, with literacy and with migrant education.
RESPONSE
An office has been designated within the Department's Policy Secretariat to provide a focal point in the development of Commonwealth policy concerning adult and community education.
Recommendation 4
The Committee recommends that, in the development of a national policy for adult and community education, priority consideration be given to increased funding for the sector.
RESPONSE

The Government notes that the sector is currently largely self-funding, and would not support any major diversion of public funding to change the basis of funding for the sector. Nonetheless, it recognises that there are uncertainties associated with project-based funding and that provision for the sector varies between the States and Territories. While not supporting a major change in the funding arrangements the Government will therefore further examine the funding situation in the context of the development of a national policy. (See response to Recommendation 1).
Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that the Department of Employment, Education and Training modify its funding guidelines to provide for both vocational and non-vocational criteria in determining grant allocations for adult and community education.
RESPONSE

The Government recognises and endorses the important role played by the adult and community education sector in providing development opportunities and avenues into the educational process for people who have had limited educational opportunities in their youth. In the current situation of high unemployment, priority must be given to assisting people to gain employment as quickly as possible and guidelines for the delivery of labour market programs will therefore need to retain a principally vocational focus. The Government will give consideration to the extent to which guidelines for Commonwealth grants could be modified to accommodate personal development activities relevant to employment.
Recommendation 6

The Committee recommends that State and Commonwealth governments adopt funding practices which facilitate long-term planning in adult and community education by focusing on triennial funding rather than submission-based funding processes.
RESPONSE

As noted in response to Recommendation 4, the Government recognises that there are uncertainties associated with project-based funding, but would not support any major diversion of public funding to change the current self-funding basis for the sector. The Government therefore expects that specific purpose and labour market program funding will continue to be the predominant source of Commonwealth funding for the sector. In so far as its funding is concerned the Commonwealth therefore considers this recommendation impracticable. While predicability in funding can have its benefits there are also benefits in a flexible and client oriented approach to program management which, under current arrangements, is a feature of adult and community education providers. As noted above, the Government will further examine funding arrangements in the context of the development of a national policy.
Recommendation 7

The Committee recommends that whenever government agencies provide a grant to adult and community education providers for the delivery of a particular program that grant shall include, as a matter of course, a component specifically to provide for child care.
RESPONSE

This recommendation may run counter to the principle of needs-based subsidies for child care and would need careful consideration in its implementation. The issue will need to be examined on a program by program basis given the wide diversity of programs which are included in the ACE sector.
Recommendation 8
The Committee recommends the introduction of State Government funding support for Neighbourhood Houses Community Learning Centres in those States where it does not yet exist.
RESPONSE
This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider.
Recommendation 9

The Committee recommends that each State and Territory establish a formal consultative mechanism across human services departments at ministerial level or senior officer level to coordinate and monitor policy on adult and community education.
RESPONSE
This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider.
Recommendation 10

The Committee recommends the development by all States and Territories of a network of regional councils of adult and community education with the intention that as far as practicable decisions which have a direct bearing upon local providers—particularly those relating to the distribution of resources—be devolved to the regional level.
RESPONSE

This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider. However the Commonwealth acknowledges that the strength of this sector is drawn from its local community support and would wish to see this maintained and developed with a minimum of layers of co-ordination and control.
Recommendation 11

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth establish, with support from the States, a National Institute of Research, Innovation and Teaching in Adult and Community Education. The precise structure and functions of the Institute should be determined by the proposed Commonwealth Advisory Committee to the Minister, to reflect the close relationship between research and the practice of adult education. The adult education community should have significant control over the program and activities of the Institute.
RESPONSE

The Australian Research Council has been asked to advise on existing research activity and research needs in this area. The need for coordination of the research effort relating to the sector will be further considered in the light of action proposed in response to Recommendation 16.
Recommendation 12
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth undertake a comprehensive review of the funding and delivery of the basic education of adults. Such a review should consider, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: the extent of publicly-funded entitlements which adults can utilise to meet their basic education needs; such entitlements could range from tax concessions to vouchers.
the minimum level of education which all adults can expect to receive at public expense, that is, at no direct cost to themselves, or in the case of employees, to their employer.

PARA.TAB: RESPONSE

Responses to previous recommendations have reflected the Government's view that courses provided by the sector that are presently self-funding should remain so and that it would not support any major diversion of public funds to subsidise courses which are presently funded by student fees and other charges. Funding arrangements will be examined in the context of the development of a national policy.
Recommendation 13
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) extends its support for existing projects directed towards the establishment of national schemes for competency standards, recognition of prior learning, credit transfer and related matters; and
(b) specifically require that such projects take into account the needs of, and recognise the skills formation role of, the adult and community education sector.

PARA.TAB: RESPONSE

The Commonwealth is presently pursuing the measures identified in part (a) of the recommendation in association with the States. Moves to competency-based training and the development of supportive curriculum for courses should increase the scope for the ACE sector to provide accredited training. In this context, it should be noted that the sector is already involved in projects supported through the Australian Committee for Training Curriculum (ACTRAC).
Recommendation 14

The Committee recommends that the Department of Employment, Education and Training commission a report into ways in which a clearinghouse function could be effected in the adult and community education sector. The function should build upon existing networks within the sector to provide for the dissemination nationally of ideas and developments in curriculum, teaching methods and other matters of professional concern to adult educators, and might be a responsibility of the proposed Institute.
RESPONSE

The Government will give further consideration to the proposed clearinghouse function, preferably utilising an existing structure within the Sector. The Government has not made a commitment to a separate research institute.
Recommendation 15

The Committee recommends that, in the development of a national policy for adult and community education, consideration be given to the establishment of a professional development fund—along the lines of the Higher Education Staff Development Fund—whereby adult and community educators may receive financial support to enable the upgrading of their professional qualifications or for other training and development purposes.
RESPONSE

The Government acknowledges the importance of improving teaching and other professional skills in the sector. This is primarily a matter for employing authorities at the State or local level. The current development of trainer training materials in the vocational education area will assist teachers in the ACE sector.
Recommendation 16

The Committee recommends that, as a stimulus to research by practising educators, the Commonwealth provide over each of the next five years two Adult Education Research Scholarship Grants comparable to average weekly earnings.
RESPONSE

The Australian Research Council has been asked for advice on current research relevant to adult and community education and to give consideration to encouraging further work in this area. As outlined in the response to Recommendation 18 the Government has provided funding for the collection and analysis of data on adult and community education and its outcomes. It will consult with the Australian Association for Adult and Community Education about further research needs. Subject to current Budget considerations and the advice referred to above, there may be scope for the funding of scholarship assistance to support research projects.
Recommendation 17

The Committee recommends that the Higher Education Council of NBEET establish a standing committee within the Council to monitor and advise on the adult and community education role of the universities, particularly its links with formal award courses, and its contribution to the intellectual and cultural life of the community at large.
RESPONSE
The Chair of NBEET has been asked to address this recommendation when providing advice in response to Recommendation 2.
Recommendation 18

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth commission a national survey of participation in community-based adult education and its benefits, either as a discrete exercise or through the Australian National University's National Social Science Survey.
RESPONSE

The Government recognises the importance of collecting further data about participation in and outcomes from adult and community education programs. The Department of Employment, Education and Training is providing $75,000 over 3 years for this purpose.
Recommendation 19
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) commission a cost-benefit analysis of participation in a representative sample of adult and community education provision (eg. workplace basic education, rural community adult education, a group of neighbourhood houses); and
(b) within the context of the exercise, assist the providers involved to design and trial a method of documenting costs and benefits at a local level.

PARA.TAB: RESPONSE

The Commonwealth does not support the commissioning of a cost benefit analysis. From time to time, the Commonwealth will ensure that the programs it funds are evaluated to assess their effectiveness. In other areas the Government notes the large number of people attending and paying for the courses provided by the ACE sector, an indication that the private benefits of participating in such courses outweigh the costs of involvement considerably.
Recommendation 20

The Committee recommends that the Australian Education Council engage a consultant to advise on a mechanism for the collection of standardised national statistics on participation in adult and community education. This mechanism should avoid the imposition upon providers of burdensome record-keeping.
RESPONSE

The Committee on TAFE and Training Statistics—a Commonwealth/State body established by Vocational Employment, Education and Training Advisory Committee (VEETAC)—is an appropriate body to undertake this work. This matter will therefore be referred to VEETAC.
Recommendation 21
The Committee recommends that State and Territory governments establish policies which provide for:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the free use of school and TAFE buildings by bona fide non-profit community adult education organisations; and
(b) reasonable access by such groups to associated facilities such as libraries, computer rooms, etc.

PARA.TAB: RESPONSE
This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider.
Recommendation 22

The Committee recommends that State education authorities examine the possibility of the use of regional and rural school bus services by participants in bona fide adult and community education activities.
RESPONSE
This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider.
Recommendation 23
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth publish a comprehensive guide detailing the various government support schemes available to the private sector to enhance its training effort.
RESPONSE

This Recommendation would need to be considered when broader issues of Commonwealth/State relations are determined. The Programs book produced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training provides information on relevant Commonwealth programs.
Recommendation 24
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth support the development of a comprehensive information database of private training providers and courses.
RESPONSE
Information requirements on private training providers and courses is currently being considered by the Commonwealth and the States in the Committee on TAFE and Training Statistics of VEETAC.
Recommendation 25
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) acknowledge the demand upon the adult and community education sector to meet the needs of adults with disabilities, and its potential in this regard; and
(b) clarify departmental responsibilities for the education of adults with disabilities and direct resources accordingly.

PARA.TAB: RESPONSE

SPEECH.PARA: (a) The Commonwealth acknowledges the role and potential of the ACE sector in meeting some of the needs of adults with disabilities.

(b) The Disability Reform Package provides a new focus for the disabled to gain access to counselling and training in relation to vocational skills. Other services to the disabled are coordinated through the Departments of Health, Housing and Community Services and Social Security.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 26

The Committee recommends that State and Territory governments reflect in their policies and planning related to the aged the proven benefits of sustained educational activity into the so-called third age.
RESPONSE
This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider.
Recommendation 27
The Committee recommends that:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) universities give favourable consideration to requests from third age learning groups for access to lectures, library facilities and so on at a level consistent with equity and resource considerations; and
(b) local governments and regional offices of human services agencies assist third age learning groups through the provision of basic administrative support for their operations.

PARA.TAB: RESPONSE
This is a matter for the agencies concerned.
Recommendation 28

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth take appropriate steps to allow bona fide non-profit community adult education organisations to be granted Sales Tax Exemption status under item 63A of the first schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935.
RESPONSE

Advice received from the Commissioner of Taxation suggests that adult education organisations are not necessarily precluded from having sales tax exemption status. Exemption status may be granted where an organisation has a set curriculum in a recognised discipline, appropriately qualified teachers, a building or room set up as a school, and where certain standards of achievement lead to qualifications or promotion to higher grades of learning. This definition may exclude some legitimate adult and community education providers. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training will ask the Treasurer to examine the matter further.
Recommendation 29

The Committee recommends that the ACT Government review its policy concerning the charging of fees for adult basic education courses in TAFE, in the interests of social justice and a consistent approach to adult basic education across States and Territories.
RESPONSE
This is a matter for the ACT Government to consider.
Recommendation 30

The Committee recommends that State and Territory governments establish a grant-aid scheme for prisoners to meet the costs of fees and materials incurred during further education and training while in prison.
RESPONSE
This is a matter for the States/Territories to consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the Government's response to the Come in Cinderella report. Of course, all honourable senators would be aware by now that that was the first report written on adult and community education in this country since 1944. If it does nothing else, at least it sets out a history and picture of what has gone on since 1944 in adult education throughout this country. I understand that the report is now being used as a base document for a significant number of educational institutions around the country, simply because of the information that is provided.

PARA.TAB: As far as this Parliament is concerned, the interest is not necessarily in just the base information but also in our recommendations, of which there are a significant number. The Government has responded to them all; it has responded to some positively, put some on the back burner and specifically rejected others. If we are to make anything of the value of Senate committees in this country, we should follow the pattern established by a few other committees in the past and ensure that our reports are followed up by government; ensure that debate takes place with government on those issues where, for example, we disagree; and ensure that, where there is agreement, we assist government to fulfil the obligations that it is prepared to accept as a result of these recommendations.

I do not want to go into all the recommendations because a number of other members of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training wish to speak. However, I want to make a couple of in-principle points that relate not only to this report but to education as a whole.

Firstly, there is a tendency—and I note it in the Government's response—for a significant number of major movers and shakers in the education industry in this country to separate what they call vocational training from personal development. Personal development courses have been called other names, but basically such people have attempted to split the two as appropriate parts of the educational activity spectrum.

I make it quite plain today that the biggest mistake we can make as a country, which is now starting to be much more interested in training than we were about 10 years ago, is to accept that false dichotomy. There is no major split between vocational training and personal development teaching or education. If we placed certain attributes into the category of personal development, we would see that those attributes are an essential springboard to what is described as strict vocational training.

For example, a course which has been described as one which creates in the learner confidence, self-respect, personal development, a capacity to work with others and a capacity to solve issues as an individual or as part of a group, has already done a great deal to prepare a person for further training. Yet so many responses—it is, unfortunately, implicit in some of the Government's responses—to the big educational questions do make that distinction. They say, `Yes, there is strict vocational training, which is what we have to get people into, and then there is other personal development stuff'. Ballroom dancing, flower arranging and those types of activities are used as examples to indicate that personal development courses are less important than what they see as the very important strictly vocational courses.

The two are part of the same spectrum. People who walk into a Neighbourhood House and learn to be competent at a skill—learn to relate to other people around them, learn to problem-solve, feel more at home with themselves and their community and feel more self-confident—are on the way to becoming educated people. Without those basic attributes it is very difficult for someone to be a successful learner.

It is a bit like teaching children to ride a bike. The first thing to do is to get them to be slightly adventurous, physically competent and confident. If you walk alongside them and say, `The penalty for failure is this', `I don't think you can do it', or other such phrases, you inevitably inhibit their capacity to learn that skill. So when government bureaucrats in Canberra, for example, say we should be putting our money into vocational training rather than personal development courses, it is obvious that they are blind to the absolute connection between personal development and the successful learning of skills.

This report quite clearly shows that there is a continuum and that getting people back into education and training starts with courses which, in traditional terms, may not be described as educational with a capital `E', but for many people they are a first step back into the educational process.

It is very interesting to look at three of the major companies in Germany—Mercedes, Siemens and Bayer. Like most major German companies, they have a very well organised program for training their employees. The vast majority of their employees are being continuously trained throughout their working lives. Those companies regard the training of their employees as an essential responsibility of a major company.

It is very interesting that, when outlining their corporate goals, these German companies say quite clearly that the training of workers is not just about teaching them how to use a lathe better, handle electronic equipment better, or work on an assembly line better. They quite clearly push the line that workers ought to improve their own self-confidence and learn how to do things for their own sake—set goals for themselves and enjoy achieving those goals. They want their workers to do that because they know that a fully developed, rounded, confident worker is someone who can be trained in specific skills later.

Breakdowns were taken of German industry and figures were examined.One thing that came out quite clearly was that for every person who was doing a specific skill retraining course in those four major companies that I mentioned, there was another one doing some course related to personal development and recreation, with the company's full support. It did not matter whether it was bushwalking, abseiling, repairing motor cars or whatever. The aim was to get people to be competent in something that they chose and that was of interest to them. That was the first step. After that, if they wanted to, they could move into areas of specific skill training.

This is the message I want to leave today. It is very easy for bureaucrats in Canberra who have to spend money in the most appropriate and responsible way, in a time of scarce dollars, to plump for what they regard as skilled vocational training. At the same time it is very easy for those bureaucrats to neglect the essential springboard value that personal development courses have in getting people into the education spectrum.

I agree with those bureaucrats who, for example, say that if people are unskilled, they are likely to be unemployed and are likely to be unemployed more often than other people; that if people are unskilled, they will have less value to the gross domestic product and to themselves. That is true. There is no doubt that many unskilled jobs in this community and in a number of other OECD countries have gone by the board. They have simply been phased out. Therefore, the need constantly to re-skill people and to upgrade their skills is paramount and obvious to us.

The point I make, along with a number of people from this adult education area who came to our Committee, as distinct from a number of these bureaucrats—although we all see the same problem—is that you have to have a springboard into particular skilled training that starts by making people feel keen, confident and able to relate to their peer group. One of the key things is that most education never occurs in an atmosphere of loneliness and isolation. Learning occurs, generally speaking, in consultation and in cooperation with other people.
