I think that some bureaucrats have the notion that education of the future will involve a person sitting in front of a modem, probably surrounded by a wall, a la Port Arthur model prison chapel, tapping on a keyboard, putting in questions and getting responses and vice versa and ticking off the number of successes one gets to the questions asked. That is a very isolated operation. I have been into schools and I have seen this sort of thing happening. Young people put their headphones on, go into the booth and then spend an hour isolated with their thoughts, and in some cases the teachers are not working with them before or after or even during that process. All one has is an isolating experience, not an extending experience.

The answer in regard to young people learning French or adults learning French or German or Swahili or Chinese or Japanese is not to use isolating techniques of learning like that. It is to get people to work together, to get from a group that which you cannot get from a book or from a video.

The answer in future to upgrading the skills of our society will not necessarily be a technological one. If that were the case, many years ago we would have had every kid in this country strapped up to a modem with earphones on, punching away at a keyboard or doing things by using television. That has not happened, for the simple reason that human beings prefer to learn in a situation which is a mixture of individual activity, quiet study and group activity.

Everyone in this chamber knows that most of what they have learnt has been precisely as a result of that mixture of activities—what we do as a group and what we do individually as we read or watch videos or television. The Government must examine this response and it must examine other documents that come before it. We have to ask ourselves a basic question. Are we artificially creating a dichotomy between personal development and vocational training? If we are, we will end up funding and running programs which take into account only half of a person's learning potential.

It is easier to say, `We only fund what is strictly vocational and that personal development courses are to be paid for by the user'. If we make those distinctions, we isolate a significant number of people who ought to be coming back into the education area. I refer, for example, to people who had bad experiences at school and do not want to know any more about education. We have to get those people back again because they are the ones who, in a changing society, are usually most at risk in terms of their economic potential, their capacity to get jobs and to hold jobs and their capacity to deal with their own lives—literally running a household, bringing up children and relating to each other. Some people are more vulnerable than others and the ones who left school early are generally, according to virtually all the studies I have seen, the ones most likely to get into difficulties.

If we believe in fairness and equity and giving everybody a chance to fulfil their potential, we have to look at our education system becoming more relevant. If we do not, firstly, it will fail a significant number of people in our community and that is unfair; secondly, we will waste a lot of talent that ought to be available to our society; and thirdly, people will walk away from the education system. They will say, `I do not want to know about it'. In many cases these are people who would love to send their children to school and have those children reach the highest levels of attainment.

The middle classes will start to walk away from public or publicly funded education, and they have already begun to do so. One has only to look at the figures. I believe Tasmania has the lowest percentage of students in private schools compared with students in public schools. To some extent that is because the education there is better, or was better than in other States, because it has had more money spent on it.

To take the point further, no formal education system at the moment seems capable of educating all the people who come into it. There will be many people who do not realise their potential within the formal education system. They may be the very brightest ones who are simply bored, the bright ones who are not taken to their full potential; or they may be those with lesser abilities or those with some social handicap which makes it difficult for them to learn. Both of those groups miss out under the current formal education system.

The adult and community education area has and always will have a vital role to play. It picks up those people. It also picks up the people who have gone through the formal education system and who need to know more for their own personal benefit or for the increased capacity to get on in their jobs, to get new jobs, to change jobs.

I find it absolutely amazing, for example—and I will take a gamble here—that probably Senator Tate and Senator Cooney, in addition to me, cannot type. It seems amazing to me that I, a writer—someone who earned a living as a writer before I came into Parliament—could not type and had to pay typists to do my scripts. I still write novels by hand and have someone else type them up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good novels, too.
—Thank you. It seems amazing to me that Senator Cooney, whose previous career and current career is the use of the word, probably cannot type.
—That's true.
—Senator Tate tells me that he cannot type. Madam Acting Deputy President, can you type?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can; you would be rare. I ask whether Senator Baume can type.
—I am true to type.

—Senator Baume was a journalist; he had to type. There are a few, but on the whole the pattern for males of my age group and my educational level in Australia would be no typing skills at all. Probably the majority of us here cannot speak another language, yet we live in one of the most multicultural countries in the world. How many of us actually learn a second language later in life? In Australia there are 480,000 people who live in families where Italian is one of the major languages, either spoken as a first or a second language. Yet how many people in this chamber, let alone the community at large, have studied another language? One could count those in this chamber who have done so, I guess, on the fingers of one hand.
—Does hieroglyphics count?

—Hieroglyphics would count. So there are two of us who can speak another language, and my guess is that there is probably no-one else, from what I know. These are just some examples of life skills that are related to personal development skills that are lacking in this chamber amongst a very significant number of people. They would be very valuable skills for us to have.

PARA.TAB: How are we going to get those skills? Here comes the big advertisement: we are going to get them through adult and community education. If one thinks about us, one is talking about a fairly elite group. Imagine what it is like out there, when people really do need to get those skills, when people know that their future jobs or their chances of getting another job rely upon their having those sorts of skills—keyboard skills, for example. I know nothing about computers and my guess is that that would be the pattern for a significant number of people in this chamber who are males, over 40—

TALK.START.PARA: —And overweight.

—Overweight and overfed. Yes, that would be a fair picture of the majority of people in this place—without casting individual aspersions, of course. So the picture, then, is of a group of people in this place who lack many of the skills that would help them—and this is the key point that I am making—to do their jobs better, to be more effective.

PARA.TAB: If we translate what is lacking in this chamber to what is happening out there in the community at large, we can see that the improvement of particular skills by a wide section of people in the community can only benefit the country, let alone individuals. Our children, the ones who are 19, 20 and 21 years of age, on the whole have been a bit better trained than we have in terms of the overall skill pattern. But, nevertheless, at high school or, for that matter, at primary school or even at university, one cannot give students all the skills they are going to need throughout their lives. So adult and community education will always fulfil a major need in the community.

The big question is whether the Government can make the departments responsible for reacting to this report; whether the Government is prepared to force them to make a 100 per cent effort in moving these recommendations forward. They have all-party support. We spent a lot of time on them. They represented the attitudes and ideas of a very significant number of people throughout this country. They represent the hopes and aspirations of a lot of people who previously have been cut out of the education system, who will not have what they want given to them by universities or by the TAFE system, who are going to have to look at the adult and community education providers for the skills and the personal development that they need.

This is a pioneer activity because governments have traditionally shied away from funding or being involved in adult and community education. No government likes to pick up commitments which will cost it more and more each year. But if the clever country is going to be just that—a clever, comfortable, happy country—and if we are going to move towards those sorts of goals, then the development of adult and community education will be absolutely vital. It will not be done through TAFE, universities and high schools alone. There is an absolute requirement for this flexible sector of the education industry. It will require a rethink on the part of governments of all persuasions.

The benefit from this joint party Committee's unanimous recommendations is that, regardless of what party is in government here next year, there will be a group of people who will be able to pursue an agenda, and the agenda simply says: `No. 1 right through to No. 30'. Adult and community education is a vital part of the whole education industry—of the educational spectrum—and it has to be supported in a way that it has not been supported in the past. This Parliament has a responsibility to do something about that. If governments get laggardly over this issue; if they get conned by the bureaucrats, who will do as little as possible; if they get conned by hypotheses and theories, and ideas that are half-baked and that, for example, separate vocational from self-development courses; if they get conned by those sorts of notions, then it is the role of this chamber, in particular, to make sure that they are brought back to reality.

So there is a challenge here for the chamber—to make sure that we make our reports work and that governments not only have to respond in terms of the written word in a formal report like this, but that they actually carry out the propositions that we put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, Senator Aulich, and endorse his remarks to a great extent. As a member of the Committee which prepared this report, Come In Cinderella—the Emergence of Adult and Community Education, I retain a keen interest in what happens to the report, although I am now no longer a member of that Committee and I know that Senator Sowada has a much closer and more detailed knowledge of what is happening there now.

PARA.TAB: I wish to address a few remarks on the tabling of the Government's response to this report because I think it is important to do so. The timeliness of this response is to be acknowledged. By way of further endorsement of the Chairman's remarks, I can only say that I was fortunate to be a member of the recent parliamentary delegation to South America. On that trip, I was reminded of the very sorts of things that Senator Aulich, as Chairman of the Committee, has just been speaking about; that is, that there is, and should not be, a distinction between vocational education and the development of people's personal skills. It was self-evident, particularly in Brazil, where we were fortunate enough as a delegation to visit the office of the TNT transport company, an Australian company which had made an investment in Brazil. Part of that investment was for the company to meet the need of its work force in basic workplace education.

The fact that the education was necessary was not only an indictment of the education system of the country but also an acknowledgment of the personal skills that are required to work in any industry. One can imagine the chaos which would be caused in delivering parcels from one end of Brazil to the other if the literacy of the deliverers was in question. As well as that, one can imagine the further inability of workers to perform the most basic functions of a worker in the transport industry if there was little knowledge of geography and the clerical skills required to ensure that the right parcel, package or item was delivered to the correct consignee.

It was made apparent at the most basic level to those of us who visited the company that there was a need for adequate education and that, because this was not present in the country, the operating company had to provide for that need. In doing so, that company was then able to develop loyalty to the company based on what it had provided for its workers. Of course, the workers' appreciativeness was reflected in the fact that, unique or at least uncommon to the companies in San Paulo, this particular company had a loyal, longstanding and fairly static work force.

I use that example to endorse the Chairman's remarks. I can also bring to this government response my experience since the Come In Cinderella report was tabled in speaking to practitioners in the adult and community education field. I am pleased to report to the Senate that the Committee's report has been very well received, endorsed and discussed very widely amongst those practitioners with whom I have personal acquaintance. I will make certain that this response is dealt with in the same way, that it is widely discussed. I have no further comments to make. I realise that my link with this is now somewhat tenuous, but I just wanted to record my agreement with the Chairman's remarks.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tierney) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the review of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: CONTENTS

SPEECH.PARA: Background 3
Overview of the Government's Response4
Responses to recommendations:
(A)Management and Organisation5
(B)The ACIAR Research Program7
(C)Funding9
(D)Relations with Other Organisations10
(E)ACIAR in the Future11
(F)Extending ACIAR's Mandate13
(G)Public Awareness15
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REVIEW OF THE AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH CONDUCTED BY THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE, AUGUST 1992

PARA.EMPHASIS: BACKGROUND

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) was established as a statutory authority within the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Act 1982 (ACIAR Act 1982). That legislation provided for scrutiny and review by way of a sunset clause limiting the life of the organisation to 12 years (June 1994), subject to a review at the 10 year stage, ie. by June 1992.

Prior to arranging for the mandatory sunset review, on 18 October 1991 the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans, formally referred the matters of ACIAR's effectiveness against its charter and its statutory authority status to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for review and report. The Minister requested that the review be concluded prior to May 1992. In requesting that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade conduct the inquiry, the Minister hoped to expose the Centre's operations and performance to public scrutiny and also to help obtain a wider understanding of ACIAR's role.
To examine and report upon:
a.the effectiveness of ACIAR as an element of Australia's official development assistance program against its charter embodied in the ACIAR Act 1982;

b.the desirability or otherwise of the continued existence of the Centre as a Statutory Authority after the expiration of twelve years of operations (June 1994), the maximum length of existence specified in the current Act.
The JCFADT report was tabled in April this year.
This document addresses the individual recommendations of the Committee, according to the order and topic groupings in which they are listed in the Committee's report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: OVERVIEW OF THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE

SPEECH.PARA: The Government congratulates the Committee on its extremely thorough approach to the review. The Committee has made careful and considered recommendations on the matter of the continued existence of ACIAR and has made a number of valuable recommendations for improving ACIAR's efficiency and effectiveness in the future. Their implementation will lead to enhanced performance of ACIAR as an important element of the aid program.

The Government agrees with the fundamental recommendation that ACIAR continue as a statutory authority, located within the foreign affairs and trade portfolio, and that the sunset clause limiting the life of the Centre be removed. ACIAR performs an important function independently in the aid program in improving the well-being of people in developing countries and Australia through collaborative research partnerships aimed at the development of sustainable agricultural systems and the design of appropriate natural resource management strategies. ACIAR's projects mobilise Australian research expertise, thereby contributing to building research capacity both in Australia and developing countries.

The Government agrees that the Centre should continue to undergo external reviews at regular intervals, as required of all statutory authorities, but considers that such reviews should be conducted by appropriate persons selected at the time of review and with the objectives of the review in mind.

The Committee recommended that the role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities be investigated by the appropriate Parliamentary Committee. The Government notes this recommendation and suggests it would be appropriate for the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to draw the matter to the attention of the Presiding Officers of Parliament.

The Government agrees that ACIAR's functions and mandate should be expanded further to include responsibility for the administration and disbursement of funds to the International Agricultural Research Centres, the conduct of project-related training and administration of the relevant training scheme and funds, and the carrying out of modest project-related development activities where practicable.

The Committee made two recommendations concerning the Centre's governing bodies. The Government agrees with the Committee's recommendation that ACIAR's Policy Advisory Council be reduced in size, but considers it to be important that, in its advisory capacity, the Council have a substantial number of members from countries other than Australia. The Government also considers that ACIAR's Board should be a five-member board which need not necessarily have AIDAB representation.

The Committee made a number of valuable recommendations pertaining to the focus, administration and internal management of ACIAR's research program which the Government endorses in principle. In some cases the Government has advocated a broader approach and has commended the recommendations to the consideration of ACIAR's Board of Management and Policy Advisory Council for future policy directions.

The Committee made several recommendations concerning, or with implication for, funding within the aid program, namely an increase in ACIAR's budget to 3.5% of the aid budget by 1997, an increase in core funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres (IARCs) to 1.5 of ODA by 1997, and the creation of an establishment along the same lines as ACIAR with responsibility for research and development assistance in areas including manufacturing systems and human resource development. The Government considers that ACIAR's performance and the importance of the IARCs' programs warrant a reconsideration of their funding priority within the aid budget. Further consideration to a body similar to ACIAR to deal with non-agricultural sectors will be given.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSES TO RECOMMENDATIONS

SPEECH.PARA: (A)MANAGEMENT & ORGANISATION

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that section 8(1)(c) dealing with AIDAB representation on the ACIAR Board of Management be amended as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (c)the person for the time being occupying, or performing the duties of, the office in the Australian Public Service known as Director-General, Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, or his or her nominee; and

PARA.TAB: Government's Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that it is important for ACIAR to maintain close dialogue with AIDAB and considers that it would be imperative for the Director-General of AIDAB or his or her nominee, to be a member of the Policy Advisory Council. However, the Government does not accept the on-going need for AIDAB to be represented on the Centre's Board of Management, given ACIAR's evolution and performance as a statutory authority completely independent of AIDAB. The Government considers that ACIAR's Board of Management should be an executive body composed of 5 members, but not necessarily having AIDAB representation.
The Committee recommends that section 19 of the Act, dealing with membership of the Policy Advisory Council, be amended as follows:
19.(1)The Council shall consist of—

PARA.TAB: (a)a President;
(b)the Director;

SPEECH.PARA: (c)the person for the time being occupying, or performing the duties of, the office in the Australian Public Service known as Director-General, Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, or his or her nominee; and

PARA.TAB: (d)9 other members.
(a)the Minister shall ensure that half the number of Members of the Council are resident of countries other than Australia.
Government's Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the importance of ACIAR's Policy Advisory Council as an advisory body to the Minister which has played a fundamental role in the evolution of the Centre's programs. The Council is unique in its composition of distinguished partner country members and eminent Australians. The Government agrees that there is scope for reduction in membership of ACIAR's Policy Advisory Council but considers that the JCFADT's recommendation of an absolute size of 12 members could be too restrictive. A membership of 12 to 14 would provide greater flexibility.

While the JCFADT's recommendation that the number of partner country and Australian members be equal reflects the partnership concept well, the Minister may care to have a larger number of partner country representatives than Australians on the Council from time to time or vice versa.

The Government therefore does not accept the JCFADT's recommendation that the number of Australian and overseas country representatives need be equal on the Council. It would seem that maximum benefit could be derived from the Council as an effective and fundamental advisory body if it were composed of 12 to 14 members, a substantial number of whom would be drawn from ACIAR's partner countries.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 3:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee further recommends that the quorum requirement for a meeting of the Policy Advisory Council be reduced from 9 to 7 and that the President has a deliberative and casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The JCFADT's recommendation that the quorum requirement for a meeting of the Policy Advisory Council be reduced from 9 to 7 reflects the reduction in overall membership of the Council. The Government considers that the requirement of 7 members for a quorum will also accord with a flexible membership of the Council of 12 to 14 members. The Committee's recommendation that the President have a deliberative and casting vote, however, reflects the Committee's view that the Council comprise equal numbers of Australian and overseas country representatives. With a flexible number of Australian and overseas country members, the preferred option outlined above, the need for the President to exercise a deliberative and casting vote will not apply.
(B)THE ACIAR RESEARCH PROGRAM

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that ACIAR's primary focus remains South East Asia and the South Pacific. However, as funding permits, ACIAR should foster collaborative projects of mutual importance in other parts of the world, including Africa, the Middle East and South America. North Africa and the Middle East, in particular, should be a priority because of Australia's expertise in dryland farming.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that ACIAR has fulfilled well its mission of improving the well-being of people in developing countries through its programs, which have been focused in those countries of importance to Australia's aid program. The Government agrees with the JCFADT that the assistance ACIAR provides should continue to be in line with Australia's aid objectives and thus focus primarily on programs in Asia and the Pacific, notably South East Asia and the South Pacific. The Government sees no reason why ACIAR should not foster collaborative projects in Africa, the Middle East and South America, capitalising on Australian expertise relevant to these areas, but notes that the expansion of programs into these regions would be resource dependent. ACIAR will continue to maintain existing programs in Asia and the Pacific and will assess proposals for projects in Africa, the Middle East and South America in the context of availability of resources, research priorities, impact and potential benefits in both Australia and the countries concerned. The Policy Advisory Council will provide advice on this issue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that ACIAR, in conjunction with its commissioned organisations and partner institutions, continue to evaluate the length of stay of Australian scientists in-country on a project by project basis.

PARA.TAB: Government's Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with the need for ACIAR to continue to maintain flexibility of approach to research partnerships and project design and considers it important that the factors applied by ACIAR in project evaluation and implementation regularly be clarified and publicised to the stakeholders concerned. The matter of the extent and duration of involvement of project scientists in-country work is important to ensure maximum benefits are derived by partner countries from collaboration between their scientists and Australian scientists. It is recognised, however, that this will vary from country to country, institution to institution and project to project, having regard to the level of science and technicality in projects and the internal capacity of the partner country institutions. Thus ACIAR will continue to be sensitive to these factors and will need to evaluate the level of scientific interaction required on this basis.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that ACIAR be more flexible in determining project length, allowing projects to be approved on a case by case basis for periods of between 3 to 5 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges that there may be instances where ACIAR projects could achieve optimum results and impact if implemented over a 5 year period rather than the current 3 year project duration. ACIAR currently adopts a flexible approach whereby extensions to 3 year projects are implemented to continue research or focus on particular aspects of research arising from the initial 3 years. The Government agrees that ACIAR needs to retain this flexible approach but may also consider the option of 5 year projects as necessary, bearing in mind the constraints of forward commitments and planning in administrative and resource terms.

The Committee recommends that ACIAR, in conjunction with its commissioned Australian research institutions, develop a detailed set of guidelines governing the relationship between ACIAR and these bodies, detailing the relevant responsibilities of each position.

The Government agrees that there is benefit in defining the relationship between ACIAR and Australian commissioned organisations in clear guidelines. However, the relative responsibilities of each organisation in terms of the conduct of projects are already clearly spelled out in the formal Project Agreements entered into by ACIAR and commissioned organisations and it is difficult to see where these could be elaborated or improved. ACIAR will continue to evaluate and refine the terms of the Project Agreement, remedying deficiencies as this becomes required. The Government therefore does not accept the Committee's recommendation that there is a need to develop a further set of detailed guidelines at this stage.
(C)FUNDING

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the ACIAR Act be amended to permit:

TAB.TAB: (a)delegations by the Minister to an appropriate person within the Centre, particularly in relation to financial matters;
(b)funds provided on trust or subject to condition to be paid into the ACIAR Trust Fund; and
(c)financial reporting requirements to be satisfied by one set of financial statements only.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government fully agrees with the need for the ACIAR Act to be amended to remedy deficiencies relating to delegations, ACIAR's Trust Fund and financial reporting mechanisms. Approval has already been given by the Prime Minister for these technical amendments to the ACIAR Act to proceed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that ACIAR's priority within the aid budget be increased, and that by 1997 approximately 3.5 per cent of the aid budget should be allocated to ACIAR.
Government's Response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the JCFADT's recommendation that ACIAR's priority within the aid budget be increased. In the light of the Committee's favourable review of ACIAR and the positive recommendations concerning its future, together with the merit and cost-effectiveness of its program, it is clear that ACIAR's priority in the aid program will need to be reassessed, with a view to ACIAR's share of the aid program increasing, as budgetary circumstances allow.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 10:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the ACIAR Board of Management formalise and issue a policy on the matter of overheads and cost recovery for the information and guidance of Australian collaborative institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The JCFADT's recommendation that a policy on overheads be formalised and issued by the Centre occurs in the context of increasing demand by Australian research institutions to recover to a greater extent a proportion of their overhead costs. In this context ACIAR's Board of Management has determined a policy of considering overhead charges on a project by project basis, having regard to the policies and practices of commissioned organisations. The Government endorses this approach which responds to an evolving situation. ACIAR's Board of Management may need to reconsider its policy and reassess the current approach in response to the position eventually adopted by commissioned organisations, and re-issue an appropriate policy when required.
(D)RELATIONS WITH OTHER ORGANISATIONS

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres, together with the resources needed to administer these funds, be transferred from AIDAB to ACIAR.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government endorses the Committee's recommendation that funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres, (IARCs) be transferred, together with appropriate administrative resources, from AIDAB to ACIAR. The necessary administrative arrangements have already been put in place by AIDAB and ACIAR such that ACIAR has now assumed responsibility for the IARCs, although AIDAB at this stage retains the funds and responsibility for disbursement of these pending technical legislative amendments to ACIAR's Act. The amendments will enable ACIAR to disburse funds in its own right to the international organisations concerned and will complete the transfer of responsibility.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee further recommends that the funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres is to be additional to the increase in ACIAR core funding recommended earlier (Recommendation 9); and that the level of International Agricultural Research Centre core funding be increased to 1.5 per cent of total official development assistance over 5 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the recommendation that the level of core funding for the International Agricultural Research Centres be increased. The IARCs' programs are the key to devising sustainable food production systems globally and an increase in funding to the level indicated will send a strong signal to the donor community and developing countries that Australia has real concerns about sustainable food production and sound environmental management. The Government agrees with the JCFADT that an increase in funding to the IARCs is warranted, that any increase in funding to them should be additional to increases in ACIAR's core funding, and that the share of the aid program devoted to this activity should increase, as budgetary circumstances allow.
(E)ACIAR IN THE FUTURE

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that ACIAR continue as a statutory authority, located within the foreign affairs and trade portfolio, reporting to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with the continuation of ACIAR and fully endorses the JCFADT's recommendation that ACIAR continue to be a statutory authority, located within the foreign affairs and trade portfolio. ACIAR will continue to report to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the appropriate Parliamentary Committee inquire into the role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the Committee's view on the advantageous role played by the sunset clause in ACIAR's Act and the consequent recommendation that an appropriate parliamentary committee examine the role of sunset clauses uniformly as a review mechanism for the performance of statutory authorities. The Government suggests it would be appropriate for the JCFADT to draw the matter to the attention of the Presiding Officers of Parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the new Act to continue ACIAR include a fundamental review, every 5 years, of ACIAR's Terms of Reference including the continued existence of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with the need for regular review of ACIAR. In this regard, the provisions for review set out in Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises will apply. It is not considered necessary to have legislative provision for such review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the review of ACIAR be carried out by a Parliamentary Committee because this will assist in achieving greater public awareness of the value of ACIAR's work; and the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is the appropriate body to conduct such a review.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognises the value of the review of ACIAR undertaken by the JCFADT, particularly in terms of exposing ACIAR in an open and accountable way to a Joint Committee of the Parliament and in raising both public and parliamentary awareness of the important role ACIAR plays. This type of review the Government considers important and there may be merit in the JCFADT assessing ACIAR in line with its periodical assessments of the aid program. However, the Government would see the value of review of ACIAR by bodies other than the JCFADT from time to time.
(F)EXTENDING ACIAR'S MANDATE

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the ACIAR Act be revised to allow ACIAR to conduct project-related training (both informal and post-graduate); and that responsibility for the administration of ACIAR's training scheme together with the concomitant resources, should be transferred from AIDAB to ACIAR.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government concurs that ACIAR should have the flexibility to be able to conduct project-related training in its own right, and agrees that resources currently administered by AIDAB for ACIAR's training scheme be transferred from AIDAB to ACIAR.

The Committee recommends that AIDAB establish a Technical Advisory Committee with the task of monitoring ACIAR research projects to enable earlier identification of results that could be developed through the AIDAB program. The Technical Advisory Committee should be chaired by the Director, Country Programs, AIDAB and should include representatives from ACIAR as well as AIDAB.

The JCFADT recommends the creation of a Technical Advisory Committee within AIDAB to monitor ACIAR research projects and determine options for development. The recommendation is a valuable one which would appear to be intended to help to coordinate activities and cooperation between the two organisations. A less formal arrangement already exists between ACIAR and AIDAB for consultation on projects at a high level, involving the Director of ACIAR and a Deputy Director General, AIDAB. This arrangement appears to be working well, and there would seem to be little need at this stage to set up a more formal mechanism such as a Technical Advisory Committee, although this option will be borne in mind should it be warranted in the future.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that, when AIDAB has declined to conduct a follow up project utilising ACIAR research results, ACIAR should have the option of extending the post-project phase to include a small pilot program, with Board of Management approval.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with the JCFADT's recommendation that ACIAR have the flexibility to commission project-related development activities, subject to approval by the Board of Management of the Centre. However, while ACIAR will maintain an active dialogue with AIDAB on development activities and opportunities for mutual input, there may be occasions where it would be more appropriate for ACIAR to commission a development activity in its own right or to implement development work within a strict timeframe. For this reason the Government does not agree that it would be advantageous for ACIAR only to have the ability to conduct development work when AIDAB had declined to do so, but considers that there would be benefit in ACIAR's having the flexibility to commission development work relevant to projects on its own assessment. An independent mandate for development activities will help to place ACIAR in a responsible and catalytic role in assisting in the adoption of the results of the research it commissions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government examine the possibility of establishing an organisation along the same lines as ACIAR with the purpose of providing research and development assistance to regional countries in manufacturing systems, human resource development, etc.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with the JCFADT's recommendation that the establishment of an organisation along similar lines to ACIAR to provide R&D assistance in non-agricultural sectors to regional countries be examined. The Minister has asked for a report in due course from the portfolio on the proposal for this new initiative in the aid program.
(G)PUBLIC AWARENESS

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that ACIAR consult with AIDAB on ways to increase public awareness of the importance and achievements of ACIAR's work in solving major agricultural problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with the recommendation that there is a need to improve public awareness of ACIAR's achievements, particularly in terms of the mutual benefits of ACIAR's programs to both partner countries and Australia. ACIAR will consult with AIDAB and other bodies as appropriate on how best to publicise the achievements of the agricultural partnerships ACIAR supports.

—In accordance with the provisions of section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, I present the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia board on the operations of the bank, together with the financial statements and the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1991-92.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: On many occasions Reserve Bank reports have provided an insight into a different level, nature and style of official advice which is given to the Government. It is unfortunate that ever since Mr John Phillips appeared to take a considerable role in the preparation of reports a couple of years ago, the Reserve Bank annual reports have tended to echo much more the evident attitudes of the Government rather than express what one would have hoped might have been strongly individual views or a strongly independent view of the monetary authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know they are not?

—The Minister interjects, `How do you know they are not?'. I would have thought that at the moment it would be very difficult to find a unanimity of view about the level of the present Government's incompetence. Certainly, there is a widespread view that it is incompetent, that its management of the economy has been monumentally incompetent. It is curious to find that the Reserve Bank, apparently, has very little disagreement with anything that has been done by the Government in leading this nation into the most appalling, disastrous and largely unnecessary recession. This recession has been influenced to only a relatively small extent by external factors, unlike the 1982-83 recession which was basically drought driven. The Reserve Bank deals with that matter.
—You want them to agree with you.
—If the Minister will just hold his rampant tongue and open his generally closed ears, I will deal with that matter a little later on.

PARA.TAB: In its report the Reserve Bank says:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988 and early in 1989, a strong world economy and buoyant terms of trade underpinned an excessive rate of domestic spending.
I suppose it is all very well for the Reserve Bank to say that now. But what was the Reserve Bank doing at the time; what was Government policy at the time? The report goes on:
. . . policy has been pursued with an eye to the implication for activity and employment, as well as the need to achieve a breakthrough in perceptions about inflation.
I suppose the million unemployed could wonder whether the eye of the Reserve Bank is like that of Nelson's because it certainly has a blind eye on the question of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Reserve Bank mentions:

SPEECH.PARA: Real interest rates as conventionally measured have remained relatively high throughout the downturn, suggesting a firm monetary policy.

There is no doubt that real interest rates have remained high and maybe this is one reason that there has been such a very slow recovery from recession. The bank notes in its report that there has been a reluctance on the part of corporations to extend their indebtedness. It may well be, of course, a reluctance by the banks to extend credit. But the continuing very high level of real interest rates clearly is a factor.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note, too, in the context of the Victorian State election that the bank recognises that there have been different economic results in different States. The bank notes:

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of falling asset prices and the associated impacts on financial stability and confidence were concentrated most heavily in those areas which had become most overextended. Victoria (and more lately South Australia) suffered the worst falls on most measures of economic activity. . .

It is significant, as the Reserve Bank said, that Victoria and South Australia became the most overextended States. It is interesting to note that the State banks in both those States played a key role in that overextension. The State banks, under the policy directions of their Labor State governments, have played a key role in the disasters from which these two States are now suffering.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that the Reserve Bank in effect underlines in its comment almost the culpability of the Victorian State Government, which owned the Victorian State Bank—this also applies in the case of the South Australian Government. This led to a ludicrous situation in which Victoria became overextended and, as a result, it is now suffering the most. I hope that the Victorian electorate recognises the role that its State Government played in this overextension as a result of which it is now suffering.
The bank also says:
An early return to a solid rate of growth is not inconsistent with the maintenance of low underlying inflation. Indeed, employment growth needs to be restored promptly. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know that the Budget is going to do that. All we see in the Budget is in fact an absence of any major, or even minor, programs that will encourage the generation of real and lasting private sector jobs, and this is the only place which can provide genuine increases in employment. So it appears that, despite the Reserve Bank's enthusiastic remarks about employment growth needing to be restored promptly, this Government is doing nothing about it except creating temporary jobs paid for not by the taxpayer but as a result of increasing debt—paid for on Bankcard.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the dramatic differences between the nonsense of the Government's approach and the sorts of genuine assistance and encouragement for the private sector which are contained in the Opposition's Fightback policy, which takes taxes off business, helps generate jobs in the private sector and provides a real solution to Australia's problems. The One Nation package is now a clear failure. Mr Hawke, the former Prime Minister, quite properly identified it as containing such ludicrous forecasts and statements of expectation that it has in fact damaged the Government's credibility. Mr Hawke, of course, is quite right.

There is one thing the Reserve Bank has stressed that I think is very important and that is the difference between this recession and the 1982-83 recession. We keep hearing from economic imbeciles on the other side—from the front bench in particular—who try to pretend that somehow things were worse in 1982-83 and that their problems are all because of what happened then. The Reserve Bank makes a very significant statement about this. It points out that the major recession in the early 1980s `had been exacerbated by the effect of drought on rural output'. It goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The contraction in the non-farm economy—
that is, in the current recession—
on the other hand, appears to have been larger than in 1982-83.

Let us get this clear: the Reserve Bank acknowledges that the fall in the non-farm economy in this recession has been larger than in 1982-83. In other words, this Government has managed to do this without the savage impact of drought which, of course, decimated the Australian economy in 1982-83. Let us hear no more of these nonsensical comparisons, because the Reserve Bank is demonstrating that the Labor Party has simply been misleading the people of Australia on this score. The report goes on:
The fall in aggregate employment was similar in the two episodes—
both in 1982-83 and in this recession the fall in aggregate employment has been similar, despite the fact that in 1982-83 there was the massive impact of drought—
with employment declining by 2 3/4 per cent between mid 1990 and the end of 1991, but the latest cycle has been more protracted—
that is, than in 1982-83—
and full-time employment noticeably weaker.

So this recession, on the Reserve Bank's evidence, is deeper, more protracted and worse than the 1982-83 recession. It is about time those sitting on the Government front bench recognised the reality and stopped spreading the Labor lie that somehow things were worse in 1982-83.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, dear. What about the Liberal lie that you are just putting now?

—I acknowledge that interjection. I have just read from the Reserve Bank's annual report and the Minister says that that is a Liberal lie. This sort of pathetic nonsense from this Minister just gets worse and worse every day. It is incredible that this poor person cannot even read—I know he cannot understand, I acknowledge that—the Reserve Bank's annual report which so clearly maintains the proposition that the Opposition has been maintaining for some time, and that is, that the comparisons with the 1982-83 recession which the Labor Party keeps trotting out are phoney and dishonest.
—Rubbish.
—That is simply shown by the facts in this report which I have read out.
—Rubbish.

—I suggest that before the Minister keeps reiterating the word `rubbish', he should go away and, if he can understand the Reserve Bank, apply what is left of his mind to it. The Reserve Bank made another interesting point about another damaging impact of this incompetent Government on the economy. This might have slipped through to the keeper. It had not struck me quite as forcefully as it appears to strike the Reserve Bank. It notes that one of the reasons for this instability and these problems in the economy is:

SPEECH.PARA: A period of political instability around the turn of the year added to general uncertainty about both short-term economic prospects and the stance of policy.

That is a polite way of saying that the Keating coup was another bit of icing on the cake of his contribution to the destruction of the Australian economy, and that that coup helped damage the economic recovery. I suppose it is only a drop in the bucket of the disasters that Mr Keating has brought to this nation, but it is certainly worth recognising.

PARA.TAB: I had also failed to pick up, until the Reserve Bank report did so, that the increase in consumer demand for retail goods, which rose in the June quarter, was largely a recovery brought about by this Government by handing out loot. In other words, it can fiddle the national income figures with taxpayers' money just as it can fiddle the unemployment figures, and it has been doing both. The Reserve Bank says:

SPEECH.PARA: Consumer demand for retail goods. . . rose further in the June quarter, helped by the one-off supplementary payment to families in April.

Here we have a situation where, clearly, if a government puts its mind to it, like this Government, it can fiddle the consumer demand element of the national income figures by paying out taxpayers' money, or borrowed money—which has now been demonstrated because of the huge size of the deficit—to fiddle the accounts. It means that one must take the national income figures with even larger grains of salt when the Government quotes national income figures to demonstrate economic recovery.

PARA.TAB: The next point I want to make refers to the Reserve Bank's comments on the balance of payments. It points out that the net income deficit declined to $15.7 billion, down from $18 billion, in 1991. But then it reveals something else that I must admit I had not noted sufficiently well, that is, that this fall reflected a decline in the cost of servicing foreign liabilities mainly as a result of lower interest rates on foreign debt. It notes:

SPEECH.PARA: For the year to March 1992, the annual interest burden represented around 17 per cent of the value of exports of goods and services, around 3 percentage points lower than two years earlier.

In other words, there does not appear to be a fundamental basic improvement in the balance of payments at all. On the contrary, it is simply because of lower external interest rates that the cost of servicing our debt diminished. That eased the burden and gave the false appearance of things being an awful lot better, and that the Government was somehow doing something to fix up the balance of payments crisis that Australia is in. It is simply not true. It is another indicator that does not really indicate that things are getting better at all. It certainly does not indicate that this Government is doing anything to improve the situation. As the Australian dollar falls, the servicing costs will increase, and I notice that in the Budget Papers there is a clear indication that the current account balance will worsen yet again.

PARA.TAB: The final point that I want to make relates to another element of the Reserve Bank's annual report. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: To recover from the recession without a permanently higher level of unemployment, but with the external accounts structurally improving and inflation low, is a considerable challenge.
It sure is, because the Budget Papers themselves show that external accounts are going to get worse this year and that there will be a permanently high level of unemployment. It goes on to say:

Minimising the fallout of the recession on the labour market will require balanced macro-economic policies, acting on the demand side of the economy. It will also require further micro-economic policies aimed at increasing flexibility on the supply side. In particular, successful competition in the international market place ultimately requires a highly skilled and adaptable labour force.

What is the Government doing about these vital objectives that the Reserve Bank says must be achieved? I guess we could say that it is trying to improve the skill levels and the adaptability of a labour force, because it is trying to increase the numbers of people who are unemployed who are able to pick up skill levels. To that extent, I suppose we could say, `For heaven's sake, at least the Government has recognised part of the problem'. But it has not recognised what the Reserve Bank points out first—that we have to have balanced macro-economic policies acting on the demand side of the economy and, further, micro-economic policies aimed at increasing flexibility on the supply side. What is the Government doing in these areas?

PARA.TAB: I hope that my colleague Senator Short, who will be following me, will demonstrate that this Government has really done nothing in terms of any micro-economic policies on the supply side and is doing very little in terms of macro-economic policies on the demand side. It would be useful if the Government, instead of sneering at the Fightback package, had a good look at the positive measures that can be taken to fix this disaster that we are now putting up with in Australia.

The Reserve Bank notes that there are problems with the public sector borrowing requirement. It says that the current financial situation `will make it more difficult to wind back the PSBR than in the 1980s, as well as limiting the scope for further discretionary increases in spending or cuts in taxes'. Here we have the Reserve Bank saying that the economic situation will limit the scope for further discretionary increases in government spending and this Government is, in fact, increasing government spending by borrowing—unfunded schemes and a massive deficit. The report then says that it will also be more difficult to introduce cuts in taxes, yet the Government says that it is going to proceed with cuts in taxes.

On the two issues where the Reserve Bank says `There would be great difficulties in going down that track', the Government is going down those very tracks. It is going to cut taxes, even if it has to increase taxes to pay for the cut taxes. That is a rough translation of what Mr Dawkins said in the Budget.

Although the Reserve Bank's annual report is not as clearly a source of different, independent advice to the Parliament and to the Government as one has seen in the past, it does, nevertheless, reveal some clear failures of this Government. It clearly indicates that the Government is not undertaking a course that appears—if one reads between the lines of the Reserve Bank's report—to be one that the Reserve Bank would favour in some instances. The report clearly indicates that the present disaster in Victoria, for example, is directly attributable to the sorts of policies that allowed the financial institutions controlled by the governments in Victoria and South Australia to over-extend themselves and to over-expand. For all that, the Reserve Bank report is a useful document, but it would be nice to see it more of an independent one in terms of its general policy thrust and advice than it appears to be at the moment.

It is extraordinary that, in this time of crisis, there appears to be, at least on the surface, a sort of unanimity of policy advice between the Treasury and the Reserve Bank—if in fact statement No. 2 is the Treasury's statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about this report, and endorse the comments made by my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume. I want to touch on two main aspects of the bank's report. Firstly, I would like to point out that net profits made under the Reserve Bank Act—profits which basically relate to the activities of the bank—amounted to $2.6 billion in 1991-92. This was approximately $1 billion up on the amount of $1.6 billion—or near enough to it—in the preceding financial year of 1990-91. I would also like to make the point that those profits have been appropriated essentially to the Commonwealth Government. That $2.6 billion was very important in enabling the Government to produce a Budget deficit for this year of $13.4 billion instead of the much higher underlying deficit that really exists.

PARA.TAB: The Government has published in the Budget the figure of $13.4 billion as its bottom line deficit. The true deficit is, in fact, closer to $20 billion. Indeed, it is $20.5 billion. The most important single element in bridging the gap between that $13.4 billion and $20.5 billion—namely, $7.1 billion—is the very large Reserve Bank profit of $2.6 billion. It is not a cooking of the books by the Commonwealth Government in terms of its Budget formulation; nevertheless, if we are making an accurate assessment of the Government's true budgetary position, that figure should be set aside. Therefore, the Reserve Bank has once again, as it did last year, made a significant contribution towards allowing the Government to publish a much lower Budget deficit figure than the true figure.

Of course, the published figure is already horrendously high at $13.4 billion. That is something like 40 or 50 per cent higher than the far too high $9.3 billion deficit last year, which was, in itself, one of the important contributing factors in the continuing growth in the tragic level of unemployment in Australia. That deficit was also the reason for the level of economic growth—particularly in the private sector—being much less than it should have been.

Another point I want to make about the Reserve Bank's annual report—and in this I endorse the comments of Senator Baume—is that there is an eerie similarity this year between the assessments of the bank and the assessments of the Treasury about the economic situation and the prospects for the future. Like Senator Baume, I would like to see a more full-blooded and independent assessment by the bank of the economic situation.

The bank has had a very proud record of objectivity over many years—for most of the past years, anyway—in terms of its analysis and the frankness with which it publishes material. Senator Baume referred to the era when Mr Phillips was the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank. There have been previous occasions when, under Governors such as Bob Johnston, Harry Knight and Jock Phillips—as well as some of those other great Governors of the Reserve Bank—the bank was fearless in the advice that it provided to government and to the wider community. I detect a lessening of that in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just that it doesn't agree with you.
—No, not at all.
—Those people wrote reports disagreeing with us.

—That is right. It is extremely important that the Reserve Bank, as the central bank of this nation, is not only independent and fearless in the advice it gives to government and in the information it publishes for the community but also is seen to be independent. I hope that that situation of apparent independence, which I think has lessened in recent years, will be restored because it is of very considerable importance. The coalition, on coming to government after the next election, will be taking several major steps to ensure that the Reserve Bank is an independent institution, not only in reality but also quite obviously in the community's perception of it.

PARA.TAB: On page 19 of the bank's report, there is a section relating to the period ahead. It makes some interesting comments on which I wish to elaborate. It makes this quite obvious point:

SPEECH.PARA: A year or so after the economy reached its lowest ebb, it is apparent that recovery so far has been patchy, and weak overall.

That statement would have to err, if anything, on the optimistic side. I do not know that there has really been any recovery at all in the economy. The national accounts figures show very halting growth. Much of the anecdotal evidence that is available to us indicates that in most major segments of the economy there has been no recovery, but a continuing deep recession and continuing major lay-offs of people in jobs. So `recovery' is a word that ought to be used very cautiously. The words of much greater significance are that any action or development that has occurred has been very weak overall.

PARA.TAB: The Reserve Bank is less than fulsome in its views about the prospects for the next 12 months. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the next 12 months, subject as always to developments abroad and policies at home, the prospects are for a faster pace of growth.

That really is not saying too much at all, given the snail's pace at best that we have had in the past 12 months. Indeed, it has caused unemployment to continue to escalate in Australia to more than 11 per cent. In the Government's own Estimates published in the Budget only two days ago, the Government forecasts that the average rate of unemployment in this current financial year of 1992-93 will be 10.5 per cent, which is higher than the figure for 1991-92 on average of 10.4 per cent. So the Government itself is admitting that the average level of unemployment this current financial year will be even higher than the average level of unemployment in the last financial year.

PARA.TAB: There is a statement by the Government in the Budget that there is an expectation that over the course of the next 12 months unemployment will fall to below 10 per cent. But it is talking about a fall of about one per cent in the unemployment rate, achieved at a very great cost through a massive pump-priming spending spree designed to try to get the Government over the line at the next election.

There should be no doubt at all about the motivation for the structuring of this year's Budget. It is a Budget simply designed to try to buy votes to get this desperate Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and this desperate Government re-elected at the next election. It has gone down like a lead balloon, both in the financial markets and in the general community.

Within the next few days we will see the decisions in the Budget sink without trace. Instead, we will be left with a massive tax threat hanging over the head of every Australian because even the Government was forced to acknowledge in the Budget that it will almost certainly not be able to balance its books by the mid-1990s unless it imposes savage increases in existing taxes and/or imposes new taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does it say that?

—It acknowledges that it will not be able to balance its books by 1995-96 on all reasonable expectations unless it increases the level of taxation. There is no way that the taxes that it nominates for increase, namely, fringe benefits, withholding and prescribed payments—as Senator Cook should know but obviously does not—can provide the necessary increase in revenue to fill the void unless the Government savagely increases those taxes. Even then, the Government probably would not make it.

PARA.TAB: The certainty would be that if the Government were re-elected, it would finish up with a goods and services tax in the next couple of years. This would happen without any of the offsetting tax cuts, the $13 billion of tax cuts in personal income tax, the $20 billion of cuts in the taxes that are so onerous on business in Australia today—none of the generous compensation measures and provisions contained in the coalition's Fightback proposals to go with the major restructuring of the taxation system of which the goods and services tax is only one part.

If this Government is re-elected, which will not happen, there is no doubt that there would be a savage increase in the total level of taxation over the next few years. That is obvious, given the amount by which it is putting itself into hock. This year the financing requirement of the Government will be $18.5 billion. That is the amount of money it has to find out in the money markets either here or abroad, simply to meet the extent to which its expenditure this year will exceed its revenue.

That puts the Government into increasing hock. It means that the public interest payments—the interest bill that has to be met by taxpayers this year—will go up by 26 per cent, to quote the Government's own figures. Next year, it will go up by 33 per cent. Even the year after, it will go up by another 15 per cent. All of that has to be paid for out of taxpayers' funds even before one starts to pay off one cent of the actual massive increases in borrowing.

Over the next three or four years, we will see a cumulative deficit in this country of a figure which could well approach $50 billion. The Reserve Bank's report talks about the size of deficits. It does not express quite the degree of concern that I certainly would have about the deficit over the past couple of years. It does make a statement that is important because it conflicts completely with the actual situation that we will face in this country. It says that for a variety of reasons, `temporary large deficits do not themselves pose a serious problem'.

The first point to be made about that is that the deficit that we face as a nation in the Commonwealth Budget accounts is not temporary. It is an enormous deficit of an ongoing nature which the Government itself has acknowledged will continue well into the 1990s. That imposes structural constraints on the economy which are highly detrimental to the growth in GDP, investment, savings and, therefore, unemployment. The whole policy approach enshrined in the Budget of two days ago is a policy approach which is absolutely contrary to the requirements of this nation if we really do want to get back and be a dynamic, growing, job creating nation.
In the same section of the annual report the Reserve Bank says:

SPEECH.PARA: Looking further ahead, the economy still faces a considerable adjustment task over the next several years.

That would have to be the understatement of the year. As Senator Baume said in his remarks, to date no adjustment has been undertaken. That is the reason why this nation is in its present dreadful mess, with its tragic level of unemployment, desperately low growth, and an abysmally low level of savings and investment. If it is said that the economy still faces a considerable adjustment task over the next several years, all I can say to that is, it sure does.

PARA.TAB: The longer that the adjustment task is delayed, the more intractable that problem will become and the more deep-seated our fundamental underlying problems will be. The bank says—and it is wrong here—`some progress has been made in the balance of payments area'.

This year's Budget forecast was for a balance of payments deficit on current account of $15 billion compared with $11.9 billion in the year just ended. That $15 billion deficit is probably optimistic because it is based on what I think can reasonably be described as an optimistic forecast for the growth in exports, given the uncertain situation that faces us in the major export markets that we rely on. Sixty per cent of our exports go to the Asian region, of which Japan is a very important part. The Japanese economy, as we all know, is pretty rocky at the moment and has some considerable problems of adjustment ahead. That will have an impact throughout the Asian region, and some of the individual major countries in the Asian region are undergoing their own readjustment problems, with lower growth rates than they have had in the past.

Without being too pessimistic, if we were to make a more reasonable assessment about the prospects for Australian export growth over the next 12 months, I think it would be reasonable to assume that the balance of payments deficit now forecast of $15 billion could end up being closer to $17 billion.

The report also says that the lower inflation environment can only be good for overall savings performance and for the process of allocation of these savings. I agree with that in theory. In practical terms though, we now have almost the lowest level of savings as a nation that we have had certainly in living memory. One of the essential reasons for that is that the Government, through its budgetary policy, has been drawing on the nation's savings at an unprecedented rate. While I agree with the bank in its report that a positive overall savings performance is what is needed—of course it is—if the Government were to believe that, it would be taking steps through its Budget policy and other policy measures to ensure that it encouraged that performance rather than, as it is in fact doing, detracting from it very severely.

The public sector borrowing requirement, to which I think Senator Baume referred in his comments about the bank's report, is a fundamental problem for us at the moment. There has been a turnaround in the public sector borrowing requirement as a proportion of gross domestic product of no less than 7 per cent in the past three years. So far as I am aware, never in our history have we had a turnaround and deterioration of the public borrowing situation of that magnitude. This year will compound the problem even further.

Reading very carefully between the lines of the report's assessment of the prospects ahead for the economy, I think the bank is really pointing the way quietly—and I would have liked to see it come out more forcefully in the report—to several major fundamental problems that underlie the prospect ahead.

The sooner we get on with the task of restructuring this economy, tackling the real areas of great need—reform of the taxation system, as well as of the industrial relations system, shipping, transport systems, the telecommunications system, the power generation system—all those key so-called infrastructure industries which determine very importantly the level of productivity overall for our economy, the better. The longer we delay in undertaking the necessary reforms in those areas, the longer we will be condemned to a decade of low growth in the economy, low investment, low savings and—as I have said and as has been said all too often—a tragically high level of continuing unemployment.

That is a prospect that we as a nation, with all the potential advantages and attractions we have, should not allow to continue. The sooner a change of government occurs in this country, with the present Government succeeded by a government which is absolutely committed to achieving those reforms and changes, the better it will be for us all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am afraid that earlier this afternoon before this last motion came on my little legs were a bit slow in getting me down to the chamber.
—You should have bobsledded down.

—Yes, indeed; I would have been down here in record time. Unfortunately, I missed the presentation of the annual report of the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee. Therefore, I seek leave to move a motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is interesting because the tobacco industry is in a state of flux. I note the comment that Mr Arthur Graham, Chairman of the Advisory Committee, has made on page 5 of the report, where he says:

The value of the Australian dollar has shown remarkable resilience despite the adverse economic climate in Australia in recent years. While the advantage to the growing sector of a depreciation of the Australian dollar is obvious, any sustained appreciation would only compound the challenge of trading without any market regulation and the continuing decline in tariff protection.

PARA.TAB: One of the great problems the tobacco industry faces is that it is competing against countries where there is no free float of the currency. In fact, one of the major competitors of the Australian producers is Zimbabwe. That country principally has one cash crop, and that is tobacco leaf. The consequence is that every time growers in Australia or the United States become competitive with the growers in Zimbabwe, Zimbabwe devalues its currency. Zimbabwe then can still get good returns in soft currency, but of course it drags down the price that it is fetching on the world market.

The problem for us is that we do not devalue our currency every time we want to give a boost to the cash crop. In fact, some people would say that the currency at the moment is far too high. The great challenge for the Australian industry is how to compete with this.
From the figures in the Budget and from the portfolio profile of our foreign denominated debt, it seems very clear that Treasury expects the Australian dollar to appreciate against the US dollar.

That is a real challenge because this year tobacco growers in Zimbabwe are selling their leaf for prices denominated in US dollars. So if the Australian dollar increases against the greenback, the consequence will be that, even if the price of tobacco leaf as sold in Zimbabwe stays the same, it would come in here much cheaper. Of course, the other problem is that Zimbabwe could well do a devaluation of the sort of magnitude we saw at the end of last season, which would throw huge amounts of leaf, sold at well under what is a realistic price, into the market and wipe out Australian growers.

This industry has a net value of leaf of about $80m, which does not seem like a lot. Of that, $47m worth is grown within almost a stone's throw of where I live on the Atherton Tablelands, so of course it is a major concern for me.

Given that it is almost inevitable that tariffs in the tobacco industry will come down—although it does not really make much of a substantial impact on prices—I believe that we should take a serious look at the definitions of `dumping' and `countervailing'.

Although neither a dumping action nor a countervailing action should be used as a form of non-tariff protection, we have to be very aware that some countries do not have a clean float of their currency. We also have to be aware that, if we express the prices in perhaps the black market price for their currency rather than the official price, there is de facto dumping of the goods into the international market—and, most importantly, dumping of the goods into the Australian market.

When we look at possible dumping we should be looking at expressing the price at which it is sold in the parallel marketplace for that crop rather than the official exchange rate in the country in question. If we did that, we would really wipe out the advantage in terms of selling into Australia that countries such as Zimbabwe had last year by their dirty devaluation. All I am asking is for the Government to go away and look at this problem. It is a very real problem—not just from Zimbabwe but from many other East African countries—which will remain with us until we take some positive steps.

The question I put to the Senate is: whether one smokes or not, does one want to throw away a $80m industry and deprive a town like Mareeba of $47m of income in the next financial year? That is the question with which we must grapple and that is why I must challenge these issues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
