SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report of the Australian Institute of Criminology, as I congratulate regularly the Institute on its continuing work. In speaking to this report, I want to respond to an attack on the integrity of the Institute and its past Director of Research, Dr Paul Wilson, by Senator Harradine in speaking to this document during the last session. I believe it was actually in March, but it has taken a long time to reach the top of the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: In reference to the annual report of the Institute, Senator Harradine attempted to show that there had been some impropriety regarding the Institute's payment of $3,618 towards the cost of bringing a Danish criminologist, Dr Berl Kutchinsky, to Australia to speak at the Institute's Conference on the Sex Industry and Public Policy.

Senator Harradine's objections seemed to focus on the fact that Professor Kutchinsky's findings that there had been a 30 per cent decrease in sex crimes in three European countries since the legalisation of adult erotica were opposed to his personal beliefs that non-violent adult sexual depictions lead otherwise normal human beings to rape or even to kill. I attended that conference and recall that Professor Kutchinsky's contribution was very well received.

Senator Harradine quoted Dr John Court and Dr Judith Reisman as criticising Kutchinsky's research and therefore calling into question his suitability to address the conference. I would like to inform the Senate of what the British Royal Commission on Pornography had to say about Dr Court. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: We reject his—
that is Court's—
evidence and to the extent that they rely on it, those who quote him.

From my own experience of Dr Court's published work, I would concur with the Commission's view. Senator Harradine also claimed that the Institute had failed to invite any of Dr Kutchinsky's critics to debate his findings. That puzzles me and perhaps Senator Harradine has begun to re-evaluate his traditional allies, because both the Reverend Fred Nile and Senator Shirley Walters attended the conference, and it is my recollection that both were invited speakers. Senator Harradine also claimed that the selection of funded speakers was made solely by Dr Wilson. This is incorrect as all speakers were approved by the Director of the Institute who was kept informed through all stages of the preparation and the conference itself.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kutchinsky's work was published in the International Journal of Law and Psychiatry where it was of course peer reviewed and should therefore be beyond reproach. It was also extensively quoted and praised throughout the Williams Commission. I will seek leave to incorporate the conclusion of Dr Kutchinsky's contribution. I regret that the contribution itself is too long and not in a suitable form to incorporate. I will also seek leave to incorporate a letter from the coordinator of the largest file on sex crime in the world in Michigan in the United States, who says that he can demonstrate a stronger correlation between sex crimes and alcohol than he can between sex crimes and sexual depictions.

Research like Kutchinsky's answers narrow-minded and prejudiced calls for prohibition and censorship of a wide range of material made by Senator Harradine and his supporters. I personally wish that those who favour prohibition would focus on areas such as extreme violence and extreme sexism which, from current research, have been shown to be more likely to cause harm and offence in the community than the non-violent depiction of human sexuality.

I commend the work of the Institute of Criminology, as I have before, for its research and for the opportunity it provides through conferences and seminars, such as the one Senator Harradine attacked and the more recent one on homicide, which I also attended and which enabled informed debate on issues that should concern us all. I condemn the Opposition who are happy to distort Institute research results for their own purposes, for example, in their recent leaflet on violent crime and the aged. I believe the Opposition proposes to axe the Institute itself as part of the Fightback package. I seek leave to incorporate the material I referred to.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

The aggregate data on rape and other violent or sexual offenses from four countries where pornography, including aggressive varieties, has become widely and easily available during the period we have dealt with would seem to exclude, beyond any reasonable doubt, that this availability has had any detrimental effects in the form of increased sexual violence. Especially the data from West Germany are striking since here the only increase in the sexual violence takes place in the form which includes the least serious forms of sexual coercion and where there may have been increases in reporting frequency. As far as the other forms of sexual violence are concerned, the remarkable fact is that they decreased—the more so, the more serious the offense.

PARA.TAB: The finding is not so strange. Most other research data we have about pornography and rape suggest that the link between them is more than weak. And our knowledge about the contents, the uses and the users of pornography suggests that pornography does not represent a blueprint for rape, but is essentially an aphrodisiac, that is, food for the sexual fantasy of persons—mostly males—who like to masturbate.

The policy implications of this conclusion are, of course open to debate. But as mentioned earlier, the mainstream attitude would seem to be a combination of two movements; (1) To reduce the area of total prohibition and censorship to a minimum, and (2) to implement a variety of restrictions, suitable of each form of pornography, in order to obtain maximum protection of children, and of adults who want no confrontation with the material.

PARA.TAB: My office has received an order request from the Michigan State Police study on pornography and it's impact on sex motivated crime. This is truly the most distant request we have ever received. For several years I have responded to requests from all over the United States and Canada. This study was allegedly conducted by a former member of this Unit and presented in various public forums. Since his retirement, several attempts were made to locate this study. After years of investigation, the truth is that no such study was ever conducted.

The promise of the study was supposed to show that pornography causes sexual assault. Anyone who has ever studied human behaviour knows that this is extremely difficult, if not impossible to say that one things causes certain behaviour. The best one can show is a correlation. The Michigan State Police maintain the largest computerized sex motivated crime file in the world. This file was initiated in 1955 and continues to be present, with almost 75,000 cases on file. The information that we can glean from these reports is greater today than during the time that this study was allegedly conducted. I have attempted to replicate the information that was being offered about pornography. There is insufficient data to indicate anything other than a weak correlation between pornography and sexual assault, and even less information to suggest that pornography was used prior to or during sexual assault.

As the criminal personality profiler for the Michigan State Police, I can offer that pornography is used to enhance sexual fantasy and for arousal. That this material would cause one to work themself up into a frenzy and then commit a sexual assault would be a giant leap indeed. In fact, one of the most popular magazines in prison amongst child molesters is the J.C. Penney catalog (retail store), because it features young boys and girls in their underwear. I believe that the person who presented this study had a religious agenda. Wouldn't it be nice if all we had to do was eliminate pornography and we could eliminate sex crimes? Aside from the difficulty in defining pornography, I could show a stronger correlation between the use of alcohol and sexual assault than pornography and sexual assault.
I hope this answers any questions you might have had on our non-existent study. If I can ever be of further service to you, please feel free to contact me.

SPEECH.PARA: Sincerely,
David Minzey, D/Sergeant
Michigan State Police
Investigation Resources Unit,
Violent Crimes.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education Council: Report to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the Senate is presented with a report courtesy of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, NBEET, which, thankfully, will be abolished after the coalition comes into government at the next election.

PARA.TAB: As NBEET is one of the most prolific producers of asinine reports in the Public Service system, it was with some relief that I read this report and discovered that it is actually looking at a very useful issue and had some very useful comments on HECs and educational profiles. Needless to say, the opinions expressed by the Higher Education Council through NBEET are just a continuation of the sort of rhetoric that we have come to expect from this organisation.

A perfect example from the report is that NBEET states that `There is strong support for the profiling process'. This opinion has been obtained by going around the various universities and asking them if they approve of it. This is not a very sound method of assessing the feelings for the education profile process or anything else. No university vice-chancellor is about to bite the hand that feeds the university. When the report says, `There is generally strong support for the profiles process overall', the praise seems to have a somewhat hollow ring to it.

As I have moved around universities in Australia and talked to senior staff, this is not what they are telling me. They see it as a huge imposition and a drain on their resources. I noted in visitations to various educational institutions by the Higher Education Council that they were not meeting with staff. The question immediately arises, therefore, as to how accurate their claim of general acceptance of the profiling process actually is.

One of the main groups affected is academic staff, and they were not given an opportunity to express their opinion. Staff are particularly affected by the profiling process and suffer significantly under the bureaucratic nightmare established by the bane of Australian education, Mr Dawkins. Data collection and educational profiles are an extreme waste of time and resources. Staff are often subject to tedious bureaucratic data collection when time is desperately needed in other areas of their work. It is no wonder that the education sector in Australia is unable to attract and keep a lot of academic brilliance.

Data collected is often refined to such an extent that comparisons between institutions are not possible. Changes in criteria often increase the time taken by staff to collect data. As this report states, some comments were received that more data was collected than was used. Questions were raised in this report regarding the quantum, manageability and usefulness of data collected through the profiling process.

Another criticism examined by the report is the legislative basis of the profiling process. The legislation governing the process does not indicate the purpose to which the profiles can be put or limit the content, and there is no opportunity for public scrutiny of the profiling arrangements. This leaves open the way for the process to become increasingly regulatory in character.The report dismisses these concerns as it considers that the process is open and subject to multiple levels of scrutiny. All these levels of scrutiny are from within. The only external scrutiny received is through the Parliament, and the decisions for negotiations and advice from HECs are tabled. This is not adequate.

Clearly, the need for higher education institutions to comply with the profiling process in order to obtain funds, constantly in fear of failing to meet the Government's hidden agenda, is a major threat to institutional autonomy. How can universities operate with autonomy and determine their own academic agenda without undue influence, when this agenda is subjected to such a high level of scrutiny by government?

This report concludes that the education profiling process is working well and that it is generally accepted by the institutions. I reject this proposition. Our higher education institutions are restricted in what they can do by the dictates of this Government's policy, and the resources wasted on putting together institutional profiles could be put to infinitely better use.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words about the report on the state of the automotive industry which was produced by the Automotive Industry Authority. It says a number of interesting things about the state of the industry and where it is heading in the future.

PARA.TAB: This is the seventh report by the Automotive Industry Authority, whose principal functions are: firstly, to encourage the industry to develop in a way consistent with the policy of the Commonwealth Government; secondly, to promote change within the industry directed at improving its efficiency; thirdly, to monitor the performance and outlook for the industry; and, fourthly, to provide information and advice on the industry to government.

It is very clear that three challenges face the car industry in the run-up to the year 2000. The first is the reduction of tariffs to 15 per cent by the year 2000. The increase in automation, which will improve productivity but which will have a detrimental impact on the number of jobs, is really a second major challenge that the industry must face, and one that must be recognised by the public and government when seeking to increase job prospects in the industry in the long term.

Thirdly, a change in consumer demands will clearly impact on the kind of product that the industry will produce. The environmental concerns expressed by consumers through their purchasing power will, in the long term, affect the car industry in a very real way. That is a challenge that the car industry in Australia must face if it is going to retain a viable industry into the year 2000.

Tariffs have been substantially reduced already from 57.5 per cent in 1984 to 35 per cent to date, and will be reduced to 15 per cent by the year 2000 under the Button car plan. The Government is using this strategy to force the car industry to make improvements in price, quality and efficiency. It has certainly been a very effective tool, if that has been its major goal. The reduction in tariffs in the eyes of many has resulted already in the closure of one car factory and the loss of many thousands of jobs with Nissan.

I really impress upon the Government how poorly regarded within the industry the tariff policy is. One would not find one person in the car industry at the moment who welcomes and embraces the Government's car tariff policy, especially given the very tight economic circumstances surrounding the economy and the car industry as a whole. Many are really wondering whether it is this Government's intention to simply kill off the car industry altogether by its headlong rush into lower tariffs. Certainly the car industry has made every effort to meet that challenge, but it is a real struggle and, certainly in the current economic situation, it would welcome a 12-month pause in the tariff phase-down, which would help it to restructure in this time of economic stress.

In our view, the key to a successful car industry is improved productivity, innovation and meeting the needs of customers. Interestingly enough, this report states several times that one means of improving productivity is to increase investment in automation and advanced manufacturing technologies. It must be remembered that automation will not result in more jobs. If anything, automation will result in fewer jobs as robotics increasingly take the place of those skilled workers who once performed those functions. The Government must be aware of that and make plans to take up those workers by way of training programs and so forth, so that they are not just left on the unemployment scrap heap.

The report also states that the difference in productivity between Australian and overseas car companies is due to our low level of automation. I find it interesting that it is not due to restrictive work practices, as one would be led to believe by other senators in this chamber.

A third challenge facing the industry is changing consumer demands. I find it interesting to note that there has been a marked increase in imported small cars over the last few years, which indicates that consumers are not looking for large six-cylinder vehicles but smaller cars with fuel efficiency. This will become more important for the industry over time as the impact of the Californian emissions regulations come into effect. They will have a ripple impact throughout the car industry around the world as vehicles will be produced that will have lower emissions and will be much more fuel efficient.

It is vitally important for the Australian car industry that manufacturers and components manufacturers recognise that these developments will eventually impact on what happens here in this country. Long term plans must be made to ensure that the industry restructures.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
