PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of General Business notice of motion No. 1028 standing in the name of Senator Short relating to the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) admitted in the Budget speech on 18 August 1992 that the Keating Government will have to raise taxes to pay for its unfunded personal income tax cuts promised for 1994-95;
(b)notes that these new taxes will come in the form of one or all of the following:
(ii)increased taxes on business, and hence on investment and jobs,
(iii)bracket creep, that is, giving back what has been taken from taxpayers, and/or
(iv)the Labor Left's old favourite, a wealth tax;
(c)condemns the Government for its cowardice in not being prepared to tell the Australian people which new or additional taxes they will have to bear;

(d)notes that the Treasurer also announced that the Government's promise to return the Budget to surplus has now been unceremoniously discarded in favour of the personal income tax cuts pledge, perceived as more electorally popular; and
(e)condemns the Government for its irresponsible `spend now, pay later' `Bankcard Budget'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) the other evening, at page 13 it was pointed out that, in the absence of new measures, revenues are likely to decline over the period to 1995-96. He said that if the fiscal position nearer to the time is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain the revenue structure. These changes, referred to in the Budget statements, would allow for the 1995-96 deficit to be between one-half and one per cent of gross domestic product—in other words, about $2 billion to $4 billion.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely clear from all the evidence available that the Government will be forced to implement those tax changes, those tax increases, if it is to even get anywhere near meeting its so-called promise to cut personal income tax by 1994-95 and 1995-96, as it `promised' to do in the One Nation statement in February, a promise that it reiterated in the Budget Speech the other night. It is an ironic situation, is it not, that the Government is now virtually admitting in this Budget that it will have to increase taxes over the next few years in order to give the personal income tax cuts that it had promised.

The big question that arises from that, and the question which I posed in the Senate today and which Dr Hewson and Mr Reith and my colleagues have been posing very strongly in the House of Representatives, is: just what will be the size of those tax increases and what new taxes will have to be introduced to meet the revenue needs that the Government says it will require? It will require those and more unless it can do far more than it has demonstrated in the last nine years to keep its own house in order on the expenditure side. What new taxes will it introduce and why on earth will it not come clean with the Australian public and with this Parliament and give us those details?

That is a fundamental difference between, on the one hand, this deceitful Government, this Government that is not prepared to be honest and open with the Australian people, with the electorate, and, on the other hand, the coalition—the alternative government, the next government—which has so clearly articulated in great detail both the expenditure and the revenue proposals that a Hewson-led government will implement. Those proposals in the area of taxation are very wide ranging indeed.

They involve a reduction averaging 30 per cent in the income tax to be paid by every Australian personal income tax payer. They include the abolition of $20 billion of taxes that are now imposed on the cost of doing business in Australia, the cost of making goods and services in Australia, the cost of employing people in Australia—taxes like the wholesale sales tax, the most inefficient, archaic indirect tax system in the world. We will abolish that. We will also abolish the tax on jobs—payroll tax. It is absolutely ridiculous that a country such as ours, with the unemployment problems that we have facing us, should tax jobs, should tax employment, by having a tax on payrolls. We will also abolish a tax which has become an absolute milch cow for this Government over the nine years it has been in office—namely, fuel excise.

When the Hawke Government came into office in 1983, fuel excise was 6c a litre; today it is 26c a litre. That money has not gone into building roads or anything to do with motorists or transport. It has gone towards feeding the insatiable demand, the insatiable diet, that this Government has for spending, spending, spending. That policy has cost Australia very dearly indeed. It has cost jobs, jobs and jobs. It has cost economic growth and it has cost investment. It has reduced savings in this nation to the lowest level in our history.

We will abolish the fuel excise tax completely because it is such a major burden, not only on domestic motorists but, more importantly, on the transport industry in Australia—an industry that goes to the core of virtually all areas of economic activity in this nation of ours, huge as it is in terms of land mass, so highly dependent as it is on road transport for the distribution of goods. The transport system enters into every facet of production in Australia. It is mightily burdened by that excessive fuel excise and we will abolish it. Those are the differences between this Government and the alternative government.

The alternative government, the coalition, the next government, has put right up-front in the Fightback proposals of last November what it will do. We have spelt it out chapter and verse; we have detailed it dollar by dollar. What does this Government do? This Government says in the Budget that it will run out of money in effect in the next few years if it is to balance its books. It is going to increase taxes, but it is not going to tell people how it will do it. It is not going to tell people which taxes it is going to increase, other than naming two or three in the Budget which would have no hope on earth of providing the necessary revenue required to balance the books. It sneaks those ones out or buries them right down at the back of the Budget Papers.

The Government is not prepared to say anything else at all about what additional tax increases will so obviously, so clearly, so indisputably, be required in the next two, three or four years if it were to be re-elected—and thank heavens that is a very unlikely prospect. But if it were re-elected, as the Government said to the Australian people on Tuesday night in the Budget, `We are going to tax you more, but we are not going to tell you how, where or how much'.

We even had the deposed Prime Minister, Mr Hawke—the Prime Minister that the current Prime Minister, Paul Keating, so brutally assassinated politically last December after working on undermining his own Government for two or three years—last night saying publicly, to his credit, that the Government's proposals and forecasts were all of a nature which would make one question the bona fides of this Government in terms of where it is going and what it is doing to the Australian people. That is the bottom line of what Bob Hawke was saying last night in his well publicised comments and that is why I have brought this motion to the Senate.

The motion notes that the Government will have to raise taxes for its unfunded personal income tax cuts promised for 1994-95. To that should be added—and it is in fact included in a notice of motion that I have on the Notice Paper which was the subject of a question here in the Senate today—that it is not just to pay for the unfunded personal income tax cuts promised for 1994-95, but also to pay for the absolutely irresponsible profligate blow-out in government spending that has occurred over recent years, notably last year and even more notably and regrettably this year when there will be an increase in Commonwealth government spending of the order of $9 billion. In real terms the figure will be about $6 billion. That comes at a time when the private sector is struggling to find an economic environment in which it is able to save, invest, grow and create jobs. There has not been a more irresponsible Budget introduced into this Parliament since the Whitlam Budgets of the 1970s, and we all know what those Budgets did to the economy and this great nation of ours.

Indeed, on some measures, this Budget is worse than any of the Whitlam Budgets. The deterioration in the Commonwealth's budgetary situation in the last two years has been unprecedented. It well exceeds the deterioration that occurred in the years of the Whitlam Government. It is only three years ago that the Budget was in surplus to the tune of $8 billion—thanks not to this Government but to cyclical events. I must say also that at that time there was some greater expenditure constraint than is evident or available to the Government, quite obviously, today. But we had an $8 billion surplus in the Budget in 1989-90. That surplus fell to less than $2 billion in 1990-91 and was totally reversed in 1991-92 to a deficit of $9.3 billion, despite the fact that only 12 months ago, when the 1991 Budget was introduced, the deficit for the year was forecast to be $4.7 billion. That deficit forecast had to be revised four times in the course of the year and the actual outcome was $9.3 billion which was a 100 per cent error on the original forecast.

Currently we have a deficit which is published at $13.4 billion, but when we take account of the creative accounting involved in that, the figure is really closer to $20 billion. Indeed, on my figuring, the actual underlying Budget deficit this year will be $20.5 billion. I am not alone in making that forecast. The very respected economic commentator Alan Kohler says $21 billion, I think, and another very respected economic commentator, Max Walsh, puts the figure at around the same level. So I am not on my own in making that estimate of a $20,000m hole in the Government's finances this year.

What does that do to the economy? It does a lot of very serious things. It means that the Government has to borrow that money; it has to go out into the marketplace and find the money to fill the hole—and that is what it is going to do. If any of the Government's rhetoric about a recovery in the economy being under way is to be believed, it follows automatically that that Government borrowing requirement will thwart and chop off at the ankles any recovery in the private sector that could occur, because the private sector will be out there in the marketplace having to compete for funds for investment, for job growth and for increased production. The private sector will be out there competing with an avaricious, greedy government that is unable to control its own spending proclivities.

Inevitably that means either a potential major increase in interest rates, if the money is to be borrowed domestically, or, if the Government reverses its policy of recent years and goes overseas to find some of the funds required, pressure on our exchange rate and the balance of payments and an increase in the already horrendous debt that this nation owes to the rest of the world. Australia has a net debt to the rest of the world of about $150 billion. Our gross debt to the rest of the world is about $180 billion. That figure compares with only $30 billion or thereabouts when this Government came to office in 1983.

The really soft underbelly of the Australian economy has been massively exposed and damaged by the actions and policies of this Government. That underbelly is, of course, as it has been for a long time, the external account—our balance of payments, our ability to compete in the world, to be able to afford to buy what we want to buy from the rest of the world by selling to the rest of the world. We are unable to do that. Taking everything into account—goods and services and also all of the invisible items like profit flows, interest payments on accumulated debt and so on—Australia is in hock to the rest of the world again this year by an estimated $15 billion on the Government's own figures. That is a worsening of more than $3 billion on the year just gone by. Indeed, that $15 billion is an optimistic estimate; the more likely figure is about $17 billion, but I will not argue about a billion dollars here or there. The overall fact of great concern is that Australia will be going into debt to the rest of the world again this year by a figure approaching $1 1/2 billion dollars—certainly well over a billion dollars—every month.

That will all be compounded by the fact that, as the decade progresses, the Government will have to find more revenue to meet the hole in its Budget. That will come from new taxes. It cannot come from anywhere else unless there are absolutely savage increases in the level of existing tax. Where will those new taxes come from? What form will they take? One can only speculate on that. It depends on whether the Socialist Left faction of Senator Bolkus—I see him coming back into the chamber—holds sway. If there were to be another Labor government, you could be as sure as eggs that a fair chunk of it would come from that hoary old Labor notion of a wealth tax.

A wealth tax has to be on the cards in any re-elected Labor Government because the Left is increasing in strength, as Senator Bolkus satisfyingly knows. His prospects within his own Party of getting Labor to agree to a wealth tax have increased quite startlingly and worryingly in the last couple of years. A wealth tax has to be on the cards if Senator Bolkus's faction sees the light of day in terms of overall control of the Labor Party.

We will also find a big increase in tax revenue—a rip-off of taxpayers—through another old Labor favourite of bracket creep. This Government refuses to give back to taxpayers the amount it has ripped off them simply because they have paid more tax through moving into a higher tax bracket as a result of an increase in prices—that is, inflation. Bracket creep is a time-honoured device of this Government for raising revenue and, obviously, that will continue in bigger measure.

If the Government is going to honour its so-called promises to provide personal income tax cuts in 1994-95 and 1995-96, there are two other sources of revenue to finance those cuts. One would have to be an increase in the taxes on business. This Government has taxed business blind over the last nine years. All the portents are that it would have to continue to do so in the next few years if it were re-elected. Of course, increased taxes on business, particularly on the cost of doing business—on the cost of producing goods and services—automatically means a tax on investment and a tax on jobs. How on earth can we expect to get job growth in this country if we continue to be saddled with a government that believes it can milk the cow of the private sector dry, and not expect it to suffer in terms of employment, profitability and investment as a result.

The final new tax that would obviously be a near certainty if this Government were re-elected would be the introduction of what Paul Keating, as the most articulate exponent ever, I think, of such a tax, pushed in 1985 before he got rolled by the trade union movement—that is, the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax or, to use our parlance, a goods and services tax. Paul Keating knows, and the Government knows, that the only long term solution to getting an efficient tax system in this country, where the burden of taxes on business is reduced and the burden of tax on individuals is reduced, therefore restoring incentive, encouragement and reward to them, is to massively restructure the tax system. That has to involve adopting a tax of the nature of a goods and services tax, which virtually every other developed country in the world has and which more than 100 other developing countries have.

All of the high growth countries in the world, and all the economies of the western world, have a goods and services tax to some degree. We are the laggard. What we are proposing in the Fightback proposal is to try to bring the Australian tax system at least part way into the twentieth century and hopefully prepare it for its vital role in the twenty-first century.

The difference between our proposals and what the Government will inevitably be forced to do through its goods and services tax is that our goods and services tax proposals are accompanied by massive tax reductions in other areas, as I have outlined earlier. They are also accompanied by very generous compensation measures to take account of the one-off 4 per cent price impact that would occur from the introduction of a GST. Never has there been any indication from the Government that its introduction of a GST, or a value added tax, would be accompanied by that massive restructuring. It would simply use it as a continuing milch cow.

Those are the reasons why I move this motion on behalf of the coalition. We now have a Budget before this Parliament which has to be debated over the weeks ahead which is a totally irresponsible, spend-now-pay-later Budget. `Get the few goodies now'. They are pretty limited, although they cost a lot of money. `Let's get ourselves over the election line and then let's slug the Australian taxpayer to pay for it over the years ahead'. That is a dishonest form of government in the extreme sense.

That is why this motion, amongst other things, condemns the Government for its irresponsible spend-now-pay-later, Bankcard Budget. That is why I believe members of the Australian public—the electorate—will turn increasingly against this Government. They see that the Government has no real solutions, no proposals that show any glimmer of tackling, let alone solving, the fundamental problems facing this economy. That is why I believe the Government will be dealt with accordingly by the electorate at the next election.

In the meantime, we have that Government in office and this Parliament is beholden to do all it can to bring to the attention of the Australian public just what is happening in this country in relation to taxes and government spending, government irresponsibility and profligacy. I hope this motion will have the support of the Senate so that the Senate, at least, can make its voice heard loud and clear about the very deep problems facing this nation and the very positive things that can be done to correct that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very surprised by Senator Short's motion that is before the Senate this evening. I really expected the Opposition to come in and move a motion congratulating the Government on its magnificent achievement of getting inflation down. That is an integral part of the Budget and a very important part of the Budget forecast.

PARA.TAB: Australia recorded a 2 per cent inflation rate in the last financial year—in other words, prices rose by 2 per cent, on average, for the year—versus 3 1/4 per cent, on average, recorded by our major trading partners. All the countries with which we normally trade averaged a 3 1/4 per cent rise in prices in the last financial year, which was well above the 2 per cent recorded in Australia. Clearly, on any indication, the Australian economy is becoming much more competitive and price sensitive compared with our major trading partners. There is absolutely no recognition of that by the Opposition in moving this motion here today.
The reaction from the Opposition about inflation is not correct. Inflation has come down for two important reasons.
Senator Reid interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid knows as well as I do that interest rates are now part of the base for the inflation rates in Australia. Every time we have brought interest rates down—on 13 occasions—there has been a reduction in inflation as measured through the various indexes. That is very important. We have also deregulated the economy significantly. There have been a number of price reductions, or pauses in price rises, as a result of increasing efficiencies in the Australian economy, as a result of those activities. That has held down pressures on prices in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I want to take up a specific point made just a moment ago by Senator Short. He claimed that there was a blow-out in Government spending in this Budget. That is totally wrong. We could nail this concept of a blow-out very quickly by simply looking at the record—the history of Budget outcomes and government spending as recorded in Budget Paper No. 1. At page 5.6, table 3 shows the history of government spending, government revenue and government outcomes going back to 1953-54. That table shows very clearly that government spending this financial year is expected to be 27 per cent of gross domestic product—27 per cent of Australia's national income if you like—compared with 28.8 per cent in the last year the Liberals were in government in this country.In 1982-83, 28.8 per cent of our gross domestic product was taken by government spending.
Debate interrupted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only one positive thing about this Budget—it will be the Labor Government's last. For 10 long years Australians have been fed lies, misinformation and broken promises. We have had J-curves, Priority Ones, One Nations and even Budgets that were meant to bring home the bacon. We have had 17 economic statements by this Government, cumulatively achieving a legacy of gloom and hopelessness.

PARA.TAB: Budgets have regularly contained Prime Minister Keating's glib one-liners and false promises about greater things that lie ahead. I remind you, Mr President, of Mr Keating's 1990 Budget Speech. He said:
. . . the current account will markedly improve and employment will pick up. . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is what he said in 1990. This was delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession. Today it sounds like a sick joke.

PARA.TAB: Prime Minister Keating, the architect of the recession `we had to have', retains no credibility at all. Australians will no longer believe the man whose Government has put nearly a million people out of work; who has bankrupted thousands of small businesses by enforcing impossibly high interest rates; and who has crushed the living standards of low and middle income earners by high taxation. This credibility problem of Mr Keating overshadows the Budget.

But first, Mr President, let me put the document in context—the Australian scene after 10 years of hard Labor. Trevor Sykes, writing in the Bulletin recently in an article titled `The recession we didn't have to have', presented a scathing picture of Labor's policies. He said that Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: now has one in nine of its people out of work; where regional unemployment is high enough to be labelled depression rather than recession; where a large proportion of our youth has been condemned to the dole queues for so long that they are probably permanently unemployable; where greater inequality of income exists than ever before in Australian history; and where large sections of Australian manufacturing industry have been dismantled.

Mr President, what a sad legacy; what a tragedy for Australia. The figures do not lie. Under Labor, per capita real income has fallen to 6 per cent below the OECD average. That is the Kelty contribution to productivity in this country. As a trading nation, we continue to slip. We are now nineteenth in terms of our share of exports. And, of course, our foreign debt stands at a massive $144 billion—up from $40 billion when Labor came to office; an increase of over $100 billion in just 10 years.

PARA.TAB: Just look for a moment at the worst manifestation of Paul Keating's incompetent economic management, and that is unemployment. Unemployment rates are around 11 per cent, the highest since the Great Depression. When we add the underemployed, those who have given up, those who have been forced on to training schemes who actually want to work, the figure is, of course, substantially higher.

Youth unemployment at somewhere around 35 per cent, and in some places even higher, is a calamity. Even more serious than youth unemployment is the picture for the long term unemployed. Long term unemployment is projected to reach 300,000 in 1994 from 190,000 in 1993. Further, 680,000 Australian children are now living in families where neither parent has a job. One in six Australian children aged 14 or under have no family breadwinner with a job. Seventy-five thousand Australian children are now on the street. Remember the promise—no Australian child will live in poverty? We do not just have a financial crisis in this country; we have a massive social crisis as well. And this Government has the nerve to refer to itself as a `caring government'.

Against that appalling background, what Australians had a right to expect was a government which addressed the need for sustainable job creation and, linked to that, an economic framework within which business might be more competitive and, thus, encouraged to rebuild and employ. On both counts Mr Keating has again unambiguously failed the Australian people. The massive spending in this Budget of Whitlamesque proportions is being directed towards rectifying the political effects of inappropriate economic policies rather than the fundamental causes of our economic malaise. Instead of embracing a comprehensive program of major economic reform, as the coalition has done in Fightback, to address honestly Australia's serious problems, the Labor Party is applying a bandaid to the consequences of its policy failures—that is, unacceptable levels of unemployment.

There are two statistics in this Budget which demonstrate its failure in stark terms. The first is that the current account deficit is expected to rise from $11.9 billion last year to $15 billion this year. The second is that the Budget forecasts yet another fall in business investment. In other words, despite all the pain Australians have had to suffer under Labor, we remain uncompetitive and there is still little incentive for business to invest and grow.

I suppose we should not be surprised by the former statistic as the 1992 World Competitiveness Report prepared in Switzerland rated us just sixteenth out of 22 OECD countries on a scale of competitiveness. Australia did not have to have a recession. There were other policies open. But within the constraints of Labor Party politics, an arrogant and incompetent Paul Keating drove up interest rates to impossible levels. This `scorched earth' economics of the man the Labor Caucus subsequently rewarded drove thousands of small businesses to the wall, with horrific unemployment consequences. But now, rather than tackle the fundamental weaknesses, he attaches this bandaid of make-work schemes in a short term effort to improve the figures—schemes which have been found deficient on so many previous occasions. It is another example of Paul Keating's incredible arrogance, because to do otherwise would have required him to admit error.

This credibility gap is vitally important. If the community cannot believe the Prime Minister, it logically follows that they will not have confidence in his policies. Only a few months ago this Prime Minister, in his One Nation statement, estimated a Budget deficit of $6.8 billion. It ended at $9.3 billion and now we are expected to find an extra $13.4 billion to put on the tab. In fact, it is at least $16.1 billion. The Government will sell a few assets and transfer some Reserve Bank profits in an effort to fund just a small proportion of this annual deficit. I think the sale of Qantas will reduce its Budget deficit for this year by about 8 per cent, and Qantas will be gone forever. Some commentators argue that without the Prime Minister's creative accounting, the real anticipated deficit is nearer or just over $20 billion. This is why the people cannot trust Paul Keating; it is why they do not believe him.

Only a few months ago, again in One Nation, Mr Keating predicted growth figures for this year of 4.75 per cent. Now he estimates growth at 3 per cent. He let Australians believe that highly optimistic forecast—I think today Senator Button referred to it as a `scenario' rather than a `forecast'—which he claimed would magically produce jobs, surpluses and tax cuts. He let us believe that it had some independent bureaucratic sanction. Now, of course, we know that it came out of the Minister's office. Cruel, false expectations created for base political motives—that is the style of Paul Keating, and Australians are unimpressed.

Only this week we read in the Sydney Morning Herald that in the preparation of the 1989 Budget the Prime Minister's staff directed the joint economic forecasting group to reduce the current account deficit forecast from the Treasury's estimate of $21 billion to $18.5 billion. The figure turned out to be $22 billion. What was Mr Keating's response this week to such an allegation of political manipulation? The typical Keating response: he attacked the journalist.

That is why I say that the whole Budget has to be looked at in the context of the background of this man, promoted by his mates—a man who has never been endorsed by the Australian people as the expected Prime Minister. This lack of credibility makes understandable such a grossly irresponsible Budget that does nothing to rebuild Australia's competitiveness.

This is a secret tax Budget. Apart from the increases in the Medicare levy, tobacco excise and fringe benefits tax, there is a raft of other increases, many of which have not yet been concentrated upon. Budget Paper No. 1 notes that the Government has made tax increases in 22 other different areas. What plans for tax increases does this Government have after the election? We have already had a hint of new taxes not detailed in the Budget further down the track. We are told:

SPEECH.PARA: If the fiscal position is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain revenue structure.
What does that mean? It means further tax hikes and most likely the introduction of a goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister must know how imperative it is to reduce taxes on production, because all other industrialised nations have already had to make the shift from taxes on production to taxes on consumption. He must know that, without Australia reforming its tax system likewise, our businesses—those who employ—suffer a competitive disadvantage. He argued for such a restructuring of the tax system in 1985. But rather than tell the truth, which would be for him to abandon his opportunity to engender fear in the forthcoming campaign, he says that the new taxes will be on business. Surely not even Paul Keating would be so crazy in Australia's current dire economic predicament as to increase tax on those who employ and provide long term sustainable jobs.

Nothing is surer than that Australia, in these days when the world economies are so interdependent, will have to reform its taxation system to be competitive. This will mean a tax on consumption as taxes on income are reduced. The difference is that on one side the coalition is being honest and on the other side—surprise, surprise—Paul Keating is not telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the first time.

—It is not the first time. In this Budget the Government has provided for a range of temporary make-work schemes and training programs costing $3.5 billion. This will create 27,000 jobs and hide 430,000 unemployed in training places with no guarantee of a job at the end of their training.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you will note from the document that the make-work schemes end in two years time. Job creation projects should have been focused on increasing the economy's productivity and encouraging business investment through changes in the tax system rather than electorally motivated symbolic gestures. One wonders how many people under these schemes will end up with skills which can be utilised in the work force in the longer term; or will it be a case of employed one day, permanently unemployed the next? There is a place for training schemes, but even then they can only provide assistance to a very small proportion of the unemployed.

Under the special youth employment training program, between 1978 and 1983 only 13,500 teenagers received assistance, which is less than 10 per cent of teenage unemployment. Similarly, for Jobstart, only about 15 per cent of jobs created were new jobs. Does anyone remember the Government's Priority One: Young Australia, a youth traineeship scheme?
Senator Walters interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters will remember that advertising and promotion cost half a million dollars. But how many jobs did it produce? How many traineeships were created out of the scheme? The Government boasted in 1985 that 75,000 traineeships would be created. Did it reach its target? Where are these people now? Are they some of the casualties of the current recession?

PARA.TAB: The essential problem is lack of demand from employers. Until such time as this issue is addressed, job creation schemes of the sort announced in the Budget can be only superficial bandaid measures and training schemes will have minimal effect in overcoming Australia's unemployment tragedy. It is this issue of lack of demand from employers which should have been principally addressed in this Budget. The Government should have addressed the burden of still uncompetitive infrastructure.

Micro-economic reform has stalled under this Government. The waterfront, transport and communication industries are still not efficient. Elsewhere the results are similar. For example, while the power industry has now improved productivity, the massive debt of electricity utilities has caused power prices to remain high. Then there is the issue of the insidious on-costs which have risen significantly during this Government's period of office. The accord may have delivered some wage restraint at the expense of productivity, but businesses have been lumbered with the superannuation levies, training levies, fringe benefits tax, workers compensation changes, payroll tax and a raft of other imposts.

The Business Council of Australia survey of May 1992 noted that on-costs add 40 per cent to the wage bill. Is it any wonder that business is struggling and investment spluttering? Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that between 1989-90 and 1990-91 superannuation costs increased by 18 per cent, fringe benefits costs by 17.3 per cent and payroll tax by 11.5 per cent. The Government's disastrous increase in the superannuation levy will only add further to business costs.

Then there is the taxation system. Not only is Labor's taxation system biased against business, as I have outlined, but the total tax take is uncompetitively high and is further increased by this Budget. The reason it is uncompetitively high is that Paul Keating refuses to cut government expenditure because it might cost short term votes. Sadly, under the Keating economic regime, it is easier for businesses to retrench and relocate than it is to invest and remain in Australia.

It is time that the Government encouraged business instead of putting road blocks in its path. Until such time that policies are introduced which lift the burden from our producers and exporters, the misery of high unemployment levels will continue; yet instead of opting for courageous economic measures the Government has opted for easy ones, for the status quo over reform, and for its own self-interest over the public interest. Therein lies the stark contrast between Labor and the coalition's Fightback program.

Labor has put down five economic strategies in the last 18 months as it has fumbled in its search for survival. By contrast, our strategy is clear. It is designed to boost economic growth by building a more competitive and productive economy and a more attractive climate for investment. We have committed ourselves to creating two million new jobs by the end of the decade by reducing business costs and other impediments to growth such as the inflexible labour market. Our strategy of widening the taxation base by introducing a goods and services tax and reducing government spending will create a more productive environment.

We have already said that we will cut taxes on business by $20 billion. Payroll tax—an insidious tax on employment—will be abolished. That measure alone will create 200,000 new jobs. Similarly, abolishing the training guarantee levy and freezing the level of compulsory employer contributions to employee superannuation will save a minimum of 50,000 to 100,000 jobs.

We will speed up the pace of micro-economic reform of national transport, shipping, telecommunications, aviation and utilities infrastructure which currently impose cost disadvantages of between 20 per cent and 50 per cent on Australian producers. Our anti-inflationary strategy and reductions in the size and cost of government will significantly lower real interest rates and produce competitive exchange rates.

Our industrial relations policy will provide wide-ranging labour market reforms to encourage voluntary employment agreements and to allow workers and employers to negotiate at the workplace so that wages are based on productivity. We have also committed ourselves to a youth training wage which would create over 100,000 new job opportunities. Additionally, Austrade will provide the long term unemployed with a chance to re-enter the full time work force and gain valuable on the job training.

This is the contrast that the country has before it. Labor: unfunded programs, spending that does not improve competitiveness, short term, make-work schemes and hints of new and expanded taxes. The coalition: a detailed program on the table, fully funded, which reforms and reduces tax to provide incentives for growth and employment. Add to that a Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who more than any one person is responsible for Australia's unemployment tragedy, who has lost credibility and who does not deserve to be trusted. It should be clear why I can say so confidently that this is Labor's last Budget—and thank goodness for that, say so many Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with mixed feelings that I present the Australian Democrats' response to the 1992-93 Budget. I have feelings of relief that in minimal part—I stress in minimal part—people are coming before ideology. But I have feelings of regret that it is too little, too late. I have feelings of vindication that some measures which we Democrats have advocated for years have found their way at last into the Treasurer's program.

PARA.TAB: This Budget reminds me of guilty parents who buy presents for their children, the children they have abused, but who book up those presents on a credit card with very little hope of ever paying that credit card off. They do it in part because they have a commitment—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I seek your guidance on an important matter. Senator Button is not in the chamber tonight for this important debate. It seems to me that as a matter of protocol he should be in the chamber. Indeed, there is not a Minister in the chamber. Have you heard from Senator Button whether there is any particular reason why he is not able to be present in the chamber this evening?

—I would like to speak very briefly on the point of order, Mr President. The most outrageous breach of protocol is to raise a specious point of order just after Senator Coulter has started to deliver his speech as a Party leader in here. All the Party leaders are given the courtesy—as the Leader of the National Party, Senator Boswell, will be given by us—of being heard in silence in order to be able to make their contribution. It is an outrage that this specious point of order has been raised in this way. Senator Coulter should be free to proceed to deliver his speech in the proper and considered manner. Senator Hill's speech received all the consideration on this side that it warranted.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. I thank Senator McMullan for those remarks. I would hope that Senator Kemp observes the niceties of this chamber. As I said, this Budget reminds one of guilty parents who buy presents for their children, the children they have abused, but who book those presents up on a credit card that they have little hope of ever paying off. They do it in part because they have a commitment to their children, but they do it also because the social worker's review is almost due and they do not want their children taken away from them.

PARA.TAB: I do not doubt Labor's historical concern for the people of Australia, especially for the poor and disadvantaged. Indeed, it was Labor which instituted most of the great social reforms of the nine decades since Federation. Curtin, Chifley and Jack Lang were stars in the firmament of Australia's reform history. Universal suffrage, social security, sickness and hospital benefits and free education are rights and privileges that we owe to Labor. But now Labor is tired and run down, like the metaphorical parents of whom I spoke.

Labor has deserted its roots and its support. Instead, since 1983 it has embraced trendy economic ideas which now have turned sour. Labor has abused its children. For those Australians to whom its brand of moderate socialism once brought hope and opportunity, Labor has now led to the dole queues, to bankruptcy courts and foreign takeovers. Australians are bewildered, disillusioned, alienated and angry. The land of opportunity has eluded them, the welfare state has withdrawn, and now the god of economic rationalism has failed. We find in this Budget little acknowledgment by Labor that its god has forsaken it.

The level playing field is still the Labor icon of the 1990s, along with deregulation and privatisation. So is reliance, though cautious and sober, on the econometric forecasting which has let Labor down in the past and which is still, as David Clark said in the Australian Financial Review recently:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . pretending to know what would have happened if what does happen hadn't.

Although the big picture has not changed greatly, there are token attempts in this Budget to clean up the mess that economic rationalism has left behind. There is, after all, a judgment day just ahead. Labor is once again courting the Australian people—not with the reforms which once won the allegiance of the workers, but with token handouts designed, probably in vain, to pacify people into voting Labor once again at the next election. There are not as many of them as we expected and some of them, in any case, we strongly support, although we would like to have seen them two years ago.

PARA.TAB: In the area of health, the Australian Democrats welcome the Budget's reaffirmation of the Government's commitment to a publicly funded health care system, a commitment which we have consistently shared. We too

SPEECH.PARA: have consistently called for an increase in the Medicare levy to strengthen the public health care system. Just the same, we are disappointed that the Budget once again fails to initiate structural reform of Medicare which could remedy its problems. It is therefore difficult to see the Budget's health measures as much more than a belated and somewhat ad-hoc effort to reduce hospital waiting lists immediately prior to the Federal election.

PARA.TAB: In social security, we obviously welcome pension increases, however illusory, although young unemployed people have once again missed out. The Government has finally extended eligibility for pensioner concessions to all part pensioners—a measure we have been advocating for some time—but we would extend it further to all retirees over 60 with an income of less than $15,000 per year.

I am happy to say that our repeated calls for welfare rights centres have finally penetrated the Government's somewhat deaf ear. In fact, several of the social security measures have been the subject of Democrat amendments or Democrat urging over the past two years. We could have saved a lot of heartache and hardship had Labor's guilty conscience regarding its traditional constituents surfaced much earlier.

In agriculture, the farm sector is one of the most neglected of Labor's children. Even now, guilt-tripping has led only to modest gift-giving. We are pleased to see an increase in funding to the rural adjustment scheme, even though it drops dramatically in a year. We note the $800,000 for rural counselling services and the $1.8m to rural community services. But will honourable senators now consider these amounts paltry in view of the crisis in the rural community and the need for substantial social and emotional support? In this area we are also appalled to find no mention of tariffs. Labor's insistence on their reduction has reduced the farmers to beggars. We, on the other hand, want them frozen until a formal inquiry can decide on the protection of our primary producers from cheap imports.

In manufacturing, we are relieved that the Government is assisting the beleaguered textile, clothing and footwear industry, the pharmaceutical industry and the food industry. But we are disappointed at other spending cuts in manufacturing. In research, increased funding, however minimal to scientific research, development and commercialisation is always good news, although the Budget substantially has recycled the One Nation statement in this area.

We note, however, that the Government has reversed One Nation's proposed cuts in tax concessions to private sector R&D, and its retention of support for rural R&D. The Government has repeatedly identified the biggest failure in the `clever country' not in our scientific enterprise but in the commercialisation of the appropriate fruits of that research. In the absence of enough large indigenous companies in Australia, there is a role for direct government investment in this commercialisation. This Government is neither clever nor wise in its failure to see this.

After years of neglect of rail transport, Labor has finally carried out the promises made in One Nation to boost rail funding. This, we have demanded for years. But there is not enough, and it is perhaps far too late. Rural branch lines are threatened with closure—many have already closed—and massive job losses are likely.
As income tax rebates in remote area zones are increased they are another guilty concession to a much abused sector.

Tobacco excise has increased, as we have advocated for years, but again it indicates a tardiness on the part of Labor as it timidly waited until the non-smoker component of the electorate increased beyond the size of the smoker component so that that concession was electorally acceptable.

In relation to the environment, it is clear that this Government does not understand ecologically sustainable development and that it certainly has no commitment to it. Having spent a considerable amount of money and taken a great deal of the time of industries and the conservation movements, the Government has now shown up the whole ESD process as an expensive vote-buying smokescreen.

In recent days we have seen a two-day meeting organised by the Government break up at the end of the first day when it became clear to both environmental and industry groups that they were wasting their time and that the Government had no intention of implementing the good and practical recommendations that had come from the ESD committees. Similarly, we have seen the Federal Government quietly drop its commitment to the 20 per cent Toronto greenhouse target, even though there is abundant evidence that this could be achieved without detracting from Australia's economic performance. Indeed, many commentators say that there could be considerable economic advantages in that direction.

It is solid evidence like this on the record that convinces me that the present Budget allocations to ESD and greenhouse are merely further window-dressing and will not result in any real moves on either front. ESD funding is commendable in any case, but only when it is spent in an environmentally responsible manner. That seems unlikely, for instance, if national forest policy—a recipient—allows continued logging in old growth forests and in wilderness areas and no protection of native forests. The national forest funding is, moreover, pitiful. I heard just yesterday that the Wilderness Society and forest conservation groups—voluntary bodies—will spend more on forest protection in the next four years than will the Federal Government.

We welcome increased spending on energy conservation and renewable energy, but the plain fact is that the amounts are trivial in relation to the size of the problem. For some years now the Democrats have proposed a modest levy on fossil fuels, with exports exempted, to raise $750m for the development of a sustainable energy industry and the upgrading of urban public transport. This is the sort of money that is needed. It is the sort of money which is not allocated in this Budget. We welcome the planned injection of $25m to establish a national energy grid, but deplore the fact that there is no indication that the planning of generation options will conform at all to the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

In relation to education, the open learning scheme is a step in the right direction, but the claim that all Australians will be able to benefit from tertiary study if they have access to a television set and a letterbox is farcical unless the open learning program is free of charge. We reject a user-pays element in education, whether it applies to Austudy, voluntary student loans or English as a second language programs. We congratulate the Government, however, on its increase in post-graduate awards, which it clearly adopted after reading our Getting to Work document.

In relation to women, we are pleased to see increased funding for the Affirmative Action Agency and continuing expenditure on child-care, although it clearly needs to be increased further. We are not so pleased to find no incentives for private and public enterprises to establish work-based child-care programs. Where are the measures to make child-care, parental leave, job-sharing and sick leave adjustments for the care of a sick child, part of the minimum standard for any workplace bargain agreement?

On consideration, we believe that some of the Governments gifts are a little shop worn. Some recipients do not score much at all, even in an area such as trade where there is much more to be done.Where are the tariffs? Where are assertive bilateral trading policies? Where are the streamlined anti-dumping procedures that are so vital for the protection of Australian producers? Where are the simple, inexpensive remedies, such as the mandatory `Buy Australian' labelling scheme we have been promoting?

We commend the Treasurer for the offers he has made, but they are certainly too little. We hope they are not too late. It is precisely this tardiness of timing that is suspect. Pension increases scheduled for March are being brought forward to January; the remote area income tax rebates go into effect in January; a tax on car parking fringe benefits, which we applaud, is postponed until April; and the increased Medicare levy is postponed until next July. So there are no prizes for guessing the election date.

In these recessionary times, however, the aim of the Budget, the primary objective of any government, must be to provide jobs for the one million Australians whom Labor's policies have deprived of the right to work. This is where the erring parents have finally tried to make amends, although whether it is too late is difficult to say. In any case, Labor has at last distanced itself from its economic rationalist mentors enough to initiate a broad program of public spending which it claims will create tens of thousands of jobs in the short term.

The program is linked, as we have suggested for years, to local government bodies. Obviously, we support this link, although we also encourage all public and private bodies to apply for job creation funding when they have appropriate projects in hand. The Budget's new jobs will cost Australia $742m in the first year. We consider this money well spent. But the Australian Democrats recently released a plan to provide, conservatively speaking, 150,000 new jobs. This would have cost a total of $2.5 billion which we would raise by means of a jobs levy of 1 1/4 per cent on the employed.

We commend the Government's jobs initiative, therefore, but feel it does not go far enough. It is not reducing the unemployment rate by much at all, and this is admitted by the Government. I can well imagine the feelings of unemployed Australians with families they cannot support, mortgages they cannot pay and fading memories of the lifestyles they are unlikely ever to enjoy again, when they hear that unemployment will be more or less constant over the next few years.

Labor is to be congratulated on its honesty, but certainly not to be congratulated on its policies. A 10 per cent unemployment rate is simply unacceptable. The fact that the Government cannot bring it down means that Australia's economy is in a disastrous state.

Let us examine the economic fundamentals. The Budget projects a fall in business investment of 2 per cent. Investment is going into housing instead of into productive plant and machinery. Under the present deregulated banking system, this could lead simply to another property boom and another boom-bust cycle. The desperately low level of household savings will slide even further. Import penetration is rising in many sectors. Growth is estimated at only 3 per cent, but our current account deficit will increase by 25 per cent and our foreign debt will continue to grow.

I wish to be clear. I do not criticise the Budget deficit per se. The tragedy is that the warning signs were not heeded earlier. We do criticise the lack of a sustainable funding base for job creation—and the emphasis there is on a sustainable funding base for job creation, such as we have provided in our Getting to Work economic package. Without such a base, this Budget can deal only—and this we have seen already—with short term job creation. It cannot set guidelines for long term policy at all.

High levels of unemployment are here to stay, unless we create permanent jobs in both public and private sectors. One-off labour market programs in one Budget will not address the underlying problems. That is why I repeat that we need a jobs levy to fund at least 150,000 jobs a year over five years. We cannot afford to run large deficits forever. In living on tick, as we do, we are selling off the farm. What do we do when our creditors foreclose?

Although the rationalists have lost the battle over job creation programs, unfortunately they have won the war to accelerate the dismantling of the public sector. We object to the acceleration of privatisation. In addition to the airlines, it is indefensible to sell Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Ltd and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. They are saleable because they are efficient and profitable. Why can the country not continue to reap the benefit? We opposed privatisation of the gas pipeline and the Housing Loan Insurance Corporation the first time the Government proposed it. Our view has not changed. Labor's insistence on this betrayal of its socialist heritage is just another demonstration that economic rationalism, though reeling, is still ruling.

If the Government appears unable to free itself of its failed theories, it seems equally powerless to shake off the shackles of a costly Cold War mentality. The defence budget demonstrates graphically that Labor is unable to reorder its priorities to meet the challenges of the 1990s. The 1992 defence policy is essentially the same one put forward five years ago—a policy inspired by fear of the Soviet Union's naval and air base in Vietnam, and by the suspicion that the USSR and Libya were infiltrating the South Pacific.

But in 1992, the real threats to our security are not military threats. It is not an armed attack that Australians fear, but unemployment, national debt, environmental degradation, violence and crime. As our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, has said, Australia's security environment is benign and there is every prospect that it will remain that way.

This is not to say that we do not need a defence force; we do. We need a true defence force. We need to monitor and protect our territory and our fishing zone. We need to guard the security of shipping on the high seas, and we need to participate in United Nations peacekeeping operations. But we do not need to build and buy submarines and frigates whose primary role is to defend United States aircraft carriers in a war with the Soviet Union. We do not need F111 bombers which Mr Beazley, our Cold War Minister for Defence, had earmarked for bombing the Soviets out of Cam Ranh Bay. And we certainly do not need to keep throwing money at security threats which do not exist while claiming we cannot fund solutions to the real challenges that face us.

It remains an unpalatable fact that this year the Government will spend $1.2 billion on new submarines and frigates. That is almost four times the amount to be spent on our 10-year Landcare program to combat degradation costing us upwards of $1 billion every year. I give another example. The amount allocated to military research this year alone is more than $200m. But the Government is putting little more than one-tenth of that amount into renewable energy and energy conservation measures. Investigation of the greenhouse effect, the most serious challenge to our way of life that we face today, runs a very poor second to our quest for new and better ways of killing and destroying.

In our Getting to Work statement we propose defence cuts of $1.25 billion, eliminating the submarine and frigate programs. Much of this is either capital intensive or involves foreign labour. Some $450m of the savings would be used to help companies and workers convert to civilian production. The rest would go into restructuring industry and funding badly needed public infrastructure programs—on shore in this country, employing Australians in peaceful work. These savings, plus the revenue from the jobs levy, would therefore net us nearly $4 billion.

Our colleague Dr Hewson in the other place this week described the Government's proposals as a `Bankcard Budget'. But it is economic rationalism, of which Dr Hewson is an even more ardent advocate, that has created the social and economic chaos that made a Bankcard Budget necessary. Let us make no mistake. Under Dr Hewson's anorexic economics, the pain would be even greater.

We have to accept some degree of living on tick for the moment, but we must set up programs and structures that will eventually lead this great country out of recession and into solvency. This Government must stop neglecting its primary responsibility to the citizens of Australia and the environment in which they live. Like the Opposition, it has for too long fanatically embraced the religion of economic rationalism, and it has regularly sacrificed the people of Australia to this cruel god.

It is time for the Government to rekindle the flame of the light on the hill, snuffed out by the `econocrats' of Treasury and Finance through their willing pupil the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), formerly the Treasurer of Australia. It is the Government's responsibility to look beyond the next few years. It is the Government's responsibility to establish structures and implement programs which will deliver prosperity and sustain it in the long term. It is the Government's responsibility to serve not the ideology of economic rationalism but the people of Australia. We do not believe that this Budget discharges that responsibility.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1992 Federal Budget confirms the sorry tale of how this Labor Government has disgracefully mismanaged Australia during its guardianship over the past 10 years. Australia today is a sad scene—massive unemployment, declining numbers of primary and manufacturing industries, and dim prospects for a future investment growth in industries that can foster both export earnings and real sustainable jobs.

PARA.TAB: In two years the Australian people have been burdened by a Government that has gone from a forecast Budget surplus of $8 billion to an official deficit of $13.4 billion—and that takes some doing. The Budget deficit of $13.4 billion rises to some $17 billion when $1.6 billion from asset sales and the Reserve Bank's windfall profit of $2 billion are taken into consideration.

The overspending by the Government in this Budget is to take the wrong direction. Just when it has never been more important to go in a direction that will set Australia on the right path to recovery, instead the Government is burdening the country through its own high government spending. Since the 1991 Budget that spending has increased by 5.9 per cent. With growth in the economy forecast to be between 2.75 and 3 per cent, government spending is taking place at twice the rate of the growth of the economy. The interest bill on our public debt has gone up to 13.6 on the last year's debt level, all at a time when the interest rates are going down. Next year the interest bill on government borrowings is projected to go up to even 20 per cent.

Our current account deficit has been forecast to go up from $11.9 billion to $15 billion. Imports will come in faster and our exports—the hoped-for lifeline of this great exporting country—are not expected to increase. In this nation of efficient agricultural producers, food imports continue to grow. We now import $2.247 billion of food—up from $2.166 billion last year. Meat, dairy products, cereal and sugar imports have all risen over the last year.

An extra $1.2 billion will be spent as a result of this Budget on infrastructure and assistance to the unemployed, bringing up a total of $3.5 billion being spent by the Government this financial year just to try to get unemployment down below 10 per cent. What a target! That is the Government's great ambition—to have unemployment at 10 per cent.

The Government's emphasis is all wrong. There is nothing in this Budget about supporting the private sector where any real growth and true job creation will come from. Interest rates were kept too high for too long by this Government, crippling our vital rural and small business sectors. We have become used to the Government's rosy growth predictions. This year it says that there will be growth of 3 per cent, but these growth levels are not believed by business, as seen by its refusal to invest.

How many times has the Government issued statements to balance and prop up the economy? Since last year there has been the March industry statement, the November Prime Minister's economic statement, the discredited One Nation statement, and in February and July of this year there was the Government's national youth employment and training statement.

This year business investment dropped for the third successive year by 16 per cent. The year before it dropped by 11 per cent. The Budget forecast is that it will remain negative for the forthcoming year. Manufacturing industry is leaving this country in droves, driven out by non-competitive government policies and high interest rates. Real jobs are also being moved offshore. Already, $6.8 billion worth of Australian industry has moved to Asia. According to one survey carried out on the manufacturing industry in New South Wales, one in eight businesses is thinking about moving offshore as the only way to survive.

The Government has to face the question of where Australia now goes in a world of emerging trade blocs. This year a trade bloc was announced between the six Asian countries of Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, the Philippines, Singapore and Indonesia. This trade bloc contains 350 million people and excludes Australia but allows free trade between each of its states. Then last week the NAFTA agreement was announced between the USA, Canada and Mexico. This is the world's largest trade bloc of 360 million people, with combined economies of $6,000 billion. Australia has been waiting for a successful conclusion to the GATT Uruguay Round for the last 5 1/2 years while large trading blocs have been building up around us, and the Government has done nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sad story.

—It is a very sad story. Business in the private sector got no mention in this Budget—nothing, except for a $10 a week wage rise. This wage rise can only act to put pressure for similar wage rises in the community and remove the incentive for meaningful employee-employer relationships and negotiations.

PARA.TAB: This is done on top of the damage done during the year by the Government by means of the superannuation guarantee levy of 3 per cent to 5 per cent and an increase in the training guarantee levy from 1 per cent to 1.5 per cent. In particular, small business is being denied its great potential to employ and boost the economy. In this Budget small business did not receive its much needed capital gains tax roll-over or any lessening of its enormous tax and regulation burden.

The small business sector, which is the largest employer in this nation—there are about 800,000 of them—was invited to give its views on how it could employ youth and help reduce Australia's disgraceful figure of 35 per cent of youth unemployed. The small business sector fronted up to the recently held youth unemployment conference and told the Government what it required. It asked for one quarter of a year's delay in the collection of provisional tax; a reduction of provisional tax on the uplift factor—that is, the assumption by the Government that a business will make 10 per cent more this year than it made last year, at a time when approximately 17,000 small businesses have gone bankrupt and personal bankruptcies and insolvencies have occurred in the same year—an extension of the provisional tax variation error margin to 20 per cent so that small business will not be penalised for genuine mistakes when they are self-assessing; and the recognition of on-the-floor job training for small business.

The Government completely ignored the submission of the largest employer group in Australia—small business. They wasted their time and energy preparing their submission and got exactly nothing. The Government is a slow learner. After 10 years it still has not learnt that reduced direct and indirect costs on business equate to real and sustainable jobs—jobs that will be there when the Government's funding on mickey mouse jobs runs out and so do the jobs.

Of course, rural and mining industries contribute 62.4 per cent of our export earnings and continue to lift Australia out of its doldrums. Instead of helping those industries, the primary industries budget was cut by 8.7 per cent in the Government's desperate bid to rob a long term productive sector to gain short term politically motivated jobs. Rural industry has a great future that is not only the equal of its glorious past but an even better future. Over recent years rural industry has borne the brunt of natural disasters such as the droughts which presently grip 70 per cent of New South Wales and western Queensland. It has also been reduced to pauper status by the Government's high interest rate policy, leaving an average farm debt of $103,000 and an average farm income of minus $30,000 to service that massive debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can they keep going?
—They are going on faith and prayer at the moment.
—And not much hope.

—And little hope. On top of this, there has been a commodity price downturn for world prices in grain, sugar and dairying in particular, distorted by annual world subsidies of $412 billion. As exporters of 80 per cent of our produce, these corrupt rural market prices have returned prices, particularly for sugar and grain, below the cost of production.

PARA.TAB: This Budget does not even begin to address any of the concerns of the farming community. Instead, it removes $98m from primary industry. While the Budget shows $1,760m will be spent on primary industry, the industries themselves will contribute $774m in charges and levies and $438m in rebates on diesel fuel. Actual spending will only be $551m, down by $97.8m, despite many farmers still suffering from the same levels of negative income.

Today the Government brought in the IED scheme—income equalisation deposits—which the National Party and the Liberal Party introduced because they saw it as vital that farmers be able to put money away in good years to draw out during bad years. The Labor Government decimated the scheme in 1983 on coming to government, causing great hardship to farmers in the recent years of drought and low prices.

Withdrawal tax has been reduced from 29 per cent to 20 per cent. It increases maximum deposit levels to $300,000 and reduces minimum deposit levels to $1,000. After a hue and cry from the farming and scientific community, the Government has fortunately done an about-turn on its short-sighted approach to save $24m by reducing funding to all rural research and development. The Government should be condemned for threatening the long term future of rural industries and the supporting scientific community by a short-sighted grab for $24m.

The National Party and the Liberal Party commend the Government for reading the Fightback package and introducing a similar 25 per cent increase in remote area zone allowances. This will result in new levels of $338 in basic zone A, $1,173 in special zone A and $57 for zone B. While the $8m funding to encourage doctors in rural areas is welcomed, rural areas and country towns are also suffering from the distress of excessive unemployment. The grants of $345m for local government will largely miss the areas of rural Queensland.

Today the Government released the new national drought policy and flagged the direction of the new rural adjustment scheme. The last major drought we had was in 1982-83. The breaking of the drought coincided with the election of Mr Hawke as the new Prime Minister. He was able to capitalise on this and form the basis of his Government's growth when agriculture was able to bounce back after the drought. Agriculture grew at the rate of 45 per cent, contributing to growth after that recession of 6 per cent. This was possible because, during the last drought, the National-Liberal Party Government stood by primary industry with policies that retained our breeding stock and other fundamentals so that rural Australia could grow and bloom again after the drought was broken. The Government spent $244m in those days on keeping the national herd and flock for the future, thus protecting Australia's nest egg and enabling the economy to be kick-started once the drought had ended. In today's values that would equate to $415m.

In contrast, the present Government has provided a total RAS funding of $157m in 1991-92 and promised $166m for this year, which is an increase of $9m for an industry providing 28 per cent of Australia's total exports during a period of depressed commodity prices and when rural Queensland and New South Wales are absolutely drought stricken. In a nutshell, this stark comparison demonstrates this Government's lack of commitment to agriculture compared to the Fraser-Anthony total commitment to rural Australia.

The Government's scheme of assistance has been poorly targeted and never ahead of the game; it has rarely hit the mark and has been purely reactive. Today's national drought policy is long on rhetoric but short on what counts—money. In 1989, the Labor Government removed drought from the national disaster arrangement, which meant that the Federal Government ceased funding for drought from that time on. Despite widespread severe drought across most of Australia, which continues in New South Wales today, funding from the Commonwealth has been in a state of uncertainty since then—until today. Proper and fair access to the rural adjustment scheme and drought funding are vital to maintaining our internationally efficient export earning industries, yet the Budget forecast a further deterioration in our net export position and no improvement this year in our terms of trade.

A prosperous Australia has always had mining and agriculture going for it in a very strong way. We have developed this expertise over the last 100 years or more and it is recognised worldwide. We have internationally efficient and competitive rural industries, but they are in a mess because of the Government's high interest rate policy and massive international subsidies which are depressing world prices.

The final flaw in the Government's approach in this Budget is that it does not even begin to address increasing our export levels, despite this being the only way that we can begin to reduce our horrendous deficit of $13.4 billion and our forecasted excess of imports over exports of $15 billion. The Government boasts that manufacturing exports have increased at a rate of 10 per cent this year to June last, but research shows that growth has been from a low base. Most of the export growth has been with elaborately transformed manufactures, and 60 per cent of these have received government assistance. Much export growth has been recession driven as many companies are forced to export to maintain factory viability. When the domestic market improves, these exports, sold at under cost, will reduce.

Our top seven manufacturing exports are either motor vehicles or parts, aircraft parts or other iron and steel products, which have all received, or are receiving, assistance from the Government. This export growth has really been government driven and assisted and paid for. While manufacturing is important and should be supported, that support should never be at the expense of our great primary industries.

The Government's One Nation statement in February this year represented a Budget deficit of $9.3 billion and growth rates of 4.75 per cent. In six short months, the Government has managed to lead Australia into 11 per cent unemployment, a deficit of $13.4 billion and a forecasted growth of 2.75 per cent. At this rate of deterioration, how many more months of the Labor Government must Australia endure before an election leads to a change of government?

This Budget has been totally irresponsible in the way that it has overspent to fund short term jobs. The deficit was to be reduced by 1995 under One Nation. The deficit is now promised to be reduced only as soon as possible. Sadly, this irresponsible Budget will have to be paid for, at great cost, by all Australians. Inflation is expected to rise to 2 per cent; the Medicare levy is to rise to 1.4 per cent; fringe benefits taxes are to be extended; the tobacco excise is to be increased by $5 a kilogram; higher interest rates are predicted. What sort of Budget is this?

New taxes are inevitable. In fact, they are even predicted. The Government has foreshadowed increased taxes in 1995-96 if the deficit is not reduced to $5 billion or $6 billion. The Government has once again taken the wrong track. Through this Budget, the Government has deliberately not taken up opportunities to assist Australia to be competitive and to create real jobs and sustainable economic recovery. The vote buying potential of $1.2 billion for job creation schemes has been offered at the cost of neglecting to create real and sustainable jobs through the Government's encouragement of a climate for increased business investment and growth in our export earning industries.

The Budget has ignored the very sector that could brighten Australia's future. In this Budget the Government has ignored the rural sector, the manufacturing sector and the small business sector. It is the last Budget of a government that has squandered every opportunity Australia has had over the last 10 years. It no longer deserves the support of the Australian electorate. Time has run out for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening I was responding to a claim in Senator Short's motion that there had been a blow-out in the level of government spending in this Budget. I was referring to the historic record, which shows very clearly that that claim cannot be substantiated. In fact, the level of government spending this financial year in relation to our gross domestic product is 27.0 per cent. That is shown very clearly in table 3 on page 5.6 of Budget Paper No. 1. In 1982-83, the last year in which the Liberals were in power federally in this country, government spending was 28.8 per cent of gross domestic product. That is a much higher figure. Hardly can it be said, then, that government spending has blown out in this Budget.

PARA.TAB: I also note the very sloppy drafting of the motion moved by Senator Short. At point (b) he refers to what he says are—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you looked at some of your drafting lately?

—Those people opposite sit there time and time again and throw at us policy questions and so forth. As soon as we get up to reply, they become very sensitive; they cannot stand the heat and they ought to get out of the kitchen. I refer—and I am going to really dish it out—to point (b) in Senator Short's motion where he refers to what he says are new taxes. Then he goes on to talk about bracket creep, which is also known as fiscal drag—the phenomenon of wage and salary earners being propelled into higher income tax brackets through the effect of inflation on prices and wages. Bracket creep is hardly a new tax. It is simply an aspect of an existing tax that is the phenomenon of people moving into higher personal income tax brackets as a result of inflationary pressures.

PARA.TAB: I well remember the last Liberal Government which went to the people saying that it would act on bracket creep, it would act on fiscal drag. Mr Fraser went to the people and said that he would end taxation by stealth. That Government pledged itself to adjust all the income tax brackets for inflation. It actually pledged itself to every year increase the tax threshold for each bracket by the inflationary factor for that year. I think that lasted for about 1 1/2 years. After this very strong promise by the Fraser Government, the Liberal Treasurer at the time—I think it was Sir Phillip Lynch—then ditched it. He halved the factor; therefore saying that it was not important to adjust the tax brackets for inflation. Finally, we saw Mr Howard, the present spokesperson for industrial relations in the conservative Party, actually ditching the inflation adjustment completely—I think in the 1978 Budget.
