So let us not have Liberals coming into the Senate in 1992 lecturing to this Government about bracket creep and fiscal drag. The record shows them to be extremely wanting on this subject. The Liberals went to elections promising to adjust the tax scales for this phenomenon and they could not handle it. They got rid of the whole adjustment within about three or four financial years. They did it for a very clear reason. They did it for the reason that they believed there were more votes in it for them if they made discretionary income tax cuts every now and then. Instead of having tax cuts by adjustment of brackets every year, they thought there was more mileage in it for them to adjust the brackets just before an election and have very clear discretionary personal income tax cuts.

The other thing I find totally nonsensical about this is that people in the conservative party are still going on about bracket creep when we have inflation in this country down to the rate of 2 per cent. Hardly anybody is getting pushed into higher personal income tax brackets in a situation where we have single digit inflation of almost the lowest possible magnitude. I can understand interest in adjusting income tax brackets for inflation when we had inflation running at 11 1/2 per cent, as it was under the Liberals when they were last in power. I can understand the imperative of talking about adjusting tax brackets in those situations for inflation. But the reality is, as I pointed out earlier, that inflation in this country is now in single digits. It is very low at 2 per cent per annum. One can hardly say that bracket creep is a major problem facing the Australian community when we have the inflation rate at such a low level and therefore very few people moving between tax brackets for illusory reasons—reasons of inflation rather than because their real incomes have increased.

Senator Short claims in point (d) of his motion that the Federal Government is discarding the Budget's return to a surplus position in 1995-96. Point (d) of his motion is totally hypocritical when one looks at the record. The claim in point (d) is a classic case of the pot calling the kettle black. Again, all we need to do to check these claims made by conservative politicians is look at the data appendices to the Budget. In Budget Paper No. 1 at page 5.6, table 3, we can find some delicious data going back into history which shows just how poor has been the performance of Liberal governments in this country on the question of Budget surpluses.

Senator Short was lecturing us earlier tonight about not having a Budget surplus in this country. He was saying that this Government had discarded the effort to have a Budget surplus in 1995-96. As a front bench member of the conservative coalition in this Parliament, he was lecturing the Labor Government about not having a Budget surplus.

Let us look at the record. Let us look at the data on page 5.6 of Budget Paper No. 1. There on the record we can see the outcome of all Commonwealth Budgets going back to 1953-54. There is data for 39 financial years. We can ask the question: how many Budget surpluses appear in that table, which goes back to 1953-54, the golden era of Menzies? Out of 39 years there were four years in which the Commonwealth Budget was in surplus. How many of those four years were years when the Liberals were in government? None! Not one of those four years in which there was a Budget surplus saw a Liberal Government in power at the Federal level in Australia. In not one year were the Liberals able to bring in a Budget surplus. Yet they came in here earlier tonight lecturing the Labor Party about not having a Budget surplus three years into the future—in 1995-96. In the period after 1953-54, those people opposite could never deliver a positive balance, a positive outcome in the Federal Government in Australia. In that 39-year period there were 27 years of Liberal Government and in not one of those years was there a Federal Budget surplus. Meanwhile, Labor delivered four consecutive years of Budget surplus in this Government in the 1980s. So let us not have any more lecturing by honourable senators opposite, by conservative members of the Federal Parliament, about Budget surpluses, about Labor not having a Budget surplus three years into the future, in 1995-96.

Senator Short also made the rather extravagant claim that this was a spend now, pay later `Bankcard' Budget—another case of the pot calling the kettle black. I have just pointed out that in a period of 27 years of Liberal Government there was not one Budget surplus at the Federal level in Australia. In every financial year of those 27 years, the Liberal Treasurer of the day spent more than was received in revenue by that Government. There was no Bankcard then; I do not think Bankcard existed in the golden age of Menzies. There was what we used to call hire-purchase. Australia paid very dearly for those years of Liberal governments. Basically, we paid on the drip-feed basis, not on the Bankcard basis. We paid on the hire-purchase system. As a result, public debt mounted up at the Federal level as the Liberal Party in government for 27 years in two periods delivered Budget deficit after Budget deficit after Budget deficit. Opposition senators came in here today and lectured us on not having a Budget surplus in 1995-96.

I would also like to look at Senator Short's claim in his motion that we are going to introduce a raft of new taxes. Let us look at the history of taxation at the Federal level in this country. It is very revealing. In Budget Paper No. 1, for example, on page 4.59, for those Liberals who are present who wish to check it, Federal Budget taxation revenue as a percentage of Australia's gross domestic product, as a broad percentage of our national income, is expected to be 22.2 per cent this financial year. In the last year of the Liberal Government in this country, in 1982-83, the percentage of tax to our gross domestic product was not 22.2 per cent and it was not 23.2 per cent; it was in fact 24 per cent. So, while we have Senator Short lecturing us about so-called new taxes, the record shows that the percentage of our gross domestic product accounted for by taxation now is 1.8 percentage points lower than at the time the last Liberal Government was in office at the Federal level in this country.

We can see from those very clear figures that the share of our gross domestic product taken by government revenue is well below the share taken under the last Liberal Government. In fact, if we look at the concept the other way around, we can say that a great deal more revenue would have to be collected simply to reach that level obtained by the Liberals in 1982-83. In other words, conceptually, there is much room for extra revenue to be collected at the Federal level before this Government would see the proportion of gross domestic product taken by taxation rise to the level achieved by the Liberals in government in the early 1980s. Of course, we do not intend to take taxation up to that 24 per cent share of gross domestic product that the last Liberal Government had.

These are some of the points that needed to be answered tonight. I think it is very clear that we have some very hypocritical points being made in this debate by members of the conservative parties who claim that somehow Australia is letting down the side by bringing in the Budget that it did on Tuesday night. Certainly, the objective facts show very clearly that this particular Budget is well in line with the historical trends in this country. It is a Budget where government spending has not blown out, as claimed by Senator Short; where government spending as a proportion of gross domestic product is lower now than it was at the time the last Liberal Government was in power; and certainly where government taxation revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product is lower than it was when the last Liberal Government was in power at the Federal level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This, of course, is an election Budget. It is certainly not an economic Budget, a rational Budget or any other kind of Budget. It is simply an election Budget. My views about that were reinforced yesterday morning when I shared a breakfast seminar for a Sydney accounting firm, Duesburys, with a former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, John Phillips.

PARA.TAB: Paraphrasing his interesting address, he clearly indicated that the Budget was a political document that has only short term objectives and that it certainly did not look beyond the next election, although I must say that he did indicate that he thought the assumptions underlying it were much more credible than, say, those in One Nation. Many of the comments made in Budget Statement No. 2 were quite gloomy and, to that extent, quite reasonable. He did, of course, raise other matters such as the problems involving the Reserve Bank perhaps getting itself locked into set interest rate positions. But, in general, he confirmed the view I had that this Budget is a very short term Budget and is a very politically oriented, next election Budget.

If it is a next election Budget, what are the messages in it about when the next election will be? There is no doubt that if the basic messages of gloom are there, and are to be taken seriously, there is something to be said for Mr Keating perhaps taking the risk of having an election immediately. There is nothing in this Budget which shows that by next May there will be any basic improvement in the situation. Not even the multi-millions of dollars being spent buying short term jobs will resolve the problem. So we have to decide whether Mr Dawkins is the Artful Dodger, as Paddy McGuinness said, or whether Mr Keating is Mr Micawber. Mr Micawber-Keating is waiting in hope that something will turn up by next May to help his election prospects. Apparently, according to Paddy McGuinness, the Artful Dodger has come up with a lot of politically expedient stuff in the Budget which, of course, does nothing for this economy and really does nothing to create any lasting jobs.

When we look at these two Dickens characters, I suppose we have every right to say, `What in the dickens is really happening?'. I fear that looking at this Budget for any kind of indication of a real sense of recovery or real prospects of improvement is not a very fruitful exercise. It was dramatic tonight to see the difference between the manner in which the Budget was brought down earlier this week by Mr Dawkins with its feeling of gloom, disaster and no real sense of any kind of progress towards resolving Australia's major problems, and the response by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) which gave a feeling of real excitement, direction, enthusiasm and hope for Australia.

What is there in this Budget to make this Government's election prospects look any better? A bit of fiddling the books, I suppose; a bit of buying a few jobs; but, really, there is nothing there that does anything to improve the economy. The assessment of the accountants, Duesburys, in its Budget reaction paper was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget does nothing for the private sector either by way of taxation concessions or rate reductions or by providing meaningful incentives such as for exporters. A great deal could have been done to provide stimulus to the private sector by such measures thereby enabling real incentive, real growth and real jobs that would last beyond the term of the next Government. In summary, the Budget was as we expected but ignores the need to stimulate real economic recovery.
KPMG Peat Marwick, another major accounting firm, in its Budget analysis said:

The Government has failed to provide any significant stimulus to business investment and it can be expected that there will be no significant growth in employment in the private sector. A key assumption of the Budget forecast is 3% real growth in GDP of Australia's major trading partners. Given the uncertain position of both the Japanese and US economies, this may be high risk assumption.

That is what the accountants say. Let us see what the Budget statements themselves say. In fact, the Budget statements themselves contain a massively gloomy approach to the economy. That is why I strongly support Senator Short's motion which states:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) admitted in the Budget speech . . . that the Keating Government will have to raise taxes to pay for its unfunded personal income tax cuts promised for 1994/95;
(b)notes that these new taxes will come in the form of one or all of the following:

SPEECH.PARA: or an increase in existing wholesale sales taxes which of course are a consumption tax—

TAB.TAB: (ii)increased taxes on business, and hence on investment and jobs,
(iii)bracket creep, that is, giving back what has been taken from taxpayers, and/or
(iv)The Labor left's old favourite, a wealth tax.

PARA.TAB: (c)condemns the Government for its cowardice in not being prepared to tell the Australian people which new or additional taxes they will have to bear;

(d)notes that the Treasurer also announced that the Government's promise to return the Budget to surplus has now been unceremoniously discarded in favour of the personal income tax cuts pledge, perceived as more electorally popular; and
(e)condemns the Government for its irresponsible `spend now, pay later' `Bankcard Budget'.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting thing about the Budget Papers themselves is that they do say what should be done. The disaster is that the Budget Papers having said what should be done, the Government then fails to do it. Page 2.61 of the Budget Papers says:

The current level of unemployment is imposing very substantial social and economic costs. The solution lies in generating far more employment opportunities as a result of faster and more sustainable economic growth and appropriate wage outcomes.
According to the Budget Papers, there must be:
. . . faster and more sustainable economic growth and appropriate wage outcomes.

What do we see in terms of economic growth? We will have absolutely minimal economic growth compared with the forecasts that the Government came out with only in February. Suddenly things have so changed since the Government last gave its forecast that now we have slashed the forecast of economic growth and we see what it is made of. Business investment is down 2 per cent, but do not worry, the public sector is going to push ahead once again at the expense of the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear! Hear!

—I notice the Minister says, `Hear! Hear!' That is the classic left wing Labor response: increase the size of the sector that the taxpayers of Australia have to pay for. That is its only answer. That is why we have been going steadily downhill. So we see public sector demand increasing by 3 1/4 per cent this financial year, according to the Budget expectations, and business investment down another 2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: We have this ludicrous situation where GDP is going up by only 3 per cent, which is a tawdry level of recovery in view of the false expectations created in the February statement. Of course, Mr Hawke has pointed to those false expectations which have destroyed whatever credibility was left in the man who created this recession—the man who, in fact, engineered this recession—Mr Keating, who has proudly said that he engineered it. It is interesting that the Budget Papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: Experience in Australia and Europe during the 1980s suggests that it will take considerable time to reduce unemployment to more acceptable levels.

There is a whole range of reasons why it is going to take considerable time to reduce unemployment to acceptable levels. One of the main reasons is that there is such a massive level of hidden unemployed and underemployed that if there is any indication of economic upturn, there will be more of these people, if you like, coming out of the woodwork, and being available for work.

PARA.TAB: It is not just an assertion that these people are there. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has done a survey on both hidden unemployment and underemployment. The latest hidden unemployment figure shows something like 800,000 Australians prepared to work within four weeks—wanting to work, but not even listing themselves as available for work under the Australian Bureau of Statistics normal unemployment figures.

This is for a variety of reasons, but mostly because there was no point in putting their names down because they did not think there were any jobs, or because they had accepted other situations such as Austudy to get themselves out of dole queues. There are 800,000 people who would rather have a job. The recent survey done by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on underemployment showed that there was something like 600,000 people working part time who wanted to work longer hours and, in particular, wanted to work full time. So here we have something like 2 1/4 million Australians either unemployed officially; in the hidden unemployed, as revealed by the statistician; or in the underemployed.

That is why we will have a massive overhang of unemployment that this Government will not be able to get rid of, firstly, because it does not have the capacity to do so, and secondly, because it does not have the money to throw at these schemes. All that the Government has done with its massive unemployment programs, using money that it does not have in the present Budget, is prevent unemployment from rising even further. That is all it is doing. It is not cutting unemployment; it is not getting jobs for the people who are unemployed now; it is simply stopping that number getting worse.

This is evident from the figures in this Budget. The number of unemployed in the 1992-93 year is listed as being 10.5 per cent, as against the average of 10.4 per cent last financial year. This year, unemployment will be a fraction higher than it was last year. The only reason it is not an awful lot higher than that, is that the Government is throwing money into these unemployment schemes which simply provide temporary jobs at the expense of taxpayers or borrowers. Even the Illawarra Mercury, which has certainly never been renowned for supporting us, has come out with a front page article today saying that workers in Wollongong, a Labor stronghold, will not be conned by this kind of nonsense and that, in fact, all that is happening is that the Government is creating temporary jobs to get it past the next election.

The Reserve Bank Bulletin, which I dealt with earlier today, demonstrates that things are a lot worse in this recession than they were in 1982-83. Unemployment is much deeper and more sustained in the current recession; and when the drought factor is removed from the 1982-83 recession, this is a far worse recession. As the Budget Papers say:

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the recovery from the 1982-83 recession, the pick-up in demand is likely to be much slower and hence the turnaround in investment will be delayed and weaker when it occurs.
I underline `when it occurs'. It continues:
It may also be influenced by the extent to which improved management and work practices allow better use of existing plant and equipment.
In other words, greater production may be achieved without increasing employment levels, by better use of existing plant and equipment.

PARA.TAB: It also says, and I repeat what I said earlier, that it will be the public sector—the Government—that will continue to support activity in 1992-93 with a pick-up of spending through the year.While Australians, the bulk of whom are employed by the private sector, see no hope of major investment or major job increases in the private sector, we see it will be the Government that will be providing the stimulus and support to activity in 1992-93 with a pick-up of spending through the year. It even says:

SPEECH.PARA: Net exports—
on which our future depends—

are expected to detract from GDP growth. Imports are projected to rise more quickly than demand as domestic expenditure recovers. Subdued growth in the world economy, particularly the slowdown in Japan, and smaller increments to capacity in the non-rural sector are expected to constrain export growth.

So what is happening with one of the key indicators? One of the key things that dominate our economy is the current account balance and it is going to worsen to about $15 billion or 3 3/4 per cent of GDP. I said that Statement No. 2 indicates the real severity of the problem. It certainly indicates that the longer this Government waits before it has its election, the worse off, basically, Australia will be. Page 2.74 of the Budget Papers states:
During 1992-93, employment growth will be supported by declining real unit labour costs. This will reflect continued restrained wages growth and a forecast increase in productivity.

But the problem here is that unless we get greater investment in plant and equipment—and remember, it is going to be minus 2—we are not going to get nearly enough increased productivity to lift Australia out of the mire.

PARA.TAB: Another matter of some concern in the Budget Papers is a hint of higher interest rates. The Budget Papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: A significantly lower exchange rate than assumed would lead to upward pressures on inflation.
We are being told that the key will be fighting inflation. The statement continues:
However, the still moderate levels of expected domestic demand could dampen the flow-through of higher import prices to inflation.

If the policy objective is to make certain that we do not get a much lower exchange rate, I wonder what the risks are of higher interest rates in order to keep the Aussie dollar up? We have already seen massive Reserve Bank buying of the Aussie dollar to hold it up. It seems that if this Government is committed to its stated policy objectives and to the forecasts that are in this document, it may well be that even higher real interest rates—and we should remember that interest rates are already very high in real terms in Australia, as the Reserve Bank annual report tabled today pointed out—will be needed to protect the Australian dollar in the dismal situation that we are now facing.

PARA.TAB: Of course, we are now facing another dismal situation, and that is the admission by the Treasurer that in order to finance the tax cuts that he is determined to have, he is going to have to increase taxes. We have already seen some increased taxes in this Budget. For example, another $120m or so is to be raised by taxing the fringe benefit derived by people parking in city parking stations. This is probably the only bit of investment stimulus that the Government is providing. It is giving an exciting new opportunity to business by, in effect, penalising people for parking in the city. It may well be creating an opportunity for businesses to build parking stations near suburban railway stations. This will mean that they will not be subject to this tax. I cannot see any other stimulus to business in this Budget. This indirect stimulus may be the only one.

It is important to establish what taxes will be raised to pay for Mr Dawkins's tax cuts. We have heard in debates on the Fightback package that Mr Keating was a great fan of the GST. Honourable senators will remember that back in 1985 he got rolled by the former Prime Minister. Mr Keating, a former fan of this kind of tax, has repeatedly said in recent times that he attacks the tax because there is no longer any need for it; that there was a need in 1985 but there is not now because he has broadened the tax base. That is the line—the totally disreputable and nonsensical line—that Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, has spread around.

There is no doubt that Mr Keating has increased the tax base. He imposed a tax on ice cream, flavoured milk, muesli bars and on orange and other fruit juices. Of course, they do not count as food in the opinion of a man who says that he would never introduce a consumption tax on food. This line is echoed, of course, by the clones on the Government front bench in the Senate. So he did broaden the tax base to a degree—he introduced a

SPEECH.PARA: consumption tax on kids' food. But this has not in fact broadened the tax base at all. It has hit some individual items.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the facts. In 1985, when Mr Keating was claiming that there was a need for a GST, the share of total taxation revenue made up of income tax was 40.4 per cent. It is now up to 42.9 per cent. So he certainly has failed to broaden the tax base. He has imposed a greater tax burden on PAYE taxpayers since then. The burden of tax on ordinary working Australians who pay PAYE tax has gone up from 40.2 to 42.9 per cent since the time Mr Keating wanted to have more indirect taxes. Something like 60.4 per cent of all tax revenues in 1985-86 came from income taxes. The figure is now up to 68.6 per cent. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table from the Budget Papers which indicates this share of tax revenue.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [THE TABLE IS OMMITED FROM THE DATA BASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 429]

TALK.START.PARA: —The other side of this equation is quite interesting. The table shows that all of the other taxes, such as sales tax, which represented 30.4 per cent of taxation revenue in 1985-86 when Mr Keating wanted to increase them, have now fallen to 25.2 per cent of collections. It is clearly evident that the share of tax revenue made up of the sorts of taxes that Mr Keating wanted in 1985 has fallen dramatically under this Government. If these are the taxes that Mr Keating liked in 1985, they provide him with enormous scope to introduce greater taxes along those lines now that he is the boss. His then boss stopped him doing it at a time when those taxes totalled only 30.4 per cent of total taxation revenue. Now, they are only 25 per cent. So it is clear that this is a great area for Mr Keating to jump into.

PARA.TAB: After all, he cannot do much more with income tax which already represents 68.6 per cent of total collections. If he is after some extra taxes, the only place to which he can turn is the other taxes area—things like petrol tax and sales tax. I might just mention that they are the taxes that we are going to remove. They are the taxes, particularly on business, that we are going to wipe right out. They are the hidden taxes that people do not realise exist. People do not know that they are imposed on orange juice, flavoured milk and even toilet paper, soap and detergent. All of these hidden consumption taxes will be removed and replaced by a fair and equitable goods and services tax which will pay for a reduction in income tax. That is the whole point of it.

So we have a situation in which the tax bill of pay as you earn workers, who have to foot the greatest single sector of tax, has gone up since Mr Keating wanted to have a GST back in 1985-86 from 40.2 per cent to 42.9 per cent of the total bill. The ordinary Australian taxpayer is being slugged more and more and has to pay a bigger and bigger proportion of the tax burden of this nation under this Government. Yet the ordinary PAYE worker is supposed to be the person that this Government represents. Clearly it does not.

Clearly, the only organisation that is looking after the best interests of the PAYE taxpayer is the coalition, which seeks to reduce that burden of income tax. Instead of having taxes on production and income, the coalition seeks to have taxes on consumption. We need to do this so that we can reduce Australia's costs, so that we can provide incentives for Australian producers and exporters, so that we can compete again, and so that we can create new jobs. There needs to be a fair and rational consumption tax system in Australia instead of the present unfair and totally dishonest tax system which allows this Government to pretend that it does not tax consumption while it raises $10 billion a year in tax through sales tax alone as well as another $7 billion out of the petrol tax.

Looking at petrol tax alone, taking it off production would remove a massive burden on Australian industry. But this Government is not going to do anything like that. Instead of reducing the price of petrol to business users by 26c a litre—and transport costs are one of the major elements of Australian costs, which are so uncompetitive compared with other nations around the world, particularly those nations selling us goods—we should recognise the benefits that come from reducing petrol tax, and see how we can create an environment in which the private sector can employ more people and how there can be more jobs.
In other words, there is a solution. This Government has refused to follow its advice in the Budget Papers, which state:

SPEECH.PARA: The solution lies in generating far more employment opportunities as a result of faster and more sustainable economic growth and appropriate wage outcomes.

Only in Fightback do we have that solution brought into effect. All this Budget is, is a very short term Budget aimed at the next election. If the Government had any brains, it would have an election before this Budget falls apart, which it will certainly be demonstrated to have done before next May, which the pundits say is when the Government will go to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is one in a whole series of motions of this kind that have come before this chamber over the years that I have been here. No doubt very similar motions will be moved in the time after I leave. This motion says, `We've got a better Budget than you. You're spending in the wrong areas. You're raising money the wrong way. If you do this, so and so will follow'. As if what is needed to make Australia recover is the pulling of some economic levers—pull off the personal income tax and put on the goods and services tax; take off this tax, add it elsewhere; and the magic wand is waved and Australia recovers. The real problem is that it makes people out as simply economic units. The Opposition does not consider people.
—It considers people who will get jobs.

—The Opposition says, `If you take off a bit of tax here, the people will get jobs', as Senator Baume has said. What evidence there is of that is peripheral to the argument. As I see it, there has been no hard economic research done to show that what is stated in this chamber by those opposite will happen. Macbeth said, `Life's. . . full of sound and fury, signifying nothing'. That is what we tend to have in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Where is the evidence that what those opposite say will happen, will happen if the levers that they say should be pulled are pulled? Where is the evidence to show that what the Government says will happen, will happen if this is pursued? It is to be admitted that we are in hard times. It would be silly not to admit that. It is quite true. It is also true that there has been a tremendous change in the industrial, financial, social and cultural life of this nation over the last 10 years. It has to be said that no matter what party comes into power in Australia in future years, it will be inheriting and continuing the work that has been done by this Government over the last 10 years. It is only when one thinks back over the last decade that that is realised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perish the thought.

—Senator Parer is familiar with the industrial relations situation. The evidence is quite clear on that. There have been far fewer strikes and much more productivity than occurred in the 1980s, and a better feeling between employer and employee than was then the situation.

PARA.TAB: It has been said here tonight that nothing has been done for business in this Budget. I suppose a 150 per cent allowance, in terms of a deduction under the Income Tax Act, for expenditure on research and development, does not count in the eyes of those opposite as doing something for business. That is one of the problems. They see business as simply an economic unit without any regard for the human dimensions of life. If business can be given an extra quid, that will do something for it.

This Government realises that business—like the work force generally—is capable of thinking beyond the pocket. It is capable of the higher aspirations of the human heart and soul—of being generous to others and trying to do something for the nation, not simply for the dollar that might be involved. The sort of business that must be developed is not the sort of business that we had in the 1980s—the 1980s was very much the era of private enterprise—but development where real production takes place.

One of the traps that the Opposition falls into was illustrated by Senator Baume when he said that the accountancy firms said that this is a bad Budget. Maybe some of them do, but they do it on an accounting basis, as if what life, the economy and the future are all about is the counting of beans—to use a phrase that has been used before. That, somehow, if we twist the levers the right way, the right result will come.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a Keating statement—pulling the levers.

—Senator Parer says that, but what the arguments of those opposite have not addressed is the fact that people are now in need of immediate relief. There is a need for people to be given jobs. Those opposite would say, `We won't give him or her that job because it's not from private enterprise. It's only a job that will last for six months'. If I were without work and were given a job that would last for six months, it would raise my spirits, put some money in my pocket and make me feel a wanted person again. I would say, what is wrong with that? If that is the position, I simply ask that question: what is wrong with that?

PARA.TAB: The position is that this Budget will increase demand and get a sluggish private sector demand reversed. When there is a demand for goods, the production that is needed to meet that demand will take place. This is a Budget that certainly pays attention to the economic principles, but also pays attention to the need for people to be looked to as people and not simply as units in a labour market. It is a Budget that cares and it is a Budget that has been carefully drafted to accomplish that purpose.

I will go through some key Budget numbers, since numbers seem to be the order of the day. There is a deficit of less than $14 billion, which the money markets have accommodated and accepted. There is prediction of a 3.3 per cent growth in GDP. It is said by those on the other side that that is not enough, and that it should be 4 per cent or 5 per cent. I suppose if it were 4 per cent or 5 per cent, they would say that it should be 6 per cent or 7 per cent, so that they could chase figures up the ladder to make the point that they wanted to make. But the reality is that this economy is recovering and on the way up. It is heading in a direction that everybody on both sides of the House and in the community generally says it should be heading.

The interesting thing is that the criticisms made of this Government and of the Budget are limited to detail. There has been criticism from the other side that we are ignoring the goods and services tax. In the same breath the Opposition says that we do impose a goods and services tax. All this indicates is that the Opposition is going around picking whatever it can find available as a means of criticism. What it is picking at is not the reality but its interpretation of what is going on. That is not a proper analysis of this Budget. What should be brought out, if it is to be criticised, is a tight, well argued, well evidenced rebuttal to what is put forth. No rebuttal has taken place here tonight. Instead, the Opposition has gone around creating straw men which it then knocks over.

I will go through the Budget strategy. In this Budget the Government has used a fiscal approach. It has supplemented, as I said before, a sluggish private sector demand and initiated a series of employment related programs in order to remove the burden of unemployment on Australian families. As I understand the criticism from the other side, the Government should not have sought to remove the burden of unemployment on Australian families because the way it did it was not necessarily through the private sector. Since it was not through the private sector, the criticism is that in some way the jobs are tainted and should not be allowed.

The next proposition is to improve the fairness and efficiency of a range of social programs—this is very necessary—and in the medium term to contribute to a proper balance between domestic demand and supply and to reduce the call on national savings. They are all objects that are more than needed.

I wish to deal with other matters that have been raised. The Opposition says that its proposals will increase the size of the private sector, but it will leave the private sector without any protection. There will be no attempts to protect the industries in this nation in the way that they are protected overseas. On the other hand, the Government looks at each industry in its own situation and applies the proper approach accordingly.

One of the criticisms made of the Government earlier was that it had changed the thrust of some of its programs over the past six months, whereas the Opposition locked itself into a fixed position—the position as it was six months ago. It seems to me that if the approach to government by the Opposition is that there should be no flexibility in policies and that as situations change there should be no shifting in the application of policy, we are in for all sorts of difficulties if those opposite and their colleagues should ever become government. If that happens, they will be applying the policies they thought were relevant for the end of 1991, not the policies that are called for by particular problems that they face at a particular time.

This motion is a tired motion, because it repeats what has been repeated again and again over the years. It is a tired motion because the arguments put up to support it are tired ones that have been repeated again and again. They are fixed on the basis of a particular philosophy, a particular program and a particular set of policies that do not change with changing times. They are tired in the sense that the sorts of answers that are given to them must be tired because they have been repeated again and again, mainly because no new initiatives have been brought forward and no new arguments have been set forth to rebut the Government's argument. This is a Government that has led this country for well over 10 years and has set the basis for an economy, a society and a culture which will flourish in the decades ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is all `gonna be'.

—Senator Parer says that it is a `gonna be' argument. Well, all these propositions that the Opposition has put forward are `gonna be' propositions. When it was last in government, which was some considerable time ago—
—All their employment projections in Fightback are based on Industry Commission reports. They are not even in the document itself. It is an absolute fraud.

—I thank Senator Collins for making the point for me. Can Senator Crane, who will be speaking next, tell me—through you, Madam Acting Deputy President—where one finds hard economic, social or cultural evidence which gives any basis for any of the statements that are made in the Fightback! document? The Opposition has built up a model based on the words of some economists and accountants—the bean counters—that it will work in a particular way. Where is the evidence, as distinct from the hope and the propositions that the Opposition put forward, that lends support for that document?

PARA.TAB: Where is the evidence to support the propositions that the Opposition is putting against this Budget? There have been allegations across the chamber of the `Whose daddy is bigger?' and `Whose budget is better?' kind. I must say I am growing tired of the process, and will soon resume my seat. But if there were any substance in the arguments put by the Opposition, a lot of the points those opposite make would have merit; but any argument, however weak, would have merit if the propositions put were accurate.

What is really needed is not a series of propositions or allegations but a bit of evidence and a little bit of credibility. The credibility that this Government has, as I said before, and it bears a lot of repeating, is in the way it has turned Australia around over the past 10 years. We are going through hard times now, but the basis is there for quite a glorious future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Short's motion and I will certainly take up some of the points that Senator Cooney mentioned in his speech. I might have a serve for Senator Collins as well. It is interesting to note that Senator Cooney did not address the motion before us at all in his speech, except to say that it was a tired proposition. Point (a) of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . notes that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) admitted in the Budget speech on 18 August 1992 that the Keating Government will have to raise taxes to pay for its unfunded personal income tax promised for 1994/95;
The tiredness of this motion is in it being two days old. This debate is about the Budget, not about what Senator Cooney and others on the other side of this chamber have talked about.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in the House of Representatives the `shop until you drop' Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), who says, `Spend, spend, spend'—and that is shown in this Budget, despite our deficit problems—was given the opportunity to say that what was in the Budget was not correct. Today I asked a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) so that he could have an opportunity to refute or correct what was in the Budget and in Budget Paper No. 1. Neither of them did anything to change the proposition which exists in Senator Short's motion.

So the tiredness is not with this motion but with those who sit on the other side of this chamber, those who sit on the Government side of the House of Representatives, their advisers, the departmental officers, et cetera, who are sick and tired of operating with this current Government. That is where the tiredness is. It is not with this side of the chamber. Nor is it with this motion.

There are a number of fundamental reasons why the `shop until you drop' Treasurer had to make that comment in the Budget, and I wish to briefly touch on them. First of all, there has been a decline in our estimated deficits over the last three years. It is worth looking at them and reminding ourselves of them. The Government has estimated that this year we will have a deficit of somewhere between $13 billion and $14 billion. If we take into account asset sales, it is more like $16 billion. If we take into account other aspects and the inconsistency of the forecasting over the last 10 years, we could conclude that it could well be closer to $20 billion. I would certainly be prepared to lay a lazy dollar against the fact that it could well be closer to $20 billion than $14 billion.

Looking at these particular figures, at what has occurred in the last two years and the projections for this year, it was predicted in 1991 that there would be a surplus of $8.1 billion; in fact, it came in at $1.9 billion, which meant that $6.2 billion was overspent by this current Government. For the last year, a negative balance of $4.6 billion or $4.7 billion was predicted; it came in at $9.3 billion. We are now looking at a situation where, according to the Government's figures, we are faced with a negative balance of between $13 billion and $14 billion as well as, as I have outlined, the effects of asset sales and other aspects. So we have seen an enormous turnaround.

Why do taxes have to increase? Very simply, if the Government is to spend money, it has to raise income to cover that particular cost. It cannot go on forever putting things on the never-never or on the Bankcard. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is now known as the `Bankcard Prime Minister'. That is what this Budget has done.

Senator Cooney mentioned that 3.3 per cent was not enough growth. I also believe that 3.3 per cent is not enough growth, but it is a lot more realistic than the figure of 4.75 per cent that was put before us in the One Nation statement last February. But it is not enough growth to avoid increases in taxation or, alternatively, cuts in government expenditure. They are the two options the Government has to balance its Budget: it either increases its revenue base or decreases its expenditure. At 3.3 per cent the growth will not be sufficient to raise enough taxes to pay for this deficit into the future and the promised tax cuts.

Senator Cooney and others on the other side of the chamber made reference—I am not sure of the exact words—to bean counting and the economic bookworms. It is not only the economists and the accountants but also the previous Prime Minister. In the Australian today, Mr Hawke is quoted as saying yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: Now by what has happened you've got the Government in a situation where it's going to have over its head this threat of further taxes.

The former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, the longest serving Prime Minister of the Australian Labor Party in Australia's history, recognises the very simple fact that, if the Government does not balance the Budget or spends too much, it has to increase taxes. That is why the motion before us is accurate in terms of what was put down in both the House of Representatives and the Senate just two days ago. Following on from that, we need to examine where those taxes are likely to come from.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney also challenged us to make some comments about Fightback. I am quite prepared and quite happy to do that. Fightback is about putting incentive back into people's objectives; it is about giving them the opportunity to look after themselves; it is about allowing them to be independent family units. It recognises very clearly that income tax cuts and tax credits in relation to health cover and other measures primarily go to those on lower incomes. It will give them back their dignity. That is what Fightback is all about. It also addresses the situation we have in our ramshackle, indirect tax system. It removes $20 billion of business input taxes.

As Senator Hill said tonight in his reply to the Budget, estimations done by a survey of BCA members in February-March indicate that if payroll tax could be removed another 200,000 jobs would be generated in businesses. That would get rid of 20 per cent of our unemployed people and would put them into full time jobs, not mickey mouse jobs, as is proposed by the Government.

Senator Cooney also challenged us by asking what was wrong with some fiscal stimulus by the Government. There is nothing wrong with fiscal stimulus so long as it is directed in the correct way at the right time and it is fair and equitable. I have already mentioned today just how unfair and inequitable the fiscal stimulus is that the Government has through its grants program—in particular, the discrimination against country shires and the way the formula has been structured. It ends up, particularly in Western Australia, with those marginal seats held by the Labor Party being the beneficiaries.

I come back to the motion—and that is what we are hear to speak about—which, as I have already said, has been moved as a result of what occurred two days ago. Why is it necessary to increase taxes? We have options when it comes to what to do in this country. We can sell off the farm, but there comes a time when we run out of things to sell. It is noted that the sales of assets in this particular Budget are to assist in funding this deficit, not to reduce debt.

If we keep on spending money—as this nation has been doing, particularly in the last 10 years with the current account, and in the last three years with Budget deficits and the blow-outs I have already mentioned—eventually the bank manager will tap us on the shoulder and say, `No more; you have to raise some money and start paying it back'. That is why taxes will go up.

This nation has failed dismally in this area, particularly in the period of the Hawke-Keating Governments. In that period, our national debt has blown out by some $160-odd billion. Even if today we could stabilise that and pay back half a billion dollars a year—which would be an enormous performance—it would take 80 years to pay it off. So at least three or four generations to come have been mortgaged just through inappropriate activities and policies, including those high interest rate policies mentioned tonight that kill off small business, hundreds of farmers and people's jobs.

I only have to look down the street in Victoria Park just east of the business centre in Perth in which my office is situated. Over 40 per cent of businesses along Albany Highway have closed their doors almost entirely because of the high interest rate regime. That regime put those people out of business; they could not afford to carry on. Their dreams were destroyed by the actions of the current Prime Minister, the `Bankcard Prime Minister'.

We note that in the Budget Mr Dawkins said the promised tax cuts in the One Nation program would go ahead. If they are to go ahead, there are only two other areas of the community that can be taxed—and they are business and the consumer. They are the options before the present Government. I believe that the Government cannot tax business any further. If it does, more and more businesses will close down and the problems we have with bankruptcy will be exacerbated—and of course that flows on through to employment. The bankruptcy figures have virtually doubled each year in the last four years. The figures for the Hawke-Keating years are more than double those of the Fraser years.

That leaves just one option—I will not address it now because we have it before us and I will be speaking on it—and that is the sales tax legislation. There are some very significant changes in that legislation. The Government is really left with only one option to raise taxation, and that is the introduction of a goods and services tax or a consumption tax.

If we want to be internationally competitive, if we want our farmers and miners to get back on top of their problems and compete internationally, if we want industries, about which so many of us talk from time to time in terms of value-added, to become an integral part of the Australian scene, they must be allowed to be internationally competitive. To be internationally competitive, they must have an internationally competitive taxation system. Most countries in the world have recognised that. Other countries that want to be internationally competitive have recognised that they must have an industrial system that is internationally competitive, and that industrial system must give incentive to the people who are involved in the workplace. Both the current taxation system and the industrial system fail on both those counts.

Looking at Senator Short's motion and the options before the Government, having regard to the way it has gone about things over recent years with its Bankcard mentality, the Government will have no option if it is to deliver those income tax cuts but to introduce some form of consumption tax. I believe it would be totally appropriate and correct, if the Government were honest about its intentions, for it to show commitment by putting before the Australian public a long term program to address the problems we have.

Nobody can deny that we do have serious problems with our infrastructure and debt, whether it be on our current account or on our deficit. As Senator Boswell outlined tonight, we have enormous debt problems in the farm sector—some $105,000 net debt per farm in Australia. In some States, including my own State of Western Australia, it is almost double that. Yet those farmers, those individuals, go on producing an enormous amount year after year. If they are to be allowed to recover from that particular position to become effective employers again, we must take away those existing business taxes. Senator Short's motion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . condemns the Government for its cowardice in not being prepared to tell the Australian people which new or additional taxes they will have to bear.

I challenge the Government to spell out quite clearly its intentions for the next 12 months: its capital works program and how that has to be started by December this year and end in December 1993. It needs to spell out its program and what it will do over the next three, four, five and six years in a much more succinct and fair manner. It owes that to the Australian public.

PARA.TAB: While I am on that subject, the Government still has the opportunity to correct the injustices it has foisted upon many in the Australian community with this capital works program. As I have said before, I am not saying that there should not be some fiscal stimulus. I am saying that, if there is, it should be applied fair and equitably. This Budget begs the question: why does the City of Wanneroo get $7m—sorry, the City of Stirling get $7m and the City of Wanneroo, right alongside of it, get nothing?

TALK.START.PARA: —You still got it wrong.

—I did not get it wrong. The City of Bayswater on the other side of that shire gets nothing. Unemployment does not end at shire boundaries or city council boundaries, nor does it end at electoral boundaries. There needs to be a revision of that particular formula. If the present formula had been applied three years ago, Wilson Tuckey's electorate of O'Connor would have qualified for the most money, because at that particular time that is where the worst rate of unemployment existed. I find it unbelievable that this Budget, even though this money has been put forward, did not allocate the funds in a fair and equitable way.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short's motion in (d):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . notes that the Treasurer also announced that the Government's promise to return the Budget to surplus has now been unceremoniously discarded in favour of the personal income tax cuts pledge, perceived as more electorally popular.

We need in this country a government that is prepared to start governing in the interests of all Australians and for the medium and long term future of Australia. That situation certainly does not exist at this time. It must be worrying that the job prospects for those who are about to leave school and for those who have just left are very dim. If some of that fiscal stimulus had been directed towards the private sector, we could have seen some long term jobs put in place for these people. We are in grave danger of ending up with the longest, most trained dole queues in the world. That must be of enormous worry to those young people.

PARA.TAB: Last week I was talking to a young chap from Curtin University. He told me that he had now set his sights on moving out of Australia when he finished his education and training because he had a much better chance of getting a job in Asia. He was structuring his education through that university on the basis of—
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 June Senator Winston Crane made a number of allegations about alleged payments by my Department to the Australian Builders Labourers Federated Union of Workers, Western Australian Branch, for expenses related to travel from Perth to Canberra for meetings with the Government on 3 and 17 December 1991 on reform in the building industry.

PARA.TAB: I made a detailed rebuttal of those allegations in the Senate later that day, 25 June. The statement I made then stands. In that rebuttal I undertook to provide further details on two things: firstly, a list of expenditures for travel and accommodation for industry, government and union officials and union bodies involved in developing the Government's construction industry reform strategy through the industrial relations working party—these expenditures were met under my Department's workplace reform program; and, secondly, details of any relevant expenditures under the Government's funding arrangements for the Western Australian Business Advisory Group, known as WABAG, and the Western Australian Trade Union Advisory Group, known by the awkward acronym of WATUAG.

In the event, no payments for any purpose were made to the WABLF under the WABAG or the WATUAG programs over the past two financial years, the period these programs have been administered by my Department. I wrote to Senator Crane yesterday, 19 August, providing the extra details I promised on 25 June and answering further specific points put by him which were not addressed in my statement in the adjournment debate on 25 June. I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my letter to Senator Crane and its attachments.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 19 August 1992
Senator Winston Crane
Senator for Western Australia
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Crane

As promised I am writing to clarify issues you raised in the Senate on 25 June 1992 in relation to claims for payments made by the Australian Builders Labourers Federated Union of Workers, WA Branch (WABLF) to the Department of Industrial Relations.

My Department has now completed an examination of the relevant files and assures me that all payments relevant to the WABLF have been processed in accordance with normal procedures under the Workplace Reform Program administered by the Department.

The processing of claims for reimbursement of payments to the WABLF and all other organisations involved in the work on the Construction Industry Reform Strategy was made in accordance with normal financial management procedures, involving the examination and verifying of relevant invoices.

Reimbursement for air travel has been made on the basis of the applicable economy class fare. The WABLF was reimbursed for relevant accommodation costs due to the need for their representatives to stay interstate overnight because of the distances involved in travelling to and from Western Australia.

Room costs only have been paid on hotel accounts. Where hotel accounts involve cents ($172.50) it is because a Bonus Card corporate discount rate has been applied to the room charge (the normal rate was $230.00).

My Department's review of the accounts has shown some accounting errors by my Department. Details are contained in the Schedule of Adjustments annexed to the Expenditure Reconciliation Statement which is attached. There are instances of both overpayment and underpayment. The net result is that the Department owes the WABLF $105.00.

I have asked the Secretary of my Department to examine whether these errors have any broader implications for the Department's accounting and audit procedures and to report to me as soon as possible on this.

You queried (Hansard Page 4718) the airfare of $2267.00 claimed by the WABLF for travel to the meeting of 3 December 1991. The invoice submitted by the travel agent for the WABLF shows the structure of the airfare as a return airfare Perth to Canberra on Australian Airlines and Ansett on a mixed first and business class basis. This is on the basis of the following sectors:

PARA.TAB: Perth/Melbourne (first class) $861.00
Melbourne/Canberra (first class) $308.00 Canberra/Melbourne (business class) $237.00 Melbourne/Perth (first class) $861.00

SPEECH.PARA: This amount has, of course, not been paid. In any event, only a return economy fare would be reimbursed.

I should clarify the position regarding funds available under relevant Department programs. An initial amount of $19272.00 based on anticipated expenditure (see footnote(1)) was approved by me in February 1991 under the Workplace Reform Program for activities relating to the Industrial Relations Working Party. A further amount of $20000.00 was approved by me in November 1991. Of the initial $19272.00, an amount of $15285.06(2) was spent in 1990/91. The remainder was reallocated before the end of that financial year to other projects under the Workplace Reform Program. Of the further allocation of $20000.00, $6131.00(2) was spent by end-May 1992. This left $13869.00 which was reallocated by end-May to other projects under the Workplace Reform Program.

In respect of claims made by the WABLF for reimbursement of expenses for meetings attended on 3 and 17 December 1991, I confirm what I said in the Senate on 25 June 1992. The purpose of these meetings was explained in that statement.
Nevertheless, the WABLF has not been reimbursed for expenses incurred by it for these meetings.

I now provide you with the Expenditure Reconciliation Statement prepared by my Department for the relevant expenditure under my Department's Workplace Reform Program. This provides details of payments made under this Program to various industry, government and union bodies, including the WABLF, for reimbursement of expenses incurred in finalising the Government's construction reform strategy through the Industrial Relations Working Party.

I have also checked whether any payments were made for any purpose to the WABLF under the Government's funding arrangements for the Western Australian Business Advisory Group (WABAG) and the Western Australian Trade Union Advisory Group (WATUAG) over the past two financial years. No such payments were made.
If you think it useful, I will arrange for officers of my Department to be available to go through the details of these expenditures.
Yours sincerely
Peter Cook

(1) This reflected exactly a schedule prepared by the Department of Industrial Relations for anticipated travel costs associated with the IR Working Party for an expected eight meetings spread between Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra.
(2) These figures do not include subsequent adjustments resulting from overpayments/underpayments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATA BASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 438]

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to make about all of this. What Senator Crane said on 25 June—that I have improperly authorised reimbursements to the WABLF for costs associated with meetings on 3 and 17 December 1991—was, of course, untrue. It is a false allegation.
—No, it is not untrue. Your minute shows it.

—It is a false allegation and the minutes do not show it. I have not authorised such expenditures. I repeat, I have not authorised such expenditures and no money has been paid to the WABLF in respect of the meetings on 3 and 17 December last. Both my statement to the Senate on 25 June and the material I have subsequently provided make this clear. That having been said, my Department's examination of payments to the WABLF and others for meetings earlier in 1990 and 1991 on building industry reform has revealed a number of accounting errors made by my Department in several payments.

PARA.TAB: On 25 June I tabled a letter of December 1991 from my Department to Mr Kevin Reynolds, Secretary of the WABLF, setting out details of payments to the WABLF for its participation in work to finalise the Government's construction industry reform strategy. I have now provided the Senate with details of all payments to other bodies—industry, union and government—for the same purpose. This material was not asked for by Senator Crane.

I tabled the letter to Mr Reynolds on 25 June and I have tabled this additional material today to ensure that the Senate has complete information before it, and to show that there is nothing unusual in providing financial assistance to a range of bodies—industry, government and union—to participate in such work.

It has now been discovered that some of the details in the letter of December 1991 to Mr Reynolds are incorrect, in that instances of both overpayment and underpayment have now been found which alter some of the amounts finally settled. Those details are set out in full in the schedule of adjustments attached to the letter to Senator Crane which I have just incorporated in Hansard.

I should emphasise that all amounts owed to the Department by the WABLF have been repaid. Because of underpayment on some travel claims, however, the Department now finds itself owing the WABLF an amount of $105.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could not add up.

—Unfortunately, that appears to be the case. These accounting errors are of concern in that they may have implications for my Department's accounting and audit procedures generally. I have asked the Secretary to my Department to urgently review this question to see how the Department's performance can be improved in this area and to report to me on this as soon as possible. The Secretary to my Department is as concerned as I am about these errors and is giving this question his priority.

PARA.TAB: I should stress that these departmental errors do not go to the issues involved in Senator Crane's allegations in the Senate on 25 June, but they are of concern and action has been taken to correct them. I should also note that I have indicated to Senator Crane that I will arrange for officers of my Department to be available to him to go through the details of expenditures I have provided if he should so wish.

I conclude by saying that, of course, parliamentary scrutiny is important in ensuring accountability for public expenditure. I have taken the view that, while Senator Crane's allegations were and are not true, the best way of dealing with them is to prove the untruth by revealing and tabling all of the relevant documentation. This has now been done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to talk about a recent conference which served to buoy my spirits and those of my staff. At Gosnells Senior High School in Perth each year the staff and students organise a conference called Pathways Now which provides to students from many parts of Western Australia the opportunity of spending a weekend looking at important issues.

PARA.TAB: Pathways Now is a forum about change. It gives the students an opportunity to speak about the world as it is and about the world as they envisage it should be. To many people that will sound like a talkfest at which a lot of starry-eyed kids get together to show off their idealism. This is not so. Issues are discussed at length and in depth. Invited speakers from a range of occupations and specialities provide input and are questioned. I know from my staff who attended as invited speakers that the students are critical questioners and are attuned to the issues on the agenda and of the day.

Pathways Now grew from an idea among the Gosnells High School staff. The school was not designated as a specialised school in performing arts, sports development, science or maths, so some of the staff decided that the school would have a special focus on the environment. When some students attended the Pathways to the Future Conference in 1989, they came back with the idea of Pathways Now as one way in which the school could live out its environment specialisation.

Each Pathways Now conference is organised by a group of staff and students. Topics are selected, themes explored, speakers invited, and then the conference is promoted through schools in the southern part of Western Australia. It begins on a Friday evening and goes through until Sunday.

Amid the usual media picture of young people as lazy, jobless or involved in crime, if one looks very carefully each year one may find a story about a group of students who want to make an impact on our society and on the society which they are in the process of inheriting.

The standing of Pathways Now is increasingly being recognised. The West Australian reported on 22 June this year that a State government Minister, the Minister for Environment, Bob Pearce, had commented that it is one of the most important student conferences in the State. I believe that it would be a shame to let this opportunity go by without congratulating all those involved in Pathways Now and to encourage them for the future.
Pathways Now concludes each year with a communique and a list of recommendations. Those recommendations are preceded by this request:

SPEECH.PARA: The delegates at Pathways Now Student Environmental Conference earnestly request the adult community in general (and parts of it in particular) to listen, to take heed and respond in writing!
I believe that when it refers to parts of the community in particular it has specific concern about those of us who are in positions of responsibility and decision making.

PARA.TAB: Following this request, there is a list of 26 recommendations. I seek leave to have the communique which lists them incorporated in Hansard at this time.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: PATHWAYS NOW

SPEECH.PARA: BACKGROUND

PARA.TAB: In 1989 students from Dalwallinu District High School attended a conference called Pathways to the Future. They felt frustrated at the lack of concrete action and decided that they wanted to hold their own conference called Pathways Now. Gosnells SHS was the only other school attending.

Since then Pathways Now has been held for three days each year at Gosnells and each year students have undertaken more and more of the organising and running of the conference. Gosnells students, with of course considerable guidance and help from willing staff volunteers, have learned how to successfully handle publicity, organisation, invitations, catering, chairing sessions, facilitating groups, running the secretariat, media liaison and entertainment including a social and play on the conference's themes.

SPEECH.PARA: THE 1992 CONFERENCE

PARA.TAB: This year's conference was attended by eighty-two student delegates from 22 schools attended. After meeting in nine panel discussions in which they questioned adults about vital environmental issues, they went on excursions to see energy and regeneration projects and to explore ways to connect with each other and with the environment. They then developed 55 project proposals to implement in their schools on return and for circulation to give others ideas. These projects will be submitted to the Ministry of Education to stimulate ideas throughout WA. Through three mini-parliament sessions the delegates discussed the messages they would send to adult decision-makers. Their 26 recommendations follow.

SPEECH.PARA: WA EARTH CARE CHARTER 1992

PARA.TAB: The following recommendations were passed by student delegates from 24 schools and colleges throughout the South West, wheat belt and metropolitan Perth on Sunday June 14. A strict criterion was used: if more than three delegates opposed, recommendations lapsed.
The delegates at PATHWAYS NOW STUDENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONFERENCE earnestly request the adult community in general (and parts of it in particular) to listen, take heed and respond in writing:

1. Funds and labour (which were to be directed to the Collie coal power station) should be redirected to an alternative Non-Fossil power project and SECWA should encourage off peak rates to reduce peak consumption.
2. We recommend the government subsidize the planting of trees on farms to help reduce problems such as salinity.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 3. Deposit systems to be introduced with packaging, newspapers etc. Paying extra for products e.g. 20%—get it back when you return it.
4. The Federal Government reduces spending on military related projects by at least 10% and utilise this money in areas which replenish the environment e.g. reforestation.
5. The facilities for depositing recyclable products be more readily available to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 6. The Ministry of Education directs manual arts teachers not to use endangered trees for woodwork in schools. Cost factors should not be an argument against this.
7. Much more emphasis be placed on facilities for cyclists and pedestrians rather than motorists rather than building more roads.
8. That environmentally sound patents cannot be bought by private companies, for which that purchase would be a conflict of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 9. The council should encourage the use of cycleways in the urban areas by making more of them. These cycleways should be evident and regularly swept.
10. That birth control promotion by governments be increased to counter the pressures of our increasing population.

11. The families of WA undertake an environmental "Back to the Bush" camp or excursion to be initiated within the next five years so young people can appreciate the natural environment and their ownership of it.

12. The schools are made more involved in the evaluation to our environment, such as rivers and bushland, in association with CALM, and where possible are able to be involved in the clean up and regeneration process.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 13. We recommend that the facilities for depositing recyclable products be more readily available to the public.

14. We encourage the bartering system. This would occur between any families interested. One family may grow fruit, another grains, another meat etc. You could swap your spare produce with the excess from another family. This would save packaging and produce less trucks' fumes.

15. Builders and planners can make their houses to be energy efficient dwelling, such as houses facing north-south, with smaller windows that face east-west etc. If this is accomplished successfully people will have the house to convert their houses to the above and the idea will catch on and many more families will begin to feel it is a good idea.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 16. The Education Ministry set up a formal school course (eg like theatre arts) to educate students about the environment. This should include practical as well as theory education.

17. A greater incentive for the use of public transport to be introduced, in the form of a much more efficient transport system involving more buses and trains running more frequently; extra routes to facilitate movement between suburban areas and restriction on cars entering the city.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 18. The Ministry of Education provides a plan for government schools to educate students in a practical manner about the environment, using intensive recycling projects, composting sites, vegetable growing, and other examples which the students can practically apply to their own lives and homes.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 19. There should be stronger sanctions placed on industries which pollute the water ways.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 20. Our government should listen to the voice of Australian citizens, at least more than they are now. One suggestion for this solution may be to have a "People's Committee" which the government WILL listen to. Australians should be able to feel comfortable talking to the peoples committee and can speak out about their ideas about what they want in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 21. Pollution to be cut down in Cockburn Sound to reduce and prevent effects on humans and animals by: filtering wastes Education campaigns, Warning signs that poisoning may occur, tightening government restrictions and regular company checks.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 22. That government control and place tighter restrictions on the sale of highly toxic pesticides, or at the same time subsidize and encourage organic farming.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 23. The pesticide THYMIT be taken off the market.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 24. Applaud and support Greenpeace actions to prevent illegal whaling under the guise of research; excluding duck shooting.
25. Tax incentives to maintain natural bushland for habitat maintenance, based on value of land if cleared, especially on agricultural blocks and large purchases of land.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

PARA.TAB: 26. There be conferences for young adults and adults combined, particularly adults in power. They would be conferences where anyone has freedom of speech having no age restrictions. We also recommend that a young adult represents all of us as advisor in parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: ** Passed Unanimously

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that we in this Senate fit into that part of the adult community which is being addressed in this document. The recommendations cover many aspects of environmental concern and other issues which are at the heart of Green thinking. For that reason, I wish to highlight just three of them now.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 20 begins:

SPEECH.PARA: Our government should listen to the voice of Australian citizens—

and goes on to suggest a people's committee to act as a communication channel. My response to this recommendation is twofold. I am pleased that the students have not written us off, for they still believe that the structures by which our society is governed have a place. But—and this is my second response—as parliamentarians we should all take this to heart. It is not only government that needs to listen to the people; it is all sides of this chamber and of the other place. The young people who bring this recommendation will soon be of voting age. If at that stage in their lives they believe that the voice of the people of Australia is not heard within these corridors and chambers, our democracy will be in grave danger.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 26 calls for conferences involving young adults and adults, particularly adults in power. They are very tactful not to say `older adults'. It is a call for participatory democracy and for turning upside down the present political debate. The recommendation also contains these words:

SPEECH.PARA: We also recommend that a young adult represents all of us as adviser in parliament.

At a time when youth unemployment is taxing minds all over the country, at a time of summits about the issue and at a time of Budget, this call is all the more pertinent. It demonstrates that there is a reservoir of creativity among our young people and that they have the ideas and the will to participate in our society if we have the courage to listen.

PARA.TAB: Lastly, I draw attention to recommendation 4, which calls for a reduction of at least 10 per cent in Australia's defence budget, with the money being redirected into environmental projects—for example, reafforestation. Clearly, these students have recognised that we, the older generation, are stealing from them the planet they love and that we are killing it and the people of the planet. They are asking that we leave it in a habitable condition for them and for their children. It is a request we cannot ignore; nor can we push it away and declare it an idealistic fantasy. We are determining the shape of their future, not ours.
