I began by saying that the conference buoyed up my spirits. I repeat that now as I conclude. These students have looked at a range of issues over which they could have become very downhearted. But they have applied themselves to see that there is hope and work to be done. I pray that we will not stand in their way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 May in the Queensland Parliament we saw a most extraordinary incident. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a transcript of the proceedings of Question Time on that day. I did give a copy of this data to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The transcript read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Question Time, Queensland Parliament, May 7, 1992.

Joan Sheldon: My first question without notice is to the Premier, Mr Goss, did Commissioner Newnham ever raise with the Premier the possibility of illegal donations being made to a Labor member of parliament or to the Labor Party.
Wayne Goss: Mr Newnham raised with me . . .
Speaker: Order! Order! Would you repeat the question Mrs Sheldon.
Joan Sheldon: Did Commissioner Newnham ever raise with the Premier the possibility of illegal donations being made to a Labor member of parliament or to the Labor Party.
Wayne Goss: Ah. No he did not.
Speaker: Order! The member for Landsborough.
Joan Sheldon: My second question without notice is also to the Premier, Mr Goss.

Is it a fact that Commissioner Newnham forwarded directly to you a copy of a Federal Police transcript of a telephone conversation in which a $5,000 bribe was discussed by the former disgraced police Minister, the member for Chatsworth with another person under Federal Police investigation.
Is it a fact that following this advice from Commissioner Newnham arrangements were made for the $5,000 to be listed as a legal donation to the Australian Labor Party.

Wayne Goss: Mr Speaker, the situation that occurred was that there was no illegal donation which was the previous question. No, no he did not raise with me any illegal donation nor did he raise with me any bribe, at any stage. He did however, and I
Speaker: Interjections . . . Order!

Wayne Goss: No, no, Mr Speaker I am going to have to be very careful about this, I am going to have to be very careful because I have to defend the Government but at the same time I want to avoid the sort of impropriety which we have just seen from the member for Landsborough, by raising a matter which she knows is before the courts.

Now, now, Mr Speaker, and what happened was and I haven't had a chance to check this yet, but I will check it and to the best of my recollection, sometime in 1990, I think it was one or two days after the Minister for Police had gone overseas, when the Minister for Police in 1990, had left the State and gone overseas I received a request from the Police Commissioner if he could see me in the Minister's absence and he said it was confidential and he needed to see me personally, I didn't know what it was about.

When he came to see me I was very disappointed, I have not revealed this before because . . . as we all know, as we all know, the common wisdom and the media run campaign is very much one of suggesting that there has been a smear campaign conducted by the former Police Minister, against the Commissioner over the course of the last year.

But well prior to that in fact back in mid 1990 I was very sorry to say that the Police Commissioner came behind the Minister's back to se me, no, no to hand to me . . . the Minister was overseas and as soon as he went away the Commissioner came to see me to show to me a transcript indicating a certain individual, had discussed in a phone conversation with another individual, not the then Minister at all, the making of a donation to that member's election campaign. A member of the Labor Party for that member's campaign.

I said that on the face of it there was nothing improper about it but it certainly warranted investigation by myself and that I would do it and the Police Commissioner went away well satisfied with the half hours work.

Mr Speaker, what happened then was that I determined if a member of parliament, particularly a Minister, particularly a Minister had received such a substantial donation, then there were certain bench marks of propriety that that Minister would have to had measured up to, if he was to remain in my Cabinet . . . You mentioned pecuniary interests, someone did, that's one, that I would expect such a donation to be declared, another would be that I would expect, particularly if the payment was in cash as was suggested in the transcript, that, that instead of what happened in the past where it was put into somebody's pocket, that the second test would be, that it be fully documented and accounted for in the normal accounting records of the electorate organisation of that member.

I made inquiries and I found, I was able to confirm that in fact, there had been a declaration of the donation by the member in his declaration of pecuniary interests, that furthermore the matter had not been placed in the members own funds, but had simply been passed on to the Electoral Executive Committee in the normal way that all donations are passed on, in various political organisations and in the Labor Party, and it was fully receipted and accounted for in the normal way.

But, out of an excess of caution, but let me say out of an excess of caution, because one immediately becomes suspicious, one immediately becomes suspicious when somebody goes behind the back of their Minister in this way.
I decided to discuss the matter with the Chairman of the Criminal Justice Commission, Sir Max Bingham.
I laid the facts before him and Sir Max Bingham advised me that in his view, the member concerned had acted with complete propriety, complete propriety and acknowledged to me.

And I remind you that Sir Max Bingham is a former Liberal member of parliament, and confirmed to me that it was a quite normal political donation that had been handled in a normal way that had been properly accounted for and was the subject of a pecuniary interest declaration.

And I say in conclusion Mr Speaker this member is an absolute disgrace for raising a matter which she knows is before the court and the only reason it has not come out before now is because no other Queenslander would break the convention that this person has just broken by raising something that is before the courts and which has been before the courts over the course of the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Goss Labor Government, for what were clearly political reasons, wiped from the record not only a significant part of Question Time but also expunged vast sections of debate from the Hansard. What I have incorporated is that material which was expunged from the Hansard in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The questions were asked by the Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, Mrs Joan Sheldon, to Premier Goss. Premier Goss freely answered two questions from Mrs Sheldon that were very important in the public interest about the planned downfall of Police Commissioner Noel Newnham. At no time did Mrs Sheldon raise in her questions that these issues were before the court. The facts were that it was the Premier who chose to identify that these matters were before the courts. Despite that knowledge, he went on to answer the questions primarily to defend the former Police Minister, Mr Mackenroth.

Mr Mackenroth was the close Goss associate who had to resign from Cabinet after the Criminal Justice Commission alleged that he had misused his travel allowances. It was Premier Goss's response to those questions that raised more issues than they answered. These include:

SPEECH.PARA: * What the Police Commissioner told Mr Goss in February 1990 when he went to him with transcripts of a Federal Police intercept that revealed that Mr Mackenroth had received a $5000 payment from a person under police investigation who had been seeking to bribe taxation officers.
* What did Mr Goss say to CJC Chairman Sir Max Bingham?
* And was this the genesis of Labor's vendetta against the Queensland Police Commissioner, Noel Newnham?

There has been much ill-informed debate about this issue. There has been a range of arguments from some quarters that Mrs Sheldon had no right to raise this issue and that it should have been let lie. However, an examination of the transcript of the completed Coco trial showed why the Police Commissioner had reason to be worried about his new police Minister when he went to see the Premier in February 1990. This is a direct quote from the Crown Prosecutor, Mr Weinberg, who told the trial of Mr Santo Coco in Brisbane earlier this year:
The material—that is the Mackenroth tape—discloses that between the 13th and 16th November 1989, there were several communications between Coco and Mackenroth by phone and in person.
Mr Justice De Jersey of the Queensland Supreme Court then asked:
What did you say? It shows an attempt to confer a bribe on Mr Mackenroth?
The Crown Prosecutor, Mr Weinberg, replied:
It shows a willingness to have the money which has been handed over treated as a bribe.

The Crown says it shows a willingness on the part of those two accused, who have handed over a sum of $5000 in cash, indeed a preference as far as Coco is concerned, to have that money retained as a bribe.

The evidence contained in the Mackenroth material, however, shows that Coco was serious about having Vasta restored to the bench, and that Vasta was serious about having his position reviewed by the ALP when it came into government.

The Mackenroth conversations occurred between 13 and 16th November 1989 at the very same time as these two accused are allegedly engaged in a conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth by bribing the two tax officers to reverse sham transactions.

(This was) in order to be able to shout from the rooftops before the election that Vasta was wrongly found to have engaged in sham transactions and the professed aim being to have him restored to the bench.
This is the conspiracy the Crown alleges.
Coco was himself highly desirous of Mackenroth keeping the money without a receipt and treating it as a bribe.
They (Coco and Vasta) had an association which was far from innocent with Mr Mackenroth.

While I am aware that the Crown did not offer any evidence that Mr Mackenroth had knowingly accepted a bribe, it was clear that the former Police Minister was prepared to support the former Queensland Supreme Court judge, Angelo Vasta. In Parliament on 7 January 1989, the honourable member for Chatsworth, Mr Mackenroth, made a lengthy defence of Mr Vasta, when the then judge was ordered to the Bar of the House to give reasons why he should not have been removed from the Supreme Court bench.

PARA.TAB: In light of these circumstances Mr Newnham, the Police Commissioner, had been very concerned when he was handed a transcript of the Federal Police intercept of a conversation between the member for Chatsworth and Mr Coco. Even if Mr Mackenroth had not known that this $5,000 payment or donation or whatever they like to call it was meant as a bribe, it was an act of gross political stupidity by someone who was aspiring to become the Police Minister in Queensland in a few months.

So, in my view, and I believe in the view of most Queenslanders, Mr Newnham was entirely justified in seeking a meeting with the Premier, Mr Goss, in February 1990 to discuss the transcript. He had a Police Minister who was clearly involved in a Federal Police investigation and may have been involved in a criminal trial. Mr Mackenroth was then the Police Minister who had the daunting task of introducing a raft of Fitzgerald reforms to clean up a police force and take on significant corrupt elements who were still in the Service. The fact that Mr Mackenroth was caught up in this investigation laid him open to serious compromise. If this transcript had fallen into the hands of corrupt elements of the Police Service, then the whole carriage of the Fitzgerald reforms would have been threatened. In Premier Goss's answer to a question by Mrs Sheldon on 8 May, the Premier said:

SPEECH.PARA: Back in mid 1990 I am very sorry to say that the Police Commissioner came behind the Minister's back to see me. . . to hand to me. . . the Minister was overseas and as soon as he went away the Commissioner came to see me to show me a transcript indicating a certain individual. . . (and) the making of a donation to that member's election campaign.

Premier Goss made it clear in that answer that somehow he regarded it as improper for the Police Commissioner to see him about a matter of grave concern about his Police Minister. But what did the Premier suggest the Police Commissioner do with this material that he had come into possession of? Shred it? I expect this would probably be standard practice on these types of issues—destroy the evidence. Clearly it was from this point that this Labor Government decided that Commissioner Newnham was a loose cannon on the deck and that he had to go.

PARA.TAB: The first public indication of this was when the details of an incident involving the Tasmanian driving licence of CJC Chairman, Sir Max Bingham, was leaked to the press. Then we saw the issue culminate in the ultimate display of sour grapes from the disgraced former Police Minister Mr Mackenroth, who made a number of extraordinary allegations against Mr Newnham, none of which could be proved. But, of course, Mr Mackenroth worked on the notion that if you throw enough mud, some of it will stick. For months Mr Newnham found himself in limbo, fighting for both his career and his reputation.

The Premier brought special legislation to the State Parliament, supposedly to help Mr Newnham, but this was a public relations gesture. When the Police Commissioner was cleared by the Supreme Court, the Premier and his mates once again set about the task of seeking to destroy Mr Newnham and force him out of the job. What is most disturbing is that even details from the pecuniary interest files of Police Commissioner Newnham have been leaked to the press. In the Sunday Mail of 17 May, there were clear details of Mr Newnham's financial affairs in what was clearly a politically motivated leak to embarrass him. The bottom line is that the Queensland police service was leaderless at a time when it was facing a crisis.

Crime in Queensland is increasing by a general rate of about 25 per cent and, based on assaults per head of population, Queensland is, regrettably, the most dangerous place in Australia to live. What has happened to the war against corruption in the Police Service? The Government should ponder why police officers who have been investigated in the past or named at the Fitzgerald inquiry are openly cheering on the State Government's vendetta against Commissioner Noel Newnham. The public in Queensland is also wondering why the Government's thought police are working overtime to clean up the image of disgraced former Police Minister Mr Mackenroth while at the same time undermining the reputation of Police Commissioner Noel Newnham.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the notice of the Senate the plight of some investors who are in a most difficult situation. I consider them to be the victims of the unregulated investment system in this country. Their plight has been brought to my attention by the Australian Investors Association which has argued for years that our current laissez-faire approach to investment and investment promotion and advice imposes heavy costs on the unwary investor. Again, we see the effects of the `greed is good' decade of the 1980s bearing down on the ignorant and the vulnerable. In particular, the question of the remuneration of advisers is a key issue in these cases.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will be aware that the same question is currently in the public debate in the area of superannuation where, in some cases, outrageous undisclosed commissions were paid to advisers—at a level well above a reasonable fee commensurate with the amount of services actually provided. The Australian Investors Association has recently received a number of complaints about financial distress being suffered by a number of investors in relation to negative gearing investment schemes that were heavily promoted by the Advance and Challenge banks. The experience of three parties in particular has been as follows.

The first party is that of the so-called independent advisers who, in most cases, derive their income primarily from commissions and are in fact sellers of investment products who strongly recommend those investments that pay a high commission and denigrate other investments that would often be more suitable for investors. In the negative gearing schemes they earned commissions of up to 24 per cent of the investors' capital. For an investor with capital of $30,000 they would earn $7,200 for, at most, a few hours work, often done by people completely without qualifications in accounting, finance or an allied field. By contrast, if they had recommended low risk investments they would earn commissions of about $300 and on medium risk investments they would earn $1,200 to $1,800. The second case is that of the banks, which derive large income from two sources: firstly, interest on loans which they probably would not have otherwise earned; and, secondly, entry fees and management fees from the property trusts managed by their subsidiary into which the investment was made.

The third case is that of the hapless investors who suffered losses of up to 200 per cent of their capital. They now face margin calls to pay cash to the banks or to provide acceptable securities. In the event of their not being able to meet the margin calls, the whole of the debt which was scheduled for repayment two years or so ahead can become immediately due. The final result is that they could lose the investment—namely, the property trust units—and still owe to the bank an amount that may be as large as their original capital. That would mean that they would not have the option of continuing to hold the units in the hope that in time there might be a recovery in value.

If the investors had been made aware of the full extent of the risk they would face, the fact that they could lose more than 100 per cent of their capital and that the gearing multiplied the transaction costs of about 10 per cent to a figure of 40 per cent of their capital—so that an increase of less than 40 per cent in capital would mean a loss to the investor—the investors would have no cause for complaint. But they were not informed of those facts. The promotional material of the banks and their subsidiaries and the comments of the advisers made little, if any, reference to such risks. False statements were made to the effect that the expertise of the property trust managers and the ownership of prime, well located tenants would ensure that the properties would hold their values. But past experience has shown that prime, well located properties were not immune to capital decline of 40 per cent or more in market slumps that occur from time to time.

Banks have an obligation under the common law to ensure that people executing documents are aware of the nature of their obligations. As a result of court decisions, some banks, for example, will not allow people to sign a guarantee unless they have previously sought independent advice and can produce a letter from a solicitor confirming that this has been done.

Obviously, the borrowers for negative gearing investments should have been made aware of the facts set out above, including the possible loss of over 100 per cent of capital and the fact that gearing could increase costs to 40 per cent of the capital. What makes the situation more significant is that some of the negative gearing investments were made in 1990 after the property slump had started, and after a decision of the NCSC meant that no unit holder in an unlisted property trust had an assured and unrestrained right to redeem units. The fact that clients may have been advised by a so-called independent adviser does not meet the obligation of the banks, because the very strong financial incentive for advisers to recommend negative gearing meant that their advice was not independent.

One matter which these circumstances has brought to light is that the powers and jurisdiction of the banking ombudsman are inadequate. The ombudsman has no authority to act on claims against the subsidiaries of banks. I am not aware of whether this delineation is a deliberate one, but it does mean that a significant section of the financial system, which is controlled by the banks, is not covered by the excellent ombudsman arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the Senate's attention a program called SURF SAFE, which was previewed at a special showing last night, Wednesday, 19 August. Many of us are aware of the recent tragedy at Kiama on 11 July where seven people drowned. The importance of a program such as SURF SAFE has been demonstrated by this incident and a number of others which are becoming commonplace on the coastline of Australia. Such accidents are preventable, but we cannot expect people to use commonsense and a cautious approach to our beaches if there is not sufficient prior knowledge and education relating to the dangers of the ocean.

PARA.TAB: Mr Jim Bradley, the honorary national surf survival certificate coordinator for the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia, designed SURF SAFE. SURF SAFE is an audiovisual program aimed at every 10-year-old Australian schoolchild. It must be noted that a major feature of rescues is that victims do not live adjacent to the coastline. Instead, they come from areas some distance away—in most cases, in excess of 50 kilometres. Another startling statistic is that 42 per cent of rescue victims are children under the age of 16. These figures have been carefully analysed and SURF SAFE has been designed to cover the bulk of potential victims.

SURF SAFE will consist of a 23-minute video, achievement certificates and a number of theory exercises. The program is designed to cover a multitude of areas including types of waves, surf awareness, exploring rock shelves, coastal development, survival rules, the importance of obeying flags and alarms, assisting others and what to do in basic accident situations. SURF SAFE, it is hoped, will result in a dramatic decline in the number of rescues needed and the number of accidents that unnecessarily occur.

The problem lies not only in Kiama but all over Australia. It is impossible to rope or fence off the entire Australian coastline. To prevent accidents, we must increase and improve education relating to surf safety and awareness. We cannot afford such tragedies as that which happened at Kiama. The Surf Life Saving Association of Australia does its best to supervise and rescue thousands of people every summer. However, better education needs to be provided to Australians if we are to change the course of disaster along our coastline. Surfing and swimming are major developing areas in our culture, particularly among our young. SURF SAFE is a vital program, but it does rely on the support of the Federal Government and the residents of Australia.

Joanne Corbett, who is a year 10 student from Tamworth High School and who has been with me this week on work experience, has written this speech and she attended the presentation last night. We must make sure that education is good and if education of the surf could be as good as it has been for Joanne Corbett in the job that she has done for me this week in work experience, I am sure we will not have the tragedies we have had in the past. I appreciate the fact that she sat in the gallery tonight to listen to this speech and I thank her for the time she has spent working for me.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Deaths of Kenneth and Yasuko Myer and Ron Saw

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to refer briefly to the deaths of three people, two of them being, in their different ways, outstanding Australians, and the other being a very impressive Australian by adoption. I refer in the first instance to Kenneth Myer and his wife, Yasuko, who died when their light plane crashed in Alaska a couple of weeks ago. Mr Myer had a reputation as an unconventional but a very caring leader of the Melbourne establishment who decided to move to Sydney. He spent, after standing down as Chairman of Myer Emporium, most of his time in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Kenneth Myer was born in San Francisco, the son of a Russian Jewish migrant who had business interests in Australia. His father's name originally had been Simcha Baevski, but he changed it to Sidney Myer. In 1929, Sidney Myer based his family in Australia and Kenneth, the eldest son, attended Melbourne Grammar and Geelong Grammar schools.

After the war broke out in Europe, Kenneth Myer spent a year studying humanities at Princeton University in the United States before returning to Australia to join the Royal Australian Navy's anti-submarine service as a colleague in arms of my late father. He served in the Navy until 1946, attaining the rank of lieutenant and being awarded the Distinguished Service Cross.

After the war Mr Myer joined the family business as a salesman and made several overseas trips to study retailing, becoming a Myer director in 1948 and then Chairman in 1966, a position he held for 10 years. After Myer's merger with Coles, he was a director of Coles Myer from 1985 to 1989.

Mr Ken Myer presided over a big expansion of the company, as the Melbourne Age has reported. Seeing it spread into Melbourne suburbs and branch out with the Target chain, he was obsessed, the Age says, with new technology and innovation and, in 1970, he went to New York to accept the prestigious National Retail Merchants Association's international award. He was the first Australian to do so.

A noted philanthropist, a trait which he acknowledged was inherited from his father, Mr Ken Myer headed the Sidney Myer Fund, founded by the Myer Foundation in 1959, and was President of the Howard Florey Institute of Experimental Physiology and Medicine.

He was, of course, one of Australia's foremost patrons of the arts, serving as a trustee of the Art Gallery of New South Wales since 1990 and Chairman of the Victorian Arts Centre Trust from 1969 to 1975. In the 1980s he donated a 200-hectare property he co-owned on the New South Wales south coast to the State Government. This has become a sanctuary for rare flora and fauna and is part of the Mimosa Rocks National Park.

Ken Myer shocked the conservative establishment in 1972 when he signed the letter from prominent Australians urging the election of a Whitlam Labor government after 23 years of coalition rule. This caused problems in his family, with his mother, Dame Merlyn Myer, contacting the then Liberal Prime Minister, Mr McMahon, to dissociate the family from her son's statement. I must say that at some stage later it was suggested that he may well have been an appropriate candidate to succeed Sir Paul Hasluck as Governor-General, but instead the ALP government of the time proposed Sir John Kerr for the position. It is interesting to speculate on whether history would have been a little different had Mr Myer been appointed to that position.

After the election of the Hawke Government, Mr Myer was appointed chairman of the ABC, but he quit three years later after a controversial time as head of the national broadcaster. I last spoke with Mr Myer not so long ago at a dinner that my wife and I attended at the home of Robert and Angela Raymond. Ken and Yasuko were speaking with great enthusiasm about their up-coming fishing trip to Alaska, despite Yasuko's difficulty in travelling following an accident in which a four wheel drive vehicle had rolled on her. Mr Myer had some useful words of advice to me about appropriate government policies for the arts in Australia.

At the age of 71, he was one of the most energetic, lively and intellectually stimulating people one could hope to be involved with. I know all Australians will regret his untimely passing and that of his very supportive and very close wife. They had been together for 15 years and were utterly inseparable. If Ken Myer was to die in a plane crash, I think it was right that Yasuko should be with him.
The next person I will refer to is Ron Saw, who was an old journalist mate of mine from the 1950s and 1960s in Sydney where we worked together. As a tribute in the Telegraph Mirror recently said:
He was in every way larger than life—funny, generous, rambunctious, stubborn, gregarious, quick-tempered, quick-witted—and rated by contemporaries one of the best journalists Australia has seen.

SPEECH.PARA: He was a good mate and I must say that I had many lively times with him. I regret to say that in those days he had a glass jaw, which did not discourage him from expressing himself with more courage than sense in difficult situations—situations which I might say were often generated by his own ebullience when encouraged by a beer or two. At some stage he had worked for every proprietor in Sydney, having started off in Western Australia on the now defunct Daily News. In Sydney he worked at different times for Sir Frank Packer, the Fairfaxes and Rupert Murdoch.

PARA.TAB: He came to Sydney in the 1950s having been born in Western Australia into a stockbroking family. In fact, the family had held the number one seat on the Melbourne stock exchange—I think the name of the firm was Saw, Reid and Co. Ron, who was quite a good Aussie Rules footballer, had no intention of becoming a broker and got a job on the Perth Daily News before coming to Sydney in the 1950s.

From the Sydney Sun, which was then owned by the Fairfaxes, he went to the Daily Mirror and from there he moved to Sir Frank Packer's Daily Telegraph, where he wrote the Ray Castle column for many years, before moving on to the Bulletin where I worked as a columnist and editor of its `People' section. Ron Saw was laid low by a stroke in 1980. He fought back and wrote a series of articles about the experience, which won him the Journalist of the Year award and which eventually became an inspiration generally.

Ron Saw and I had lunch here not so long ago to talk about how governments could play a more useful role in preventing strokes and helping recovery. He fought his stroke and it is reasonable to say he almost won, but not quite. In 1967, Ron Saw and his third wife, Ellie, left Sydney for Noosa from where he wrote columns for the Bulletin and the Sunday Telegraph. It was in Noosa at the age of 63 that he died just a week or so ago. I am certain all journalists will regret the passing of Ron Saw and will have remarkable memories of him. We convey to his wife and family deep commiserations for the passing of an exciting and outstanding Australian journalist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the letter that Senator Cook incorporated during this adjournment debate, and make some comments on the issue that was raised here on the last sitting day of the autumn sittings. The first thing I wish to do is thank Senator Cook for putting this letter down and having the courtesy to send it to us yesterday.I want to highlight a number of points from this letter because I think they are relevant to the matter before us now.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I want to highlight in the letter is that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Reimbursement for air travel has been made on the basis of the applicable economy class fare.
I will come back to that in a moment. The next thing I wish to highlight is at the bottom of page 1. It reads:

I have asked the Secretary of my Department to examine whether these errors have any broader implications for the Department's accounting and audit procedures and to report to me as soon as possible on this.

I will be interested, if it is possible, to hear the outcomes of that request, because it is quite obvious from what we have before us that that is very necessary. The third part of the letter which I wish to comment on—and the Minister raised it here tonight—reads:
If you think it useful, I will arrange for officers of my Department to be available to go through the details of these expenditures.
I thank the Minister for that opportunity. I certainly will be taking it up and I look forward to doing just that.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make a few comments beyond that in terms of what has been put down. Firstly, it is interesting to note in terms of the accounting procedures, that all the overpayments, other than one which was $7.60 to a Mr Wayne Misdale who was a guest speaker at the working party, were to the Western Australian Builders Labourers Federation. All other claims were correctly paid.

I now return to the substance of the question that I asked on that particular day. I want to highlight precisely the so-called allegations that I made. I asked—and I reiterated it in the debate that night—`Why has the Minister approved payments of $2,267 and $634 for travel?' Possibly I could have been more technically correct and used the words `agreed to', but in essence they mean the same.

If we turn to page two of the letter that was put on the table tonight, the Minister quite correctly now informs us that this amount has, of course, not been paid. In any event, only a return economy fare would be reimbursed. What I want to say about that, and my question—and in the debate on that night I said I did not know at that time whether they had been paid—is that it is quite clear from the letter dated 1 June 1992 that the Minister tabled, that it was the intention, at least on 1 June, that these claims should be paid. If not, the 1 June letter by his senior adviser to Mr Terry Brosnan is not an accurate reflection of the discussions that were held. I refer in particular to that letter entitled `Reimbursement of Travel—WABLF'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken to the Minister about this
. He is of the view that these are legitimate expenses under the WATUAG arrangements.
. The meeting on 17 December was with the Minister and Stan Sharkey to review developments federally on the building reform strategy and forthcoming legislation on the BLF deregistration.
—it was at our request and was important to the future of our reform efforts in this area.
Grateful advice that funds are available.

As far as I am concerned, the question that I asked that day was legitimate. It was the intention from this memo that those funds should be paid. When those funds were not available, as we have been told through the Building Industry Working Group, an attempt was made to find out whether funds were available under the WATUAG agreement.

PARA.TAB: I have quite legitimate reason to believe that had I not asked that question that day, Mr Reynolds would have been paid. I also think it is fair to say that had I not asked that question, the accounting mistakes that were discovered and the overpayments that occurred would not have been picked up. I hope that the review of the accounting procedures will address and correct these problems.

I shall leave my comments at that tonight. I stand by my assertion that my question was a legitimate one. There is no doubt that the intention was to meet the claims on these expenses. As I said, this is borne out by the letter of 1 June. I look forward to taking up the invitation issued by the Minister to discuss and look at the details further with officers of his Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the attention of the Senate tonight some correspondence that I received from Mr Lewis Robinson, an 89-year-old man of fierce independence who describes himself as being still sane in this very upset planet. He is a man who has made a solid contribution to the prosperity of our community through his manual skills and his personal integrity.

PARA.TAB: After receiving his letter, I paid him a brief visit. I was able to admire in his home some of the products of his working life. I saw some of the fine furniture that he had made. In his letter to me he writes:

SPEECH.PARA: No-one seems to have time to stop and listen.
He went on to say:
I am not a religious fanatic but I do know there must be a creator because I have had a lovely garden in the past and that is divine proof.

He enclosed a little verse which he asks me to read to Parliament in the hope that somebody might take the time to listen and perhaps give it a little thought. He suggests that I might find some time in between fights of the opposing parties. I think this is such a time, so I will now read what he gave me. The verse reads:
It is a good thing that God above
Has never gone on strike
Because he wasn't treated fairly
Or things he didn't like.
If He had ever once sat down
And said, `That's it. I'm through.
I've had enough of those on earth,
So this is what I'll do.'
`I'll give my order to the sun:
Cut off your heat supply.
And to the moon: Give no more light.
And run those oceans dry.'
Then just to make it really tough
And put the pressure on,
Turn off the air and oxygen
Till every breath is gone.'
Men say they want a better deal,
And so on strike they go,
But what a deal we've given God,
To whom all things we owe.
We don't care whom we hurt or harm
To gain the things we like;
But what a mess we'd all be in
If God should go on strike.
I have fulfilled my obligation to Mr Robinson and I hope that his wishes will be granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments tonight about a copy of a letter that has come to my attention. I understand that it is a letter that Senator Kernot has sent to a wide range of farm machinery dealers throughout Australia in connection with the discussion that has been taking place following the introduction by the Government in May of its sales tax simplification package, which we are in the process of debating in the Senate at the moment. There are a couple of points about the letter that I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate. I raise them following the extensive discussions that were held on this matter during the public hearings last week of the Senate select committee which is looking at the Government's sales tax package.

PARA.TAB: To go back one step, there has been a concern amongst all the farm machinery dealers and, of course, their clients throughout Australia that one of the changes which appeared to have resulted from the sales tax simplification procedures was that farm machinery held by dealers would in fact be subject to a sales tax of 20 per cent or so, whereas previously that had not been the case and that machinery had been exempt. That was the subject of consideration by the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. That discussion of the Committee found that there appeared to have been a misunderstanding on the part of those people who had been advising the farm machinery dealers in regard to the effect of the sales tax simplification proposals. Indeed, the situation is, as we understand it on the basis of evidence from the Taxation Office officials and recorded in the Hansard of the Select Committee hearings which were held on 12 and 13 August last week, that there was a misunderstanding and that, in fact, the situation in practical terms is that there will be no change so far as farm machinery dealers and their equipment and parts are concerned from the situation now prevailing.

That was a matter which had concerned, certainly, the coalition which has received hundreds of representations Australia-wide expressing concern about the matter. I understand that it was also a matter that had been raised with the Australian Democrats. Senator Kernot, Senator Vanstone and I raised the issue at the Select Committee hearings last week and received the assurances that I have just explained to the Senate. Subsequently, Senator Kernot has written to all the farm machinery dealers saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats support the current system of allowing retailers to purchase stock free of sales tax, where the eventual sale will be exempt from tax. I raised this matter with the Taxation Office officials at a public hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax recently and they informed the Committee that the current situation will not change.

I have no quarrel with that paragraph in the letter—it is factually correct—other than just making it clear that it was not just the Democrats who raised this matter and had it flushed out at the public hearings of the Select Committee; it was a matter which the coalition had been pursuing very diligently as well. Whether we beat the Democrats to it or not, I do not know. But it would be unfortunate if there were any implication that the decision that the Taxation Office officials gave to the Committee last week was due to the Australian Democrats rather than to the coalition. I think that we both played a part in getting the right decision conveyed to us; that there had been a misunderstanding earlier.

PARA.TAB: The second part of Senator Kernot's letter concerns me a great deal more. She goes on to say to the farm machinery dealers who were the recipients of this letter:

SPEECH.PARA: I think you should be aware that the GST will impose an automatic tax penalty on farm machinery dealers. That is, your business will be detrimentally affected by the GST in exactly the manner that you feared would happen under the new wholesale sales tax regime.

PARA.TAB: According to the Fightback! documents, GST will be payable on all your stock purchases, including all transitional stocks held at the time of the introduction of the GST.

SPEECH.PARA: I can make only two comments about that letter. I can be charitable and say that Senator Kernot completely fails to understand the basic nature of a goods and services tax; or I could be a little uncharitable and say that she is deliberately setting out to mislead and concern the farming community in Australia—not only the farmers but also the dealers and distributors of farm machinery.

PARA.TAB: I hope my uncharitable option is not correct. I think it is more likely, from what I have seen and heard of the Australian Democrats and a wide range of others in this Parliament, including—I am very surprised to say—a former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, that there is a basic lack of understanding of the simple principles on which a goods and services tax or a value added tax operate.

Contrary to what Senator Kernot says in her letter, the GST does not apply to business inputs. There is no GST on business inputs. The whole of the goods and services tax is washed out of the production chain at each stage. That is why a goods and services tax is fundamentally different from a wholesale sales tax. A wholesale sales tax, by its very nature, gets caught up in the whole cost structure of the particular product that finishes up being sold. The goods and services tax, in complete contrast, gets excluded at every stage.

Senator Kernot has very gravely misinformed the recipients of this letter, who are the proprietors, as I understand it, of all the farm machinery distribution centres and networks throughout Australia. She has grossly misled them. She has told a factual untruth. I hope that Senator Kernot, being an honourable person, will take the opportunity now that I have raised this matter on behalf of the coalition to do the right thing and write another letter to every proprietor who has received this first letter.

I hope that she will be honest and admit to having made a mistake and that, contrary to her assertion in her first letter, the goods and services tax does not apply to business inputs and, therefore, will not apply to farm machinery and parts. I hope the concern that she has wrongly—I hope not wilfully—caused them will be corrected by a letter of apology for the error that she has made.

It is a matter of serious concern to me and the coalition that a political party that purports to try to follow issues in this country seems, through its senior spokesperson, not to have understood the first basic element of one of the major issues of debate in the Australian community today. I can only hope that the Democrats and the Labor Party may at last start to understand the basics of a goods and services tax or a value added tax so that they no longer continue to mislead the public in whatever they are saying on such a fundamentally important issue.

I am sorry that I did not have a chance to advise Senator Kernot that I was speaking on this matter tonight. It came to my attention at the very last minute. I hope that she will take note of my comments tonight and that she will do the honourable thing and react in the way in which any honourable senator would.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I turn to the matter that I want to raise, I wish to acknowledge the fact that the Australian Taxation Office has provided information to the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, as indicated by Senator Short. I have also been the recipient of some representations in respect of that matter. I had expressed my interest in it and I also examined the report when it was presented in the Senate. I wonder whether what the Taxation Office has said is sufficient for all time. I personally would like to see provisions in the legislation that would set at rest the minds of those in the agricultural machinery industry in particular, who made representations to me, to the Opposition, to the Democrats and, I suppose, also to the Government.

PARA.TAB: I briefly want to advise the Senate that today something quite extraordinary happened in this House. Yesterday I became aware of the fact that six of the so-called Chinese boat people whose refugee status had been acknowledged by DILGEA had come to Canberra at the invitation of some Australian and Chinese friends. We all recall the quite remarkable stories of endurance which these people went through in November and December of last year in Western Australia before they were found.

The true horror of the journey to Australia of these people is something that needs to be told at some stage. The horror of that journey was preceded by the great pressures that they were under in China. They are political dissidents. They have been persecuted in China. Because they expressed their views, a number of them were sacked from their jobs. They were pro-democracy supporters. One of them was a leader of the students in one of the major cities in south China and addressed pro-democracy meetings. Prior to the commencement of their journey, they were in hiding. The Chinese security police were seeking them out. That is some of the background. Today I invited them to come to Parliament House and invited senators and members to be present to hear some of their stories.

Of course, they are grateful for those who have supported them since their arrival in Australia, and they are of course grateful to Australia. But I have to say that we were also briefed by the President of the Indo-Chinese Refugees Association. She was able to give us some quite startling information regarding the treatment of these people at the hands of Australian authorities after they arrived here and for the succeeding months.

This information, of course, has come from a number of sources. It has been crosschecked and double-checked. The person who provided us with the information is a most honourable person whose integrity, honesty and reliability is unquestioned. All I want to say at this moment is that I am aware that a brother of one of these persons who has been granted refugee status had been refused refugee status and rejected by the Refugee Status Review Committee on the grounds that the information that was on the file was rather scanty relating to that individual's claim for refugee status. But if the information that we have is true—and it has been double-checked—that person when he came to Australia was subject to what can only be described as mental cruelty bordering on the shameful.

The Department has now been supplied with information which should convince it that this person was in absolutely no condition to confidently provide information to the officials in the manner in which it was demanded—because of that person's fear, because of that person's isolation, because of the denial to that person initially of the type of representation that was required.

I simply wish to flag the fact that I and a number of senators and members are very interested now in all of these cases. I believe this will be of great interest to this chamber, particularly to those members and senators who have had a long involvement in upholding the basic human rights of individuals. It is important to Australia to actually uphold, and to be seen to uphold, the defence of human rights in the finest tradition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long. I, too, wish to raise with the Senate a matter relating to a letter which Senator Cheryl Kernot has apparently written to, I understand, not just hundreds but perhaps thousands of proprietors of farm machinery businesses around Australia. In this letter she says that the goods and services tax, as set out in the Fightback! documents, will be payable on stock purchases, including all transitional stocks held at the time of the introduction of the goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: I discussed this matter with my colleague Senator Short before he spoke earlier this evening. I said to him that it is quite clear that Senator Kernot does not understand what a goods and services tax is all about. I hope all senators understand that it is a tax on final consumption and that taxes on business inputs are rebatable. So there is not any tax as such. Even though it may be imposed in the first instance, it is then rebatable at the time the goods are sold. I said to Senator Jim Short, `Perhaps she just doesn't understand. Perhaps you could explain it'. As a result of a conversation I had with one of her colleagues this evening, in which he indicated to me that there are many thousands of letters and that she does understand it, as does he, I believe she quite deliberately left out the business about it being rebatable. The attitude of the Australian Democrats is: when these farm machinery agents panic about the Fightback goods and services tax and contact Opposition members, they will be able to explain to them that it is rebatable. So Senator Kernot has quite deliberately set out to mislead all of these people.

Quite frankly, I find that unbelievable of one of my colleagues. As a matter of fact, today I was filling out a questionnaire, which some honourable senators may have received, about members of parliament. I was asked the question: do you think most members of parliament are honest? I answered yes. I was also asked: do you think that they are fair? I answered yes. I must say that if Senator Kernot, who appears to be a reasonable, decent and sensible citizen and who appears to be a reasonable, decent and sensible senator, is prepared to write such a letter as this in order to quite deliberately mislead people, I take it all back, and I call her a cheat and liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't call her a cheat and a liar.
—Order! It is unparliamentary to call another senator a liar.
—In Senator Evans's words, Mr President, in deference to you, I withdraw.

—I assure the Senate I will be very brief. I want to speak on the matter which Senator Harradine raised a short time ago. Senator Harradine sent around an invitation to meet with six Chinese people who have been granted refugee status in Australia. Unfortunately, I was delayed in the chamber after Question Time and the invitation did not come to my notice until some time after 4 o'clock, which was at the conclusion of the meeting that was arranged by Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: I deeply regret not being able to meet with the six individuals because I would have particularly liked to have had the opportunity to congratulate those people who, through the proper processes of the Immigration Act, have been granted refugee status in Australia. They have been granted refuge from the fear of persecution that has been proven through the system. I think the grant of refugee status to those people indicates that the system, as amended, is now working. I am very grateful for that, as I am sure all members of both Houses of Parliament are.

The people have been granted a four-year temporary residents permit because of the fear of persecution. On the granting of the refugee status to the people, they were interviewed by a number of media people. I saw one particular news item where the individuals were interviewed, as I understand it, through an interpreter. I expected the people to be expressing gratitude to Australia, the Government of Australia and indeed to the Parliament of Australia for granting those people that status. Unfortunately and regrettably, that was not the case. It turned out that whilst we have opened the doors to these people—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done today.

—I am talking about the media comments that are seen. On the day of their release, on arrival in Perth, they were interviewed by a commercial television station, and possibly the ABC as well but I cannot hold to that because I had not intended to speak on this. Instead of expressing gratitude on the TV screens to Australia, to the Parliament of Australia, to the Government of Australia and to the Department, they actually turned it into a bagging exercise. I cannot describe it as anything other than that.

PARA.TAB: It may be that the people were talking through an interpreter. I will give them the benefit of the doubt. If they were doing it on their own and they were accurately reported, I think it is wrong for people who have been taken in by this country and granted refuge to turn around and kick us in the face. I do not think it does the rest of the people who are seeking refugee status in Australia much good. There are many of them held in a number of detention centres around Australia, including Port Hedland, where the people in question came from.

There is much more that I would like to say on this matter, but I did promise not to delay the Senate.Yesterday the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations endorsed a report which will be coming to this chamber in the next two-week sittings of Parliament. This matter of refugees is discussed in-depth and in detail. It will provide ample opportunities to all senators to discuss the various matters. I will not debate the matter any further. I thank the Senate for its indulgence tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The refugees at the gathering today expressed appreciation. That was one of the first things they did.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

I do not propose to canvass all those issues. They have been put on the record by me, accurately and fully. But if one looks at what has been said and what is on the record, one will see that it does not support the allegations that have been made.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane did ask one question in his address tonight. He said that he would be interested in hearing from me or getting information about what is being done to improve or correct the accounting problems that bedevil my Department in this area. I cannot report that the Secretary to my Department has advised me that all of the accounting problems have been resolved—and I am aware that he is working on that—but I do have the letter in which he has advised me of the position with relation to the accounting problems. I showed that to Senator Crane earlier tonight after he spoke. It seems to me that for the sake of completeness it would be a good idea to now incorporate it as part of the record. I seek the leave of the Senate to do so.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO ISSUES RAISED BY SENATOR CRANE

PARA.TAB: You were entitled to receive in this matter, as on all others, advice which was right, which was right the first time, and which was right on time. The material we initially supplied to your office last week met none of these tests and it was only later brought up to the necessary high standard of accuracy and completeness. I regret that and am taking steps to remedy this less than impressive performance.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Equally important is that this exercise has shown a number of accounting errors by the Department which is of concern not only for these particular cases, but for what it might show about the Department's general accounting performance. I have undertaken urgent and major action to review in detail our performance over the last financial year in this area and to see what new steps need to be taken to ensure a much higher standard in future. I will keep you informed of progress.
(M.J. Costello)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the commercial kangaroo kill quota:
(1) Which of the 27 recommendations made by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, in its inquiry into the killing [of] kangaroos, (May 1985) have been adopted and/or acted upon.
(2) For each year between 1985 and 1992, what has been the estimated number of each commercial species of kangaroo in each State.
(3) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what was the actual number of each commercial species of kangaroo taken commercially in each year.

(4) For each year between 1985 and 1991: (a) what has been the estimated total number of kangaroos killed, including commercial, non-commercial and illegal, in each State; and (b) how have these figures been derived.
(5) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what was the total number of sheep and cattle in each of the States.
(6) How many people in each State are directly responsible for enforcing the code of practice for the killing of kangaroos.
(7) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what were the number and type of prosecutions, convictions and penalties relating to cruelty to kangaroos in each State.
(8) How many people in each State are directly responsible for enforcing laws to control non-commercial and illegal killing of kangaroos.
(9) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what were the numbers and nature of prosecutions, convictions and penalties relating to the illegal killing of kangaroos in each State.
(10) How many people in each State are directly responsible for enforcing laws to control the illegal trade in kangaroo products between the States.
(11) For the years between 1985 and 1991, what were the number and nature of prosecutions, convictions and penalties relating to illegal trade between States in kangaroo products.
(12) How many people in each State are directly responsible for enforcing laws to control the illegal exporting of kangaroo products from Australia.
(13) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what number and species of kangaroo skins were exported from Australia.
(14) For each year between 1985 and 1991, which countries imported skins and what number and species were sent to each.
(15) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what quantity of each commercial species of kangaroo meat was exported from Australia.
(16) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what countries imported kangaroo meat, and for each country, what quantity of each species was imported.
(17) For each year between 1985 and 1991, what were the number and nature of prosecutions, convictions and penalties relating to the illegal export of kangaroo products.
(18) What is the number of commercial kangaroo shooters presently operating in each State for which the 1992 quota has been approved.
(19) What is the average annual income of a professional kangaroo shooter.
(20) For each year between 1985 and 1992, what was the total royalty payment for commercial kangaroo tags in each State.
(21) During 1991, what was the total number of people directly employed by the kangaroo industry in each State.
(22) During 1991, what was the total income tax received by the Federal Government from those people directly employed by the kangaroo industry.
(23) During 1991, what was the total estimated revenue to the Federal Government resulting from the commercial killing of kangaroos, including income tax, sales tax and export levies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare (SSCAW) initiated its inquiry into kangaroos in mid-1984 and tabled in Parliament a report entitled "Kangaroos" in June 1988. As there was no report by the SSCAW in May 1985, I assume that the Honourable Senator is referring to the recommendations contained in the SSCAW report of June 1988.

Of the 27 recommendations in that report seven related solely to Commonwealth responsibilities; thirteen related to activities and responsibilities of State and Territory Governments; and seven referred to both State and Commonwealth Governments.
Recommendations which have been acted upon or implemented include recommendations 1, 2, 3, 8, 11, 13, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23 and 25.

In February this year, I announced the establishment of a National Wildlife Protection Squad within the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (recommendation 13). Implementation of recommendations 12, 14, 15 and 16 is under review by this squad.

Recommendations 6, 9 and 10 relating to verification of the marksmanship and possession of appropriate firearms, have received varying degrees of support by States. These recommendations are generally considered to be covered by the Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos.

Recommendation 22 is implemented through ongoing liaison with landowners. Inspections of all properties prior to the issuance of a licence is not possible but other sources of information (such as seasonal conditions, harvest returns, aerial survey trends and local knowledge) can be used to determine the need for inspections of individual properties.

(2) The estimates sought are not easily accessible, and since 1982, have been restricted to the four states which permit commercial harvesting of kangaroos. An attempt was made in 1980-82 to obtain a national estimate of the Red (Macropus rufus), Eastern Grey (M. giganteus), and Western Grey (M. fuliginosus) Kangaroo populations in Australia by conducting aerial surveys over 75% of the continent and extrapolating estimates to unsurveyed areas. The report on the results of the 1987 aerial surveys examined population trends for an area of 2.5 million km(2) or 43% of the 1981 survey area but encompassing areas which contained 89% of the 1981 surveyed populations.

The correction factors for Grey Kangaroos used in the original 1980-82 broad scale survey were known to underestimate populations but were retained to enable direct comparisons of population trends between the different surveys. Results of the aerial surveys, updated to include the 1990 figures, are given in Table 1. It should be emphasised that the values given reflect conservative population trends especially for Grey Kangaroos and not total population counts.
In 1987-88, a ground survey of Whiptail Wallaby (M. parryi) populations gave an estimated population of 783,000 animals in the areas where commercial harvesting occurs in south-eastern Queensland.

Recent broad scale ground surveys of Wallaroos (M. robustus) in northeastern New South Wales have indicated the presence of an estimated 414,000 animals in the limited areas currently subject to commercial harvesting of that species.

(3) The Commonwealth Government becomes involved in kangaroo management when access to export markets is sought for kangaroo products taken under the provisions of State legislation. Where it is the policy of the relevant State Government to permit commercial use of kangaroos which may be proposed for export, it has been the practice for State wildlife authorities to prepare and implement kangaroo management programs. The Commonwealth has no direct involvement where kangaroo products are to be used on the domestic market only.

Details of the total commercial harvests by species under approved management programs are given in Table 2. Management programs were not submitted by Tasmania in the years 1987-1991 inclusive. Consequently my Portfolio holds no data on commercial harvests of Bennett's Wallabies (M. rufogriseus) or Tasmanian Pademelons (Thylogale billardierii) for this period.

(4) (a) The total commercial kill of kangaroos in each of the States operating approved management programs between 1985 and 1991 is provided in Table 3. The total approved non-commercial kill for these States is provided separately in Table 4. These figures are based on information provided by the State wildlife authorities. There are no figures available for the illegal kill in each State.

(b) Commercial kill figures are based upon industry returns required by State management authorities and indicate the actual numbers killed. The non-commercial figures indicate the maximum permitted kill on permits issued by the State authorities. The non-commercial figures may include permits issued in both the commercial and non-commercial areas of the State concerned.
(5) Details on the total number of sheep and cattle in each of the States are not held by my Portfolio.
(6) (7) (8) (9) (10) and (11) The statistics requested are not held by my Portfolio. The matters referred to are the responsibilities of State and Territory Governments.

(12) The export of kangaroo products from Australia is subject to regulation under both State and Commonwealth legislation. Enforcement of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 rests primarily with the Australian Customs Service (ACS) which lies within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Small Business Construction and Customs. Details of the number of individuals in the ACS on a State basis are not held by my Portfolio.

In addition to ACS officers, State wildlife officers are also responsible for controlling illegal trade in kangaroo products within their jurisdiction, up to the point at which products enter another State or pass under the control of the ACS. Once kangaroo products become manufactured goods, some states no longer identify such material as subject to their legislation. Statistics on the number of State wildlife officers responsible for enforcing laws are not held by my Portfolio.
(13) and (14) Details of the numbers and species of kangaroo skins covered by export permits issued by ANPWS for the years 1985 to 1991 and the countries of destination are provided in Tables 5-11.
(15) and (16) Exports of kangaroo meat covered by permits issued by the ANPWS for the period 1985 to 1991 and the countries of destination are given in Tables 12-18.
(17) There were no prosecutions under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 relating to the illegal export of kangaroo products between 1985 and 1991.

(18) The number of commercial shooters licensed to operate in each State is subject to change during the year as new permits are issued and old ones expire. At present the figures for licensed commercial shooters are: New South Wales 395, Queensland 980, Western Australia 145, and South Australia 116.
(19) Details of the annual income of professional kangaroo shooters are not collected by my Portfolio.
(20) and (21) This information is not held by my Portfolio.

(22) and (23) There have been no studies to identify the total revenue derived by the Commonwealth Government from income tax, sales tax and export levies resulting from the commercial killing of kangaroos.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to his undated letter of April 1992, regarding the `Provision of Electoral Roll Data':

(1) Which Senators and Members requested and when did they request, that all electorate offices be provided with an electorate roll database, and did they request that it be provided in a format suitable for WordPerfect.
(2) Were the requests received before or after the Government decided to provide all electorate offices with a 386 class computer with a large hard disk and colour monitor.
(3) When the decision to equip all electorate offices was made, did the Government consider in the future providing electorate roll databases.
(4) Which electorate roll data-bases have been requested by each Senator or Member.
(5) How many and which Members have requested and which have been provided with two electorate-roll data-bases, and why.
(6) Did the electorate rolls already exist in a format suitable for WordPerfect.
(7) If the electorate rolls did not already exist in a format suitable for WordPerfect, what was the expense of converting them to such a format.
(8) What was the cost of providing a program to update and query the electoral roll data-base.
(9) What safeguards exist to prevent the merging of the electorate roll data-bases and other electronic data-bases, or the addition of phone numbers.
(10) What safeguards exist to prevent the sale or disposal to non-Parliamentarians or organisations of the electorate data-bases.
(11) Could the electorate roll data-base be used in the POLLY, PERCY or POL-FILE computer programs, developed and used by the ALP and Liberal Parties.
(12) Has the privacy of electors been compromised by the provision of electorate roll data-bases to all Members and Senators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since 1987, the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) has received numerous requests from Senators and Members for electoral roll data to be provided in electronic form. The Government's recent decision to do so directly resulted from requests by the Presiding Officers' Information Technology Advisory Group (POITAG) at its meetings in December 1990 and March 1991. Those requests did not specify WordPerfect as a required format.

(2) The decision to offer the option of 386-class computers, as part of a wider offer of additional equipment for electorate offices, was taken in October 1990. It was subsequently decided to upgrade all electorate offices to a three personal computers/two printers configuration.

(3) Not specifically, but the October 1990 decision and subsequent implementation of the three personal computers/two printers configuration anticipated a likely need to accommodate increasingly more sophisticated software packages in electorate offices; the electoral roll database is an example of that growing requirement.

(4) Each Senator has been offered the provision of the databases for two of the House of Representatives Divisions, as nominated by them, in their State or Territory; a list of the Divisions so nominated is at Attachment 1. Each Member has been provided, as a standard issue, with an electronic version of the electoral roll for their Division, as determined by the most recent redistribution of boundaries.

(5) As at 31 July 1992, and since the electoral roll databases have been available for Senators and Members, sixteen Members have requested two databases; the details of those requests and of their outcomes are at Attachment 2.

(7) & (8) The data is being supplied in ASCII format and is capable of being transcribed to, for example, the Open Access software supplied to electorate offices as a standard database package. There has been no direct expenditure on the computer program to do the necessary data conversion; it has been developed using existing staff resources.

(9) While there are no physical means of preventing the merger of the electoral roll databases provided to Senators and Members with other software programs, s.91A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 sets out the purposes to which the information provided by the AEC to authorised persons may be put. Advice of those purposes, together with a warning that the Commission claims copyright on the enrolment information provided by it, was notified to all Senators and Members at the time the databases were first provided to them.
(10) Section 91B of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 prohibits such disclosure.
(11) My Department does not have access to the computer programs referred to and therefore, is not in a position to assess their compatibility with the electoral roll database.

(12) No. What is being provided is in accordance with the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. It is the same data as is available for public inspection or purchase from the Australian Electoral Commission.
